site_title: ‘Piss drunk’: A toast to beer from Singapore’s recycled toilet water
summary: Singapore's NEWBrew, a beer made from recycled sewage, has sold out its first batch at Brewerkz restaurants and is expected to run out of supermarket stocks by the end of July. The beer, a collaboration between PUB and Brewerkz, uses NEWater, a brand of drinking water recycled from sewage, and has been praised for its neutral taste and refreshing quality. The initiative aims to educate Singaporeans on sustainable water use and recycling, as the world's water supply becomes increasingly scarce.

site_title: Zilch draws US$50m more funding to buck BNPL industry woes
summary: Zilch, a London-based fintech offering buy now, pay later services, has secured US$50 million in funding, bringing its total Series C raise to US$160 million and maintaining a US$2 billion valuation. The funding will support US expansion, particularly in Miami, where the company has already opened an office with over 150,000 pre-registered customers. Zilch's CEO, Philip Belamant, attributes the company's success to its ability to buck industry trends, with 4 times faster growth in the US than in the UK.

images.alt_text: Australian BNPL player Zip has terminated its partnership with Singtel's Dash and exited Singapore
Case president Melvin Yong noted that the association received 18 consumer complaints involving BNPL service providers from Jan 1, 2021 to Jun 23 this year.

site_title: SkillsFuture Festival kicks off with forum on July 5
summary: The SkillsFuture Singapore Forum 2022 will be held virtually on July 5, focusing on strategies for companies to upskill their workers amid economic recovery. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing will give the opening speech, and four guest speakers will discuss how companies and employees can be supported by the government. The event is part of the SkillsFuture Festival, a series of learning events running from July 5 to August 14. Registration for the forum ends on June 30.

site_title: Travels in the ‘death zone’ can transform lives and help repair our planet
summary: Travelers can play a crucial role in mitigating the effects of climate change by adopting sustainable practices and supporting destinations affected by rising sea levels. Destinations like Venice, the Maldives, and the Great Barrier Reef are threatened by erosion and extinction due to climate change. Travelers can make a difference by choosing eco-friendly transportation options, spending their money in threatened regions, and supporting NGOs working to protect these areas. By adopting a more mindful and responsible approach to travel, individuals can contribute to a positive change and help address the climate crisis.

site_title: Real estate certification company WiredScore raises US$15m in Series B funding
summary: Real estate certification company WiredScore has raised US$15 million in its Series B funding round led by Beringea, Cushman & Wakefield, Crow Holdings, and Taronga Ventures. The funds will be used to expand the company's geographic footprint in Asia and solidify its position as a leading voice for technology in the built world. WiredScore plans to make the world's buildings smarter and better connected, with its Asia headquarters in Singapore marking a significant milestone.

site_title: Kappo with a twist at Jinhonten
summary: Chef Issey Araki's omakase experience at Jinhonten, a restaurant in Singapore's Shaw Centre, offers a unique blend of drama and high-quality Japanese cuisine. Araki's flair for theatrics is evident, from carrying an 18kg rock fish to adding a pink plushie pig to the dining experience. The menu features a range of dishes, including auction-level uni, black abalone, and kinki shabu shabu, all expertly prepared and presented. With a price tag of S$450 for a 10-course dinner, Jinhonten is an expensive but memorable dining experience that showcases Araki's creativity and skill. Rating: 7.5.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Industrial Government Land Sales (GLS) programme has released 6.36 hectares of industrial land plots for the second half of 2022, the largest supply since 2020. This includes 4 confirmed sites and 3 on the reserve list, bringing the total site area to 6.36 hectares.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings and Hua Hong Semiconductor were among the analysts’ top picks out of the semiconductor basket.

site_title: Minister of State Desmond Tan appointed NTUC deputy secretary-general
summary: Minister of State Desmond Tan was appointed as NTUC deputy secretary-general, replacing Chee Hong Tat, following his secondment to the labour movement on June 13. Tan also holds roles as group director of the NTUC Training and Transformation Group and advisor to the Singapore Industrial and Services Employees' Union. He expressed gratitude for NTUC Central Committee support and vowed to champion better wages and work prospects for workers. This appointment comes after a cabinet reshuffle.

site_title: US jobless claims fall slightly, remain near 5-month high
summary: US jobless claims fell slightly to 231,000 in the week ended June 25, remaining near a 5-month high. This marks the 4th consecutive week of claims in the 230,000 range, a level not seen since the Omicron variant's peak. Demand for labor is expected to weaken further as interest rates rise and firms anticipate a potential recession.

images.alt_text: Initial unemployment claims decreased by 2,000 to 229,000 in the week ended Jun 18.

site_title: Systemic crisis in the cryptocurrency world resembles the Panic of 1907
summary: A systemic crisis in the cryptocurrency world is unfolding, likened to the Panic of 1907, where widespread panic and a breakdown in markets have led to a domino effect of failures among institutions. The crisis began with the collapse of TerraUSD and Luna, causing a 40% selloff in bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried, a 30-year-old billionaire, is attempting to save the system by lending millions to struggling firms like Voyager Digital and Celsius Network. Despite efforts, the crisis shows no signs of abating, with many experts warning of a potential collapse of the entire crypto universe.

site_title: New Zealand to enter recession in 2023 as confidence slumps: BNZ
summary: New Zealand's economy is expected to contract by 0.2% in the second quarter of 2023 and 0.1% in the third, according to Bank of New Zealand (BNZ) economists. Business sentiment remains low, with a business confidence index of minus 62.6, indicating a potential deeper recession than initially forecast. The Reserve Bank is expected to continue raising interest rates, peaking at 3.5% in 2023, but at a lower rate than market expectations. A recession is predicted for 2023, with the economy expected to enter a mild recession.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps bond purchase unchanged in July-September
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has decided to keep its purchases of Japanese government bonds unchanged in the July-September quarter, despite yields on longer maturities hovering near their highest levels since 2016. This decision focuses on maintaining the current pace of bond purchases across all maturities, rather than boosting purchases of longer-maturity bonds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip while Shanghai ends with gains
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.62% to 21,859.79, while Shanghai's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.10% to 3,398.62. The gains in mainland China were driven by forecast-beating data on the services sector, lifting economic recovery hopes. However, Hong Kong's losses were attributed to concerns over US interest rate hikes and surging inflation.

site_title: JPMorgan says crypto’s deleveraging cycle won’t last much longer
summary: JPMorgan predicts the current crypto deleveraging cycle won't last much longer, citing the advanced state of the process and the involvement of stronger balance-sheet crypto entities to contain contagion. Despite high-profile failures, venture-capital funding continued at a healthy pace, and some exchanges, like FTX, are granting lines of credit. The firm's net leverage metric suggests deleveraging is already well advanced, indicating a potential end to the current phase of deleveraging in cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Further pain in store for Asian currencies after turbulent first-half
summary: Asian currencies are forecast to remain under pressure in the near term due to elevated commodity prices, narrowing interest rate differentials, and a reluctance among central banks to hike rates. Despite a potential Chinese economic recovery, investors are cautious until data confirms the pace of growth. The Taiwanese dollar, South Korea's won, and Philippine peso have weakened by over 6.8% against the US dollar this year, while the Indian rupee is near record lows. Asian central banks are expected to implement smaller and slower rate hikes compared to the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk along a road in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, June 29, 2022. site_title: Europe: Stocks sink at open
summary: Europe's stock markets plummeted at the open on June 30, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 1.6% to 7,194.36 points, and Frankfurt's DAX index and Paris CAC 40 both sliding 2.1%. The decline is attributed to resurgent fears of a global recession sparked by hefty interest rate hikes to combat soaring inflation.

site_title: Oil falls 3% on uncertainty over future Opec+ output, recession fears
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Thursday as Opec+ confirmed it would only increase output in August by 648,000 barrels per day, despite tight global supplies, leaving the market uncertain about future output. Brent crude futures dropped 3% to $109.03 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 3.7% to $105.76 per barrel. The decision came as recession fears and sanctions on Russian oil continue to impact the energy market, with some analysts predicting further price declines amid supply disruptions.

images.alt_text: OPEC+ began two days of meetings on Wednesday with sources saying a big policy change was unlikely this month.

site_title: Japan Airlines mulls short-haul fleet replacement
summary: Japan Airlines is considering replacing its 45-year-old Boeing 737 short-haul fleet with the Airbus A320neo family or 737 Max range. The airline is weighing a potential order of 30-50 new jets, with deliberations preliminary and no final decisions made. This move comes as the airline and other carriers globally overhaul their fleets amid travel surges post-pandemic. Japan's tourism industry is also seeking support, with the government considering expanding a domestic travel subsidy program.

site_title: Zilingo’s ousted CEO Ankiti Bose resigns from board
summary: Former Zilingo CEO Ankiti Bose has resigned from the board of directors due to lack of access to information, despite being a director and large shareholder. This comes as the board weighs options, including liquidation and a management buyout, following allegations of financial irregularities and her ouster as CEO in May. Bose had endorsed a buyout proposal made by co-founder Dhruv Kapoor, but her resignation is seen as a response to the board's opacity and failure to provide her with investigation reports.

site_title: Xi Jinping arrives in Hong Kong for handover anniversary
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Hong Kong on June 30 to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the city's return to Chinese rule and the inauguration of new leader John Lee. This is Xi's first visit to Hong Kong since 2017 and his first known trip outside mainland China in over 2 years. Heavy security was deployed, and authorities warned against any acts of violence or public disorder. Xi is expected to spend the night in Shenzhen and depart from Hong Kong on Friday, where he is also set to swear in John Lee as the new leader.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping speaks following his arrival via high-speed rail across the border in Hong Kong on June 30, 2022, for celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of the city's handover from Britain to China. (Photo by Selim CHTAYTI / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Thai central bank to ease rules on banks' dividend payouts
summary: The Bank of Thailand has amended rules on banks' dividend payouts, allowing them to pay a reduced 0.23% of deposits per annum to the Financial Institutions Development Fund until the end of 2022. This move is aimed at supporting the country's financial sector and promoting economic growth.

site_title: Singapore’s June market cap down 2.2% as banks’ values shrink and STI falls 4%
summary: Singapore's market capitalization fell 2.2% in June, with banks' values shrinking and the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 4%. Local banks UOB, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and OCBC led the losses, with DBS and OCBC losing S$3.25 billion and S$1.99 billion, respectively. The losses were attributed to shifting attention to growth risks and recession concerns, as well as policy tightening. Despite this, some sectors, such as manufacturing and properties, saw gains, with Nio, Hongkong Land, and Prudential emerging as top gainers.

site_title: ‘We believe Three Arrows defrauded the crypto industry’: Blockchain.com
summary: Blockchain.com and Deribit, a crypto derivatives exchange, confirmed they are among creditors seeking the liquidation of Three Arrows Capital at a court in the British Virgin Islands. Blockchain.com stated it believes Three Arrows defrauded the crypto industry and intends to hold them accountable to the fullest extent of the law. The liquidation order was made on June 27, following a reprimand by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for providing false information and exceeding its management limit.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia to deepen cooperation in digital and green economies
summary: Singapore and Malaysia agreed to deepen cooperation in the digital and green economies, with the goal of concluding Frameworks of Cooperation by the end of this year. The frameworks will focus on inter-operability, decarbonization, and entrepreneurship in both economies. The move is aimed at promoting sustainable and inclusive growth for both countries, with potential benefits for businesses and workers. The agreement was reaffirmed by Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong and Malaysia's Senior Minister and Minister of International Trade and Industry Mohamed Azmin Ali during a meeting in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Lenskart buys Owndays shares in bid to form an Amazon of eyewear
summary: Lenskart, an Indian eyewear startup backed by SoftBank Group, has agreed to buy a majority stake in Japan's Owndays, creating one of Asia's largest online retailers of eyewear. The deal will allow Lenskart to expand its presence in physical retail, while Owndays will target the premium segment. The companies project combined sales of $650 million by March 2023, with Lenskart aiming to reach profitability at $400 million in sales. The move aims to create a retail giant with operations in over a dozen markets, with co-founder Peyush Bansal calling it a chance to build an "Amazon for eyewear".

site_title: Kimly unit enters joint venture to operate coffeeshop at Kitchener Complex
summary: Kimly Makan Place (KMP), a unit of Catalist-listed Kimly, has entered a joint venture with 808 Ta Sun to operate a coffeeshop at Kitchener Complex. The joint-venture company, Da Sun Food House, will be 49% owned by KMP, with 808 Ta Sun holding the remaining 51%. KMP paid S$1.13 million for its stake, and the joint-venture will enter a service agreement with KMP. The deal is part of Kimly's strategy to expand its network of food outlets in Singapore and diversify revenue streams.

images.alt_text: Kimly posted a net profit of S$18.5 million for its first half ended March, declining 14.7 per cent year-on-year.

site_title: Singapore office rents hit hard in previous recessions: IREUS
summary: Singapore's office rents in the Central Region were hit hard during the last three recessions, with market declines lasting longer than the overall economic downturn and rents falling about 30% from pre-recession rates. Occupancy rates also fell by 4.2 to 7 percentage points during the downturns. According to a report by IREUS, office rents respond to economic contraction in a similar manner to other variables like manufacturing output and employment, and are often determined by the availability of existing stock in the market.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as S&P 500 concludes worst H1 since 1970
summary: US stocks ended the worst first half of a year since 1970, with the S&P 500 falling 0.9% to 3,785.38, a loss of over 16% for the last 6 months. The Dow Jones and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, amid persistently high inflation and consumer spending. The Federal Reserve's aggressive measures to rein in growth and pricing pressures have prompted investors to weigh the possibility of another interest rate hike in July.

site_title: Biggest forex rout since '97 puts Asia central banks in bind
summary: Asia-Pacific central banks face a dilemma as the dollar surge puts their currencies on course for their worst quarter since the 1997 financial crisis. The region has accumulated trillions of reserves, but policymakers must balance defending currencies with the risk of hurting growth. With inflation soaring and the Fed set to raise interest rates, central banks are considering rate hikes, but may also need to use their foreign-exchange reserves to intervene in foreign exchange markets. The Bloomberg JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index is poised for a 4.5% drop, the steepest since 1997.

images.alt_text: China's foreign exchange regulator said on Wednesday the recent retreat of foreign investments from the country amid a weakening yuan was "well under control" and that Beijing would continue to open up both outbound and inbound investment channels.

Thailand’s central bank says the movement of the baht has had limited impact on inflation and the economy, after the currency reached its weakest level for 5 years against the US dollar on Thursday (May 12).

site_title: KIT inks term sheet with sponsor for 50% stake in owner of Marina East desalination plant
summary: Keppel Infra Trust (KIT) has entered a non-binding term sheet to acquire a 50% stake in Marina East Water (MEW) for S$355 million, with KIT and its sponsor, Keppel Infrastructure Holdings, holding a 50% joint-controlling stake in MEW post-transaction. MEW owns the Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant, which can produce 137,000 cubic meters of fresh drinking water per day. The deal is part of Keppel's asset monetization strategy and aims to support KIT's distributable income per unit, adding to its green credentials and water resilience.

images.alt_text: YTL Power's wholly owned subsidiary, YTL PowerSeraya, had completed the purchase at $270 million in cash.

site_title: Keppel Land unit ends joint venture for Chennai residential project
summary: Keppel Land's unit, Orizona, has terminated a joint venture with Emerald Haven Realty to develop a Chennai residential project. The decision does not impact Keppel's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year. The parties have agreed to terminate the share-purchase agreement and joint-venture agreement, with no further liability. This move will not affect Keppel's financial performance.

site_title: Why no-brand label Muji is a cult favourite
summary: Japanese brand Muji, which translates to "no-brand, quality goods," has gained a cult following for its minimalist designs and affordable prices. Founded in 1980, Muji's products are guided by 15 verbs that represent the thought process behind their creation. The brand's focus on simplicity and sustainability is reflected in products such as refill tissues, which come in a bundle to reduce waste, and a wall-mounted CD player designed by Naoto Fukasawa. An ongoing exhibition, "To the Forest of Verbs with 'MUJI IS'," showcases the brand's products and design philosophy, now on display overseas for the first time.

site_title: Indonesia approved as Singapore's new source of frozen, chilled chicken
summary: Singapore has approved Indonesia as its new source of frozen, chilled, and processed chicken meat. This move diversifies the country's chicken supply, with Indonesia joining over 20 countries accredited to export chicken to Singapore. The decision comes as Malaysia's chicken export ban, which affected 34% of Singapore's chicken supply, remains in effect. To ensure food safety, the Singapore Food Agency will conduct detailed evaluations, on-site audits, and inspections on imported consignments from Indonesia.

site_title: Philippines begins new era of Marcos rule, decades after overthrow
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son and namesake of the late Philippine dictator, was sworn in as president on June 30, 2022, marking the end of a 36-year period since the Marcos family's overthrow in a popular uprising. Marcos Jr. won a landslide victory in the election, vowing to take the country forward with policies benefiting everyone. He pledged education reforms, improved infrastructure, and support for overseas Filipino workers, while acknowledging his family's past and seeking to move forward. The inauguration ceremony was attended by his family members, including his mother Imelda and sister Imee.

site_title: Magnus Energy inks deals for nickel extraction in Indonesia
summary: Magnus Energy has signed agreements with Indonesian private companies to extract and supply nickel ore from mining sites in Kolaka, Sulawesi. The initial deal involves the sale of 20,000 metric tonnes of nickel ore, with the option to increase the purchase quantity. The company's unit, MHI, will source the ore and transport it to a smelter in south-east Sulawesi at the local market price. The agreements are seen as a crucial step in enhancing the business viability of the group, with the business expected to contribute positively to cash flow but not earnings per share for the current year.

images.alt_text: Industrial metals are still on track for the biggest quarterly plunge since the 2008 financial crisis amid rising fears of an industrial slowdown across major economies.

site_title: US consumer spending softens; prices rise less than forecast
summary: US consumer spending declined 0.4% in May, the first time this year, as inflation-adjusted spending fell for the first time since February. The personal consumption expenditures price index rose 0.6% from the previous month, but the core PCE price index increased only 0.3%, less than expected. Despite resilient demand for services, concerns about the economic outlook grow, with recession fears on the rise and household sentiment at a record low. The Federal Reserve will consider the latest figures when deciding on interest rate hikes at its July meeting.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell vowed to ensure rapid price increases don't become entrenched.

site_title: With IPOs on ice, banks' stock offering fees plummet
summary: Global investment banks' fees for equity capital markets (ECM) deals plummeted 74% to $2.6 billion in the second quarter, driven by recession fears and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This led to a 25% decline in global IPO issuance to $94 billion, with US and European deals making up only 9% of the total. Bankers hope for market improvement in the second half of the year, but some IPO hopefuls have written off 2022 altogether.

images.alt_text: The increase in domestic Chinese IPOs contrasts with the local market about a decade ago, when offerings completely stalled.

site_title: Casting of Rodin's Thinker fetches 10.7m euros at Paris auction
summary: A casting of Auguste Rodin's iconic sculpture "The Thinker" sold for 10.7 million euros at a Paris auction, surpassing Christie's estimated price of 9-14 million euros. The 1880 original sculpture, designed to be the crowning element of "The Gates of Hell," was first exhibited individually in 1888 and later enlarged in 1904. This was the size of the original model and one of roughly 40 authentic outstanding castings. The sale sets a new record for a Rodin "Thinker" sculpture, following a 2013 sale of US$15.3 million at a Sotheby's auction in New York.

site_title: Thermal coal, nitrogen, among commodities most vulnerable to long-term climate change, say analysts
summary: Fitch Ratings analysts warn that thermal coal and nitrogen are the most vulnerable commodities to long-term climate change, posing an existential threat to investors. By 2040, coal-generation capacities are expected to largely remain in China and India, and by 2045, thermal coal should be "almost eliminated" from the energy system. However, nickel and copper are expected to see bright demand outlooks, driven by the global energy transition, while aluminium demand will rise due to electric vehicles and renewable power generation. Fertiliser producers, particularly those in the nitrogen and phosphate sectors, face regulatory challenges and high emissions intensity, while potash fertilisers have the smallest carbon footprint and potential for increased demand.

Shell’s chief executive Ben van Beurden said while that tapering of O&G investments is exactly on track, the investments in renewables have yet to pick up pace.
Australia’s climate change minister on Wednesday rejected a proposal to temporarily halt new coal and gas projects in the country, one of the world’s top fossil fuel exporters.
Many AGMs increasingly feature “Say on Climate” resolutions, which allow shareholders to vote on companies’ approaches to tackling climate change.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on mounting growth worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on June 30, 2022, amid worries about central banks' efforts to combat inflation potentially hindering global economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.77%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.86% and 1.16%, respectively. The decline marked the end of a dismal first-half year for the market.

site_title: Apple eyes fuel purchases from dashboard as it revs up car software
summary: Apple is set to launch a new feature in its CarPlay software this fall, allowing users to tap to buy gas directly from their car dashboard. The feature, which has been quietly unveiled at Apple's developer conference, will allow users to navigate to a pump and pay using a fuel company's app. This move is part of Apple's push to turn vehicles into stores for goods and services, following previous launches of apps for parking, electric vehicle charging, and ordering food. The feature is expected to hit hundreds of car models already compatible with CarPlay, and is seen as a major step forward for the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on June 30, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.26 points to 1,444.22. The trading day saw 2.265 billion lots worth RM1.972 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 521 to 327.

site_title: A taste of 3-Michelin-starred California-Japanese cuisine at SingleThread Singapore
summary: Chef Kyle Connaughton of 3-Michelin-starred SingleThread in Sonoma, California, will bring his California-Japanese cuisine to Singapore through a one-month residency at the Basque Kitchen by Aitor. The residency, starting July 1, will feature a 7-course menu combining local flavors and ingredients with traditional Japanese techniques and ingredients. The menu will include dishes such as abalone chawanmushi, grilled cucumber, and Miyazaki wagyu, all presented with elaborate floral decorations. Connaughton is excited to share his passion for donabe cooking, a traditional Japanese clay pot cooking method, with his guests in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kiyose's dark and broody interiors feature dramatic mood lighting.

site_title: Uber records 38% drop in reported sexual assaults in 2019-2020
summary: Uber reported a 38% decline in sexual assault and misconduct reports from 2019-2020, with 3,824 incidents, compared to its first safety report in 2019. The decline may be linked to the COVID-19 pandemic, which reduced demand for rides by 80%. Despite this, the vast majority of trips were completed without safety complaints. Uber also saw an 18% increase in fatal physical assaults and reported 101 fatalities in 2020. The company conducts thorough background checks on drivers and has removed over 80,000 drivers from the app.

site_title: Indonesian president says delivers Zelensky's message to Putin
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo met with Russian leader Vladimir Putin in Moscow, delivering a message from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Widodo expressed his "readiness" to help start "communication" between the two leaders. The meeting came amid Russia's ongoing offensive in Ukraine and Indonesia's hosting of the G20 summit in Bali later this year. Widodo and Putin discussed reviving the spirit of cooperation and moving towards a settlement in the conflict, with Putin praising the talks as "productive".

images.alt_text: More is now needed from the Group of 7 as the second half of 2022 dawns.
Widodo has departed for Germany to attend as a guest the G-7 summit from Jun 26-27, and he will then go to the Ukraine capital Kyiv to meet President Volodymyr Zelensky.

site_title: Japan’s Kirin offloads Myanmar beer business over coup
summary: Japan's Kirin has agreed to a buyout of its shares in a Myanmar joint venture with a junta-linked conglomerate, completing its exit from the market following the 2021 coup. Kirin had held a 51% stake in the joint venture, which operated the popular Myanmar Beer brand, with a market share of nearly 80%. The company had initially announced its intention to end the joint venture in February 2021, citing concerns over the military's actions. Kirin will transfer its stake through a share buyback agreement worth approximately 22.4 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Asahi’s stock climbed 4.3 per cent, outperforming a 1.2 per cent drop in the benchmark Nikkei index.

site_title: Chinese tech giants vow to stop NFT secondary trading
summary: Chinese tech giants, including Tencent Holdings and Ant Group, have signed a pact to stop secondary trading of digital collectibles and self-regulate their activities in the market. The Digital Collectible Industry Self-Discipline Development Initiative, led by the Chinese Cultural Industry Association, aims to prevent speculation and ensure the security of blockchain technologies and user data. The 14-article pact includes real-name authentication and protection of personal information, following China's ban on cryptocurrency trading and tradition of stamping out speculation for financial stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Tencent is seen at its booth at the 2020 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Toyota seeks to shed light on future in car-light towns
summary: Toyota and Borneo Motors have partnered with Singapore Power Group to launch a car-sharing scheme in Tengah, Singapore's 24th town project, a low-carbon, smart energy town. The partnership will supply 8 Toyotas, including 7 hybrids and 1 full electric, to test car-sharing as a sustainable transportation option. Residents will be able to use the cars via a phone app, with discounted rates and early access to the bZ4X, Toyota's first mainstream electric car. The goal is to collect data on car-sharing usage and its impact on residents' transportation habits.

images.alt_text: The e-GMP electric engine assembly line at the carmaker Stellantis engines factory in Tremery near Metz, France.

site_title: Hong Kong May retail sales fall 1.7%
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales fell 1.7% in May from a year earlier, easing from a 11.7% increase in April. Total sales reached HK$29.1 billion (S$5.2 billion) for the month. This marks a year-on-year increase of 4.7% for the two-month period. The decline is attributed to a sharp increase in April, which was likely a one-time surge.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide as growth, inflation concerns mount; STI falls 1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1% on Thursday, June 30, as concerns over growth and inflation weighed heavily on markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 32.66 points to 3,102.21, following a weak overnight performance on Wall Street. The decline was influenced by rising cost pressures and central banks tightening monetary policies to combat inflation. Other Asian markets also fell, with Taiwan and Hong Kong losing 2.7% and 1.5%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The decline also highlights the challenge the world's third-largest economy faces in overcoming supply disruptions and persistently high prices of raw materials and energy.
The Fed chief warned of a "re-division of the world into competing geopolitical and economic camps, and a reversal of globalisation" that could result in lower productivity and growth.
Asian stocks struggled with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Wellington all down in morning trade..

site_title: Australia: Shares post worst month in over 2 years on slowdown concerns
summary: Australia's shares ended their worst month in over 2 years, shedding 8.9% due to concerns over aggressive monetary policy tightening and a potential global economic slowdown. The S&P/ASX 200 fell 2% to 6,568.10, its third straight monthly drop. Central bank chiefs reiterated their commitment to controlling inflation, despite market concerns. The benchmark stock index is expected to perform better in the second half if the economy avoids a recession this year.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.3 per cent to 6,677.8 by 0050 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: The wheels have come off electric vehicles
summary: Toyota's electric vehicle, the bZ4X, has been recalled due to a risk of wheels detaching from the vehicle while driving, potentially leading to loss of vehicle control and increased risk of a crash. This is the first major recall of an electric vehicle by the world's largest car company. The recall affects 2,700 vehicles and comes as the company faces scrutiny over its commitment to electric vehicles and quality control. The incident highlights the need for greater scrutiny of electric vehicle manufacturers and regulators to set higher standards for safety before models are released.

images.alt_text: The recall by Toyota of 2,700 units of the bZ4X SUVs, rolled out less than 2 months ago in Japan, is a setback to the world’s largest automaker by sales, as it seeks to take on larger EV rival Tesla.

site_title: AIA Singapore aims to hire over 500 staff including mid-career switchers, women rejoining workforce
summary: AIA Singapore is launching its Financial Associate Scheme, introducing over 500 financial sales advisory positions with monthly base salaries ranging from S$2,700 to S$8,000 and quarterly performance-based bonuses. The scheme aims to attract stay-at-home parents, fresh graduates, and mid-career switchers, as well as women rejoining the workforce, to address the tight labour market. The positions offer full-time employment benefits and training, providing a "stepping stone" for those looking to re-enter the workforce or transition into financial services.

site_title: Micron's weak outlook sparks concerns of chip down cycle
summary: Micron Technology's fourth-quarter revenue and profit fell below market estimates, sparking concerns of a chip down cycle. The company forecast adjusted revenue of $7.2 billion, below the average analyst estimate of $9.05 billion. Geopolitical turmoil and weakening consumer spending are expected to weigh on demand for memory chips, with prices potentially dropping 3-8% in the third quarter. Micron's CEO said the company is taking action to moderate supply growth in 2023, citing long-term secular demand for memory and storage.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 76 to 46, after 82.8 million securities worth S$47.3 million changed hands.

site_title: GM calls off plan to sell India car plant to China's Great Wall
summary: General Motors (GM) has called off its plan to sell its shuttered Indian car plant to China's Great Wall Motor due to regulatory approval issues. The deal, which expired on June 30, had been extended twice but GM was unable to obtain the required approvals within the time frame. The company will now explore further options for the sale of the site, with the goal of achieving a price that reflects the asset's value.

images.alt_text: General Motors plans to return to Europe with battery-powered models starting with the Cadillac brand and is considering selling the hulking Hummer electric vehicle, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Citigroup’s family office clients are seizing on the market’s wild swings
summary: Citigroup's family office clients, with at least $1 billion in assets, are taking advantage of market volatility by boosting their investments. According to Luigi Pigorini, head of EMEA at Citi Global Wealth, these ultra-rich clients are scaling up their bets in fixed-income and foreign exchange markets. They are also taking "big positions" across various asset classes, highlighting their ability to adapt to market swings faster than institutional money managers.

images.alt_text: Lim is still optimistic on opportunities in Asia as the current market could present more dislocations.

site_title: British defence spending to reach 2.5% of GDP by end of decade, says PM
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has committed to increasing defence spending to 2.5% of GDP by the end of the decade, exceeding a target set a decade ago. This decision comes amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with defence spending projected to reach 2.3% of GDP this year. Defence Minister Ben Wallace has called for increased investment to tackle threats from Russia, China, and other countries, with spending set to review in 2024.

site_title: HSBC to relaunch India private banking business within a year: executive
summary: HSBC plans to relaunch its India private banking business within a year, after exiting the market in 2015. The bank has identified India as a key strategic market for growth, driven by wealth creation and an increase in millionaires. HSBC aims to quadruple its customer base in India over the next 3-5 years, taking advantage of foreign rivals shrinking their business. The bank has already increased its focus on Asia and has earned half of its revenue and two-thirds of its reported pretax profit from the region.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings has lost 2 senior investment bankers in Asia, according to people familiar with the matter, as global banks compete for financial technology talent and dealmaking slows down.

Ping An had held discussions with the lender to separate its Asia arm to create shareholder value, Bloomberg reported in late April. The campaign prompted an internal review with executives tapping Goldman Sachs Group on how to rebut Ping An’s case.

site_title: Singtel lays out physical and transition risks in first TCFD report
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telecommunications company, has released its first report on climate-related financial disclosures, outlining physical and transition risks. The company found that surface water flooding and bushfires pose the highest financial impact across its Singapore and Australia assets. Transition risks include carbon pricing, capital risk, and stranded assets, with Singtel expecting a high chance of losing market share if it fails to meet energy efficiency targets in Singapore. The company aims to reduce absolute carbon emissions by 25% by 2025 and achieve 100% renewable electricity in Australia by 2025.

images.alt_text: Corporate ESG disclosures have come a long way, but do they serve their intended purpose of informing the market of how well companies are managing such issues? / AFP PHOTO / ROSLAN RAHMAN

site_title: Home renovation disruptors
summary: New startups are using technology to make home renovations easier and less stressful for homeowners. homeez, a renotech platform, connects customers directly to suppliers, cutting out the middleman and providing instant quotes for renovations. The platform uses artificial intelligence to read floor plans and allows customers to design and plan their homes. Livspace, another startup, offers a one-stop renovation solution from design to fitting out all rooms, with a software program that taps artificial intelligence and virtual reality to create 2D and 3D renderings of projects. BuiltShops, a virtual-mapping platform, allows customers to shop for home decor-related items virtually, with 200 partners on its website. EightyTwo, an interior design firm, is disrupting the home decor scene by offering a luxurious client experience, from the time homeowners step into its studio to the completion of the project.

images.alt_text: Fresh demand for older flats as frustration builds over BTO

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed down 1.5% at 26,393.04, and the Topix index ended down 1.2% at 1,870.82 on Thursday, June 30, 2022, amid US stocks ending flat. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments on raising interest rates prompted worries of an economic slowdown, while the dollar rose to 136.22 yen. Automakers, including Toyota and Honda, fell, and the Japanese government reported a 7.2% drop in factory output in May due to lockdowns in China.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.19 per cent, or 51.32 points, to 26,753.28 at Thursday's open.

site_title: SenseTime dives as much as 51% in Hong Kong after lock-up expires
summary: SenseTime, a Chinese AI software maker, plummeted 51% in Hong Kong trading after a lock-up on its shares expired, marking a significant drop to its lowest ever price of HK$2.91. The company's stock has rallied 18% since mid-April, but selling pressure persists, with another block of shares set to expire near the end of the year. Insiders have been selling shares, including a major stake cut by Tencent Holdings' backer, and US sanctions have limited the company's investor base.

site_title: Samsung is first to start mass production of 3-nanometre chips
summary: Samsung has begun mass production of 3-nanometre chips, beating rival TSMC to the milestone. These chips offer up to 45% power reduction and 23% performance improvement compared to 5nm chips. Samsung plans to expand production to mobile processors, while TSMC starts mass production in the second half of the year. This move is crucial for Samsung to match TSMC's dominance in the contract chipmaking market.

images.alt_text: Samsung shows off first wafers of 3nm semiconductors. Source: Samsung Electronics Co.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down but China data offers some light
summary: Asian markets declined as traders worry about recession and inflation, despite a slight improvement in Chinese data. China's services sector showed a forecast-beating increase, and the manufacturing gauge also rose, providing some hope for the world's second-largest economy. However, the threat of elevated inflation and rate hikes has left traders weary, with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila, and Wellington all down. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce another 75-basis-point rate hike next month, fueling concerns about a global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: epa10015285 Pedestrians walk past a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 16 June 2022. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rebounded in the morning session following the decision of the US Federal Reserve to rise its key interest rate.  EPA-EFE/JIJI PRESS JAPAN OUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/

site_title: CEO of Ascott Residence Trust’s managers to be redesignated in leadership renewal
summary: Beh Siew Kim, CEO of Ascott Residence Trust's managers, will step down on July 1 and be redesignated as a non-executive, non-independent director. She will be replaced by Serena Teo Joo Ling, who will also hold executive director and committee roles. This is part of the trust's regular leadership renewal process, which aims to refresh the management team.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.36% on June 30, 2022, following a tepid lead from Wall Street, amid concerns over surging inflation and higher interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,917.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also decreased. The decline was attributed to worries about the impact of inflation and interest rates on the market.

site_title: Tesla's run of record deliveries may be reaching the end of the road
summary: Tesla is expected to report its first quarter-on-quarter decline in deliveries since 2020, with analysts estimating 295,078 vehicles, down from the record 310,048 deliveries in the previous quarter. The decline is attributed to China's prolonged zero-Covid lockdown, which caused deeper disruptions to output than initially predicted. Tesla's Shanghai factory, which produced half of its total cars last year, was significantly impacted, with an estimated 70,000 units lost in the quarter. Despite this, analysts expect deliveries to rebound strongly in the second half of the year as production increases at the Shanghai factory.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Model Y cars are pictured during the opening ceremony of the new Tesla Gigafactory for electric cars in Gruenheide, Germany, March 22, 2022. Patrick Pleul/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Business leaders say new Hong Kong chief must open up city, rebuild its image
summary: Business leaders in Hong Kong urge the new chief executive, John Lee, to reopen the city and rebuild its image by scrapping Covid-19 quarantine rules and promoting the rule of law and transparent regulations to revive foreign investor confidence. The city's border has been sealed since 2020, leading to a net outflow of over 134,000 people in the first half of this year, compared to just 1,813 in the same period of 2021. Executives emphasize the need for a major PR exercise to attract international arrivals and talent.

images.alt_text: Under a deal signed with Britain ahead of the 1997 handover, China promised Hong Kong could keep its capitalist system for 50 years.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest monthly fall in nearly 4 years
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index fell 45.35 points, or 1.91%, to 2,332.64, its biggest monthly drop in nearly 4 years, due to concerns over high inflation and an impending recession. The index ended the month 13.2% lower, its largest decline since October 2018. Investors are cautious ahead of US inflation data, while a rise in China's factory activity has little impact on the global market. Local heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also fell, with LG Energy Solution slumping 5.24%.

site_title: Cambodia and Myanmar race to become the next apparel manufacturing hub
summary: Cambodia and Myanmar are competing to become the next major apparel manufacturing hub, driven by China's relocation of factories due to rising labor costs and the trade war between China and the US. Cambodia's apparel industry has benefited from the trade war, with exports growing 34.5% year-on-year in 2022, while Myanmar has attracted Chinese investment with tax exemptions and preferential tariffs. Despite their growth, both countries still rely heavily on imported materials, and upstream industries such as textile and dyeing are not yet ready for investment.

images.alt_text: The financial hub Shanghai lifted its 2-month lockdown at the start of June by allowing more shops to reopen, more factories to resume production, and for port operation to pick up.

site_title: Crypto lender Celsius says it is exploring options
summary: Celsius Network, a retail crypto lending platform, is exploring options including deals and restructuring its liabilities amid "extreme" market conditions. The company, which froze withdrawals and transfers in June, has hired restructuring consultants to advise on a possible bankruptcy filing. The move comes as the market for digital assets has been severely impacted by volatility, with cryptocurrencies losing over $400 billion since TerraUSD's collapse in May. Celsius had promised customers annual returns of up to 19%, but its customers remain unable to redeem their assets.

images.alt_text: The New Jersey-based cryptocurrency lending company froze withdrawals and transfers earlier this month due to “extreme” market conditions, in the latest sign of the financial market downturn hitting the cryptosphere.

site_title: Technology stocks head for historic wipeout as US economy cools
summary: US technology stocks are experiencing a historic decline, with the Nasdaq 100 Index tumbling almost a third this year, erasing $5.4 trillion in value. The benchmark is on track for its biggest calendar-year decline ever, with concerns over inflation and interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve sparking fears of a recession. Top tech companies such as Netflix, Teledoc Health, and Zoom Video Communications have been among the worst performers, with some losing over 50% of their value. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic, citing cheaper valuations and the long-term growth potential of the tech industry.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 239.31 points, or 0.77 per cent, at the open to 30,790.00.

site_title: China's factory activity disappoints as services output surges
summary: China's factory activity expanded in June at a muted pace, with the manufacturing purchasing managers index rising to 50.2, its first expansion since February. The non-manufacturing gauge, measuring services sector activity, surged to 54.7, also above expectations. China has gradually eased Covid restrictions, but the economy remains fragile due to its Covid Zero strategy, and economists expect 4.1% GDP growth for 2022, below Beijing's target of 5.5%.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) promised to use aggregate and structural policy tools to boost confidence in the economy.

site_title: Japan's May factory output suffers biggest slump in 2 years
summary: Japan's factory output dropped 7.2% seasonally in May, the largest monthly decline in 2 years, due to China's Covid-19 lockdowns and supply disruptions. This marks a significant challenge for Japan's economy, which is struggling to recover. The decline is attributed to both supply shortages and weak demand, with inventories remaining stable despite the drop in output. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expects a 12% rebound in June and a 2.5% expansion in July, but the data highlights concerns about the country's manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: The financial hub Shanghai lifted its 2-month lockdown at the start of June by allowing more shops to reopen, more factories to resume production, and for port operation to pick up.

site_title: Shaky housing adds A$10t hazard to Australia's economy
summary: Australia's A$10 trillion housing market is expected to slow down, posing a significant risk to the country's economy. Economists disagree on the magnitude of the impact, with some predicting a recession and others expecting the economy to withstand the correction. The Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe is forecast to hike interest rates at the fastest pace on record, which could trim household spending and lead to a housing correction. Unemployment remains low, and household savings are high, but the country's record-high debt level of 187% of income poses a risk to consumer spending.

images.alt_text: The Sydney Opera House and city centre skyline are seen as the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continues in Sydney, Australia, April 20, 2020. REUTERS/Loren Elliott/File Photo

site_title: Bombardier quadruples Singapore facility size as Apac business jet activity expected to surpass pre-pandemic
summary: Bombardier has expanded its Singapore Service Centre at Seletar Aerospace Park with a US$85 million investment, quadrupling the facility's size. The centre now spans 27,000 square metres and is expected to support over 2,000 business jet visits annually. CEO Eric Martel expects Asia Pacific business jet activities to surpass pre-pandemic levels, driven by pent-up travel demand and a lack of routes and frequencies for commercial flights. The expansion also includes new heavy structural and composite repair capabilities and an integrated parts depot, with plans to add 100 staff in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Billionaire economy is booming with private jets in short supply

site_title: Globe Telecom said in advanced talks for US$1.5b tower sale: sources
summary: Globe Telecom is in advanced talks to sell about 6,000 towers in a deal valued at up to $1.5 billion. The Filipino telecom giant is considering a two-part deal, with consortiums consisting of Stonepeak Partners and Manila Electric, and Partners Group Holding and Aboitiz Group, negotiating for the assets. Other parties, including KKR & Co, remain interested. This sale comes after Globe's rival PLDT sold its towers for $1.9 billion in April.

images.alt_text: Globe Telecom’s principal shareholders - Singtel and Ayala Corporation, have both indicated their support for the stock rights offer.
Globe Telecom is weighing selling around half of its telecommunications tower portfolio in a deal that could be worth as much as US$1.5 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Hello Kitty owner soars on China licence deal with Alibaba unit
summary: Sanrio, the owner of Hello Kitty, has signed a 5-year licensing deal with Alibaba's Alifish unit to expand its reach in China. The deal, effective January 1, covers 26 characters, including Hello Kitty, My Melody, and Little Twin Stars. The partnership is expected to capitalize on changing consumer appetites in mainland China and further value Sanrio to $2 billion. Shares rose 15% on the news, the largest intraday gain in over a decade.

images.alt_text: Outside a Sanrio store in Tokyo.Photographer: Kentaro Takahashi/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst quarter since pandemic hit of early 2020
summary: Europe's stocks suffered their worst quarter since the pandemic in early 2020, with the Stoxx 600 index dropping 1.5% to a 10.7% quarterly loss. The decline was driven by hawkish central bank actions to tame inflation, with the ECB expected to hike rates for the first time since 2011. Euro zone inflation reached record highs, and single stocks such as Uniper SE and Fortum SE fell after withdrawing their 2022 financial year outlooks. The European Central Bank will scrutinize the first estimate of June inflation on Friday ahead of its policy meeting.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index lost 1.6 per cent to 7,194.36 points compared with the closing level on Wednesday.

site_title: A tale of three cities
summary: Hong Kong, Singapore, and Shanghai are vying for dominance as Asia's financial hubs. Hong Kong's status as a global finance center is being challenged by Singapore's business-friendly environment, low taxes, and proximity to China. The number of Chinese firms with regional headquarters in Hong Kong has increased, while American firms have shifted their Asian operations to Singapore. Shanghai is gaining ground in wealth management and capital markets, but Hong Kong remains a key gateway to China due to its quarantine-free status. Singapore's strategy of attracting businesses to the city while allowing them to remain in Hong Kong may become more attractive in the long term.

images.alt_text: On Friday, Hong Kong reaches the halfway mark of a 50-year experiment designed to give the city a high degree of autonomy under Chinese rule. Critics of the government say political and civil liberties have been hugely curtailed, but the financial sector has thrived since the handover. The value of Hong Kong’s stock market has surged to HK$27.65 trillion (S$4.88 trillion) as of end-June, up from HK$3.2 trillion in 1997; global investors have become increasingly reliant on Hong Kong to trade mainland stocks.
Under a deal signed with Britain ahead of the 1997 handover, China promised Hong Kong could keep its capitalist system for 50 years.
The region’s potential for digital payment is immense, and there is much Singapore can offer the financial world with its highly competitive attributes.

site_title: Pokemon Go creator Niantic cancels 4 projects, cuts 8% of staff
summary: Niantic, the company behind Pokémon Go, has cancelled four projects and will cut 85-90 jobs due to economic turmoil. The cancelled projects include Heavy Metal, Hamlet, Blue Sky, and Snowball. The company, which has struggled to replicate the success of Pokémon Go, will focus on its key priorities, including Pokémon Go and NBA All-World. Niantic's CEO John Hanke wrote in an email that the company needs to "streamline operations" to weather economic storms ahead.

images.alt_text: Niantic CEO John HankePhotographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Riksbanken rate hike lifts Swedish krona
summary: The Swedish krona rose 0.1% against the euro after the Riksbanken's 50-basis-point interest rate hike, reaching 10.6810. The euro dropped against most peers amid safe-haven demand due to concerns over higher rates and a global recession. The eurozone's second-largest economy, France, saw inflation rise to a record high of 6.5% in June, adding to the euro's decline. The US dollar remained strong, with losses this week leaving it set for a 3.6% monthly decline, while the yen touched a 24-year peak.

images.alt_text: In May, the HOX Sweden housing-price index decreased by 1.6 per cent from the previous month, which is the largest drop since the pandemic in April 2020.
Karen Donfried said Washington understood that the talks between the parties earlier this week had been constructive.

site_title: Gold inches higher; set for worst quarter in 5 as dollar shines
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,818.31 per ounce, despite facing its worst quarter since 2021, due to a decline in US Treasury yields. The dollar strengthened, making gold less attractive for buyers holding other currencies. Central banks' aggressive tactics to combat inflation have led to rate hikes, increasing the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The world's top central bank chiefs warned that bringing down inflation could be painful and potentially lead to a recession.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were hemmed into a tight range in the previous session as investors were caught between pressure from prospects of higher interest rates and support from recession risks.

site_title: MAS reprimands crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital for false information, exceeding AUM threshold
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reprimanded crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital (3AC) for providing false information and exceeding its allowed assets under management (AUM) threshold. 3AC, which had claimed an AUM of about US$3 billion, exceeded the limit between July 2020 and September 2020, and between November 2020 and August 2021. The regulator also found that 3AC failed to notify of changes to directorships and shareholdings, and that its representation of a novation of management to an offshore entity was misleading.

images.alt_text: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum, DogeCoin, Ripple, Litecoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Chinese homebuilders skirt discount limits with 'fancy' promotions: report
summary: Chinese developers in small cities are offering food, such as wheat, garlic, watermelons, and peaches, as down-payment substitutes to make properties cheaper. This circumvents rules against excessive discounting, raising suspicions about whether developers are trying to bypass curbs on price cuts. Property sales by floor area fell 31.77% in May, with most major real estate firms achieving less than 30% of their sales targets. This is part of a broader trend of desperate developers trying to boost sales in a struggling market.

images.alt_text: The financial hub Shanghai lifted its 2-month lockdown at the start of June by allowing more shops to reopen, more factories to resume production, and for port operation to pick up.
China Vanke chairman Yu Liang cautioned that recovery will be slow and mild, but his comments helped drive the mainland’s CSI Real Estate Index up 6 per cent.
China's housing sales have fallen year-on-year for 11 months straight, a record since the nation's private property market began in the 1990s.
A Central China sales agent who answered the phone number on the advertisement said the promotion, aimed mainly at farmers in the region, started on Monday (Jun 20) and will end on Jul 10.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.12 points or 0.01% to 1,451.36. The market saw 130.20 million lots traded worth RM70.74 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 150 to 113.

site_title: Australia job vacancies surge as firms struggle to find staff
summary: Australia's job vacancies surged 13.8% in the May quarter to 480,100, reaching an all-time high, as firms struggle to find staff amid a tightening labor market. This drove the jobless rate down to 3.9%, its lowest in almost 50 years. Vacancies in the private sector rose 14.2% and public sector vacancies grew 9.4%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to hike interest rates by another 50 basis points at its July meeting, citing the strong labor market and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: People walking past and queueing at the National Australia Bank (NAB) ATM machine.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as slowdown fears return, energy top loser
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.3% to 6,677.8, marking their worst month since March 2020, amid fears of an economic slowdown and soaring inflation. Energy stocks were the top losers, falling 1.7% due to lower oil prices, while financials declined 1% and AGL Energy jumped 1.7% after a Canadian investment manager acquired a stake in the company. The S&P/ASX 200 index has slumped over 10% since the start of the year, with exports-centric miners also falling.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.94 per cent to 6,700.2 points at the close of trade, with most sectors in negative territory.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip on Thursday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% or 7.31 points to 3,127.56 at 9:02 am, despite advancers outnumbering decliners 72 to 46. The decline follows a flat Wall Street session, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up 0.3%, and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank chiefs maintained a hawkish stance, fueling fears of a global recession.

images.alt_text: Straits Real Estate, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Straits Trading, said on Wednesday that it was acquiring a portfolio of office and industrial buildings and several plots of development land in Gloucester Business Park for £130 million (S$219.5 million).

site_title: Shopify shares slide after completing 10-for-1 stock split
summary: Shopify shares dropped 5.8% after completing a 10-for-1 stock split, marking the latest move by tech companies to attract retail investors. The stock has plunged 76% this year due to slowing e-commerce traffic and rising borrowing costs. Despite this, some retail traders showed interest, and analysts believe the split could have a positive near-term impact on shares.

images.alt_text: Shopify has reported adjusted earnings of 20 US cents per share, far short of analyst calls for 64 US cents.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yanlord, Straits Trading, TTJ, Second Chance, iWOW
summary: Straits Real Estate, a subsidiary of Straits Trading, acquired a portfolio of office and industrial buildings and development land in Gloucester Business Park for £130 million (S$219.5 million). The acquisition is Straits Trading's largest deal to date. Shares of Straits Trading closed 0.4% lower at S$2.88. This deal may have implications for Straits Trading's performance.

site_title: Crypto crash aside, NFTs are here to stay
summary: NFTs are not going away, according to economics professor Magnus Resch, who believes they will stabilize in the coming years and become a part of the cultural landscape. NFTs solve the art world's problems, including transparency, authenticity, and money. Resch notes that the days of excessive speculation are over, citing the crypto crash and unrealistic price increases of some projects. Instead, NFTs will establish provenance and become a standard part of the art market, with every work of art having an NFT attached to it.
