site_title: Deutsche Bank sees Bitcoin returning to US$28,000 by year-end
summary: Deutsche Bank analysts predict Bitcoin may reach US$28,000 by year-end, driven by a potential S&P 500 recovery and increased correlation with traditional markets. The coin has underperformed this year, losing over 50%, but the analysts suggest it may follow the tech-heavy index's rebound. The digital currency is likened to diamonds, a highly marketed asset, rather than gold, a stable safe-haven commodity, and its price may be influenced by marketing efforts rather than fundamental value.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin dipped below US$20,000 for the first time in almost a week, as the token’s lack of sustained upward momentum caused some technical analysts to raise the prospect of further declines.
Several publicly listed bitcoin miners collectively sold more than 100% of their entire output in May as the value of bitcoin tumbled 45%.

site_title: UK business confidence drops to 15-month low as inflation surges
summary: UK business confidence has dropped to a 15-month low, reaching 28% in June, according to Lloyds Banking Group's gauge. This represents a 10-point decline from the previous month. Companies have been more resilient to inflation than households, but the latest survey suggests that this trend is reversing. Businesses are feeling gloomy about their trading prospects due to concerns over higher costs and slowing demand, which may limit their ability to pass on increased costs and maintain profit margins.

site_title: Central bankers write requiem for low-inflation strategies
summary: Central bankers are shifting their focus from low inflation to higher inflation, warning of a potential "re-division of the world" and a reversal of globalization. The European Central Bank's Christine Lagarde and Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell emphasized that persistent price pressures and supply shocks will change the landscape of monetary policy. The Fed has already raised interest rates by 75 basis points and signaled further hikes, with economists predicting a more aggressive policy pivot. The risk of longer-lasting scarcity and lower productivity growth is a concern, with central bankers warning that unrelenting price increases could shift expectations and lead to higher inflation.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) promised to use aggregate and structural policy tools to boost confidence in the economy.
Monthly figures show that Indonesia's stash is at the smallest since November 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index falling 0.19% to 26,753.28. The decline followed US stocks ending flat, as investors sought new trading cues. The broader Topix index also lost 0.34%. The move was largely driven by market uncertainty, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: New Zealand business sentiment continues to weaken as supply issues dominate
summary: New Zealand business sentiment weakened in June as supply issues persisted, consistent with ongoing inflation pressures. The ANZ Bank survey found a net 62.6% of respondents expected the economy to deteriorate over the next year, up from 55.6% in May. A contraction of 9.1% of respondents also expected their businesses to contract in the next 12 months, up from 4.7% previously.

site_title: Katrina discloses further details on URA investigation, affirms suitability of CEO
summary: Katrina Group CEO Alan Goh Keng Chian is under investigation by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) regarding possible breaches of the minimum stay requirement for short-term accommodation. Two employees of ST Hospitality, a subsidiary, are assisting the investigation. Goh has received a notice to attend an interview but the nominating committee has deemed him suitable to remain CEO, citing his professional conduct and past working relationship with the company. The investigation is ongoing, with no charges made against Goh.

images.alt_text: The URA investigation involves possible breaches of the minimum stay requirement by ST Hospitality and its subsidiaries.
Katrina said that the investigation is still ongoing, and no charges have been filed against the group nor any of the relevant people.

site_title: Britain’s car output revs up in May after 10-month slump
summary: Britain's car production rebounded in May with a 13.3% increase to 62,284 vehicles, ending a 10-month slump. Electric vehicle production more than doubled to 4,525 units. Despite the growth, the sector still faces challenges, including supply chain issues, rising costs, and geopolitical instability. The industry is 46.3% below pre-pandemic levels in 2019.

images.alt_text: Britain's trade minister Anne-Marie Trevelyan said it would target 100 priority issues worth £20 billion (S$33.8 billion) that could be resolved outside of negotiations over new Free Trade Agreements to replace the arrangements that Britain operated under in the EU.

site_title: Disney unveils first new cruise ship in a decade, dips toe into metaverse
summary: Disney has unveiled its first new cruise ship in a decade, the 4,000-passenger Disney Wish, after a 6-year development process. The ship features innovative technology, immersive experiences, and attractions such as the AquaMouse and Star Wars-themed lounge. The launch marks a bright spot for CEO Bob Chapek, who has secured a 3-year contract extension despite recent controversies. The cruise business has generated a "double-digit return on investment" for Disney, with operating income reaching $4.2 billion in the first half of fiscal 2022.

images.alt_text: People gather to protest the Supreme Court's 6-3 decision in the Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization at Washington Square Park on June 24, 2022 in New York City.
“Disney Parks Around The World – A Private Jet Adventure” will fly 75 mega-fans around the world in July 2023 to all 12 parks, starting at a hefty US$110,000 per person.

site_title: Australia swiftly needs US$9b in grid investment for energy transition
summary: Australia needs approximately A$13 billion ($9 billion) in transmission investments to support the country's transition to renewable energy by 2050. The Australian Energy Market Operator's two-year plan aims to boost connections within and between states, with five key transmission projects expected to be completed between 2026 and 2031. The investments are necessary to handle increased renewable energy capacity and address the need for affordable and reliable energy amid accelerating energy system transformation.

images.alt_text: Australia’s climate change minister on Wednesday rejected a proposal to temporarily halt new coal and gas projects in the country, one of the world’s top fossil fuel exporters.

site_title: Two music icons, 2 surprisingly similar paths
summary: Two new movies, "Elvis" and "George Michael: Freedom Uncut," explore the lives of music icons Elvis Presley and George Michael. Despite their different backgrounds and timelines, both men relied on similar formulas for success, including using their masculinity to sell music and navigating racism and homophobia. Both Presley and Michael paid a high price for their success, with Presley's fame leading to a troubled marriage and Michael's struggles with his sexuality and addiction. The films offer different approaches to telling their stories, with "Elvis" focusing on Presley's mythology and "George Michael: Freedom Uncut" offering a more intimate look at Michael's private world.

images.alt_text: Movie still: Elvis starring Austin Butler

site_title: Snap debuts paid service Snapchat+ with exclusive features
summary: Snapchat has launched a paid service called Snapchat+, offering exclusive features for $3.99 a month in the US, UK, Germany, and United Arab Emirates. This move follows a tumultuous period for the company, including a 43% share decline and revenue and profit forecasts being cut. Other social media platforms, such as Twitter and Telegram, have also introduced subscription models. Snapchat+ is aimed at "some of the most passionate members of our community" and marks the company's diversification of revenue streams away from advertising.

images.alt_text: Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Government puts out largest supply of industrial land plots under GLS programme since 2020
summary: Singapore has released 6.36 hectares of industrial land plots under the GLS programme, the largest since 2020. Four sites are confirmed for tender, while three are on the reserve list, generating 1.35 million square feet of potential gross floor area. This follows a 37% increase from the previous programme, with rental indices showing the best quarterly performance in 8 years. Ongoing geopolitical tensions and macroeconomic uncertainties also influenced the decision, with a larger land supply released on the reserve list to meet market demand.

images.alt_text: Reflection and skyline of Central Business District viewed from the Esplanade on May 25, 2022.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls after open on rate hike woes
summary: The US stock market fell on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq experiencing declines, after several policymakers advocated for faster interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose slightly. The market's decline followed recent data painting a negative picture of the economy.

site_title: Nato invites Finland, Sweden to join, says Russia a 'direct threat'
summary: NATO has invited Finland and Sweden to join the military alliance, marking a significant shift in European security following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The decision was made at the NATO summit in Madrid, where allies agreed to formally treat Russia as the "most significant and direct threat to their security." Finland and Sweden will be covered by NATO's Article 5 collective defense clause once ratification in allied parliaments is completed, expected to take up to a year. The move aims to bolster NATO's presence in the Nordic region and increase military exercises and naval patrols in the Baltic Sea.

images.alt_text: Nato will be “strengthened in all directions across every domain -- land, air and sea,” Biden said at a summit of the transatlantic alliance being held in Madrid.

site_title: Straits Trading unit to acquire office and industrial buildings and land in the UK for £130m
summary: Straits Trading's unit, Straits Real Estate, is acquiring a £130m portfolio of office and industrial buildings and land in Gloucester Business Park, UK. The 276-acre park has 9 properties and 6 plots of development land, with existing tenants including GE Aviation and Lockheed Martin. The acquisition offers recurring income and potential for upsized returns through development of logistics warehouses, a sector in strong demand. The deal is part of Straits Real Estate's focus on new economy assets, with CEO Desmond Tang stating it provides a balanced blend of income and growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Clementi Mall.

site_title: iWOW FY2022 net profit rises 4% on growth in sales of IoT solutions
summary: iWOW Technology's FY2022 net profit rose 4% to S$3.9 million, driven by growth in sales of IoT solutions. Revenue increased 31% to S$34.5 million, with the IoT-as-a-Service segment growing 44%. The company declared a final dividend of 0.36 Singapore cent per share and plans to shift revenue mix towards higher-margin subscription models, aiming for sustainable growth. iWOW has S$4.8 million in cash and is gearing up for geographical expansion and portfolio growth.

site_title: Stellantis' French diesel engine plant to get EV motor boost
summary: Stellantis plans to boost electric motor production at its Tremery, France factory, aiming for 50% of capacity by 2024. The move comes as diesel engines, which accounted for 67% of production in 2021, will make up only 30% of capacity by then. Petrol engines, used in hybrid electric vehicles, will account for 20% of capacity. The factory, which currently employs 2,400 people, will see a significant shift in production, with a joint venture with Nidec aiming to produce over 1 million electric motors by 2024.

site_title: Sembcorp’s year-to-date performance shows there’s ‘good in goodbye’
summary: Sembcorp Industries has made steady progress in its clean energy pivot since its demerger from Sembmarine in 2020. The company's conventional energy segment has benefited from soaring electricity prices due to a global energy crunch, while its green appeal remains intact with new developments such as energy storage projects. Sembcorp's renewables portfolio has grown to 7 GW globally, and it has completed several major acquisitions in China and India. The company's market performance has been strong, with a 44.5% return this year, making it the second-best performer among Straits Times Index constituents.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp spruces up portfolio with green courage
The trading halts come amid talks of a potential merger between Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) and Sembmarine.
The general wariness among investors is arguably as much of an obstacle to Sembmarine coaxing its minority shareholders to support the proposed merger as the dilutive nature of the deal.
Without the merger, Sembmarine said it will as a standalone entity have to navigate an “even more competitive landscape” .

site_title: Crypto hedge fund Three Arrows set for liquidation: source
summary: A British Virgin Islands court ordered the liquidation of Three Arrows Capital, a crypto hedge fund that invested heavily in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, following a US$2 trillion market wipeout. The fund's assets under management were estimated to be around US$10 billion, and its liquidation will oversee talks with potential buyers and creditors. The move comes after the fund's founder, Zhu Su, hinted at its reversal of fortune and growing plight in a cryptic tweet. The liquidation is seen as a setback to the industry's policy efforts and a result of poor risk controls that put customer funds at risk.

images.alt_text: Three Arrows Capital (3AC) has failed to make required payments on a loan of 15,250 BTC and $350 million USDC, Voyager Digital has said.

Crypto lending platform BlockFi said it continues normal operations and no client funds are impacted, in an apparent move to allay concerns over contagion risks from the suspected troubles at crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital.

The crypto market has suffered heavy losses, with companies such as Coinbase, Gemini, Blockfi and Crypto.com laying off thousands of employees, as investors sell risky assets in a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Strike underway at Exxon refinery in France
summary: Workers at Exxon's Esso refinery in Fos-sur-Mer, southern France, have gone on strike demanding higher wages and a shutdown of refining units. The strike, which began on Tuesday, aims to cover inflation, with wage negotiations scheduled for September. The refinery has a capacity of 7 million tons per year, and the strike is part of broader union efforts in the energy sector, impacting other companies like EDF. The strike is aimed at alleviating pressure on household budgets due to surging inflation in France.

site_title: Britain pledges to tackle trade barriers for exporters
summary: Britain's trade minister, Anne-Marie Trevelyan, has pledged to target 100 priority trade barriers worth £20 billion to boost exports. The barriers, including those on meat exports to Asia and restrictions on UK-trained lawyers in Japan, will be resolved outside of new Free Trade Agreements. The move comes after the UK extended steel tariffs, which breached international trade rules. Trevelyan considers herself a champion of free trade, but acknowledges the need for safeguards. The removal of some barriers, such as restrictions on British beef in South Korea, will take up to five years.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat as market searches for positive news
summary: US stocks ended flat on Wednesday, failing to recover from the prior session's 2% decline. Inflation and tightening monetary policy continue to weigh on the market. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%. General Mills' strong quarterly earnings report lifted the Dow, but Bed Bath & Beyond's quarterly loss and CEO change dragged down the Nasdaq Composite Index. Investors await the upcoming quarterly earnings season for potential catalysts, but risk disappointment.

site_title: Britain extends steel tariffs in breach of trade rules
summary: Britain has extended steel tariffs and quotas on 5 steel products by 2 years, despite breaching international trade rules. The move aims to shield the UK steel industry from foreign competition, with Trade Minister Anne-Marie Trevelyan citing "serious injury" to producers if the measures are not maintained. The decision, while welcomed by the UK steel industry, is likely to upset some local manufacturers relying on overseas steel.

site_title: US secures 105 million doses of Pfizer vaccine for fall
summary: The US has secured 105 million doses of Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine for the fall, with a $3.2 billion contract that may include Omicron-specific vaccines. Delivery will begin in late summer and continue into the fourth quarter. The contract, which includes vaccines for babies, young children, teens, and adults, was made possible by reallocating $10 billion in existing funding from COVID-19 response efforts. The move aims to keep vaccines free and widely available to Americans, although funding for future vaccines is uncertain without new congressional approval.

site_title: Coinbase renews overseas expansion plan after cutting US staff
summary: Coinbase, a San Francisco-based cryptocurrency exchange, is reviving its international expansion plan after cutting US staff. The company aims to build its presence in Europe, registering in Italy, Spain, France, and the Netherlands, and is open to acquisitions to accelerate its overseas growth. Despite cutting 1,100 jobs, Coinbase remains committed to its mission to expand globally, with the goal of its international segment dominating its business. The company has already registered in the UK, Ireland, and Germany, and has hired its first employee in Switzerland.

images.alt_text: "We believe Coinbase will need to make substantial reductions in its cost base in order to stem the resulting cash burn as retail trading activity dries up," Goldman analyst William Nance wrote.
CRYPTOCURRENCY exchange Coinbase Global said on Tuesday (Jun 14) it would slash 18 per cent of its workforce, or about 1,100 jobs, as part of efforts to rein in costs amid volatile market conditions.

site_title: Amazon plans to share cashierless store data with brands and advertise
summary: Amazon plans to share data from its cashierless store technology, "Just Walk Out," with brands and advertisers through its Store Analytics initiative. The data, collected from cameras and sensors, will provide insights on product discovery, consideration, and purchase rates. Brands will have access to aggregated and anonymized data, which will help inform decisions on product selection, promotions, and ad campaigns. The program aims to help Amazon recoup development and operating costs, but raises concerns about shopper privacy.

site_title: R. Kelly, who dodged sex allegations for years, sentenced to 30 years
summary: R&B singer R. Kelly has been sentenced to 30 years in prison after being convicted of running a criminal ring that exploited teenagers and women in a web of sexual, emotional, and physical abuse. The 55-year-old artist, who sold over 75 million records globally, faced decades of sex abuse allegations, including child pornography charges that were first documented in the 1990s. Kelly's defense team portrayed him as a "playboy" and "sex symbol," but the jury found him guilty of using his fame to recruit victims for sex.

site_title: Better payment authorisation rates mean greater customer retention
summary: Better payment authorisation rates are crucial for customer retention in the e-commerce landscape. According to the Global Payment Report 2021, the Asia-Pacific region has a high cart abandonment rate of 73.2%. To address this issue, businesses must focus on refining their end-to-end payment ecosystem, prioritizing customer experience, and improving authorisation rates. By understanding the reasons behind failed transactions and partnering with a good payments company, businesses can increase revenue and build credibility with customers. This can be achieved through strategies such as knowing the process, ensuring easy and efficient transactions, and leveraging digital wallets and network tokenisation.

images.alt_text: Despite increasing competition in mobile payments, Jun Hasegawa says Opn's years-long experience in South-east Asian markets and ability to adapt to complex local regulations give it an edge against rivals.

site_title: WHO warns 'sustained transmission' of monkeypox risks vulnerable groups
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of "sustained transmission" of monkeypox worldwide, which could lead to the virus affecting vulnerable groups such as pregnant women, immunocompromised individuals, and children. Reports of infected children have been investigated in the UK, Spain, and France, with none of the cases being severe. The virus has been identified in over 50 new countries outside of Africa, where it is endemic, and WHO is calling for increased testing to slow the spread. This could potentially put high-risk groups at risk.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde sees inflation fight as an 'art'
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said finding the right monetary policy response to tackle soaring inflation is an "art," not a science. The ECB is set to trigger its first rate hike in over a decade on July 21 amid an 8.1% inflation surge in the eurozone, its highest rate in the euro area. Lagarde acknowledged the difficulty in gauging the impact of cutting Russian supplies on inflation and growth. The US Federal Reserve recently raised interest rates by 75 basis points, prompting concerns of a recession, but the US economy is considered "strong."

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde speaks during a press conference after a Governing Council meeting focused on monetary policy in the euro zone in Amsterdam on June 9, 2022. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)
Soaring inflation is “a great challenge”, ECB President Christine Lagarde said in a speech at the bank’s annual conference on monetary policy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as hawkish c.bank bets fan recession fears
summary: European stocks fell 0.7% on Wednesday, snapping a three-day rally, amid fears of a global recession. The Stoxx 600 index dropped, with real estate and auto sectors leading the losses. The European Central Bank and US Federal Reserve stuck to their hawkish stance, with ECB President Christine Lagarde saying inflation would require "some pain." Analysts warn of a recession across major markets, with the Stoxx 600 down 15% this year.

site_title: Powell says US economy in strong shape, Fed can avert recession
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US economy is in a strong shape, and the central bank can maintain a solid labor market while reducing inflation to 2% without sparking a recession. Powell vowed to prevent rapid price increases from becoming entrenched and emphasized the Fed's aim to raise interest rates "expeditiously" to move into restrictive territory. The Fed has raised rates by 1.5 percentage points this year and forecasts further cumulative tightening of 1.75 points in 2022.

site_title: China's central bank to step up policy implementation to spur growth
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced plans to implement more aggressive monetary policies to boost the slowing economy. The PBOC will use aggregate and structural tools to increase confidence, improve market-oriented interest rates, and reduce financing costs for enterprises. The central bank also reaffirmed its stance on keeping the yuan exchange rate flexible and stable. This move aims to support the economy, which is facing triple pressures of shrinking demand, supply shock, and weakening expectations. The PBOC's actions are in response to the global economic slowdown and geopolitical conflicts.

images.alt_text: China last tweaked yuan trading hours in 2016 when it extended trading by 7 hours.

site_title: Chip exports to Russia plunged by 90% after curbs: US official
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stated that global semiconductor exports to Russia have plummeted by 90% since the US imposed export controls on Moscow over its Ukraine invasion. Controls on Russia's aerospace sector are hindering revenue generation and military aviation support. The US may force Russia to ground 50-67% of its commercial aircraft in 4 years to cannibalize spare parts. The US is also threatening to "shut down" China's top chipmaker SMIC if it supplies chips to Russia.

site_title: Logistics players step up investments as e-commerce charges ahead despite supply-chain hiccups
summary: Logistics players are increasing investments in the e-commerce sector despite supply-chain disruptions. GXO Logistics, a US-listed supply-chain management company, has upgraded its growth guidance to 11-15% for this year and is reviewing its entire landscape, with a focus on South-east Asia and Singapore. Regional logistics company J&T Express is also bullish on the region, citing strong consumer demand and a growing manufacturing industry. The company is investing RM600 million in a logistics centre in Malaysia and upgrading its automated parcel sorting system. Contract logistics providers, such as GXO, are seeing positive tailwinds due to the growth of e-commerce, with customers increasingly outsourcing to them for faster and more efficient delivery.

images.alt_text: The area inside the warehouse where outbound shipments are being processed as seen during a media tour of the FedEx Express Life Sciences Express Hub (LSEH) on January 21, 2021. With APAC readying itself for global vaccine shipments, cold chain transportation and storage facilities and technologies are high in priority to serve the global healthcare needs.

Amazon packages being pushed on to ramps leading to delivery trucks by a robotic system; unlike traditional storage sites, fulfilling online orders requires technologically advanced warehouses, saidys Mark Manduca, chief investment officer at GXO.

E-commerce logistics has boomed across the region.

site_title: Opec+ meets with little prospect of pumping more oil
summary: OPEC+ ministers are meeting to confirm August oil output policies, with little prospect of a significant increase in production. The group had previously raised output by 648,000 barrels per day in June, but its ability to raise output further is questioned, with Saudi Arabia and the UAE considered to have limited spare capacity. The meeting, which began on Wednesday, will focus on confirming August policies, with discussions on September output likely to emerge later. International oil prices have risen to near $120 a barrel due to tight supply and concerns about OPEC's ability to increase production.

images.alt_text: The group has been struggling for months to deliver the volumes of oil to the market that it has pledged, as some members contend with diminished investment and operational issues.

site_title: US personal spending revised sharply lower in Q1 data
summary: US personal spending declined sharply in Q1, revised to an annualised 0.3% drop from little changed, reflecting less robust spending on durables. This marks a surprise downward revision, suggesting an economy on weaker footing than previously thought. Overall GDP was revised down to a 1.6% annualised decline in Q1, with spending on services and merchandise also revised lower. The decline in non-durable goods spending at a 3.7% rate moderated consumer spending, contrary to expectations of acceleration.

site_title: If Putin was a woman, there would be no Ukraine war: UK's Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stated that if Russian President Vladimir Putin was a woman, he would not have started the war in Ukraine, calling it an example of "toxic masculinity". Johnson also suggested better education for girls and more women in positions of power. Putin responded by citing Margaret Thatcher's decision to launch an offensive against Argentina in 1982, and Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov compared Johnson's comments to a subject for Sigmund Freud's research. Western allies must support Ukraine to be in the best strategic position for potential peace negotiations with Moscow.

site_title: Yanlord’s third batch of apartments in Shanghai project sold out, pulls in RMB6.1b in pre-sales
summary: Yanlord Land Group's third batch of apartments in its Shanghai project, Yanlord Arcadia, sold out, generating RMB6.1 billion in pre-sales. The 372 units, averaging RMB115,000 per sqm, were taken up by 1,769 registered customers. Located in Shanghai's Yangpu district, Yanlord Arcadia will feature 1,171 residential units across 16 towers. The company's shares closed flat at S$1.08 following the successful pre-sales.

site_title: Bailey says BOE has option to act more forcefully on inflation
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey hinted that the central bank may boost the benchmark lending rate by 50 basis points at the next meeting to combat inflation. Bailey emphasized that the decision is still a month away, but acknowledged that policy makers have the option to act more forcefully if price increases persist. The UK economy is showing signs of slowing down, and financial markets are pricing in upside risks for interest rate increases, Bailey said. The BOE's goal is to bring inflation back to target, and Bailey will closely monitor the shift in inflation composition.

site_title: Mercedes readies plants to produce electric vehicles
summary: Mercedes-Benz is preparing to produce luxury electric vehicles at its German and Hungarian plants, aiming to halve CO2 emissions per passenger car by the end of the decade. The company has adjusted its network to manufacture new models in top-end, core luxury, and entry luxury segments, with battery systems supplied by factories in three continents. This shift is part of Mercedes' plan to switch to electric by the end of the decade, following talks with worker representatives.

site_title: Oil slides 2% on rising US fuel stocks and output
summary: Oil prices slid 2% on Wednesday due to rising US fuel stocks and inventories, offsetting concerns about tight crude supplies. US crude inventories fell despite production hitting its highest level since April 2020, while fuel stocks rose as refiners ramped up activity. The rise in US dollar against other currencies also contributed to the decline. Despite concerns about supply and demand, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies are unlikely to make significant policy changes this month, citing low spare capacity and recovering demand.

site_title: Global O&G market low on spare capacity, but Shell to stay focused on future of energy
summary: Shell's CEO Ben van Beurden stated that the global oil and gas market is in a "turbulent period" with low spare capacity, but the company remains focused on the future of energy. Despite scaling back O&G investments, Shell has invested in various renewable energy forms, including hydrogen, solar, and wind. Van Beurden emphasized the need for integrated solutions to achieve net-zero emissions globally by 2050, citing the need for multiple solutions across different sectors. Shell aims to offer customers a suite of solutions to support its net-zero ambitions.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil, Shell and Cnooc signed a non-binding agreement with the Guangdong government on a facility that would capture as much as 10 million tons of carbon dioxide a year.
The airline industry requires huge investments in so-called sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), which are currently in short supply and far more expensive than conventional jet fuels.

Screens promoting the use of green hydrogen at an airport in Santiago. Major oil companies still spend the bulk of their money on oil and gas, but are devoting a growing proportion to low-carbon energy.

site_title: Record trade deficit weighs on US economy in first quarter
summary: The US economy contracted in the first quarter at a 1.6% annualized rate due to a record trade deficit, but domestic demand remained strong. Final sales to private domestic purchasers increased at a 3.0% rate, while consumer spending accelerated in April. However, the economy's rebound is losing momentum due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary policy tightening to combat inflation, heightening recession fears.

images.alt_text: With American families struggling in the face of soaring gas and food prices, the Fed has shifted into high gear, implementing the biggest rate hike in nearly 30 years earlier this month to try to cool the economy and rein in inflation.

site_title: Giving citizens a stake in Forward Singapore
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong launched Forward Singapore, a national conversation aimed at renewing Singapore's social compact. The initiative emphasizes a "more open and compassionate meritocracy" that values workers in every profession and pays them well. It also focuses on shared responsibility, including individual obligations to society, and is framed as a renewal of the social compact rather than a vision for the future. The government seeks to engage citizens and encourage participation in building a more equitable society, but will need to convince taxpayers to contribute to increased spending on social programs.

images.alt_text: Explaining the need to refresh Singapore’s social compact, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said a social compact, broadly, is a shared understanding of how everyone in society relates to each other, as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of various groups.

site_title: Indian rupee hits record lows despite central bank intervention
summary: The Indian rupee hit a record low of 78.97 against the US dollar on June 29, 2022, due to concerns over rising inflation and weak growth. Despite the Reserve Bank of India's intervention, the currency ended at 78.9650/9750 per US dollar, losing over 6% against the dollar this year. Analysts predict further depreciation, with the rupee expected to weaken towards 81 to a US dollar by the end of FY23, mainly due to FIIs selling local shares, rising crude prices, and the US dollar strengthening.

site_title: Malaysia’s Unique Fire aims to raise RM21.8m in Ace Market listing
summary: Malaysia's fire protection system assembler and manufacturer, Unique Fire Holdings, plans to raise RM21.78 million through its initial public offering (IPO) on Bursa Malaysia's Ace Market in August. The company aims to expand its coverage in Penang and Johor, increase manufacturing facilities, and improve operational capabilities. With a market capitalization expected to reach RM104 million after listing, Unique Fire will be the first fire protection system assembler and manufacturer listed on Bursa Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Farm Fresh aims to raise RM1b in IPO

site_title: BT Explains: Are cryptocurrencies a good hedge against inflation with their prices falling?
summary: Cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, have lost significant value and are no longer considered a reliable hedge against inflation. Despite their limited supply and potential to increase in value, their prices have fallen by 70% since November last year, and their correlation with traditional assets like the S&P 500 has increased. Experts argue that their volatility and lack of stability make them unsuitable for inflation protection, and that investors should focus on assets that can generate returns higher than inflation.

images.alt_text: "We believe Coinbase will need to make substantial reductions in its cost base in order to stem the resulting cash burn as retail trading activity dries up," Goldman analyst William Nance wrote.
blockchain, technology, smart
Cryptocurrencies are here to stay and their dramatic recent crash is just part of an economic cycle, Changpeng Zhao, one of crypto's most influential figures, told AFP in an interview on Thursday.

site_title: World Bank's Reinhart 'skeptical' global recession can be avoided
summary: World Bank chief economist Carmen Reinhart expressed skepticism about avoiding a global recession, citing spiking inflation, sharp interest rate hikes, and slowing growth in China. Reinhart noted that historically, it's challenging to reduce inflation and achieve a soft landing simultaneously. The World Bank has slashed its global growth forecast to 2.9% for 2022, warning of recession risks, with potential growth falling to 2.1% in 2022 and 1.5% in 2023. Reinhart believes the Federal Reserve should have acted sooner to address inflation, increasing the likelihood of a recession.

images.alt_text: World Bank economists estimate that low- and middle-income economies owe a record US$9.3 trillion to foreign creditors and that 40 poor countries, and about half a dozen middle income ones, are either in debt distress or at a high risk of it.

site_title: Searches for overseas flights surge after China shortens quarantine
summary: Online searches for air tickets on international routes with China surged after Beijing shortened Covid-19 quarantine norms, with Qunar reporting a 60% increase in ticket purchases over the previous week. The easing was welcomed by travel operators, but concerns over inflation and recession remained. China's relaxation was also met with caution, as airlines face strict load factor limits and a "circuit breaker" system requiring flight suspensions. The news drew over 28 million views on Weibo, with many expressing excitement about the potential for international travel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A China Eastern Airlines aircraft and a Shanghai Airlines aircraft are seen in Hongqiao International Airport in Shanghai, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, China June 4, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
In anticipation of high passenger traffic, Changi Airport will reopen Terminal 4 in September and the south wing of Terminal 2 in October ahead of the northern winter season that begins Oct 30.

site_title: Amazon Cloud Unit on course for US$3 trillion value, Redburn says
summary: Amazon's cloud storage unit, Amazon Web Services (AWS), is on track to reach a US$3 trillion value, nearly triple its current market value, according to Redburn analyst Alex Haissl. AWS' revenue jumped 37% to US$18.4 billion in the first quarter, driven by its strong performance. Haissl recommends buying Amazon shares, predicts a US$270 price target in the next year, and rates Microsoft a buy and Snowflake neutral. He notes that AWS' lower costs and better technology position it better than rivals Microsoft and Alphabet.

site_title: Euro trims declines against US dollar after Spanish inflation surge
summary: The euro steadied against the US dollar to US$1.0525 after falling to a 6-day low due to conflicting inflation data in Germany and Spain. The euro declined initially after German June prices in North Rhine-Westphalia dropped 0.1% lower than in May, but recovered after Spanish 12-month inflation rose to 10.2%, surpassing 10% for the first time since April 1985. This surge in Spanish inflation data has reduced pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates.

site_title: No increase in S$0.23 offer price for TTJ
summary: TTJ Holdings' offer price of S$0.23 per share remains unchanged after 4 directors recommended that shareholders reject the bid. The directors, who include the company's executive chairman, concur with an independent financial adviser's advice to reject the offer, citing it as "not fair and not reasonable". The offeror, THC Venture, is solely owned by Teo Hock Chwee, who holds 84.4% of the company's shares, just 6 percentage points away from the 10% free float threshold required by the listing manual. The offer will close on July 8.

site_title: Bitcoin dips below US$20,000 with Fundstrat eyeing ‘final washout’
summary: Bitcoin has dropped below US$20,000 for the first time in almost a week, with technical analysts predicting a potential "final washout" decline. Fundstrat's Mark Newton estimates the token could fall to US$12,500-US$13,000 before a rebound. Despite recent stability, the crypto market remains under pressure from central banks' liquidity efforts and investor confidence.

site_title: US mass shooting insurance rates jump as incidents rise
summary: US mass shooting insurance rates have surged over 10% this year, driven by a string of deadly events, including the Texas elementary school shooting. The number of inquiries for such insurance has also spiked, with insurers seeing a 25% jump in revenue and a 30-35% jump in inquiries. Clients are now purchasing coverage for up to $5-10 million in losses, up from $1-3 million four years ago, with premiums increasing by 5-10% compared to last year.

images.alt_text: Thousands of gun control advocates protest against gun violence during a rally near the Washington Monument on the National Mall in Washington, DC, June 11, 2022.

site_title: Thai PM says weak baht good for exports, eyes 10 million visitors in 2022
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha stated that the country's weak baht is beneficial for exports, despite its negative impact on some individuals. The tourism ministry forecasts 9.3 million international arrivals in 2022, with spending of 1.27 trillion baht, and expects 10 million visitors this year. Foreign arrivals have already surpassed 2 million, with spending of 113 billion baht, led by visitors from India, Malaysia, and the US.

images.alt_text: People make their way down a busy street past food stalls and massage parlours in Bangkok on May 17, 2021, as Thailand recorded its highest daily record of new Covid-19 coronavirus cases since the start of the pandemic. (Photo by Jack TAYLOR / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia reinstates price cap for chicken amid rising food costs
summary: Malaysia has reinstated a price cap for chicken, capping the standard whole chicken at RM9.40 (S$3) per kilogram and Grade A chicken eggs at 45 sen each, effective July 1. The move aims to control rising food costs amid a 2-year low currency and the nation's fastest food inflation rate since October 2011. The government has allocated RM369.5 million as a subsidy for the new price cap, reversing a plan to end price caps on chicken and eggs by June 30.

site_title: Singapore's US$14 billion mega-port takes aim at shipping chaos
summary: Singapore is investing US$14 billion to build the world's largest automated port by 2040, doubling its existing space and featuring drones and driverless vehicles. The mega-port, Tuas, will provide solutions to global shipping congestion caused by the pandemic and ongoing supply chain issues. The project aims to improve efficiency, reduce paperwork, and increase capacity to 65 million TEU by 2040. Singapore's strategy is to set itself apart from competitors, offering a one-stop shop for ships to carry out various needs, including banking, refueling, and cargo handling.

site_title: Toyota's vehicle output shrinks before planned production hike
summary: Toyota produced 634,940 vehicles in May, 5.3% fewer than the previous year due to supply-chain disruptions. The company had planned to pause production in the April-June quarter but aims to boost output in July-September by 40% from last year. Toyota has shielded itself relatively well from the industry disruption and is expected to maintain its scale, product range, and geographic diversification, limiting profit deterioration compared to peers.

site_title: Tianqi Lithium aims to raise up to US$2b in Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: Tianqi Lithium, a top lithium chemicals producer for electric vehicle batteries, plans to sell 164.12 million shares in a Hong Kong listing, aiming to raise up to US$2 billion. The shares will be sold between HK$69 and HK$82 each, with a potential greenshoe option raising the amount to US$1.66-1.97 billion. The listing, set to debut on July 13, will help revive Hong Kong's banking market, which has seen deal volumes decline due to volatile global financial markets.

site_title: Biden announces US military air, sea, land reinforcements in Europe
summary: US President Joe Biden announced significant reinforcements to NATO forces in Europe, strengthening the alliance in all directions across land, air, and sea. The reinforcements include boosting naval destroyers, establishing a permanent headquarters in Poland, and deploying additional rotational brigades in Romania and the Baltic countries. Biden also committed to enhancing air defense and capabilities in Germany, Italy, and Britain, and pledged to make sure NATO is ready to meet threats from all directions. The move comes amid tensions with Russia and in response to the invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Heads of States and Governments from Nato's member countries and key partners are gathering in Madrid to discuss important issues facing the Alliance and endorse Nato's new Strategic Concept, the Organization said.

site_title: China reaffirms subsidy to refiners if oil hits above US$130
summary: China has reaffirmed a plan to subsidize refiners if global oil prices exceed US$130 a barrel, aiming to shield consumers from price shocks. The subsidies will be based on sales volume and initially last for two months, with further announcements if prices remain above US$130. This policy, in place since 2016, tracks global crude oil prices between US$40 and US$130 and aims to maintain stable fuel supplies and alleviate costs for manufacturers and consumers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.26 points to 1,451.48. A total of 2.378 billion lots worth RM1.774 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 461 to 368.

site_title: Singapore shares buckle under regional selling pressure; STI falls 0.17%
summary: The Singapore bourse closed 0.17% lower at 3,134.87, buckling under regional selling pressure amid inflation and recession woes. The Straits Times Index fell for the first time in three days, with losses outweighing gains. Key gauges in Japan, China, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Australia also posted losses, while Hong Kong and South Korea fell the most. The US Q1 GDP data, expected to remain unchanged, will be closely watched by traders.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade on Wednesday, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Jakarta and Wellington were all down.
The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.94 per cent to 6,700.2 points at the close of trade, with most sectors in negative territory.
The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.88 per cent, or 422.08 points, to 21,996.89.

site_title: Thailand ready for rate rise to fight inflation, World Bank says
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to gain momentum and reach pre-pandemic levels in the fourth quarter, driven by a drop in Covid-19 cases and relaxation of border restrictions. The World Bank suggests that Thailand's central bank can raise interest rates to fight inflation, now at a 14-year high, and expects headline inflation to stay at 5.2% in 2022. The Bank of Thailand has kept its key interest rate unchanged at 0.5% for 16 meetings, but may hike rates in the next scheduled meeting on August 10.

site_title: S&P upgrades Chinese developer Greenland days after cutting to 'selective default'
summary: S&P Global Ratings upgraded Greenland Holdings Corp to "CCC" from "selective default" after the Chinese state-backed property developer completed a one-year maturity extension on US$500 million in senior unsecured notes. The upgrade comes days after the downgrade to "selective default" due to the proposal and completion of the maturity extension. Greenland faces heightened repayment risk due to significant debt maturities in 2022 and weak liquidity. Repayments will largely depend on cash collection from sales and asset disposals.

images.alt_text: Shanghai-based Greenland is the first state-backed developer to extend a dollar-bond payment since the country’s property sector plunged into a debt crisis last year.

site_title: Australia: Shares close nearly 1% lower on renewed recession fears
summary: Australian shares closed nearly 1% lower on Wednesday, June 29, amid renewed recession fears following dismal US consumer confidence data. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.94% to 6,700.2 points, with most sectors in negative territory. Despite upbeat Australian retail sales data, investors showed little response to the news, with local banking stocks making some gains. Energy and lithium stocks, however, rose on upbeat oil prices and a new lithium supply deal.

site_title: Second Chance grants option to purchase Lucky Plaza units for S$13.39 million
summary: BCP, a subsidiary of Second Chance Properties, has granted an option to Lew Chee Beng to purchase Lucky Plaza units for S$13.39 million. The option will expire on Aug 1, with an option fee of 1% of the sale price paid to BCP. The sale is expected to be completed by Jan 31, 2023. Rentals at Lucky Plaza have fallen to almost half pre-Covid levels, making it uncertain if they can revert to pre-pandemic levels. The sale is seen as a prudent business decision to reduce the company's debts.

images.alt_text: Crowd outside Lucky Plaza on May 2, 2021 between 10.30am to 11am.

site_title: 'Impossible situation' for Sri Lankans struggling for petrol
summary: Sri Lanka faces an "impossible situation" with a severe fuel shortage, exacerbating its economic crisis. The government restricted fuel supplies to essential services for 2 weeks, but medical staff and others are struggling to get to work due to lack of fuel. Protests continue, with doctors, nurses, and medical staff demanding a solution and calling for the government to step down. The country's economy is expected to contract by 7.5-9.0% this year, and an IMF team is in talks for a potential bailout package of up to $3 billion.

images.alt_text: The island nation's cabinet of ministers Monday decided to limit distribution of fuel to essential services until Jul 10 adding that inter provincial public transport would likely come to a halt.

site_title: Nippecraft in talks on Jurong West property, but says sale not guaranteed
summary: Nippecraft, a CATALIST-listed stationery company, is in discussions with a third party regarding the sale of its Jurong West property, 9, Fan Yoong Road. The company had previously disclosed in April that it was reviewing options for the property, but no certainty has been given that these discussions will lead to a sale. The news led to a trading halt and a significant surge in the company's share price, with 9.6 million shares traded, before being lifted.

site_title: G7 needs more momentum and boldness, post-Ukraine
summary: The G7 summit concluded with few significant agreements, leaving the group in need of more boldness to address the growing range of challenges, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The summit failed to achieve a strong consensus on energy security, with some leaders seeking short-term goals and others prioritizing climate ambitions. Despite the political leadership's weakened state, the G7 has a history of working effectively in turbulent times and has played a key role in managing geopolitical crises. The group's involvement in the Ukraine crisis has been criticized, but it remains a crucial player in Western policymaking and international security.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor and summit host Olaf Scholz, who spearheaded the proposal, said it would allow countries to accelerate climate action while avoiding competitive disadvantages.

Internally displaced people wait for food aid to be distributed by a charity in Taiz, Yemen, April 8, 2022. The Group of Seven rich democracies will commit up to US$5 billion to improve global food security.

site_title: Digi, Celcom Axiata get green light for merger in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia Commission has given the green light for the merger between Celcom Axiata and Digi, expected to be completed in the second half of 2022. The combined entity, Celcom Digi Bhd, will become Malaysia's largest mobile service operator by revenue. The merger is expected to generate annual revenue of around $3 billion and core profitability of $1.4 billion, with Axiata and Telenor holding an equal stake of 33.1% each.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's major telcos mull equity stakes in state 5G agency

site_title: Philippines open to jumbo hikes to aid peso, new BSP chief says
summary: The Philippines' central bank, led by incoming governor Felipe Medalla, is open to jumbo interest-rate hikes to combat a weakening peso and inflation. Medalla stated that the central bank won't match US Federal Reserve rate hikes, instead focusing on addressing exchange rate issues and imported inflation. The peso has fallen 6% against the US dollar this quarter, with Medalla warning that aggressive hikes will be considered if the exchange rate "overshoots" and stokes inflation. The central bank aims to balance inflation and economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Felipe Medalla, governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP), during an interview in Manila, the Philippines, on Tuesday, June 7, 2022. The Philippines will likely follow its interest-rate increase last month with at least two more hikes to curb inflation, according to the central bank’s incoming governor. Photographer: Geric Cruz/Bloomberg

site_title: China has quietly cemented lockdown rules as it eases quarantine
summary: China has revised its Covid guidelines, cutting quarantine time in half for inbound travelers and establishing standardized policies for mass testing and lockdowns. The move solidifies the country's "Covid Zero" strategy, with President Xi Jinping stating China is capable of achieving a "final victory" over the coronavirus. While the guidelines aim to balance control with economic growth, critics argue they do not significantly change China's overall stance on the virus, and new outbreaks pose risks to the economy.

site_title: Oil prices slide after three-day rally
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, taking a break after a three-day rally, as concerns about the global economy weighed on the market. Brent crude futures dropped 98 cents to $117.00 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures slid 62 cents to $111.14 a barrel. Despite tight supply, analysts expect prices to remain above $110 a barrel due to potential supply disruptions, including hurricanes, and concerns about a potential recession.

images.alt_text: The group has been struggling for months to deliver the volumes of oil to the market that it has pledged, as some members contend with diminished investment and operational issues.

site_title: Going digital spices up sales for home-based condiment business
summary: A home-based condiment business, Hot Spicy Mama, has seen a 40% increase in sales after expanding to digital platforms such as Shopee and Lazada. With the help of the Singapore Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry's (SMCCI) Digital Transformation Office (DTO), the business listed on e-commerce platforms and online grocery store RedMart. Digitalization has also enabled the company to create its own digital accounting system, reducing costs and increasing efficiency. The DTO has supported over 130 businesses during the pandemic, and a second version of the program is set to launch, focusing on digitalization optimization and international expansion.

site_title: Shanmugam on the death penalty, a minority Prime Minister, and Section 377A
summary: Singapore's Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam discussed sensitive topics on the BBC's HARDtalk show, including the country's approach to the death penalty, drugs, and Section 377A. He defended the mandatory death penalty for drug trafficking, citing deterrence and the devastating impact of drugs worldwide. However, critics pointed out the execution of Nagaenthran Dharmalingam, who had an IQ of 69, as a potential human rights issue. Shanmugam argued that the individual had the "working of a criminal mind" and was not intellectually disabled. He also defended Singapore's laws on homosexuality, citing a compromise between the government and the population. The minister acknowledged that attitudes are shifting, but laws may not change immediately.

site_title: H&M reports jump in profit, says June sales are seen falling
summary: H&M reported a 33% increase in second-quarter profits to 4.78 billion kronor (S$652 million), beating analyst estimates. However, the company expects a 6% decline in June sales due to the ongoing war in Ukraine and supply chain disruptions. Despite this, H&M's sales have rebounded due to consumers refreshing their wardrobes for work and special events after 2 years of staying at home. The company aims to prioritize profitability and maintain its market position by raising prices less than competitors.

images.alt_text: Although it was open earlier this month, the 3-storey building in downtown Shanghai was on Friday (Jun 24) boarded up with its H&M signage gone.

site_title: Volkswagen still optimistic for Q4 Porsche IPO: CFO
summary: Volkswagen's CFO, Arno Antlitz, expressed optimism for a Porsche IPO in the fourth quarter, citing entrepreneurial freedom and investor appetite. The luxury brand would gain more autonomy, and Volkswagen can expect significant contributions. Despite market volatility, Antlitz believes all necessary conditions are in place for the IPO, which is part of the company's expensive transition to electric vehicles.

site_title: Home reno goes high-tech
summary: Startups are using technology to simplify home renovations, allowing homeowners to plan designs, save money, and find reliable contractors. These tech-enabled platforms connect clients directly with designers and suppliers, cutting out middlemen and enabling virtual furniture shopping. The goal is to make home renovations less painful and more efficient, with some startups offering luxury client experiences.

site_title: Tan Chong to acquire remaining stake in Ethoz Group for S$42.7m
summary: Tan Chong International agreed to purchase the remaining 50% stake in Singapore-based car rental company Ethoz Group for S$42.7 million. This deal, expected to be completed on July 1, 2022, will make Ethoz a wholly-owned subsidiary of Tan Chong. The acquisition is expected to enhance control over Ethoz's operations, allowing for greater strategic direction and decision-making flexibility, ultimately accelerating efficiency and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Tan Chong to sell 2 properties in Upper Bukit Timah Road to CDL for S$126.3m
Singtel Comcentre building at Killiney Road, 16 December 2017.

site_title: Europe: Equities slide at open
summary: European stocks slid at the open on June 29, 2022, following a gloomy US consumer confidence report. London's FTSE 100 index lost 0.5% to 7,289.08 points, while Frankfurt's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices fell 0.9% and 0.5% respectively. The US economy's low consumer confidence, driven by concerns over inflation, overshadowed a surprise move by China to shorten quarantine periods for incoming travelers.

site_title: Xi says Covid zero policy most economic, effective for China
summary: President Xi Jinping stated that China's Covid Zero policy is the most "economic and effective" approach for the country, and it is capable of achieving the goal of stamping out infection. Xi visited Wuhan, where the virus first emerged, and emphasized the importance of protecting people's life safety and physical health, particularly the elderly and children. This statement is likely to dash hopes of a gradual exit plan from the lockdowns and mass testing measures, which have been criticized for their social and economic costs.

site_title: Japan's Renesas, India's Tata Motors partner to develop chip solutions
summary: Japan's Renesas Electronics and India's Tata Motors have formed a strategic partnership to develop semiconductor solutions, including "next-generation automotive electronics" for electric and connected vehicles. The collaboration aims to accelerate growth in these areas globally. The companies will work together on emerging technologies such as advanced driver-assistance systems and wireless network solutions, including 5G. This partnership follows India's efforts to establish domestic semiconductor manufacturing, with a plan to invest $10 billion in incentives.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Analysts at DBS Group Research said the global tech sector is facing a bleak outlook due to weak demand. Hotel room revenue rose for the fourth straight month in May, with Singapore's CBD Grade A office rents recovering to 0.6% below the pre-pandemic peak. DBS raised its 2-year fixed home loan rate to 2.75% per annum, the highest among local banks. Nio's shares plummeted after a short-seller report alleged the Chinese EV maker had inflated revenue and boosted net income margins. The Singapore stock market fell 0.17% under regional selling pressure.

site_title: China businesses lose advantage against global peers amid zero-Covid policy
summary: China's zero-Covid policy is hindering the country's economic growth, with economists warning of a potential slowdown in the second half of the year. To achieve a 5.5% growth target, China needs an 18% increase in infrastructure investment, but policymakers' efforts to promote credit growth and stimulate the economy are falling short. Nomura and Natixis have downgraded their growth forecasts to 3.3% and 3.5% respectively, citing weak consumer and investor sentiment, and unresolved issues in the real estate sector. Beijing's reliance on a "Covid business cycle" strategy may lead to external economic implications and strain the financial health of smaller banks.

images.alt_text: "This year, we face some downward pressures of growth due to Covid-19 and external shocks, and the monetary policy will continue to be accommodative to support economic recovery in aggregate sense," PBOC governor Yi Gang said.
China Vanke chairman Yu Liang cautioned that recovery will be slow and mild, but his comments helped drive the mainland’s CSI Real Estate Index up 6 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: The flag of property developer Shimao Group flutters next to a Chinese flag in Shanghai, China January 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Technology and the triumph of pessimism
summary: Paul Krugman discusses the disconnect between technological progress and societal improvement in his book "Slouching Towards Utopia". Despite rapid technological advancements, humans have not become more satisfied or optimistic, and instead, technology has enabled new forms of destruction. Krugman points to the "long 20th century" as a period of sustained rapid technological development, but notes that progress has not brought about a utopian society. Instead, eras of optimism, such as the pre-WWI and post-WWII periods, were short-lived and ultimately ended in tragedy. The book raises questions about why this happened, and whether the engines of technological progress are slowing down.

images.alt_text: An office set up with typewriters.

site_title: Kovan’s Jansen Mansions sold higher at S$19.1m
summary: Macly Capital has bought Jansen Mansions at Kovan in a public tender for S$19.1 million, surpassing the reserve price of S$18.9 million. This is the third attempt by owners to sell the 12-unit development collectively, following unsuccessful attempts in 2021 and 2018. The property is zoned for residential use with a 999-year leasehold tenure and features a land rate of S$863 per square foot per plot ratio. Interest in the plot increased this year, with attributes such as the 999-year land lease and location appealing to buyers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drop on recession worries; won falls most in 16 months
summary: South Korean shares dropped 1.8% on Wednesday, June 29, amid recession worries driven by high inflation and monetary policy tightening. The benchmark Kospi ended down 44.1 points, snapping a three-session rising streak. The won posted its worst daily performance in 16 months, while the bond yield remained flat. Consumer confidence fell sharply in both the US and South Korea, and recession fears were fueled by weak US data and expected interest rate hikes. Heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motor fell significantly, with the won also declining to a 16-month low.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 20.17 points or 0.84 per cent at 2,422.09, extending gains for a third session.

site_title: The soul of democracy is on the ballot in Israel and America
summary: The soul of democracy is at stake in Israel and the US as the collapse of a national unity government in Israel mirrors the hyper-partisanship in US politics. The unity government, formed by right-wing and left-wing parties, including an Israeli Arab Islamist party, was a historic breakthrough that demonstrated Israelis can govern together. However, it was toppled by Prime Minister Netanyahu, who seeks to maintain a two-tier legal system favoring Israeli settlers in the West Bank. Similarly, US politics has become polarized, with the Trump far right's victory-at-any-cost mentality and antidemocratic values threatening the country's democracy. The future of both societies depends on whether left and right come together to govern effectively.

images.alt_text: statue of liberty, turmoil, stormy

site_title: EQT-backed HMI weighs stake sale at S$1b valuation: sources
summary: HMI Group, a Singapore-based healthcare provider backed by EQT, is exploring selling a 30% stake valued at around S$1 billion. The company plans to issue new shares to fund expansion and acquisitions. Deliberations are ongoing, and no guarantee exists that the transaction will occur. HMI Group serves approximately 500,000 patients annually across two hospitals and medical centers in Malaysia and Singapore. The company went public in 1999 and was previously taken private by EQT in 2019.

site_title: Volt, Australia's first online-only bank, shuts down due to fundraising woes
summary: Australia's first online-only bank, Volt, shut down due to fundraising woes. The bank, which had A$113 million in deposits and A$80 million in home loans, failed to raise sufficient funds to support its business amidst rising inflation and interest rates. Volt's collapse marks the third of four prominent neobanks to fold or be sold since being approved by Australian regulators in 2018. The bank's closure reflects pressure on startups worldwide that have taken on the financial establishment with promises of lower overhead and faster turnaround.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese people are also accustomed to using cash, Yang added.
Conditions are ripe now for Asia to take the lead globally in developing regional digital currency co-operation for cross-border payments.

site_title: Nio shares plunge on short-seller allegations; company says report ‘without merit’
summary: Nio shares plummeted after a short-seller report claimed the Chinese electric vehicle maker was inflating revenue and boosting net income margins through accounting games, similar to Valeant Pharmaceuticals. Nio denies the allegations, calling them "without merit" and stating that numerous errors and speculations are present in the report. The company's board is reviewing the allegations and considering action to protect shareholders.

images.alt_text: A NIO Inc. dealership in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, June 8, 2022. site_title: Meet the 'zombie star' that survived a supernova blast
summary: Scientists have observed a "zombie star" white dwarf in a nearby galaxy that survived a supernova blast, emerging brighter than before the explosion. The star, located in NGC 1309, is about 3 quarters the size of the Milky Way and 108 million light years from Earth. It is believed to have gained mass from its companion star, causing thermonuclear reactions in its core that led to the supernova. The star's radioactive material powered the brightness of the explosion, and some of this material remains, fueling the star's increased brightness. This discovery helps scientists better understand "type Iax" supernovae, which leave behind "undead" white dwarf remnants.

site_title: Deliveroo rolls out ads on its delivery app to increase revenue
summary: Deliveroo is introducing a new advertising platform, Deliveroo Media and Ecommerce, which will allow consumer brands to purchase ad space on the company's app and website. The platform will also sell ad space on the order-tracker page, enabling brands to reach customers during meal delivery. The move aims to increase revenue and profitability for the company, which has seen a 56% decline in its share price this year. The new platform will launch in the UK before expanding to other markets, with Criteo providing technology and media sales services.

site_title: Thai factory output unexpectedly drops 2.1% y-o-y in May
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index unexpectedly fell 2.11% from a year earlier in May, due to lower production of cars, hard disk drives, and plastic pellets. This contrasts with a forecast 1.50% rise in output. The decline reverses the 0.03% yearly drop in April.

site_title: Vietnam sees 2022 growth beating goal as recovery powers on
summary: Vietnam's economy is on track to surpass its 2022 growth goal of 6-6.5% with a likely 7% growth this year, according to the General Statistics Office. The country's GDP expanded 7.72% in the April-June period, beating the median estimate of 5.9%. The recovery is driven by a strong manufacturing, exports, and services sectors, as well as the government's US$15 billion fiscal stimulus and easy monetary policy. However, inflation remains a concern, with consumer prices rising 3.37% in June.

summary: The European Union has approved a plan to end the sale of combustion engine vehicles by 2035, aiming to reduce CO2 emissions to zero by 2050. The decision, made in response to competition from China and the US, will lead to a complete shift to electric engines in the EU. Luxury brands will benefit from a five-year exemption from CO2 obligations for producing fewer than 10,000 vehicles per year. The measure must now be negotiated with the European Parliament, with French Minister of Ecological Transition Agnes Pannier-Runacher calling it a "necessity" for the automotive industry.

site_title: Garuda bets recovery on Indonesia market, wants more Airbus jets
summary: Indonesia's flag carrier Garuda Indonesia is expected to post an operating profit next year after renegotiating aircraft leases and focusing on the domestic market. The airline aims to expand its fleet to 120 aircraft by 2022 and 180 by 2026, primarily through buying or leasing used Airbus jets, including the A320. site_title: Bank of Japan’s Kuroda vows to keep easy policy as Japan less affected by global inflation
summary: The Bank of Japan will maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy despite Japan's core consumer inflation exceeding the 2% target due to soaring global commodity prices and a weak yen. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the economy has not been significantly affected by global inflation, and monetary policy will remain accommodative. Core consumer inflation is expected to slow to around 1% in the next fiscal year, and wages and prices have remained subdued due to the country's 15-year experience with deflation.

site_title: Taiwan central bank says it is working on digital currency, unclear on timetable
summary: Taiwan's central bank is working on a digital currency, with Governor Yang Chin-long stating that the project will push ahead despite an unclear timeline. summary: Hong Kong marks the halfway point of its 50-year capitalist experiment after the 1997 handover to China, with uncertainty clouding its economic future.
