site_title: Europe: Shares extend gains on China Covid-19 relief, rising oil prices
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by improved risk appetite after China eased its Covid-19 quarantine mandate and rising oil prices. The Stoxx 600 index rose for a third straight session, with the energy sector gaining 2% due to major producers Saudi Arabia and the UAE unlikely to boost output significantly. The benchmark index's gains were tempered by a drop in June US consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index jumped 1.0 per cent to 7,329.48 points.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rex International, Raffles Infrastructure
summary: Rex International's subsidiary, Lime Petroleum, has successfully raised S$134.2 million through a senior secured bond. The bond will be used to refinance an existing bond and fund further acquisitions on the Norwegian Continental Shelf. Meanwhile, Raffles Infrastructure dismissed executive director Ma Zhi for failing to meet company standards. These developments may impact trading of the companies' securities.

site_title: Gold prices tick lower on dollar strength
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,818.74 per ounce, as the dollar strengthened, making gold less attractive to investors. The US Federal Reserve hinted at further interest rate hikes to combat inflation, raising the opportunity cost of holding gold. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields eased, providing some support to gold. Meanwhile, US consumer confidence dropped to a 16-month low, raising recession concerns.

site_title: US medical experts call for Omicron-specific Covid-19 boosters
summary: US medical experts have called for Omicron-specific Covid-19 boosters this fall, citing concerns over waning vaccine efficacy and severe outcomes for high-risk patients. The FDA panel voted 19-2 in favor of the measure, following presentations from Pfizer, Moderna, and Novavax on their mRNA and protein subunit vaccines. Experts favor bivalent vaccines targeting both the original Wuhan strain and the latest Omicron variants. The FDA officials expect the virus to continue evolving along the Omicron branch, making Omicron-specific boosters necessary for ongoing seasonal protection.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Vials with Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccine labels are seen in this illustration picture taken March 19, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Russia fines foreign firms for alleged data storage violations
summary: Russia has fined four foreign companies, including Amazon-owned Twitch, Pinterest, and Airbnb, for allegedly refusing to store Russian citizens' personal data in Russia. The companies were fined 2 million roubles (S$50,943) each by a Moscow court. The fines come as part of Russia's efforts to regulate Big Tech and impose data storage requirements. The move is part of a larger dispute between Russia and Western tech companies over content, censorship, and data. Other companies, such as Google and UPS, have also faced fines for alleged data storage violations.

images.alt_text: ussia defaulted on its foreign-currency sovereign debt for the first time in a century, the culmination of ever-tougher Western sanctions.

site_title: Net-zero targets aren't attainable without ending deforestation
summary: A UN-backed report concludes that the global economy won't reach net-zero carbon emissions without ending deforestation. Protecting and restoring forests could result in 18% of the cuts needed by 2030 to combat climate change. Companies in the timber, land, and agriculture industries, responsible for 22% of global emissions, must take urgent action to tackle deforestation in their supply chains. Despite progress from some companies, nearly 90% could miss their net-zero commitments due to lack of progress on deforestation.

images.alt_text: The transition to a net-zero future will not be smooth

Climate change progress lurks in the spaces between companies and governments, between individuals and communities, between rich and poor, as everybody tries to steer complex, shared industrial systems away from the brink.

site_title: Sun Venture in exclusive due diligence to buy Bugis Junction Towers; office deals gather steam
summary: Sun Venture Group is conducting exclusive due diligence on Bugis Junction Towers, a 15-storey office block in Singapore, with a potential purchase price of S$675-680 million. Meanwhile, Kajima Corporation is buying the 9-storey Nehsons Building in Peck Seah Street for S$111.1 million, with plans to redevelop it into a mixed-use asset. LaSalle Investment Management is acquiring Victory Centre, a 7-storey industrial facility, for S$90 million. The deals reflect the growing demand for office and industrial properties in Singapore, driven by the limited supply of good-quality prime CBD offices and the potential for capital gains.

images.alt_text: Mercatus owns about 720,000 sq ft of space at Jurong Point.
krwest - Westgate Tower near Jurong East MRT Station

site_title: Johnson urges Nato allies to boost military spending
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is urging Nato allies to boost military spending in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Johnson will tell the Nato summit in Madrid that the 2% defense spending target, set for 2024, is a "floor, not a ceiling" and that allies must continue to increase spending to ensure deterrence. Only eight of Nato's 30 members met or surpassed the target in 2021, with some nations, like Germany and Italy, increasing spending this year.

images.alt_text: Over the weekend, G7 leaders committed to providing indefinite support to Ukraine for its defence against Russia's invasion.

The latest moves “strike at the heart of Russia’s ability to develop and deploy weapons and technology used for Vladimir Putin’s brutal war of aggression against Ukraine,” the US Treasury Department said in a statement.

site_title: Tesla lays off hundreds of autopilot workers in latest cuts: sources
summary: Tesla has laid off hundreds of Autopilot team workers, with approximately 200 employees let go at its San Mateo office. The cuts are part of the company's effort to trim its workforce, following a surge in hiring in recent years. The affected employees worked on data labelling for Tesla's Autopilot driver-assistance features. This move comes as CEO Elon Musk announced layoffs earlier this month to address an increasingly shaky economic environment, with around 10% of salaried employees expected to lose their jobs over the next three months.

images.alt_text: China’s EV industry hit a trough during Shanghai’s lockdown - when not even one car was sold in the city in April and factories were forced to shut down or operate under heavy restrictions.
Tesla plans to double its original planned annual target to 1 million cars.

site_title: EU countries splinter in hunt for deal on new climate laws
summary: European Union environment ministers failed to agree on new climate laws, including a 2035 phase-out of new fossil fuel-powered cars and reforms to the EU carbon market, after a contentious meeting in Luxembourg. The EU aims to reduce net emissions by 55% by 2030, but countries disagree on the size of a fund to shield poorer households from CO2 costs and the timing of the new carbon market's launch. Germany backed the proposal for a 2035 ban on new combustion engine cars, but Italy and other countries want to delay the target to 2040.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble after weak consumer confidence data
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, falling 1.6% to close at 30,946.99 due to a weak consumer confidence report, its lowest level in over a year, amid surging inflation concerns. The report suggested consumers doubt the Federal Reserve's efforts to tame inflation, with a 2.0% drop in the S&P 500 and a 3.0% decline in the Nasdaq Composite Index. Positive news about China's relaxation of Covid-19 restrictions failed to offset the gloomy report, with Nike also experiencing a 7.0% drop after projecting tepid sales growth.

images.alt_text: Wall Street’s main indexes opened higher on Tuesday (28 June) after China relaxed some Covid-19 quarantine requirements for international travellers, raising hopes of a revival in global growth.

site_title: Time for Asian cross-border digital payment innovation
summary: China or Asia's more digitally-savvy countries could lead globally in developing regional digital currency co-operation for cross-border payments, following the US dollar's decline as a global reserve currency. Conditions are ripe for Asia to take the lead, with its base of Internet users far exceeding other regions. China has been actively pilot-testing its e-CNY, a central bank digital currency (CBDC), while Facebook's Diem project, a cryptocurrency for global use, could serve as an alternative. Asia could explore a Diem-like "Asian Dollar" or build on the development of a Pan-Asia m-CBDC shared platform to reduce dependence on the US dollar for cross-border payments.

images.alt_text: It is high time that central banks devote all their energies to fighting inflation. Dabbling in digital technologies should be put on the back burner.

site_title: Microsoft's US$22b combat goggles get crucial field test with US army forces
summary: Microsoft's US$22 billion Integrated Visual Augmentation System (IVAS) combat goggles underwent field testing with US Army forces over 3 weeks, ending June 18. The 70 infantry soldiers wore the devices during 3 scenarios, and results are set to be released in September. The testing aims to determine the feasibility of the goggles, which feature night vision and a "heads-up display" for commanders. The Army's projected spending on the devices over a decade could reach US$21.9 billion, but the results may impact the US$424.2 million proposed in the defense budget.

images.alt_text: Soldiers wear Integrated Visual Augmentation System Capability Set 3 hardware while mounted in a Stryker.

site_title: 11,504 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, more than double the infections a day ago
summary: Singapore reported 11,504 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, more than double the 5,309 cases on the previous day. This surge in cases follows the typical spike in infections after the weekend.

site_title: G-7 disappoints with fossil fuel 'loophole'
summary: The G-7 nations failed to fully commit to ending fossil fuel financing abroad, instead allowing public investment in new international fossil fuel projects under certain conditions. The decision was seen as a "loophole" by civil society groups, who criticized the move as undermining efforts to tackle global warming. Despite this, the G-7 reaffirmed its goal to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and speed up the green energy transition, and agreed to set up an international "climate club" to coordinate climate action.

images.alt_text: Representatives of Seven rich nations (G7) and Outreach guests are pictured at the start of their fifth working session about "Investing in a better future: Climate, Energy, Health" on June 27, 2022 at Elmau Castle, southern Germany, during the G7 Summit. - G7 leaders are under pressure to hold fast to climate pledges when they meet in Bavaria from June 26 to 28, as Russia's energy cuts trigger a dash back to planet-heating fossil fuels. (Photo by Susan Walsh / POOL / AFP)
German Chancellor and summit host Olaf Scholz, who spearheaded the proposal, said it would allow countries to accelerate climate action while avoiding competitive disadvantages.

site_title: This startup built a bot army to reveal risks facing Chinese companies
summary: A startup called MioTech, backed by JPMorgan Chase & Co and GIC, has built a bot army to gather non-financial risk data on Chinese companies. The data is scraped from government and corporate sites, providing insights on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. MioTech's parent company, Cayman-based Mioying Holdings, is raising US$150 million at a valuation of US$1 billion, with existing investors including Moody's and billionaire Li Ka-shing's Horizons Ventures. The company aims to provide a more comprehensive view of ESG risks in the region, despite a growing trend of investors shunning China-related ventures.

images.alt_text: (From left) BetterData co-founders Uzair Javaid and Kevin Yee; Margaret King, vice-president of fintech partnerships and corporate strategic investments at Franklin Templeton; and Chetan Karkhanis, senior vice-president for digital advisory and wealth management in Asia-Pacific at Franklin Templeton

site_title: Oil settles higher as major producers flag capacity limits
summary: Oil prices rose for a third day, with Brent crude futures climbing 2.5% to $117.58 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 2% to $111.76 a barrel. Major oil producers Saudi Arabia and the UAE are unlikely to boost output significantly, despite Western governments exploring ways to cap Russian oil prices. The G-7 agreed to impose a ban on transporting Russian oil above a certain price, aiming to deplete Moscow's war chest. Energy shortages and production constraints are expected to continue, with analysts citing potential supply disruptions in Ecuador and Libya.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$1.97, or 1.7 per cent higher, at US$115.09 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Oceans key to global warming fight: US climate envoy
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry emphasized the importance of safeguarding the world's oceans in combating global warming, stating it will be fundamental to tackling the issue. Kerry warned that efforts to curb carbon pollution face "powerful headwinds" due to the ongoing war in Ukraine and its economic fallout. The UN Ocean Conference in Lisbon has no negotiating agenda, but Kerry's comments aim to raise awareness about the critical role oceans play in mitigating global warming.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor and summit host Olaf Scholz, who spearheaded the proposal, said it would allow countries to accelerate climate action while avoiding competitive disadvantages.
Leaders of the Group of Seven rich nations on Tuesday watered down a key pledge on ending fossil fuel financing abroad, as the need to tackle global warming clashed with fears over energy shortages.

site_title: Novartis to cut up to 8,000 jobs globally
summary: Novartis, a Swiss pharmaceutical company, is set to cut up to 8,000 jobs globally, including up to 1,400 in Switzerland, as part of its restructuring program aimed at saving at least $1 billion by 2024. The company has already implemented a new organizational structure and is expected to provide further updates in the coming weeks. The job cuts are part of efforts to eliminate roles and reduce duplications across the organization.

site_title: US consumer confidence hits 16-month low on drag from inflation
summary: US consumer confidence dropped to a 16-month low in June, falling to 98.7 from 103.2 in May, as Americans became more downbeat about the economy, labor market, and incomes due to inflation concerns. Higher borrowing costs from the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes risk deterring purchases of big-ticket items. Despite this, buying plans for vehicles and appliances remained steady, while vacation plans softened. Nearly 30% of respondents expect business conditions to worsen in the second half of the year, reinforcing a growing risk of recession by year-end.

site_title: Ernst & Young to pay US$100m fine after auditors cheated on ethics exams
summary: Ernst & Young, a world's largest auditing firm, has agreed to pay a $100 million fine after US securities regulators found that some of its auditors had cheated on ethics exams. The penalty is the largest ever imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against an auditing firm. The firm admitted to its wrongdoing and vowed to enforce compliance with ethical rules, but had not done enough to stop the practice from 2017 to 2021, affecting hundreds of its auditors.

images.alt_text: Britain’s accounting watchdog said on Tuesday it has fined KPMG £3.3 million (S$5.7 million) over the company’s audit of aero engine maker Rolls-Royce more than a decade ago.

site_title: Uber agrees to Australia minimum pay body after similar moves in Britain, Canada
summary: Uber agrees to support a federal body in Australia that enforces minimum pay for its drivers, following similar moves in Britain, Canada, and US states. The Transport Workers Union (TWU) and Uber signed a joint statement to support the body, which would set minimum earnings and benefits for platform workers and protect drivers' rights to organize. The move reflects Uber's response to global pressure from unions to establish a floor under wages.

images.alt_text: UBER TECHNOLOGIES will scale back hiring and reduce expenditure on its marketing and incentive activities, CNBC reported on Monday (May 9), citing a letter from chief executive officer Dara Khosrowshahi.

site_title: US implements G-7 sanctions targeting Russian military, gold
summary: The US has implemented G-7 sanctions targeting Russian military and gold, aiming to "strike at the heart of Russia's ability to develop and deploy weapons and technology used for Vladimir Putin's war of aggression against Ukraine." The sanctions blacklist 70 entities and 29 individuals, freezing US-held assets and prohibiting financial transactions with US institutions. They also ban imports of gold from Russia, excluding gold already held outside the country, and target state company Rostec and other industries critical to the defense sector.

images.alt_text: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy attending a working session of G-7 leaders via video link from Kyiv as Russia's attack on Ukraine continues.

site_title: Arm launches new chip technology for smartphone games
summary: Arm, a British chip technology firm, has unveiled new chip technologies to improve video games on smartphones while preserving battery life. The new products, including graphics processing units and central processing units, aim to increase performance while reducing electricity consumption. This move comes as Arm customers, such as Apple and Qualcomm, are reducing their dependence on Arm by designing more critical parts of their chips themselves. The new solutions are expected to "raise the threshold of what's possible in the mobile market," according to Arm executive Paul Williamson.

site_title: Allied Tech to convene EGM over attempt to remove CEO, chairman from board
summary: Allied Tech will convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on July 13 in response to a requisition notice from two shareholders, Lin Tah Hwa and Kenneth Low, who hold over 10% of the company's shares. The notice proposes removing CEO and chairman Clement Leow and independent non-executive director Chin Chee Choon, and appointing three new directors. The EGM will determine the fate of the proposed changes, which could potentially lead to the removal of the current leadership.

site_title: Opec+ oil output is half a billion barrels behind on supply deal
summary: OPEC+ is significantly behind its pledged oil supply deal, with a shortfall of over half a billion barrels since May 2020. The group's production cuts, aimed at rebalancing the global oil market, have been inconsistent, with a compliance rate of 256% in May. This is despite the group producing 2.7 million barrels a day below its collective target. The struggling production has exacerbated concerns about the group's ability to balance the global market, raising questions about its long-term commitment to the agreement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)  in Vienna March 16, 2010.REUTERS/Heinz-Peter Bader/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on boost from easing China Covid curbs
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, June 28, 2022, after China relaxed Covid-19 quarantine requirements for international travelers, boosting hopes for global growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.35%, the S&P 500 gained 0.33%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.15% at the open.

site_title: Singapore can become the Suez Canal of money movement
summary: Singapore has immense potential to become a key financial hub for digital payments, leveraging its strategic geographical location and global connectivity. The country's competitive attributes and fintech innovations make it an attractive destination for companies looking to facilitate cross-border digital payments. By tapping into the growing demand for e-commerce and embedded finance, Singapore can establish itself as a thriving payments hub, rivaling the Suez Canal in its role as a conduit for money movement between the East and West.

images.alt_text: MAS has awarded 3 more in-principle approvals for its much-coveted digital payment token licence.

site_title: DBS enters agreement to sell property under Tee International
summary: DBS has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell 33 Changi North Crescent, a property under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department, for S$18 million. The sale is part of DBS' efforts to satisfy outstanding debts owed by embattled Tee International to the bank and other creditors. The sale is expected to be completed on or around July 18, with proceeds used to cover outstanding amounts and transaction expenses. This move is part of DBS' mortgagee sales process for Tee International.

site_title: Whirlpool to exit Russia with sale of operations to Arcelik
summary: Whirlpool has agreed to sell its Russian operations to Arcelik for up to 220 million euros over 10 years. The sale includes manufacturing and sales sites in Russia, Kazakhstan, and other countries. Whirlpool expects to record a loss of $300-400 million in the second quarter. The move follows a strategic review of its business in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, and is part of a trend of US companies exiting Russia. The sale is expected to be completed in the third quarter, with Whirlpool employing around 2,500 people in Russia.

site_title: TTJ offer: IFA, directors unexpectedly adopt pro-minority stance; regulators should too
summary: TTJ Holdings' minority shareholders may reject a cash offer of S$0.23 per share from THC Venture, a privately held company owned by the company's controlling shareholder, due to an independent financial adviser's (IFA) recommendation that the offer is "not fair, not reasonable". The IFA valued TTJ shares between S$0.37 and S$0.46 per share, significantly higher than the offer price. This stance has sparked opposition among investors, who may be inclined to reject the offer if the company's share price remains above S$0.23. The company's controlling shareholder may raise the offer price if the share price falls below this level, potentially exploiting a loophole in the Companies Act to compulsorily acquire the company.

site_title: Singapore’s ‘comply or explain’ approach has not worked as well as hoped
summary: Singapore's "comply or explain" approach to corporate governance has been deemed ineffective, with institutional investors failing to exercise their stewardship role. The country's regulatory framework also lacks guidance on company groups and environmental and social risks. The author suggests revising the Code of Corporate Governance to include these areas, as well as addressing issues with variable interest entity structures and the Catalist regime, which he believes may not prioritize public shareholders' interests. The author also recommends a taxonomy approach to regulating different types of companies, acknowledging that one-size-fits-all solutions may not be effective.

images.alt_text: Britain's company directors should sign up to a code of conduct to improve behaviour in boardrooms after high-profile corporate collapses, such as builder Carillion and retailer BHS, an industry body proposed.
S-REITS offer one of the highest dividend yields and lower volatility compared to REITs in other jurisdictions and indexes, according to a REITAS report.

site_title: G-7 to launch ‘climate club’ to tackle global warming
summary: G-7 leaders agreed to create a "climate club" by the end of the year to coordinate efforts to tackle global warming. The club, open to countries committed to the Paris agreement goal of limiting global temperature increases to 1.5 degrees Celsius, aims to accelerate climate action while avoiding competitive disadvantages. The club will focus on industry sector cooperation, addressing carbon leakage risks, and may adopt common carbon pricing standards. Environmentalists have criticized the club as vague on details, while German Chancellor Olaf Scholz emphasized the need for ambitious goals and cooperation among willing nations.

images.alt_text: Internally displaced people wait for food aid to be distributed by a charity in Taiz, Yemen, April 8, 2022. The Group of Seven rich democracies will commit up to US$5 billion to improve global food security.

site_title: Indonesia will use Covid tracking app to sell cheap cooking oil
summary: Indonesia is utilizing its Covid-19 tracking app, PeduliLindungi, to distribute cheap cooking oil, aiming to ensure subsidies reach their target. The app allows users to scan QR codes and verify their health and vaccination status, also enabling them to purchase up to 10 kilograms of subsidized cooking oil daily. This move follows President Joko Widodo's previous attempts to regulate the local cooking oil market and reduce export prices.

images.alt_text: Packages of cooking oil are displayed as a vendor waits for customers at a traditional market in Jakarta on May 23, 2022. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)

site_title: Maybank accepts ecoWise’s request to withhold legal action; Al-Rajhi Bank revises credit facility
summary: Maybank has accepted ecoWise's request to withhold legal action against the company and its Malaysian subsidiaries, with conditions including monthly payments and a concrete repayment proposal. Al-Rajhi Bank has also revised its credit facility for ecoWise, requiring the settlement of overdue bills and a sinking fund build-up. Both banks' letters will be automatically terminated if any parties are hit with winding-up proceedings. The revised agreements follow a series of letters of demand issued by the banks in March and June.

images.alt_text: ecoWise has reported S$6.93 million in total comprehensive loss for FY2021 based on its audited financial statements, almost twice the unaudited figure of S$3.63 million.

site_title: Iran applies to join China and Russia in Brics club
summary: Iran has applied to join the BRICS group, consisting of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, amid tensions with the West. The move is seen as a strategic alliance with Russia and China, with Iranian membership expected to bring "added values for both sides." Argentina has also expressed interest in joining the group, following in the footsteps of its President Alberto Fernandez, who has reiterated his desire to join BRICS. The BRICS grouping accounts for over 40% of the world's population and 26% of the global economy, with China having the largest economy in the group.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Iranian flag flies in front of the UN office building, housing IAEA headquarters, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, in Vienna, Austria, May 24, 2021. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner/File Photo

site_title: World Bank calls for sovereign debt changes ahead of looming crises
summary: The World Bank has called for changes in sovereign debt laws to give governments more control when crises strike and restructure their debt. Economists estimate that low- and middle-income economies owe a record $9.3 trillion to foreign creditors, with 40 poor countries and 6 middle-income ones at risk of debt distress. The World Bank proposes four key changes to the Common Framework debt relief plan, including stipulating creditor cooperation in good faith, limiting creditor lawsuits, and including "Collective Action Clauses" to facilitate restructuring.

site_title: Ambani’s son to lead Reliance Telecom unit in succession signal
summary: Mukesh Ambani, chairman of Reliance Industries, has appointed his son Akash Ambani, 30, as chairman of the telecom unit Reliance Jio Infocomm, marking a leadership transition within the conglomerate. Mukesh Ambani resigned from the board, staying as chair of the holding firm, while Akash was part of teams negotiating Meta's investment into Jio and leading key acquisitions. The move signals a step towards succession, with experts praising the effort to strengthen the team around Akash Ambani.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Mukesh Ambani, Chairman and Managing Director of Reliance Industries, arrives to address the company's annual general meeting in Mumbai, India July 5, 2018. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: G-7 commits US$5b to tackling global food insecurity: US official
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) rich democracies have committed up to $5 billion to improve global food security, with the US providing over half of that sum. The funds will be used to fight hunger in 47 countries and fund regional organizations. The decision comes amid concerns about the impact of the war in Ukraine on food security, particularly in developing nations. G-7 leaders also agreed to take a more coordinated approach to challenging China's market-distorting trade practices and to remove forced labor from global supply chains.

images.alt_text: Countries meeting at the World Trade Organization’s ministerial conference in Geneva this week are trying to reach a consensus position on food security.

site_title: Raffles Infrastructure terminates executive director Ma Zhi after investigation
summary: Raffles Infrastructure terminated executive director Ma Zhi after internal investigations, citing failure to meet duties and obligations. Ma had been appointed in April 2020 and served as a non-executive director for another company. The decision was based on documentary evidence. Shares closed flat at S$0.06 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: US goods trade deficit narrows in May
summary: The US goods trade deficit narrowed 2.2% to $104.3 billion in May, the first time it may contribute to economic growth this quarter in nearly two years. Goods exports rose $2.0 billion to $176.6 billion, while imports fell $0.4 billion to $280.9 billion. This marks a reversal from the record trade deficit in the first quarter, which weighed on the economy and resulted in a 1.5% annualized GDP decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hong Kong, Shanghai stocks rally on China quarantine move
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rallied on June 27 after Chinese officials reduced quarantine periods for incoming travelers, boosting hopes for the world's second-largest economy. The Hang Seng Index jumped 0.85% to 22,418.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.89% to 3,409.21. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.21%. The move lifted market sentiment and fueled gains in Hong Kong and Shanghai, with investors optimistic about the economic recovery.

site_title: Hyundai and Kia raided by prosecutors in German diesel probe
summary: German prosecutors raided Hyundai and Kia's offices as part of a diesel probe, alleging the companies used defeat devices to mask emissions. Eight premises were searched in Germany and Luxembourg, targeting 140 people and companies, including BorgWarner and Robert Bosch. The investigation centers on 210,000 cars sold between 2015 and 2020, which allegedly failed to comply with EU emissions rules. Hyundai confirmed the raid and cooperation with authorities, while Kia and the other companies have declined to comment. The probe is the latest in a long-standing diesel scandal affecting the car industry since 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 16.62 points to 1,454.74. A total of 2.289 billion lots worth RM1.617 billion were traded, with 470 gainers outnumbering 411 losers.

site_title: China's Sinopec produces first biojet fuel at east China refinery
summary: Sinopec, China's state refining giant, has produced its first biojet fuel at an industrial-scale facility in east China. The biojet fuel is made from used cooking oil and can cut carbon dioxide emissions by more than half over its life cycle. This marks a significant step forward for Sinopec's commercial biofuel production, which began in 2009. The International Energy Agency predicts global biojet demand could reach 2-6 billion litres by 2026, driven by growing concerns over climate change.

site_title: Michelin to transfer Russian operations to local management
summary: Michelin to transfer its Russian operations to a new entity under local management by the end of the year, following the suspension of manufacturing activities in Russia due to supply difficulties and the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. The company has a 250 million euro balance sheet exposure from Russian operations, but it expects the transfer not to impact its financial guidance. The new entity will operate independently.

site_title: Populous Chinese province kicks off disaster insurance trials
summary: Henan province in China is launching pilot programs for catastrophe insurance in six cities hardest hit by historic floods in 2021, including its capital Zhengzhou. The program aims to determine a unified insurance plan based on the cities' history, probability of disasters, and local conditions. The trials are a response to the devastating floods, which caused billions of US dollars in economic losses and hundreds of fatalities. The program will expand coverage areas and scope of protection based on the situation, with the goal of eventually covering the entire province.

site_title: Doctors’ threat adds to turmoil awaiting Johnson on UK return
summary: The UK is facing a summer of discontent as various public sector workers threaten strike action over pay, following the largest rail strike in three decades. Doctors are set to join the strikes, with the British Medical Association voting for a 30% pay rise to make up for years of underpayment. The government is resisting calls for pay increases to match inflation, citing concerns of fueling further price increases. The Prime Minister's return from overseas summits coincides with the growing discontent, which poses a significant peril to his leadership, following a recent confidence vote that nearly ended his premiership.

images.alt_text: Jo Sidhu, a barrister, speaks during a protest by criminal lawyers outside the Old Bailey law courts in central London on Monday (Jun 27). The Criminal Bar Association, which represents thousands of barristers in England and Wales, said around 80 per cent of its members backed the walkout that’ll target 14 days of strike action over the next month.

Commuters waiting at a bus stop outside London Victoria railway and underground station during a rail workers strike in London on Jun 21. Since then, criminal trial lawyers have also staged a stop-work event; teachers and National Health Service staff are mulling the same amid widening unhappiness among unions with work and pay conditions amid rising living costs.

site_title: China's Xi to visit Hong Kong for Jul 1 anniversary, police say
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will attend events in Hong Kong on July 1 to mark the 25th anniversary of Chinese rule, marking his first visit to the city since 2017. The trip comes despite rising COVID-19 cases in Hong Kong and a heightened security presence, with police warning of the possibility of local terrorism. Xi's visit is seen as a demonstration of Beijing's control over the former British colony, following the imposition of a national security law in 2020 that has crushed dissent.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes above key 27,000 level as energy shares rally
summary: The Nikkei index closed above 27,000 for the first time in two weeks, rising 0.66% to 27,049.47, driven by energy shares that surged after crude prices rebounded. The broader Topix jumped 1.06% to 1,907.38, while US e-mini stock futures turned positive. Despite gains, market participants remain cautious due to uncertainty over interest rate hikes and recession fears.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was down 0.23 per cent, or 61.25 points, at 26,810.02 in early trade on Tuesday,

site_title: Eswatini rolls out welcome mat for Singapore firms to invest in the African nation
summary: Eswatini, formerly known as Swaziland, has rolled out a welcoming environment for Singaporean firms to invest in the African nation. The country's strong backing and generous incentives have attracted investments, with Singapore-based Tolaram setting up a $34 million noodle factory in partnership with Kellogg's. This is part of Eswatini's objectives to encourage investment and expand existing businesses, with plans to develop a $1.2 billion integrated power project and participate in the African Continent Free Trade Area. The country aims to become a launchpad for businesses supplying goods and services to the region.

images.alt_text: SBF CEO Lam Yi Young says: “SBF is glad to have received good responses from our members and the wider business community for our events and activities.”
Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chairman Lim Ming Yan has been re-elected for a second term.

site_title: Microsoft faces investor call to publish global tax affairs
summary: Microsoft faces calls from investors to publish global tax affairs, with over $350 billion in assets demanding country-by-country financial and tax information. The shareholder resolution, filed by Britain-based proxy advisers PIRC, aims to assess fair taxes and identify tax reform risks. Similar resolutions have been filed for tech giant Cisco, following previous attempts at Amazon's investor meeting that failed to pass. Microsoft and Cisco have not commented on the resolutions.

site_title: Singapore stocks eke out slight gains amid recession, inflation worries; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.09% to 3,140.21, reversing losses from the previous day's rally, as recession and inflation concerns persisted. Despite gains, caution remained due to lingering worries and upcoming US data releases. The Dow Jones fell 0.2% and the Nasdaq lost 0.7%, while most Asia-Pacific markets posted gains, except for Taiwan. Key drivers included rising oil prices and speculation on interest rates.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks sagged on Monday, fading after last week’s positive run.

The listing of Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation marked the largest local IPO in the first half of 2022 after raising S$208 million, followed by Pegasus Asia and Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition raising S$170 million and S$150 million respectively.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's IPO market has seen its busiest half year in five years, thanks to the recent listing of Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) raising a total of S$528 million. The largest local IPO in the first half of 2022 was Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation, which raised S$208 million. Meanwhile, businesses in Singapore have seen a 50% increase in B2B bad debt write-offs, and the 10-year average return for the July issue of Singapore Savings' Bond rose to 2.71%, its highest since 2015.

site_title: The US Supreme Court: An agent of political polarisation?
summary: The US Supreme Court has emerged as a powerful force advancing the agenda of the American political right, sparking controversy over its recent rulings on gun control and abortion. The court's 6-3 decision to strike down state laws limiting public gun rights and overturn the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling, which protected abortion rights, has polarized the nation. Critics argue that the court's conservative majority is politicized, with all the justices who ruled to overturn Roe nominated by Republican presidents and all the states that want to ban abortion controlled by Republicans. The decision has raised concerns about the court's impact on other contentious issues, such as same-sex marriages and access to contraception.

US Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts has ordered a probe into the leak of the draft opinion.

site_title: Thailand agrees 338 billion baht investment in industrial east over 5 years
summary: Thailand has approved a 5-year investment of approximately 338 billion baht (S$13.2 billion) in its industrial east, the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC), from 2023. The investments will cover 77 projects, mainly in infrastructure and utilities, and create around 20,000 jobs. The government will invest in 61 projects worth 178.6 billion baht (US$5.09 billion), with the remainder in public-private partnership projects. The EEC aims to boost growth and encourage investment in high-tech industries, particularly in the eastern provinces of Thailand.

site_title: China's economy recovering but foundation not solid, premier says
summary: China's economy has recovered to some extent but its foundation is not solid, according to Premier Li Keqiang. He stated that the country will strive to drive the economy back onto a normal track and bring down the jobless rate as soon as possible. The economy has recovered overall, but the implementation of the policy package to stabilize it is still accelerating.

site_title: FTSE 100 hits over two-week high as China eases Covid curbs
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index reached its highest level in over two weeks on Tuesday, boosted by China's easing of Covid-19 curbs, which lifted global equities and commodity prices. China reduced quarantine time for inbound travelers by half, sending industrial metals and mining stocks up 2.7% and oil majors 2.2% higher. The FTSE 100 climbed 0.9% to its highest since June 10, with commodity stocks leading the gains. Analysts attribute the surge to increased demand from China and investors buying into the market.

Residents queue at a Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai, China, on Monday, June 20, 2022.  China on Tuesday slashed the quarantine time for inbound travellers by half in a major easing of one of the world’s strictest Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Woman charged with running fund management business while unlicensed
summary: Lee Ying Hui, a woman, has been charged with running a fund management business without a license from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. She is accused of managing clients' portfolios and entering spot foreign exchange contracts between December 2017 and June 2020. If convicted, she faces a fine of up to S$150,000 or imprisonment of up to 3 years.

site_title: The lights are going out for crypto’s laser-eyed grifters
summary: Cryptocurrency influencers, known for promoting virtual cash on social media, are losing their influence as the market routs continues. Their business model relies on taking real dollars to promote virtual cash, but with trading diminishing and startup funding drying up, their earnings are dwindling. Celebrities and social media personalities are being scrutinized for promoting ads, and regulatory intervention and voluntary crackdowns by social media platforms are likely. The crash has highlighted the need for consumer protection and financial literacy, particularly among young people, to prevent further exploitation.

images.alt_text: Between end-2019 to the peak in Nov 2021, a bitcoin investor would have chalked a gain of over 800 per cent against the US dollar.
A smartphone screen displaying the logo of FTX, the crypto exchange platform, with a screen showing the FTX website in the background in Arlington, Virginia on February 10, 2022. -

site_title: Philips says tests on recalled ventilators 'very encouraging'
summary: Philips has conducted independent tests on recalled ventilators and found that foam degradation was rare, linked to aggressive, unauthorised ozone-based cleaning products. The tests were "very encouraging" and showed that the problems were almost exclusively caused by these products, rather than the ventilators themselves. This suggests that the recall was largely unnecessary, with the company's chief executive Frans van Houten stating that the issues were "very rare".

site_title: ECB vows to counter 'undesirably high' inflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has vowed to combat "undesirably high" inflation, which rose to an all-time high of 8.1% in the eurozone in May. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that the bank will go "as far as necessary" to stabilize inflation at its 2% target. The surge in inflation is driven by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, energy, and food costs. Despite this, the ECB expects the eurozone to avoid a recession and maintain positive growth rates. The bank has agreed to its first interest rate hike in over a decade and is designing a new tool to tackle high borrowing costs for indebted eurozone members.

images.alt_text: In the past, the ECB had mostly sold bonds after finding out they didn't meet the QE programme's purchase criteria.

site_title: Euro below US$1.06 as Lagarde keeps July policy options open
summary: The euro held below US$1.06 after European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde stated the central bank would move gradually but decisively on medium-term inflation, with interest rate hikes in July expected to combat soaring inflation. Oil prices surged 10% in a week, supporting the Canadian and Australian dollars, while the euro faced resistance at the $1.06 level. Economists predict a rate hike in July, but the magnitude of the hike remains uncertain, with cumulative rate hikes expected to be around 238 basis points by mid-2023.

images.alt_text: A woman holds Euro banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Renault teams up with Atos on data gathering
summary: Renault has partnered with Atos to collect and analyze data from industrial equipment at scale, aiming to improve operational excellence and product quality. The data partnership will support manufacturers in reducing costs through digital transformation. Renault Group's EVP Jose-Vicente de los Mozos stated that the collaboration marks a new step in Renault's digital transformation and innovation capacity. The partnership will enable manufacturers to structure data from industrial equipment, ultimately leading to improved operational efficiency and product quality.

site_title: Malaysia urges palm oil mills to resume production despite price drop
summary: Malaysia's palm oil mills are urged to resume production despite a 22% drop in prices, which have made operations unprofitable. The government received complaints about mills refusing to buy oil palm fruits from farmers, which could rot if left untreated. The Malaysian Palm Oil Board will discuss the matter with mills, and the industry association estimates that mills would lose RM150,000 for every 100 tonnes of crude palm oil produced at current prices. The move aims to support smallholder farmers and prevent losses.

images.alt_text: The shortage has worsened to around 120,000 workers, compared with 36,000 before the pandemic.

Indonesian farmers want authorities to scrap a requirement for exporters to sell a portion of their palm oil domestically, a move that should boost shipments and mean mills pay more for fresh fruit bunches.

site_title: Tencent to explore hardware opportunities with extended reality unit
summary: Tencent Holdings has established an extended reality unit to explore opportunities in virtual reality and augmented reality technologies, aiming to create industry benchmarks within the next 4-5 years. The company's gaming chief Steven Ma emphasized the importance of combining hardware and software in creating immersive experiences. This move reflects Tencent's growing interest in XR, driven by technological breakthroughs in VR devices, and marks a rare foray into hardware for the tech giant.

site_title: ‘Forward Singapore’ roadmap to engage Singaporeans through 6 pillars: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced the "Forward Singapore" initiative, a nationwide exercise to refresh the country's social compact, which aims to engage Singaporeans through 6 pillars led by fourth-generation leaders. The 1-year exercise will conclude with a report in mid-2023 outlining policy recommendations and how different segments of society can contribute to shared goals. Wong emphasized the need to refresh the social compact due to external trends and domestic worries, including a rapidly ageing population and rising geopolitical tensions. The exercise will focus on strengthening the progressive system of taxes and transfers, making meritocracy more open and compassionate, and giving more help to workers in difficult times.

images.alt_text: Singapore's 4G leaders will develop the country's roadmap for the next decade in a "Forward Singapore" agenda to refresh its social compact, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, who was 2 weeks ago identified as Singapore's prime minister-in-waiting.

site_title: SPAC listings nudge Singapore IPO market to busiest H1 in 5 years
summary: Singapore's IPO market experienced its busiest first half in five years, with the listing of three Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) generating S$528 million in initial public offering (IPO) proceeds. The largest local IPO in the first half of 2022 was Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation, raising S$208 million. The market's surge is attributed to strong interest in these SPAC listings, following close by Pegasus Asia and Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition, which raised S$170 million and S$150 million respectively.

images.alt_text: Asian sponsors of blank-check firms are facing a tough market for initial public offerings wherever they turn, as a combination of increasing regulatory scrutiny and fading investor demand shutters the window for new listings from the US to Asia.

FILE PHOTO: The filing for bankruptcy by Electric Last Mile Solutions Inc makes the company the first of the electric vehicle startups that merged with special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) to go out of business amid the recent market slump.

site_title: Why investors should not ignore bonds in a rising-rate environment
summary: The US Federal Reserve has raised interest rates by 75 basis points, signaling a shift to an inflation-fighting posture. This move has led to a rout in the bond market, with a 15% drawdown in the Bloomberg Global-Aggregate Total Return Index. Despite rising interest rates, long-term interest rates are expected to rise at a slower pace. Fixed income assets can provide regular cash flow, lower volatility, and diversification benefits, making them an attractive option for investors. Investors can deploy strategies such as purchasing short-duration bonds, taking credit exposure, and laddering up their bond portfolio to lessen the impact of rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Monthly figures show that Indonesia's stash is at the smallest since November 2020.

site_title: First ever 'Africa Fashion' exhibition opens in London
summary: The Victoria and Albert (V&A) Museum in London is hosting the first-ever "Africa Fashion" exhibition, showcasing the continent's diverse fashion heritage and cultures. The exhibition, which opened on July 2, features designs by past and present African designers, including Moroccan fashion designer Artsi Ifrach. The show highlights the intersection of fashion, politics, and culture, with displays on sustainability, gender, and identity. The exhibition aims to address the historical imbalance in representation of African creativity in the museum, and is part of the V&A's ongoing commitment to foregrounding work by African heritage creatives.

site_title: China’s yuan eases after PBOC chief vows to keep policy accommodative
summary: China's yuan eased against the dollar after its central bank head, Governor Yi Gang, said monetary policy would remain accommodative to support economic recovery. The comments contrasted with other global central banks' hawkish stances, raising concerns of increasing monetary policy divergence. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.693 per dollar, 80 pips weaker than the previous fix, and the onshore yuan opened at 6.6980 per dollar, 32 pips weaker than the previous close.

site_title: GIC largest international cornerstone investor in Thai Life IPO
summary: Thai Life Insurance's initial public offering (IPO) has attracted 18 cornerstone investors, including GIC, which is the largest international investor, subscribing for $164 million. The IPO aims to raise up to $1.04 billion, with domestic investors accounting for 50% of the deal. Retail investors will have access to $318 million worth of stock. The IPO proceeds will be used for working capital, digital transformation, and strengthening distribution channels.

images.alt_text: Thai Life is offering 2.1 billion shares, about 18.8 per cent of total shares and a greenshoe option of 161.3 million shares.
Founded in 2004, Greenko develops solar, wind and hydro power projects with 7.5 gigawatts of operating capacity across 15 states in India.

site_title: Bankrupt Sri Lanka opens oil market to foreign firms
summary: Sri Lanka has opened its oil market to foreign firms, allowing them to import and sell fuel using their funds, amid an unprecedented economic crisis. The move comes after chronic fuel shortages forced a nationwide halt to petrol and diesel sales, with motorists waiting in daylong queues for scarce supplies. The country is struggling to pay for essential imports, including food, medicine, and fuel, and has dispatched ministers to Russia and Qatar to source discounted oil. Sri Lanka defaulted on its $51 billion foreign debt in April and is in bailout talks with the International Monetary Fund.

images.alt_text:
Motorists queueing along a street to buy fuel at a Ceylon petroleum corporation fuel station in
Pugoda, some 50 km from Colombo.  The country  remains virtually without both diesel and petrol, and the government is unable to say when fresh stocks will arrive.

site_title: Credit Suisse to lean on wealth unit, technology in revamp
summary: Credit Suisse has outlined plans to boost its wealth management unit by doubling client assets under management for private market investments and expanding sustainability and next-generation programs. The bank aims to cut costs through technology simplification, aiming to save 800 million Swiss francs, and expects mid- to high-single-digit growth in lending to rich clients by 2024. The move comes as the bank seeks to regain investor confidence after scandals and a 2-year period of losses.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse criticised the case for having been brought so many years after the events in question. The money laundering took place between 2004 and 2008.
Credit Suisse already added 600 million Swiss francs (S$860 million) in legal provisions, some of which was related to the Bermuda case, in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at 1-1/2-week high on China stimulus optimism
summary: South Korean shares ended at a 1-1/2 week high on Tuesday, driven by optimism over China's stimulus package, which eased recession worries. The Kospi index rose 0.84% to 2,422.09, with technology giants Samsung and SK Hynix gaining. The Korean won also hit its highest in two weeks, while bond yields fell. Despite a record trade deficit expected in June, the market tracked China's strong policy stance to boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended up 35.32 points or 1.49 per cent at 2,401.92, after rising 2.26 per cent on Friday.

site_title: Wise says revenue to grow more than 30% as results top estimates
summary: WISE, a money-transfer firm, reported revenue of £559.9 million (S$951.7 million) in its first full-year results as a listed company, exceeding analyst estimates. Revenue growth is expected to be 30-35% in the next 12 months and above 20% in the medium term. The company's volumes grew 40% to £76 billion and active customers increased by 29% to 4.6 million. WISE will continue to invest in infrastructure and expand globally, according to CEO Kristo Kaarmann.

site_title: Australia: Miners lift shares to 2-week high on China demand hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to a 2-week high, driven by hopes that easing China's Covid-19 restrictions will boost iron ore demand. Miners, including BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals, jumped 3.3% and 3-4.3% respectively. Energy stocks also climbed, with Woodside Energy and Santos up 4.3% and 2.7%. However, financials declined 0.3% in their worst session in over a week.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose as much as 0.4 per cent by 0043 GMT on Tuesday, its highest level since June 14.

site_title: Credit Suisse renews focus on wealth management, aims to expand ‘core’ high-net-worth clientele
summary: Credit Suisse is refocusing on its wealth management business, aiming to expand its "core" high-net-worth clientele with managed investment solutions. The move comes after the bank was chastened by scandal and poor results in 2021. CEO Francesco de Ferrari is reorganizing the wealth management team and prioritizing a client-driven approach. The goal is to attract and retain high-net-worth clients with investible assets between $1 million and $10 million, rather than just ultra-wealthy clients.

images.alt_text: The wealth unit plans to double client assets under management for private market investments and expand programmes that focus on sustainability and the next generation set to inherit wealth.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Tuesday, driven by a recovery in global equities following recent sharp losses due to recession fears. London's FTSE 100 jumped 1.0% to 7,329.48 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index gained 0.8% and the Paris CAC 40 advanced 1.1%. The gains followed Tokyo's close higher, as investors brushed off new US-EU trade tensions and focused on mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Franklin Templeton looks to startups to disrupt old ways of asset management
summary: Franklin Templeton has launched its second fintech incubator, focused on Asia, in partnership with F10 Global Innovation Network Singapore. The incubator aims to disrupt traditional asset management by leveraging emerging technologies such as blockchain, data science, and predictive behavior analytics. The program will support 30 startups, providing at least $150,000 in seed funding, and offers a 2-year residency with access to a mentor network and venture capitalists. The launch follows Franklin Templeton's successful Silicon Valley incubator, which has supported startups like Brelyon and California-based hardware and software company.

images.alt_text: Rising digitalisation of financial services means that the physical payment card is one of the last physical touchpoints between card issuers and customers.

site_title: Nato to label China 'systemic challenge' in strategic plan
summary: NATO is set to label China a "systemic challenge" in its new strategic plan, highlighting concerns over cybersecurity, disinformation, and control of critical infrastructure. The move comes as Beijing's partnership with Russia deepens, prompting NATO to call Russia a "direct threat" to alliance security. The alliance will remain open to engagement with China, but will prioritize addressing Russia's aggressive behavior and compliance with international law. The decision reflects a shift in NATO's stance on China, following the US's tougher stance on Beijing, and is seen as a realistic response to China's growing influence.

images.alt_text: Finland and Sweden have applied for NATO membership, reversing decades of military neutrality.
Germany, which leads the G7 this year, has also invited Argentina, India, Indonesia, Senegal and South Africa to participate in select sessions at the summit.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices slip in May amid higher borrowing costs
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices decreased 0.3% in May from the previous month, according to official data, as potential buyers turned cautious ahead of expected rate increases in the second half of the year. This follows a revised 1% rise in April. Despite this, the number of home transaction agreements in May jumped 59% from April to a 10-month high. The city's interbank market rate has risen, influencing mortgage rates, with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority raising its base rate by 75 basis points to 2%.

images.alt_text: Residential and commercial tower blocks on the eastern side of Hong Kong island. The record-breaking Hong Kong mansion that was just sold is on the southern side of the island, in an exclusive area.
No. 15 Shouson in Shouson Hill, spanning 746 sqm of floor area, boasts a private garden, swimming pool and parking space.

site_title: Crypto data firm Kaiko raises US$53m during market rout
summary: Crypto data firm Kaiko raised US$53 million in its latest financing round, tripling its valuation from its last round in June 2021. The series B deal was led by Eight Roads, Revaia, and existing investors, despite a crypto market rout. Kaiko's CEO Ambre Soubiran described the past 2 months as "a marathon" for investors, highlighting growing caution about deploying capital to crypto-linked businesses.

images.alt_text: A smartphone screen displaying the logo of FTX, the crypto exchange platform, with a screen showing the FTX website in the background in Arlington, Virginia on February 10, 2022. -

site_title: China slashes quarantine for inbound travellers to 7 days
summary: China has reduced the quarantine time for inbound travelers to 7 days from 14 days and reduced at-home health monitoring to 3 days from 7 days, easing one of the world's strictest COVID-19 curbs. This move comes after the Chinese capital Beijing and Shanghai reported no new local COVID-19 infections for the first time since late February. The country remains cautious, with authorities maintaining the "dynamic zero-Covid policy" to block outbreaks and ensuring residents continue to undergo regular COVID-19 testing.

images.alt_text: The 2 major cities were among several places in China that implemented curbs to stop the spread of the Omicron wave during March to May, with Shanghai imposing a 2 month-long city-wide lockdown that lifted on Jun 1.

site_title: More than 2 million tourists have rushed to Thailand this year
summary: Thailand has seen a surge in foreign tourist arrivals, reaching over 2 million since January, driven by relaxed entry rules, particularly for Indians and Malaysians. The country aims to attract 7.5 million foreign visitors this year, with average monthly arrivals expected to surge to 1.5 million. The tourism industry, severely impacted by the pandemic, seeks to boost its economy, which accounts for 12% of gross domestic product. A weaker currency and cannabis legalization may also attract more tourists, although the absence of Chinese visitors due to Covid-Zero policy remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Thai baht notes at a bank in Bangkok. The slump that’s taken the Thai baht to its weakest levels in more than 5 years may be near an end as Thailand entices back tourists and the central bank edges toward hiking rates.
The move comes ahead of the end of the “Thailand Pass” system, which required visitors to register and show proof of vaccination before entering the kingdom.

site_title: Australia locks down its bees after detecting hive-killing mite
summary: Australia has locked down its bees after detecting the Varroa destructor mite, a hive-killing parasite that has ravaged hives worldwide. The detection was made at the Port of Newcastle in New South Wales, prompting a 10km emergency zone lockdown and a ban on moving bees across the state. The move aims to prevent the parasite from spreading and protect the country's $83 billion agricultural industry, which relies heavily on honey bees for crop pollination. The Varroa mite has been linked to colony collapse in the US and threatens Australia's status as a major honey producer.

site_title: India's monetary dove urges slow hikes as rates near neutral
summary: Indian monetary policy dove Ashima Goyal urges a slower pace of interest rate hikes as inflation-adjusted real interest rates approach neutral, where it can help control inflation without stifling economic growth. The Reserve Bank of India's benchmark rate has risen to 4.9%, and economists expect at least two more rate hikes before a pause, given consumer price growth above the RBI's 6% upper tolerance limit. Goyal warns that continued aggressive hikes could lead to an increase in unemployment, and advocates for a more flexible approach to anchor inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: Retail inflation eased marginally in May, after touching an 8-year high of 7.79 per cent in April, but remained above the central bank's tolerance band of 2-6 per cent for a fifth month in a row.

site_title: Scenario planning for a net-zero future
summary: The transition to a net-zero future will not be smooth, and investment managers must consider various outcomes due to uncertainty. There are multiple, equally valid pathways through the transition, each with different technology mixes and varied time horizons. To approach scenario planning, investors should apply filters to screen out conflicted forecasters, review applicable scenarios, and consider environmental, social, and governance factors. No-regret assets, such as renewables, storage, and heat pumps, are likely to perform across all viable pathways. The most prudent approach is to focus on these assets and be smart, careful, and deliberate about the future.

images.alt_text: Climate change progress lurks in the spaces between companies and governments, between individuals and communities, between rich and poor, as everybody tries to steer complex, shared industrial systems away from the brink.

site_title: Google's cloud customers will learn their Gmail carbon footprint
summary: Google plans to reveal the carbon footprint of its Workspace apps, including Gmail and Docs, in early 2023. This move aims to help customers assess their environmental impact. Alphabet-owned Google Cloud has set a goal to be completely decarbonized by 2030 and currently uses renewable energy sources for its operations. The company will also provide scope 1 and 3 emissions associated with a customer's use of Google Cloud, offering a more comprehensive view of its environmental impact.

site_title: Boost for luxury London property prices as Russians locked in
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has led to a 30% decrease in prime central London residential sales between March and May compared to last year, but prices remain up 4.7% due to a shortage of available properties. The war has caused wealthy Russians, including oligarchs and billionaire entrepreneurs, to become cautious about buying or selling properties in Britain due to sanctions. This has resulted in fewer transactions, with some buyers opting for friendlier property hotspots like Dubai or Istanbul.

images.alt_text: Canada posted its first national home-price decline in two years in April, followed by another drop in May.
The surge in rental prices also stands alongside a property market boom in the UK since the pandemic, which has driven the cost of buying to a record high.

site_title: Singapore Savings’ Bond 10-year average return rises to 2.71%, the highest since 2015
summary: The 10-year average return for Singapore Savings' Bond (SSB) has reached 2.71%, its highest since 2015. The first-year interest rate stands at 1.69% and the 10-year interest rate was offered at 3%. This increase reflects the tightening economic environment and expectations of further rate hikes from the Fed. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has capped the maximum amount offered in the upcoming issue at S$600 million, with applications totaling S$1.3 billion, a record high.

images.alt_text: Singapore Savings Bonds' 10-year average return hits new high of 1.79% for March issue

site_title: How insurance and investing can better prepare you  for retirement
summary: A recent survey by Prudential found that 20% of Singaporeans foresee a delay in their retirement age to 64 years old, with many feeling unprepared. Insurance and investing are crucial for a secure financial future, with two-thirds of those confident in their retirement invested in shares, bonds, and exchange-traded funds. Investing and insurance form the bedrock of a secure financial future, coupled with active income while working. Building a retirement nest egg involves growing retirement funds and increasing passive income through dividend-paying stocks and real estate investment trusts (REITs).

images.alt_text: The insurer said that out of 1,000 respondents aged 25 to 50, around 44 per cent are unprepared for retirement. Those aged 25 to 34 per cent made up 47 per cent of this group.

site_title: Singapore businesses see 50% increase in B2B bad debt write-offs: Atradius
summary: Singapore businesses have seen a 50% increase in bad debts that could not be collected, rising to 9% of all business-to-business invoices in 2022, up from 6% in 2021. The increase is attributed to liquidity problems, customer disputes, and administrative inefficiencies. In Asia, B2B debt write-offs have risen 60% compared to last year, with the local agri-food industry being particularly affected. The rise in bad debt poses a severe warning sign for mounting strain on business liquidity.

images.alt_text: Generic picture of Singapore-living with the pandemic. Will economy growth be on track or will 2022 be the year iof the Omicron?
Further monetary tightening will be warranted if higher inflation proves to be persistent.

site_title: Australia commits to Pacific islands defence training as China seeks rival meeting
summary: Australia has committed to establishing a defence school to train Pacific island militaries amid growing competition for security ties with China. The country will also double its funding for aerial surveillance of the Pacific islands' vast fishing zone and provide financing for Pacific islands to build more resilient infrastructure. This move comes as China seeks to host a rival meeting to the Pacific Islands Forum, which includes Australia and New Zealand, to discuss a trade and security deal with 10 Pacific island nations.

images.alt_text: China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi on Tuesday arrived in Tonga on a tour through the region where Beijing’s ambitions for wider security ties has caused concern among US allies.

American officials increasingly see China losing diplomatic ground in Asia as Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin heads to Singapore for a regional security forum that will include a meeting with a top Chinese defence official.
The UK, New Zealand and Japan will also be part of the Partners in the Blue Pacific pact, an informal mechanism to assist Fiji, Samoa and other small nations in the region.

site_title: Ukraine war: The West needs also to consider interests of the rest
summary: The West's response to the Russia-Ukraine war has been driven by the US and its allies, with most of the international community opposing their stance. The G7's commitment to providing indefinite support to Ukraine has been met with resistance from major powers like China, India, and Indonesia. The West's policies are seen as isolating Russia, but this approach has not won support from governments in emerging markets, who are more concerned with economic growth and stability. To shift the balance of power, the US and its allies should focus on addressing the global economic concerns posed by the war, such as food security and debt restructuring.

site_title: Marsiling HDB flats' acquisition: Little to no top-ups for new replacement flats
summary: The Singapore government will acquire 9 Housing Board blocks in Marsiling for an expansion of Woodlands Checkpoint. Homeowners will receive compensation based on market value and the option to buy a new replacement flat in nearby Woodlands Street 13 with a fresh 99-year lease. They will have little to no top-ups for new units if they choose the same flat type, but will settle for a smaller floor area. The acquisition is part of the Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme (Sers).

The investment aims to close a critical supply-chain gap and support 1,500 jobs, with production volumes reaching 1.2 million wafers monthly. summary: Asian markets fell on Tuesday as investors lost confidence in a recent rally, weighed down by central banks' inflation-fighting rate hikes and recession fears. Analysts warn that the upcoming earnings season could see firms lower forecasts, and some commentators remain upbeat, citing history that suggests a rebound in the second half of the year.

site_title: Sri Lanka is put on virtual lockdown as fuel supplies are halted
summary: Sri Lanka imposes a virtual lockdown due to a crippling sovereign debt crisis, halting fuel supplies until July 10. The island nation's cabinet of ministers limits fuel distribution to essential services, including port, health services, and food transport, while urging citizens to stay at home and provide services online. summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has stepped down, ending his term marked by a deadly drug war and foul-mouthed tirades. Despite global condemnation, Duterte remains popular among Filipinos, who backed his anti-crime campaign and swift justice. Critics, including opposition Senator Leila de Lima and journalist Maria Ressa, faced jail terms for speaking out against him. site_title: Australia: Shares nudge higher on mining, energy boost
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% on Tuesday, its highest level since June 14, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. site_title: Demand for warehouses in the region poised for substantial growth: CBRE
summary: Demand for modern warehouses in the Asean region is expected to experience substantial growth, driven by the increasing need for supply chain resilience and the growing importance of the region in global value chains. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and other FTAs are expected to create cumulative exports and import growth of around US$500 billion for Asean countries by 2035, spurring additional real estate requirements. site_title: Bankman-Fried's FTX is seeking a path to buy Robinhood: sources
summary: FTX, backed by Sam Bankman-Fried, is exploring a potential acquisition of Robinhood Markets, according to sources. The move comes as Robinhood has lost about three-quarters of its value since its initial public offering last July. FTX has been on the hunt for deals, acquiring Embed Financial Technologies earlier this month, and could opt against pursuing a deal. site_title: China's 'perfect plan' to revive housing market draws sceptics
summary: China's local governments are implementing a plan to revive the housing market by offering "housing vouchers" to households that agree to demolish their run-down properties. The vouchers can be used to buy new homes, and some cities provide cash subsidies. However, analysts are skeptical about the plan's success, citing limited central bank financing and strained local government finances. The plan may boost sales if fully implemented, but its success rate is uncertain, and the road to recovery is likely to be "quite bumpy" due to China's Covid-Zero policy and slowing growth.

site_title: Gold prices flat as rise in US bond yields weighs
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Tuesday, as rising US bond yields offset gains. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,824.65 per ounce, while US gold futures were flat at $1,824.70. A ban on Russian gold imports by major countries is seen as symbolic, as exports to the West have already declined. China's net gold imports jumped 58.3% in May, and a weaker US dollar makes gold more attractive for buyers holding other currencies.

images.alt_text: Gold prices have dropped about 0.9 per cent this week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Tuesday, down 0.55 points or 0.04% to 1,437.57. The index saw 291.47 million lots traded worth RM95.49 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 188 to 115.

site_title: Bitcoin miners sell their holdings amid crypto winter's chill
summary: Bitcoin miners have collectively sold more than 100% of their output in May due to the value of bitcoin tumbling 45% and rising energy costs. Several publicly listed miners have tapped into their cryptocurrency stashes, with some using proceeds to negotiate financing agreements. The crypto mining space has become increasingly difficult for miners, with high energy prices and increased competition. Analysts point to miner sales as a factor weighing on bitcoin prices, but some see a potential "light at the end of the tunnel" for miners who can survive the current market conditions.

images.alt_text: The prolonged slump in Bitcoin is making it more difficult for some miners to repay the up to US$4 billion in loans they have backed by their equipment, posing a potential risk to major crypto lenders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, mirroring Wall Street's decline. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.23%, or 61.25 points, to 26,810.02, while the Topix index dropped 0.01%. Investors locked in profits amid concerns over the slowing economy and higher interest rates. The declines follow recent record highs on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to new records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Lufthansa to bring back A380 in reversal of pandemic move to retire the jet
summary: Lufthansa to revive its Airbus A380 fleet, reversing its 2020 decision to retire the aircraft due to the pandemic. The airline is assessing its summer 2023 operations, citing delays in deliveries of ordered aircraft and soaring travel demand. The A380, which was initially seen as a symbol of luxury, will return to service with a 500-seat capacity, with Lufthansa aiming to operate almost 60% of its pre-Covid monthly flights on the superjumbo. This move comes as several carriers bring back the hulking model after two years of stringent curbs.

site_title: Food inflation relief is within sight as crops and crude pull back
summary: Food inflation may see relief as crop prices pull back. The United Nations' food price index dropped from a record high in March after the war in Ukraine impacted exports. Key producers, such as Australia and Brazil, are expected to produce large crops, replenishing war-pinched reserves. This has led to a decline in crop futures, with wheat and soybean prices falling 15% and 13% respectively. Fuel pump prices are also expected to moderate, with energy prices declining, which could lead to a temporary pause in food inflation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, UOB, Isetan, Sinarmas Land, Watches.com
summary: Singtel has refuted reports that it plans to list its Australian subsidiary Optus through an initial public offering (IPO), citing "highly speculative" news.
