summary: A US Amtrak train derailed near Mendon, Missouri, killing three people and injuring multiple others, including over 200 passengers. Seven of the train's eight cars derailed after striking a dump truck at a rail crossing without lights or electronic control devices. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities confirming the three fatalities and multiple injuries. site_title: UOB prices S$400m in 4.25% perpetual capital securities, first callable in 2027
summary: UOB priced S$400m in 4.25% perpetual capital securities, the first callable in 2027, under its US$30 billion global medium-term note programme. Holders will receive semi-annual distributions at 4.25% per annum, with a reset every 5 years. Redemption will be at the prevailing 5-year Singapore Overnight Rate Average and the initial spread of 1.47%.

site_title: Vickers Venture Partners to deepen focus on ‘deep-tech’ investments
summary: Vickers Venture Partners, a VC firm founded by Finian Tan, is shifting its focus to "deep-tech" investments, allocating 80% of its latest fund, Fund VI, to breakthrough technologies with global impact. The firm's success in deep tech investments has led to recognition and institutional investor interest, with some of its companies achieving unicorn status. However, the global macro environment of higher interest rates and volatile public markets poses challenges, particularly in fundraising and potential exit values. Sony will provide the necessary technologies, including connected cars and in-house sensors, while Honda will supply the production know-how and vehicle-sales expertise. Other countries, including South Korea and India, are also reducing their reserves. Goldman analyst William Nance stated that Coinbase needs to make substantial cost reductions to stem cash burn as retail trading activity dwindles. The company's valuation has dropped to less than $14 billion, and its bonds are among the biggest decliners in the US high-yield market.

site_title: Taking stock of crypto investing as a ‘crypto winter’ sets in
summary: A recent correction in cryptocurrency prices has prompted investors to reevaluate their investment theses and goals amid a "crypto winter." The price of bitcoin has fallen 70% from its 2021 peak, and the total market capitalization of the sector has dropped from $3 trillion to $900 billion. While some argue that the market will rebound as sentiment recovers, others point out that cryptocurrencies lack observable fundamentals and are prone to extreme boom and bust cycles. Despite this, serious investors are putting money into blockchain technology and decentralized finance, and it is likely that cryptocurrencies will remain in the market for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Snack maker Weilong to revive US$500m Hong Kong IPO
summary: Weilong Delicious Global Holdings, a Chinese snack maker, has revived its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) to raise approximately US$500 million. The listing is expected to be launched in the second half of the year, following discussions with joint sponsors Morgan Stanley, China International Capital, and UBS Group.

summary: Club Med plans to open 17 new resorts globally, including in Japan and Malaysia, within the next 3 years. Club Med's chairman, Henri Giscard d’Estaing, attributes the growth to customers familiar with the brand and those who were unable to travel due to border closures. The company's growth is also attributed to its financial partners' increased support for new resort development, with the highest level of growth of new capacity in 20 years.

summary: UK Post Office workers will strike on Jul 11 over wages, with 114 locations closing. The Communications Workers Union says a 3% raise and £500 payment are "woefully inadequate" amid 9.1% inflation. This is the latest in a series of strikes by unions, including criminal trial lawyers and railway staff. The dispute is over dignity and respect for hard-working employees, with the UK government facing pressure over pay and working conditions.

site_title: Growing interest in alternative investments in Sabah, Johor and Penang: survey
summary: A survey by Knight Frank Malaysia found growing interest in alternative investments in Malaysia's commercial real estate, particularly in Penang, Johor, and Sabah. The survey polled 200 industry representatives, showing interest in serviced residences, hotels, co-working spaces, and healthcare assets. Industrial and logistics sub-sectors also saw significant interest, with nearly two-thirds of respondents anticipating capital value appreciations. The survey noted concerns over risks such as commodity price fluctuations and political uncertainty, but highlighted the low interest rate environment as a favorable factor for commercial real estate investment.

summary: Zip, an Australian buy now pay later (BNPL) company, has terminated its partnership with Singtel's Dash and exited Singapore, winding down operations by July 20. The decision comes just four months after the partnership was announced, citing a need to reprioritize resources to focus on delivering sustainable profitability in its core ANZ and US markets. The move follows a decline in the BNPL sector in Australia, with Zip's stock down 88.1% due to market volatility and regulatory changes in Singapore.

summary: Asean envoy Prak Sokhonn urges Myanmar to allow Aung San Suu Kyi to be returned to house arrest from solitary confinement ahead of his second visit to the country. Suu Kyi was transferred to solitary confinement last week, prompting concern and condemnation from the UN and international rights groups. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has been leading stalled diplomatic efforts to end the chaos in Myanmar since last year's coup. Suu Kyi's return to house arrest is seen as a key step towards resolving the situation.

summary: Meta's stock has plummeted to its lowest level relative to earnings, attracting value buyers who believe the company's problems are temporary. The stock, which surged over 780% from its 2012 IPO, is now trading at 12 times earnings, a significant discount from its peers. Despite slowing user growth, Meta's revenue is expected to increase 6.8% this year, with growth expected to pick up in the next two years. Value funds and index investors are buying Meta shares, seeing it as a deep-value stock with a good outlook.

site_title: Qatar Energy vows to erase almost all methane emissions by 2030
summary: Qatar Energy, the world's largest producer of liquefied natural gas, has pledged to cut almost all methane emissions from its operations by 2030. The move is part of the Aiming for Zero Methane Emissions Initiative, a group of oil and gas companies aiming to reduce methane emissions. The UN estimates that 80% of measures to curb leaks from oil and gas operations can be implemented at no cost. summary: US pending home sales unexpectedly rose 0.7% in May to 99.9, rebounding from a 2-year low in April. The housing market is undergoing a transition, according to NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun, who attributes the drop in pending sales to higher mortgage rates. The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage hit a 13-1/2-year high of 5.81%.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues notice of compliance to Incredible, Watches.com over joint dealings
summary: SGX RegCo has issued a notice of compliance to Incredible Holdings and Watches.com, citing joint dealings and cross-shareholdings between the two companies. Both companies share executive directors and board members, and have entered into similar transactions, including promissory notes and securities subscriptions. The regulator has directed the companies to appoint a joint independent reviewer to assess the transactions and ensure they were entered into on normal commercial terms. Both companies are prohibited from proceeding with announced corporate actions until the review is completed.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 32.92 points, or 0.10%, to 31,533.60, while the S&P 500 gained 9.02 points, or 0.23%, to 3,920.76, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 53.40 points, or 0.46%, to 11,661.02.

site_title: US durable goods orders exceed forecast in broad advance
summary: US durable goods orders exceeded forecasts with a 0.7% increase in May, following a revised 0.4% advance in the previous month. Core capital goods orders rose 0.5%, a 0.3% gain from the previous month. The data suggests business investment remains firm despite rising interest rates and economic concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong mansion goes for US$111m in record sale this year
summary: A 6-bedroom mansion in Hong Kong's exclusive Shouson Hill neighborhood sold for HK$870 million (US$111 million), breaking this year's sales price record. The property, part of the No 15 Shouson project, features a private garden, swimming pool, and parking space. The sale, facilitated by co-developers Emperor International Holdings Ltd, C C Land Holdings Ltd, Mingfa Group International Co, and CSI Properties Ltd, comes amid a decline in secondary luxury home transactions in upscale neighborhoods. Global luxury real estate demand remains high despite rising interest rates.

site_title: Ailing oceans in state of emergency, says UN chief
summary: The United Nations has declared the world's oceans in a state of emergency due to climate change and pollution. The UN Ocean Conference in Lisbon, Portugal, kicked off with Secretary General António Guterres warning of the crisis, which threatens marine life, human health, and the planet. Oceans absorb 25% of CO2 pollution, leading to acidification and massive marine heatwaves. The conference will focus on solutions such as recycling, global plastic caps, and sustainable fishing practices, with the goal of protecting 30% of the planet's land and ocean by 2030.

summary: Vietnam has banned scuba diving and swimming at Hon Mun island in Nha Trang due to damaged coral reefs, which are badly hit by global warming. The reef, once home to over 60% living coral, has shrunk to less than 50% due to climate change, powerful storms, and human activities. The ban, effective until further notice, aims to revive the ecosystem and protect the reef, which supports 25% of marine biodiversity and could affect 4.5 million people in the region.

site_title: Credit Suisse convicted of failing to stop money laundering
summary: Credit Suisse was convicted of failing to prevent money laundering by a Bulgarian cocaine trafficker between 2004 and 2008. A former relationship manager was also convicted on money laundering charges. Credit Suisse was fined 2 million Swiss francs (S$2.91 million) by Switzerland's top criminal court. The case is the first major Swiss lender conviction in the country's history, and the bank's reputation has been tarnished by a series of scandals. The conviction occurred 14 years after the alleged crimes, sparking criticism from Credit Suisse.

The group pledged support for Ukraine and adopted a declaration committing to provide aid "for as long as it takes." US President Joe Biden announced the purchase of an advanced surface-to-air missile defense system to help protect Ukrainian cities, and the G-7 is set to discuss a price cap on Russian oil, which may be implemented through a mechanism focused on transporting oil to foreign markets.

summary: Crypto broker Voyager Digital issued a default notice to hedge fund Three Arrows Capital (3AC) due to its failure to make required payments on a loan of 15,250 BTC and $350 million USDC. summary: The US dollar struggles against major rivals as inflation expectations soften, prompting a reassessment of aggressive interest rate hike bets. Despite reaching a near 2-decade high of 105.79 earlier this month, the dollar index is trading near its recent trading range, with some analysts suggesting vulnerability to further weakness. Falling commodity prices, including copper and oil, have eased pressure on interest rate expectations, with futures pricing showing a stabilization of the US Federal Reserve's benchmark funds rate around 3.5% next year.

site_title: Sri Lanka electricity firm seeks 835% price rise
summary: Sri Lanka's state-run electricity monopoly, the Ceylon Electricity Board, has requested an 835% price hike for its poorest customers, despite the country facing a foreign exchange crisis and fuel shortages. The proposed price increase would raise the monthly cost for the smallest power consumers from 54.27 rupees to 507.65 rupees. Regulators have proposed a direct subsidy from the Treasury to keep the increase below half of the requested amount, citing concerns that the majority of domestic consumers cannot afford the steep increase.

summary: European asset manager Amundi is scrutinizing climate strategy-related resolutions at annual general meetings (AGMs) and has voted in favor of less than 40% of the 36 "Say on Climate" resolutions tabled by companies. Amundi encouraged the practice last year but has tightened its approach this year. The asset manager voted in favor of 40% of oil industry resolutions, including those of Repsol, BP, and TotalEnergies, while voting against resolutions from Santos, Equinor, Woodside Petroleum, and Shell. Amundi aims to support energy companies' transformation to achieve carbon neutrality.

summary: US government bond ETFs are set to receive the largest quarterly inflow in 8 years, with $42.4 billion in funds invested so far this quarter, according to Refinitiv Lipper data. Investors are seeking safer bonds amid recession fears and high inflation. Analysts expect central banks' tightening measures to slow global economies, deterring investments in riskier assets. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and recession odds have contributed to the shift, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a 30% chance of US recession over the next year.

site_title: China's May net gold imports via Hong Kong up as curbs ease
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong rose 58.3% in May to 8.281 tonnes, a 47% increase from April, as pandemic-related curbs were relaxed in major cities. The increase may reflect easing restrictions in Shanghai and Beijing, which control a significant portion of China's gold imports. Despite a 62% year-on-year decrease, total gold imports rose 47% to 14.13 tonnes, suggesting a potential recovery in the market. Analysts attribute the rise to consumers becoming more comfortable with discretionary spending.

summary: Singapore-based biotech startup Mirxes is considering a US$300 million initial public offering (IPO) that could value the company at over US$1 billion. Founded in 2014 as a spinoff from A*Star, Mirxes focuses on early cancer detection using proprietary RNA-powered blood tests. The company has operations in China, Japan, and the US and has raised US$130 million in funding. A successful IPO would further stimulate the IPO market in Singapore, which has seen first-time share sales total US$348 million so far this year. Discussions with bankers are ongoing.

summary: Sinarmas Land, a property developer, has formed an investment arm, Living Lab Ventures, to fund Indonesian startups focusing on smart city living, digital life, and mobility solutions. The arm will provide mentoring and partnerships with related companies. Living Lab X, an incubator, will also be established to support startups. The move aims to support local startups and integrate their tech innovation into daily lives, capitalizing on Indonesia's smart city growth potential.

site_title: Global revenue from car and bike sharing may rise 40% by 2030
summary: Global revenue from car and bike sharing services is expected to rise 40% by 2030, reaching $660 billion annually, driven by improvements in technology, governmental regulations, and consumer mobility demand. This growth will significantly transform urban transportation, offering benefits for climate, pollution, and livability. By adopting electric vehicles, new mobility services could improve air quality, reduce noise levels, and decrease cities' carbon footprint.

site_title: China's central bank will continue to support economic recovery: state media
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang said the country's monetary policy will remain accommodative to support economic recovery amid downward growth pressures due to Covid-19 and external shocks. The central bank prioritizes price stability and employment, and will focus on structural policies such as supporting small- and medium-sized enterprises and green transition. China's outstanding green loans and bonds exceed 18 trillion yuan and 1.3 trillion yuan, respectively. The PBOC has pledged to bring emissions to a peak by 2030 and become carbon neutral by 2060.

site_title: Singapore’s economy rebounded on decisive policy action, but challenges lie ahead
summary: Singapore's economy has rebounded from the pandemic, exceeding pre-crisis levels in total output last year, but faces new challenges. The war in Ukraine poses risks for slower growth and faster inflation, exacerbating existing inflationary pressures. To address these concerns, Singapore's authorities will continue to implement decisive policy responses, including fiscal and monetary tightening, to maintain price stability and resilience. The government also acknowledges the need for a new social compact to make the economy more inclusive and to accelerate transformation towards a digital, more inclusive, and greener economy.

summary: A growing demand for sustainable payment solutions is driving a shift in the payments industry, as consumers increasingly expect environmentally-friendly practices from banks. site_title: Corporate net-zero goals don't add up to a net-zero planet
summary: Despite over 5,200 companies pledging to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, critics argue that corporate net-zero goals are fundamentally flawed. The French consultancy Carbone 4 claims that companies cannot be net-zero and that their pledges may do more harm than good. They argue that carbon offsets and removals are not equivalent to actual emissions reductions and that companies should only focus on their own emissions reductions and "avoided emissions." The UN Secretary General has launched a group to evaluate corporate net-zero claims, highlighting the need for companies to acknowledge their role in the global effort to achieve net-zero.

summary: Hong Kong marks the halfway point of its 50-year autonomy experiment under Chinese rule, with critics citing curtailed political and civil liberties. Global investors increasingly rely on Hong Kong to trade mainland stocks, and business executives remain optimistic about the city's status as a financial hub. Despite uncertainty, Hong Kong is expected to remain a crucial gateway between China and the West, with President Xi Jinping set to attend the swearing in of the city's new leader, John Lee.

The plan, which includes a $15 billion investment, aims to nurture vital industries and promote social and economic development. While some critics argue the plan has an element of protectionism, proponents argue it's necessary to address Australia's deindustrialized economy and abrupt supply chain disruptions, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. The government's goal is to turn Australia into a renewable energy superpower, emulating the South Korean model of state-backed industrial development.

site_title: European fund managers set to go all in on ESG: survey
summary: European fund managers are shifting towards ESG investments, with 72% of asset managers planning to halt non-ESG product launches by 2024. ESG assets in Europe could grow to 7.4-9.0 trillion euros by 2025, accounting for up to 56% of total European mutual fund assets. Over 60% of independent financial advisers and 68% of private and retail banks plan to cease distribution of non-ESG products. The shift is driven by regulatory focus on climate change and growing demand for sustainable investments.

site_title: Hong Kong exports post surprise fall on China curbs, global woes
summary: Hong Kong's exports declined 1.4% in May from a year earlier, reversing April's 1.1% gain, due to continued disruptions from COVID and global headwinds. Trade with China fell 10.1%, worse than April's 9.4% drop. The global economic slowdown, coupled with tighter monetary policy, is expected to weigh on Hong Kong's export performance. The trade deficit widened to HK$36.7 billion, marking the fourth consecutive month of a deficit. Economists had forecast an improvement of 4.3% in exports.

site_title: Renminbi’s rise will not challenge dollar dominance
summary: The US dollar remains the dominant international reserve currency despite structural changes in the monetary system over the past 60 years. The dollar's share of global reserves has fallen to 59% from 71% in 1999, and the rise of China's renminbi is expected to continue, but it will not challenge dollar dominance. The Federal Reserve's normalization of monetary policy has strengthened the dollar, while a potential economic slowdown in Europe and the US could lead to increased investment in US Treasuries, further solidifying the dollar's position.

site_title: Fixed-rate mortgages in Singapore seen hurtling towards 3%
summary: Fixed-rate mortgages in Singapore are expected to rise to 3% or higher by year-end, driven by the US Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes. Local banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS have already increased their fixed rates, with some projections suggesting they may reach 3% or more. Experts warn that homeowners should review their affordability before committing to a home purchase amid rising interest rates, and some lenders have suspended fixed-rate options due to the rising cost of funds.

The price increase is due to the surge in coal and natural gas prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, affecting Taiwan's power supply. The Ministry of Economic Affairs will review the proposal on June 27.

site_title: China regulator proposes new rules to improve anti-monopoly governance
summary: China's market regulator has proposed new rules to improve anti-monopoly governance, aiming to enhance the country's ability to govern antitrust behavior. The revised rules, set to take effect on August 1, will include regulations on mergers and acquisitions, descriptions of monopolistic deals, and guidelines for local authorities. The proposals follow the amendment of China's 2008 anti-monopoly law, which added emphasis on the digital economy and increased penalty fines. The new rules are part of a broader crackdown on monopolistic behaviors, including those by companies like Alibaba Group and Meituan.

site_title: Leonardo Del Vecchio, billionaire owner of Ray-Ban, dies at 87

Del Vecchio's company, EssilorLuxottica, has over 180,000 employees and operations worldwide, with a net worth of $25.7 billion as of June 1. He was known for his shyness and secrecy, but his business empire was built on his drive to be the best.

summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has signed an agreement with the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) to establish a Renminbi Liquidity Arrangement (RMBLA). The decline is attributed to concerns about a slowdown in industrial activity across major economies, including China's shrinking manufacturing activity and European and US manufacturing output contracting.

site_title: Ant-backed Zomato to buy Blink stake in 44.5b rupee deal
summary: Zomato, backed by Ant Group and Sequoia Capital, will acquire Blink Commerce, a grocery delivery service, in a 44.5 billion rupee deal. The acquisition aims to expand Zomato's quick delivery business, with Blink's tech platform, scale, and network expected to save costs. Zomato plans to keep the Blink app and brand separate, focusing on increasing hyper-local delivery fleet utilization and reducing delivery costs. The deal is part of Zomato's strategy to expand into multiple categories of quick deliveries.

images.alt_text: Uber, whose shares have gyrated wildly since its 2019 initial public offering (IPO), has hived off money-losing businesses to achieve its goal of being consistently profitable.
Sequoia India has invested in more than 400 startups across India and South-east Asia, 36 of which are valued at more than US$1 billion including Byju's and Zomato.

site_title: Nasa pauses mission to metal-rich asteroid
summary: NASA has delayed the launch of the Psyche mission, a spacecraft aimed at exploring a metal-rich asteroid, due to software and testing issues. The mission, originally set to launch in 2022, will now not launch this year, with possible new launch windows in 2023 or 2024. The delay affects not only Psyche but also the Janus mission, which was set to tag along for the launch. An independent review panel will investigate the issues and suggest next steps, which could include cancelling the mission or adding to the estimated $985 million price tag.

Three Chinese astronauts docked at the country's space station on Sunday, the state broadcaster said, marking a new milestone in Beijing's drive to become a major space power.

site_title: Oil settles up but posts weekly decline on recession fears
summary: Oil prices rose by over $3 a barrel on Friday, supported by tight supply, but fell for the second week due to recession fears. Brent crude settled at $113.12 a barrel, up 2.8%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $107.62, up 3.2%. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and concerns about inflation have driven oil prices down despite strong economic data and a record-low US consumer sentiment survey.

images.alt_text: Indonesian farmers want authorities to scrap a requirement for exporters to sell a portion of their palm oil domestically, a move that should boost shipments and mean mills pay more for fresh fruit bunches.
The average price of petrol was US$4.94 per gallon on Thursday, according to data from the American Automobile Association.

site_title: Case calls for stronger safeguards for BNPL consumers including recourse avenues, advertisement regulation
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) is calling for stronger consumer safeguards for buy now, pay later (BNPL) schemes in Singapore, citing 18 consumer complaints involving BNPL service providers from January 2021 to June 2022. CASE president Melvin Yong proposes clearer recourse avenues, limits on consumer and provider spending, and regulated advertisements. He also suggests mandatory disclosures of risks and penalties, purchase limits for first-time users, and a ceiling on maximum purchases for users under 21.

images.alt_text: BNPL firms, typically offer on-the-spot interest-free short-term loans that spread payments for retail goods such as clothing, have rapidly increased in popularity.

Klarna, billed as Europe’s most valuable startup in 2021, has seen its fortunes dramatically change amid a tougher climate for privately-held tech companies, sparked by soaring inflation and tighter monetary policy.

site_title: Wall Street banks quietly test cyber defences at Treasury’s direction
summary: US Treasury officials have been working with the nation's largest banks to strengthen their cyber defenses, a move aimed at mitigating the risk of a cyberattack that could imperil the entire financial system. The simulation exercise, which included JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Morgan Stanley, tested the banks' ability to respond to various cyber-attack scenarios. The Treasury has also declassified more intelligence and extended security clearance to more employees within the big banks. This effort is part of a broader public-private partnership to improve cyberattack response and follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which heightened concerns about cyber threats.

site_title: Retail investors of Reits should take a closer look at corporate governance
summary: Retail investors should scrutinize corporate governance in Singaporean Reits, as weak practices can lead to "shenanigans" that erode investor confidence. Despite the S-Reit market's success, many companies have "elevated valuations in properties" and "high yield" supported by sponsors, raising concerns about the sustainability of yield. Investors should look beyond dividend yield and projected DPU growth to assess corporate governance, including disclosures on tenant dependency, valuation processes, and alignment of interests between shareholders and managers.

images.alt_text: CICT (formerly known as CMT) -- the first Reit to be listed in Singapore -- has generated total return of over 600% since its IPO in 2002.

site_title: When you buy diamonds, think of Bucha, Ukraine envoy says
summary: A Ukrainian diplomat urges consumers to consider the potential funding of Russia's war when buying diamonds, citing Russia's 33% stake in Alrosa, the world's second-largest diamond producer. Alrosa accounts for about 30% of global diamond output. The Kimberley Process, a coalition certifying conflict-free diamonds, is split over expanding its definition to include diamonds funding aggression by states. The international conflict diamond forum in Botswana ended inconclusively, highlighting the need for clarity on the issue.

images.alt_text: Lab-grown diamonds from local jewellery brand Authica J. Lab-grown diamonds have risen in popularity in the last 4 years among consumers due to their affordbility and sustainability.

site_title: Taking tech and technique to the slopes
summary: Kelvin Fu, managing partner at Gunung Capital, discusses his passion for skiing as a means to challenge himself and find new perspectives, mirroring his approach to investing. He highlights the impact of climate change on snow quality worldwide, citing shorter seasons and changing snow textures. Fu sees parallels between skiing and leadership, emphasizing the need to adapt and learn in a rapidly changing environment. He expresses concern about the future of skiing and the environment but remains optimistic about the potential for future generations to enjoy the sport, if climate change is addressed.

site_title: The open road to the metaverse
summary: The metaverse is a constantly growing, potentially infinite, number of virtual reality worlds, and financial services have a role to play in creating open and secure virtual environments. Companies like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley see the metaverse as a $8 trillion opportunity, while DBS Bank is exploring opportunities to introduce its banking services to the metaverse. To succeed, banks and fintechs must reimagine banking and payments, embed financial services seamlessly, prioritize user safety and convenience, and consider the user experience. An open-source approach to the metaverse is also necessary to enable wallet transfers between worlds, with potential middle grounds being a marketplace or app store-type approach.

images.alt_text: The opportunity is huge, for SMEs in Asia Pacific to employ immersive data, and the metaverse, to create new relationships with prospective customers.
Meta has disclosed plans for a mixed-reality headset code-named "Cambria" to be released this year.

site_title: The big risk to equities now is earnings, not valuations
summary: Global equities are likely to face a bear market driven by earnings recessions, particularly in cyclical sectors, rather than valuation concerns. Despite recent market volatility, stock analysts' forecasts indicate uninterrupted earnings growth for 2022-2024, contradicting recession talk and monetary policy tightening. However, models suggest an earnings recession, with US earnings expected to fall 10-15% and eurozone EPS forecast to decline 20% in 2023. Cyclical sectors like industrials, tech hardware, and energy will be most impacted, with energy sector EPS forecasts currently showing strong growth, but potentially slowing.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2 per cent to end at 30,483.13.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark strong end to nervous week
summary: European stocks surged 2.6% on Friday, marking their best session in over 3 months and pushing the pan-European Stoxx 600 index into positive territory for the week. The index had previously hit a 2022 low due to weaker-than-expected euro zone business activity data. Investors scaled back central bank tightening bets, leading to inflows into risky assets and breaking a 3-week losing streak. This marks a strong end to a nervous week for European markets.

images.alt_text: Stocks rebounded this week as financial markets have been roiled over worries that rapid rate hikes by the Fed to rein in 40-year-high inflation could cause a recession.
The next leg of the bear market is likely to be driven by earnings recessions, especially in the more cyclical stocks, sectors, and markets.

site_title: BioNTech in conflict with German regulator over new Covid vaccine approval
summary: BioNTech's new Covid-19 vaccine adapted to the Omicron variant may be delayed due to a disagreement with the German regulator over approval. The regulator, Paul Ehrlich Institute, wants BioNTech to submit animal data for approval, but the company's CEO, Ugur Sahin, plans to bypass this process, citing a 3-month delivery timeline. The European Medicines Agency suggests first approvals could be given in September if the vaccine proves superiority over existing vaccines in human trials. The approval decision is due by the end of June.

site_title: Yellen to visit South Korea, discuss sanctions on North: sources
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is set to visit South Korea next month to discuss rising inflation and possible further sanctions on North Korea over its nuclear program. Yellen will meet with senior South Korean officials, including Foreign Minister Park Jin and Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho, amid concerns that North Korea may prepare to conduct its first nuclear test in five years. The talks will also focus on economic conditions, including inflation rates, and a possible new UN Security Council resolution to address North Korea's provocation.

In an annual assessment of US economic policies, the IMF said it now expects US Gross Domestic Product to grow 2.9 per cent in 2022, less than its most recent forecast of 3.7 per cent in April.

site_title: Ukraine forces ordered to withdraw from key battleground city
summary: Ukraine's forces have been ordered to withdraw from the key battleground city of Sievierodonetsk, marking a significant reversal in the conflict that has killed thousands and uprooted millions since Russia's invasion four months ago. The withdrawal comes after weeks of fierce street fighting and allows Ukraine to limit casualties and regroup, but will be seen as a victory for Russia. The move also sets the stage for the next main focus of fighting, the twin city of Lysychansk, and comes after Ukraine's military suffered losses in other areas, including the southern port of Mariupol.

images.alt_text: Russia - which invaded Ukraine 4 months ago - holds a 33 per cent stake in Alrosa, which accounted for about 30 per cent of the world’s diamond output last year.

site_title: Rates will remain main policy took for BOE, Pill says
summary: Bank of England chief economist Huw Pill stated that interest rates will remain the central bank's main monetary policy tool as it prepares to start selling bonds. This move, known as quantitative tightening, aims to tighten monetary policy. Pill noted that the use of rates would depend on the impact of QT on asset prices and the wider economic situation. The BOE has been raising borrowing costs since December to combat inflation, which reached a 40-year high of 9.1% in May. The central bank's Monetary Policy Committee will consider the plan for asset sales in August.

site_title: IMF slashes US growth forecast, sees 'narrowing path' to avoid recession
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has slashed its US economic growth forecast, predicting 2.9% growth in 2022, down from 3.7% in April, and 1.7% in 2023, with a potential recession looming. The IMF attributes this to aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate hikes and ongoing supply chain disruptions, but notes that a "narrowing path" to avoiding a recession exists. Strong US savings and a commitment to low inflation from the Fed are seen as key factors in preventing a recession, although some "pain" for consumers may be necessary to achieve price stability.

images.alt_text: While growing affordability concerns have limited demand since the start of the year, many Americans still have the desire and wherewithal to buy a home.
The Federal Reserve subjected 33 banks to its annual “stress test” exercise, to gauge whether they would be able to weather a steep global recession.

site_title: Spirit renews support for Frontier merger after it boosts offer
summary: Spirit Airlines' board has renewed its support for a merger deal with Frontier Group after Frontier raised its cash offer by $2 per share to buy the rival ultra-low-cost carrier. The offer, worth $24.29 in stock and cash, is now $2 higher than JetBlue's offer of $33.50 per share. Spirit's board recommends stockholders vote in favor of the merger, and shareholders will vote on the proposal on Wednesday.

site_title: Fact-checking the deglobalisation narrative
summary: Globalization is undergoing changes, but it doesn't necessarily imply widespread deglobalization. Trade in goods and services as a share of global GDP fell from 61% in 2008 to 52% in 2020, but this figure is still high by historical standards. The all-out tariff war predicted by trade skeptics did not occur, and voters generally oppose protectionism. Instead, global supply chains are being reconfigured to ensure resilience, with companies diversifying suppliers and drawing up plans B, C, and D. There is also a shift towards trade in services, facilitated by digital technology, and governments are seeking to shape the paths of globalization through regulation and policy.

site_title: US: Wall Street mints big gains to end strong week
summary: US stocks ended the week on a strong note, with the S&P 500 rising 6.4% for its biggest weekly gain since May 2020. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also surged, with the Dow rising 2.68% and the Nasdaq adding 3.34%. The rebound was driven by signs of slowing economic growth and a drop in commodity prices, which tempered expectations for the Federal Reserve's rate-hike plans. The S&P 500 banks index rose 3.7% after the Fed's annual "stress test" exercise showed lenders have enough capital to weather a severe economic downturn.

site_title: New mobility concepts can solve South-east Asia’s traffic woes
summary: South-east Asia's traffic congestion and air pollution remain significant concerns, with cities like Jakarta and Kuala Lumpur struggling with hour-long traffic jams and poor air quality. However, new mobility concepts, such as Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) and "Beyond MaaS," offer a solution by combining public and private entities to create a more efficient transportation system. CASE technologies, including connected, autonomous, shared, and electrified vehicles, are expected to play a key role in reducing congestion and pollution. Governments and private entities are partnering to implement these technologies, with Singapore and other countries aiming to create a more sustainable and equitable transportation system.

site_title: World faces unprecedented global hunger crisis, UN chief says
summary: The UN chief, Antonio Guterres, warned of a "real risk" of multiple famines this year due to an unprecedented global hunger crisis. Over 460,000 people in Somalia, Yemen, and South Sudan are in famine conditions, and millions more are at risk in 34 other countries. The crisis is exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, climate disruption, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Guterres urged ministers to stabilize food markets and reduce commodity price volatility, particularly for Ukraine and Russia, which produce 29% of global wheat exports, to prevent mass hunger and starvation.

images.alt_text: A Russian naval blockade of Ukraine's Black Sea ports has stopped grain shipments from the world's fourth-largest exporter of wheat and corn, raising the spectre of shortages and hunger in low-income countries.

site_title: Lufthansa cancels 2,200 flights as Europe’s travel chaos mounts
summary: Lufthansa cancels 2,200 flights due to coronavirus infections worsening staffing shortages, adding to Europe's travel chaos as the summer vacation period begins. The airline scrapped German domestic and European routes for July and August. This follows 900 cancellations announced earlier this month. The new outbreak of Covid-19 infections is causing growing absences from workplaces, exacerbating acute labour shortages at airlines.

site_title: Low-income Americans burned through extra cash
summary: Low-income Americans are depleting their savings due to the soaring cost of living, according to recent consumer finance data. A 22% decline in cash holdings among the lowest-earning fifth of the US population from 2019 is attributed to the Covid-induced savings and federal aid. Economists warn that this trend threatens the US economy, which is already experiencing high inflation and interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Almost US$4b in Bitcoin miner loans are coming under stress
summary: Bitcoin miners are facing financial stress due to the prolonged slump in Bitcoin's price, which has halved the value of mining equipment used as collateral for loans totaling up to $4 billion. Many miners have defaulted on their loans, with some selling off their Bitcoin reserves to cover costs. If the market doesn't improve, analysts warn it could lead to a potential industry shakeout, with smaller miners struggling to repay loans and sell their machines.

site_title: Monkeypox virus feared to have more mutations than expected, say scientists
summary: Scientists in Portugal have discovered that the latest strain of monkeypox, which has spread across the UK and US, has about 50 genetic variations compared to related viruses from 2018-2019. The virus is continuing to evolve, with recent mutations including small changes in the genetic code, minor gene variants, and a deleted gene. This unexpected level of mutation has raised concerns about the potential for the virus to spread more easily or become more severe. Authorities are tracking the outbreak and expanding vaccination efforts to contain the spread.

site_title: In praise of slow sport
summary: The article praises the enjoyment of slow-paced sports, citing examples from cricket, golf, and tennis. The 2008 Wimbledon final between Nadal and Federer, lasting nearly 5 hours, is highlighted as an epic example. Other slow-paced sports like snooker and cricket, which can last for multiple days, are also mentioned. The article concludes that the steady build-up of tension in these sports creates intense joy and despair, making the experience more thrilling for fans, unlike the predictable plot twists in TV dramas.

images.alt_text: Drawing more than half-a-billion viewers, the annual cricket Indian Premier League tournament trails only English football and the National Football League in popularity globally, according to its organiser.

site_title: TTJ directors recommend shareholders reject offer, after IFA deems it ‘not fair, not reasonable’
summary: Four TTJ Holdings directors are recommending shareholders reject a privatization offer of S$0.23 per share made by executive chairman Teo Hock Chwee's investment holding company, citing that the offer price is "not fair and not reasonable" due to significant discounts from the company's net asset value. The directors, along with independent financial advisor Zico Capital, also noted that the offer may disadvantage minority shareholders and grant Teo control over the company. The offer price is below Zico Capital's estimated value range of S$0.37 to S$0.46 per share, and will close on July 8.

site_title: Some Chinese cities relax Covid testing mandates
summary: China has relaxed Covid testing mandates in several cities, including Ningbo and Hangzhou, in eastern province Zhejiang, and cities in Anhui province, as concerns over frequent testing's financial burden on local governments grow. The move comes after China emerged from its worst regional outbreaks, with cities like Beijing and Shanghai still requiring citizens to test every few days. The country aims to boost testing capacity to detect the highly transmissible Omicron variant early, while balancing the need to prevent another major outbreak with the need to minimize disruption to people's lives.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher with broad-based gains
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday, with the Dow Jones rising 169.58 points, or 0.55%, to 30,846.94, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 26.02 and 119.12 points, respectively. Slowing economic growth and falling commodity prices eased expectations for interest rate hikes to combat inflation, reducing market volatility.

site_title: Indonesian palm oil farmers call for removal of local sales rules
summary: Indonesian palm oil farmers are calling for the removal of local sales rules, which require exporters to sell a portion of their palm oil domestically, to boost shipments and increase mill payments. The current requirement has led to a 70% decline in fresh fruit bunch prices, causing pain to the industry that employs 17 million workers. Farmers' group APKASINDO claims that the regulations suppress prices, and they urge the government to revoke them to increase farmers' earnings.

images.alt_text: Indonesia allowed palm shipments to resume from May 23 following a 3-week ban designed to boost cooking oil stocks and keeping runaway prices in check amid growing domestic discontent.

site_title: US dollar stumbles as markets rethink interest rate path
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% against major currencies, marking its first weekly decline this month, as investors reevaluated interest rate expectations amid easing inflation fears. The dollar's decline was partly driven by a fall in oil and commodity prices, which eroded the safe-haven bid. Analysts now expect interest rates to peak around March 3.5% and fall by nearly 20 basis points by July 2023, with the Federal Reserve's "unconditional" commitment to taming inflation remaining unchanged.

site_title: Ryanair, Brussels Airlines strikes disrupt European air travel
summary: Ryanair and Brussels Airlines staff went on strike over pay and working conditions, disrupting European air travel during the peak summer season. Ryanair cabin crew unions in Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, and France called a 3-day strike, canceling dozens of flights, with the biggest impact felt in Belgium, where 127 flights were canceled. The strikes also affected Brussels Airlines, canceling 315 flights. The strikes, which started on Friday, were in response to Ryanair's decision to operate 73-82% of flights during the strike period, which unions argue is not sufficient.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Lufthansa cancelled 2,200 flights after a wave of coronavirus infections worsened staffing shortages, adding to Europe’s travel chaos as the crucial summer vacation period gets under way.

site_title: US Supreme Court overturns abortion rights landmark
summary: The US Supreme Court overturned the landmark 1973 Roe v Wade ruling, recognizing a woman's constitutional right to an abortion, in a 6-3 decision. The ruling, which upholds a Republican-backed Mississippi law banning abortion after 15 weeks, was powered by the conservative majority. The decision reverses a 49-year trend of declining abortion rates, with the US abortion rate increasing by 8% in the three years ending in 2020. The ruling has sparked widespread protests and condemnation from Democrats, with President Joe Biden calling it a "radical" step.

images.alt_text: Anti-abortion demonstrators celebrate outside the United States Supreme Court as the court rules in the Dobbs v Women’s Health Organization abortion case, overturning the landmark Roe v Wade abortion decision in Washington, U.S., June 24, 2022. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein

site_title: RBA to hike in 25 to 50 basis point steps, Lowe says
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor Philip Lowe announced rate hikes in 25 to 50 basis point steps to bring inflation back to lower levels. Lowe stated that Australia is on a "narrow path" to achieve this goal, but risks exist due to the global economy and uncertainty around household responses to higher interest rates. Despite rapid rate increases, Lowe believes the local economy will avoid recession due to strong underlying momentum, low unemployment, and high savings rates.

site_title: Knight Frank, SAS to set up committee safeguarding security workers
summary: Knight Frank and Security Association Singapore (SAS) have agreed to set up a committee to safeguard the welfare of security workers, addressing challenges such as a shrinking workforce, rising costs, and inconsistent service standards. The committee, to be completed by the end of 2022, will comprise security agencies, SAS, and managing agents, with the Union of Security Employees also invited to co-drive its goals. The committee aims to improve talent pools, deploy smart technology, and support the mental and emotional well-being of security workers.

images.alt_text: An association representing security officers in Singapore has asserted that property managing agent Knight Frank is engaging in discriminatory hiring practices in its tender for condominium security services.

site_title: New Hong Kong health chief aims to cut quarantine to 5 days
summary: Hong Kong's incoming Health Secretary Lo Chung-mau aims to reduce quarantine to 5 days, but the city will maintain its "dynamic zero" approach to eliminating the virus. Lo declined to give a timeline on opening Hong Kong's border with mainland China, which has been a source of consternation for business groups. This move comes as the new government prioritizes loosening border curbs, with Chief Executive John Lee planning to "quickly review" quarantine measures and prioritize the full reopening of the China border.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output in May grew 13.8% year-over-year, driven by a surge in semiconductor production, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board. This beat analysts' expectations. Additionally, GlobalFoundries plans to create 1,000 jobs in Singapore with a new manufacturing plant, set to open in 2023, and The Sun Cable project is targeting a final investment decision in early 2024.

site_title: White hot real estate markets cool, leaving buyers and sellers scrambling
summary: The global real estate market is experiencing a downturn due to aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation. In New Zealand, Canada, and the US, home prices have declined for the first time in two years, with economists predicting a 10-20% drop in prices this year. The US housing market has slowed, with 20% of home sellers cutting prices, while the UK market is also showing signs of slowing due to higher interest rates. The Czech Republic's high homeownership rate, fast inflation, and low unemployment have led to a housing bubble, with prices expected to continue rising.

images.alt_text: Housing markets in New Zealand (pictured), the Czech Republic, Australia and Canada rank among the world’s bubbliest and are particularly vulnerable to falling prices, according to Bloomberg Economics.

site_title: India rushes food, medicine to bankrupt Sri Lanka
summary: India has provided Sri Lanka with a rice and pharmaceuticals shipment, following a visit by Indian experts for aid talks. The shipment is part of India's $1.5 billion credit line to help Sri Lanka meet its food and energy needs. Sri Lanka is facing an unprecedented economic crisis, with widespread hardship due to a critical shortage of foreign currency, fuel, and medicines. The crisis has led to daily blackouts, galloping inflation, and a default on its $51 billion foreign debt. India and Sri Lanka are in bailout talks with the International Monetary Fund.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka off the tip of southeast India needs about US$5 billion in the next 6 months to cover basic necessities for its 22 million people, who have been struggling with long queues, worsening shortages and power cuts.

site_title: US crypto firm Harmony hit by US$100m heist
summary: US-based crypto firm Harmony suffered a cyber heist, with thieves stealing around $100 million worth of digital coins from its Horizon "bridge" product. The bridge, used to transfer crypto between blockchains, was targeted by hackers. This is the latest in a string of cyber heists in the crypto sector, with over $1 billion stolen from bridges in 2022. Harmony is working with authorities to identify the culprit and retrieve the stolen funds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.65 points to 1,436.70 on Friday, June 24. The index closed with 2.469 billion lots worth RM1.479 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 519 to 345.

site_title: Ukraine's EU candidacy will strengthen Europe as Russia threatens freedom: Zelenskiy
summary: Ukraine's formal EU candidacy was welcomed by European leaders, with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy calling it a key step towards strengthening Europe amidst Russia's ongoing assault. The move comes as Russia continues its war of attrition in eastern Ukraine, with thousands killed and millions displaced. The EU's decision is seen as a significant blow to Russia's efforts to test Europe's freedom and unity. Ukraine's accession to the EU is expected to boost morale and pave the way for long-term membership, but the path ahead will be challenging and could take years.

images.alt_text: Germany, which leads the G7 this year, has also invited Argentina, India, Indonesia, Senegal and South Africa to participate in select sessions at the summit.

site_title: Boustead Projects acquires Bideford Road property at S$515m, below valuation
summary: Boustead Projects acquired an 18-storey luxury mixed-use development in Singapore's Bideford Road area for S$515 million, below its independently valued price of S$550 million. The property, designed by Nikken Sekkei, had a carrying value of S$605.4 million and was sold as part of the winding-up process of its owner SC Aetas Holdings, which was placed under creditors' voluntary liquidation. The acquisition is expected to benefit the group's real estate business, expand its property portfolio, and increase income streams, with a material effect on its earnings per share for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore.
Boustead Projects reported a drop in FY2022 earnings due to an absence in one-off gain

Boustead Projects' wholly-owned subsidiary, BP Vietnam Development, has entered into a strategic collaboration with Khai Toan Joint Stock Company to acquire, develop and own a portfolio of logistics and industrial properties in Vietnam.
Boustead Projects unit fined S$94,000 for illegal drone usage

site_title: SoftBank pays ex-COO Claure US$94m in severance, incentives
summary: SoftBank's former COO Marcelo Claure has received a US$94 million severance and incentives package as part of his compensation from the tech investment giant. Claure's departure ended a tumultuous tenure marked by a compensation clash with founder Masayoshi Son. Claure had sought more authority and up to US$1 billion in compensation. His retirement follows a series of high-profile exits, including Michel Combes, and comes as SoftBank struggles to regain footing amid a drop in tech valuations.

site_title: Vietnam schools firm said to mull stake sale at US$1 billion value
summary: Vietnam-based educational services provider Nguyen Hoang Group is considering a stake sale valued at around $1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the matter. The company, which operates a comprehensive educational system with 60 campuses and over 90,000 students, is working with a financial adviser to find a buyer. This comes as private education assets in South-east Asia are in high demand, following recent sales of other education groups by private equity firms and companies in the industry. Deliberations are ongoing, with no certainty the company will proceed with the planned divestment.

site_title: Tortoise and its egg found in latest Pompeii discovery
summary: Archaeologists in Pompeii have discovered the remains of a tortoise and its egg, hidden under a clay floor in a storehouse. The tortoise likely died before the 79 AD volcanic eruption that buried the city. The unusual find highlights the transformations in the city after a devastating earthquake in 62 AD, which led to the abandonment of some areas and the expansion of public baths. The discovery sheds light on the extent of the changes and the city's resilience in the face of disaster.

images.alt_text: Archaeologists find 7,000-year-old ritual hunt site in Jordanian desert

site_title: SoftBank-backed Ride startup seeks at least US$119m in IPO
summary: SoftBank-backed car-sharing startup Socar filed for an initial public offering (IPO) of at least US$119 million, testing investor appetite in an adverse market. The company plans to use the proceeds for acquisitions and operational costs, with an indicative price range of 34,000 won to 45,000 won per share. The IPO, set for August 18, will value the startup at 1.2-1.6 trillion won, a discount from its estimated 2.4 trillion won valuation based on 12-month revenue.

images.alt_text: Softbank Group Corp's chief executive Masayoshi Son on Friday reiterated that the Japanese conglomerate was most likely to list British-based chip designer unit Arm on Nasdaq, stressing no final decision has been made.

site_title: STI up 0.6%, tracking rally in Asian equities
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,111.65 on Friday, tracking a rally in Asian equities. The index gained 18.85 points after 1.1 billion securities worth S$882.2 million changed hands. Major indices in Hong Kong, Japan, Australia, South Korea, Malaysia, and Indonesia also rose, with the Kospi gaining the most. Mapletree Logistics Trust and ST Engineering were top performers, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell.

images.alt_text: Analysts agree that while BI has remained patient so far, mounting global pressures will push the bank to adjust its key policy rate this year.
The Nikkei share average rose 1.23 per cent to 26,491.97, accelerating gains after US futures climbed.

site_title: Lian Beng’s Singapore construction order book lifted to S$1.8 billion as unit bags contract
summary: Lian Beng Group's construction order book in Singapore has risen to S$1.8 billion following the securing of a new project by its 60% subsidiary, United Tec Construction. The order book is expected to provide a "sustainable flow of activity" through FY2026. Details about the new project, including its value, were not disclosed.

site_title: H&M closes Shanghai flagship store, hurt by lockdowns and consumer backlash
summary: H&M has closed its Shanghai flagship store due to consumer backlash and the impact of China's Covid-19 lockdowns on the fast-fashion retailer. The store, which opened in 2007, was boarded up on June 24, marking the latest closure in China. The decision comes amid a boycott of H&M due to its concerns about Xinjiang cotton, which has been met with harsh backlash from Chinese consumers. The retailer had more than 500 stores in mainland China but now only lists 376 on its website.

site_title: Portugal home prices rise faster than ever on lack of supply
summary: Portugal's home prices surged 13% in the first quarter, the largest increase since 2010, due to a housing shortage and strong demand from local and international investors. The shortage is partly caused by delays in new building permits, particularly in Lisbon. Foreign buyers, attracted by the country's climate and lower cost of living, are willing to pay double the price of homes in Lisbon compared to domestic buyers. To regulate demand, the government has excluded Lisbon and Oporto from its golden visa program.

images.alt_text: 玩得好

site_title: Sanofi, GSK Covid vaccine found effective against Omicron
summary: Sanofi and GSK's experimental Covid-19 vaccine has shown 64.7% efficacy against symptomatic Covid and 72% efficacy against Omicron variant infections in a trial involving 13,000 adults. The vaccine targets both the beta variant and the original Wuhan strain. The new data will be submitted to regulatory authorities in hopes of making the vaccine available later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week on a high
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week on a high, with the Hang Seng Index advancing 2.09% to 21,719.06. The rally was driven by tech firms, which rose on hopes that a Chinese crackdown on the sector could be ending. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with the latter rising 1.32%. The strong performance follows a strong performance on Wall Street, where tech firms led the way.

site_title: Oxford University among suspected victims of building cartel
summary: Britain's antitrust watchdog, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), has found that 10 UK construction firms, including eight that admitted to the bid rigging, colluded on contracts worth over £150 million. The firms, which included the University of Oxford and Selfridges, used the practice of cover bidding to hoodwink customers into paying more for lower quality services. The CMA is set to fine the companies if a final decision confirms they broke the law, with fines potentially exceeding £150 million. The investigation, started in 2019, highlights the CMA's willingness to pursue more enforcement cases.

site_title: CMA CGM, Singapore port authority to collaborate on low carbon fuels
summary: CMA CGM and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to explore low-carbon fuels and green technologies for commercial shipping. The partnership aims to use zero and low-carbon marine fuels, such as e-methanol and biofuels, and research carbon capture solutions. CMA CGM will register 3 e-methane ready vessels under the Singapore flag and has already ordered 16 vessels powered by liquefied natural gas (LNG) and methanol, with plans to have 77 e-methane ready vessels by 2026.

site_title: India central bank deputy Patra expects inflation to breach 6% for 3 quarters
summary: India's retail inflation is expected to breach the 2-6% target band for three consecutive quarters, according to Reserve Bank of India (RBI) deputy governor Michael Patra. Inflation eased slightly in May but remained above the tolerance band for a fifth month. Patra emphasized the need for monetary action to address price pressures, citing second-round effects of inflation. The RBI will defend the rupee from extreme volatility and take measures to ensure smooth government borrowing.

site_title: Chinese authority launches probe into Chinese academic database CNKI
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has launched an investigation into the China National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), a major academic database, amid concerns over "preventing security risks of national data, protecting national security, and safeguarding public interest." This probe comes just a month after the market regulator launched an antitrust investigation into CNKI, following reports of high subscription fees and a suspension of use by the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The investigation marks a shift in Beijing's regulatory approach as the country begins to wind down its crackdown on internet platforms.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past an office of the Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) in Beijing, China July 8, 2021. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
China to crack down on tax evasion in livestreaming industry

site_title: Carmaker Stellantis to take 8% stake in lithium supplier Vulcan
summary: Stellantis, owner of brands including Jeep and Peugeot, is investing 50 million euros in Vulcan Energy Resources, a German-Australian lithium supplier, to acquire an 8% stake and extend a 10-year supply agreement. This deal supports Stellantis' plan to make 100% of its European passenger car sales battery electric vehicles by 2030. Vulcan uses a direct lithium extraction method, reducing land and groundwater usage. The investment aims to create a sustainable value chain for electric vehicle battery production and fight global warming.

site_title: Seoul: Shares log biggest daily gain in 16 months; third weekly loss
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index rose 2.26% to 2,366.6, its largest daily gain in 16 months, as investors scaled back expectations for inflation and interest-rate hikes following Wall Street gains. Despite this, the index logged a third straight weekly decline. The Korean won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell, while heavyweights such as Kakao, Naver, and Samsung Electronics also rose. The decline in shares is attributed to global uncertainties, including China's Covid-19 curbs and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and the growing risk of a US recession.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 28.49 points or 1.22 per cent at 2,314.32 - the lowest close since Nov 2, 2020.

site_title: TikTok releases first album of viral hits
summary: TikTok has released its first album of viral hits, "TikTok Classics: Memes and Viral Hits," in partnership with Warner Classics. The album features 18 full-length singles, including "No Roots" by Alice Merton and "Pieces" by Danilo Stankovic, which have been used in over 4.7 million videos on the platform. The album will be released on streaming platforms on July 8 and in record stores in August, marking TikTok's first foray into the traditional music market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at the open
summary: European stocks rebounded on Friday, June 24, 2022, despite a week of heavy losses due to recession fears. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4% to 7,047.11 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose. Investors brushed aside bruising defeats for Britain's ruling Conservatives in by-elections and data showing a drop in UK retail sales volumes. The rebound came despite heightened concerns over a global recession and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Commodity losses strip emerging markets of their lone attraction
summary: Emerging markets, which had previously benefited from rising commodity prices, are now facing losses as a global recession and China's Covid lockdowns sent raw-material prices tumbling 10% from an eight-year high. This decline has led to a reversal in the performance of commodity-exporting nations, with currencies and bonds of Brazil, Mexico, and South Africa experiencing significant losses. Experts warn that the losses will only deepen as policymakers prioritize taming inflation over economic growth, and investors are advised to be defensive on commodity currencies.

images.alt_text: A trader gestures as he use telephones on the trading floor outside the open outcry pit at the London Metal Exchange (LME) in London, U.K., on Tuesday, April 8, 2014. The London Metal Exchange, the world's largest industrial metals marketplace, wants to introduce an aluminum premium contract as early as the end of this year, said Chief Executive Officer Garry Jones. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Nutryfarm financial controller to resign about 4 months into the role
summary: NutryFarm International's financial controller and joint company secretary Yang Kai Leong will resign on July 31, 2022, to pursue other career opportunities. This move comes about 4 months after his appointment in April. Yang's departure follows the recent resignation of acting CFO Lim Boo Hiong due to health reasons and the impending departure of non-executive director Low Chin Parn Eric. Shares of NutryFarm have been voluntarily suspended since April due to financial issues.

site_title: UK retail sales fall as cost of living crisis hits food spending
summary: UK retail sales declined 0.5% in May, lower than expected, due to rising food prices and the cost of living crisis. The decline was driven by a 0.7% fall in food sales. Consumer confidence dropped to a record low, and economists warn of a poor July as inflation continues to erode consumer spending. The nation's cost of living crisis is taking a toll on the economy, with wages failing to keep pace with rising prices, leading to a more gloomy outlook than during the pandemic.

site_title: Afghanistan ends search for quake survivors; many without food,shelter as floods hamper relief effort
summary: Afghanistan has ended its search for survivors after a devastating 6.1 magnitude earthquake killed 1,000 people, injured 2,000, and destroyed 10,000 houses. Many survivors are left without food, shelter, and water, with rain exacerbating the situation. Relief efforts are being hampered by heavy rain and floods, and the Taliban government faces a huge logistical challenge in providing aid to those affected. International organizations, including the UN, have mobilized to help, but the country's isolation and limited air transport capacity are complicating the response.

images.alt_text: Wednesday’s quake was the deadliest in Afghanistan since 2002.

site_title: Tokyo: Tech helps Japanese shares rise after solid Wall Street gains
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 1.23% to 26,491.97, driven by tech stocks and the Bank of Japan's loose monetary policy. US futures climbed overnight, fueling the gains. Tech stocks, including Tokyo Electron and SoftBank Group, led the rise, while automotive stocks declined after recalls. The Nikkei posted a 2% weekly gain, but has fallen 2.9% so far this month.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was up 0.04 per cent, or 11.14 points, at 26,182.39 in early trade on Friday.

site_title: Crypto is not too big to fail, even with help from FTX
summary: Crypto exchange FTX has extended a $250 million credit line to struggling lending platform BlockFi, and $200 million to Voyager Digital, amid a recent collapse of the stablecoin market. Billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried, FTX's co-founder, has made these moves to help distressed peers, but critics argue it's a "sticking plaster" rather than a credible backstop. Despite Bankman-Fried's deep pockets, his wealth is largely tied up in crypto, and FTX's lack of regulation and risk controls raises concerns about its ability to withstand a broader market downturn.

images.alt_text: BlockFi recently acknowledged that it had to liquidate "a large client" that failed to meet its obligations on an overcollateralized margin loan without naming the customer.

site_title: Thailand relaxes mask rule to bolster pandemic-hit tourism
summary: Thailand has relaxed its mask rule, allowing people to wear masks voluntarily, as COVID-19 cases decline and the country seeks to boost tourism. The move comes ahead of the end of the "Thailand Pass" system, which required visitors to register and show proof of vaccination. The government aims to kickstart its stuttering economy, with tourism expected to increase after a two-year decline. Despite the relaxation, some public transport, such as Bangkok's metro, will still require mask-wearing.

images.alt_text: The measures to support energy prices and tourism came as Thai headline inflation hit a near 14-year high of 7.1 per cent in May, driven by rising oil prices.

site_title: Singapore factory output grows 13.8% in May as semiconductor production surges
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 13.8% in May, surpassing expectations, driven by a surge in semiconductor production. Electronics output jumped 33.6% year on year, while semiconductor output surged 45.7%. Other sectors that saw growth included aerospace, general manufacturing, and precision engineering. Biomedical manufacturing, however, declined for the third straight month. Economists attribute the strong performance to strong demand from 5G markets and data centers amid the global chip shortage, and expect this to boost second-quarter GDP growth.

images.alt_text: The aerospace segment expanded 24.2 per cent on the back of higher production of aircraft parts and more maintenance, repair and overhaul jobs from commercial airlines as a result of the lifting of border restrictions globally.
Container trucks plying the pier at Pasir Panjang terminal port in Singapore on Jun 6, 2022.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as recession talk tempers rate hike expectations
summary: Asia's stocks rose on Friday, following Wall Street's gains, as investors reassessed central bank moves to combat inflation amid recession fears. The possibility of a recession has tempered rate hike expectations, with sovereign bond yields declining. Oil prices also fell, with demand concerns driving them down. Analysts say speculation of a recession has helped push yields down, leading traders to scale back expectations for rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Asia fluctuated after a big sell-off Wednesday, with optimism at a premium among investors and analysts saying it is unlikely to improve anytime soon.

site_title: Qantas loses top candidate to replace CEO Alan Joyce
summary: Qantas has lost its top candidate to replace CEO Alan Joyce, with Gareth Evans, CEO of budget airline Jetstar, set to step down in December and leave in 2023. Evans, who worked at Qantas for 23 years, was in prime position to succeed Joyce, but the airline will appoint a new CEO for Jetstar soon. Joyce has agreed to stay on until the end of 2023.

site_title: UK Conservatives lose two by-elections, dealing blow to PM Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Conservative Party suffered two by-election defeats, dealing a significant blow to his leadership. The losses in traditionally Conservative areas in south-west England and northern England suggest the electoral coalition Johnson built in 2019 may be fracturing amid scandal and a cost-of-living crisis. Johnson faces intense pressure to resign after being fined for breaking Covid-19 lockdown rules and surviving a vote of confidence by Conservative lawmakers. The defeats mirror a growing loss of confidence in the party, with Labour and the Liberal Democrats gaining ground.

images.alt_text: XpertHR’s report followed a Bank of England business survey that showed employers surveyed in May were not planning a further acceleration in pay rates.

S&P Global's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), covering services and manufacturing firms, also showed companies raising pay and passing higher costs on to clients, a worry for the Bank of England (BOE).

site_title: SoftBank’s Son says Nasdaq listing most likely for chip designer Arm
summary: SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son has reiterated that the company is likely to list British chip designer Arm on the Nasdaq, despite no final decision being made. Son cited the US market's interest in Arm and the company's existing US listing as reasons for the potential move. The decision comes as SoftBank faces pressure from shareholders due to a record loss and falling stock prices. Son spent most of his presentation discussing Arm's business prospects, following the collapse of an agreed sale to Nvidia.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a SoftBank mobile shop in Tokyo on May 12, 2022. (Photo by Charly TRIBALLEAU / AFP)
British startups are flocking to the deeper pockets and higher valuations to be found in New York, while listings in the UK are at their slowest in more than a decade.

site_title: Barclays strikes deal to buy mortgage lender Kensington
summary: Barclays has struck a deal to acquire Kensington Mortgage Company for around £2.3 billion, expanding its reach in Britain's housing market. Kensington, a specialist lender for self-employed individuals, has been owned by private equity firms Blackstone and Sixth Street since 2014. The deal is expected to be funded from existing resources and will reduce Barclays' core capital ratio by 12 basis points. Barclays CEO Matt Hammerstein said the transaction reinforces the bank's commitment to the UK residential mortgage market, presenting an opportunity to broaden its product range and capabilities.

images.alt_text: Chinese insurance group Ping An — now in the news for its campaign to  break up HSBC — was one of Antony Jenkins' first investors, the result of a 2017 meeting between Jenkins and Jonathan Larsen, another former Citigroup executive.

site_title: Investment banking fees in Singapore grow 3.3% to US$451.3m in H1: Refinitiv
summary: Investment banking fees in Singapore increased 3.3% to US$451.3 million in the first half of 2022, according to Refinitiv. Advisory fees from completed mergers and acquisitions (M&A) rose 10.9% to US$171.7 million, while syndicated lending fees fell 6.3% to US$116.9 million. Equity capital markets underwriting fees grew 9.7% to US$77.8 million, while debt capital markets underwriting fees decreased 1.7% to US$85.0 million.

images.alt_text: Firms from China and Hong Kong have signed a record US$13.1 billion of such loans in 2022, surpassing the US$12.6 billion for all of last year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Conversely, the volume of sustainability-linked loans globally has declined.
