site_title: Mystery deepens over fate of Hong Kong's Jumbo Floating Restaurant
summary: Hong Kong's Jumbo Floating Restaurant remains a mystery after its owner sparked confusion over whether the financially struggling tourist attraction had actually sunk while being towed away from the city last week. The Marine Department initially reported that the vessel had capsized, but the company insists it had "capsized" not "sunk" and is still afloat. The restaurant had been closed since 2020 due to financial woes, with cumulative losses exceeding HK$100 million. Its fate remains uncertain as the Marine Department requests a report from the company.

images.alt_text: Jumbo floating restaurant capsized on Sunday (Jun 19) near the Paracel Islands after it "encountered adverse conditions" and began to take on water, Aberdeen Restaurant Enterprises announced in a statement.

site_title: Toyota, Subaru shares drop on recalls of their first EV models
summary: Toyota and Subaru shares dropped after recalling their first mass-produced electric vehicles, the bZ4X and Solterra, due to a risk of wheels coming loose. The recall affects 2,700 units of the bZ4X SUV and 2,600 units of the Solterra. Toyota has not yet decided on a fix and rollout timeline, citing the need to determine the cause. The recalls add to Toyota's production issues and criticism over its slow adoption of electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Toyota has recalled 2,700 of its bZ4X SUVs because of a danger that wheels could come loose.
Toyota held about 5.13 million shares of Uber in the fiscal year ended March, half the amount it reported the previous year, according to a securities filing on Thursday (Jun 23).

site_title: Crypto bridge Horizon hacked for US$100m
summary: A cryptocurrency bridge app called Horizon was hacked, resulting in a loss of approximately US$100 million. The hack occurred on Thursday morning, according to Harmony, the app's developer. This is the third major bridge hack this year, following a US$300 million theft from the Wormhole bridge in February. Harmony has begun working with authorities to identify the culprit and recover the stolen funds.

images.alt_text: MAS has awarded 3 more in-principle approvals for its much-coveted digital payment token licence.

site_title: Giant Australia-to-Singapore solar project targets 2024 build
summary: Sun Cable, a solar energy project backed by Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest, aims to export power from a giant solar and battery complex in northern Australia to Singapore via a 4,200 km high-voltage undersea cable. The A$30 billion project is expected to secure a final investment decision in early 2024, with construction beginning in 2024 and completion by 2029. It will produce 800 megawatts of electricity for northern Australia and meet 15% of Singapore's demand, with at least A$8 billion of investment needed in Australia.

site_title: Bank Indonesia continues to hold key rate, but slight tightening expected soon: analysts
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) has maintained its benchmark 7-day reverse repurchase rate at 3.5% for the 15th consecutive month, but analysts expect a slight tightening in the coming months amid mounting global pressures. Fitch Solutions predicts a 50 basis point increase to 4% by end-2022, while RHB forecasts a 4% policy rate by the later half of the year. Analysts attribute the delay to Indonesia's supported external position and commodity prices, but warn of potential inflation and real interest rate differentials shifting in favor of the US dollar, which could lead to rupiah volatility.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia will leave its key interest rate steady at 3.5 per cent on June 23 but over one-quarter of economists in a Reuters poll expect a rate rise to stem imported inflation from a weak rupiah currency as the US Federal Reserve tightens aggressively.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance at Friday’s open, mirroring Wall Street gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,106.01, mirroring US stock gains. The top traded counters included Keppel Reit, Jiutian Chemical, and Sembcorp Marine, with Singtel up 0.4% and DBS advancing 0.3%. European shares hit a 19% dip low, and Tokyo's market opened flat amid recession concerns.

images.alt_text: Del Monte's board has approved a final dividend of US$0.017 per share, about 42 per cent higher than the previous year’s dividend.

site_title: Gold set for second straight weekly drop on worries over big rate hikes
summary: Gold prices have dropped 0.9% this week, with a second straight weekly decline expected, due to worries over major central banks implementing big interest rate hikes to target inflation. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,824.72 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.2% to $1,825.90. A strong dollar and rising US bond yields have limited demand for gold, with the US Federal Reserve's commitment to reining in inflation seen as "unconditional."

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates and bond yields increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, which yields nothing.
Gold is often viewed as a hedge against inflation and a safe store of value during economic crises, like a recession.

site_title: Malaysia inflation rises to 2.8% in May, led by decade-high food inflation
summary: Malaysia's inflation rose to 2.8% in May, driven by a decade-high surge in food prices, with food and non-alcoholic beverages increasing 5.2% month-over-month. Food inflation reached 5.2%, the highest since November 2011, with meat prices surging 9.5% and chicken prices rising 13.4%. Experts predict the cost of living will continue to rise due to subsidies removal and supply chain disruptions, with the government introducing additional cash aid to alleviate the burden on low-income households.

images.alt_text: Higher food prices continue to fuel Malaysia's inflation with the country's consumer price index climbed 4.4 per cent in July this year, the highest since May last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.23 points or 0.23% to 1,434.28 at 9:15 am on Friday, driven by a 0.23% gain in the overall market. There were 176 gainers and 111 losers, with a trading volume of 175.30 million lots worth RM77.32 million.

site_title: Temasek-backed ShopBack raises US$80m led by Asia Partners
summary: ShopBack, a Temasek-backed shopping and rewards platform, has raised US$80 million in a Series F funding round led by Asia Partners, with participation from January Capital. The funding brings ShopBack's total capital raised to over US$230 million. Founded in 2014, ShopBack powers US$3.5 billion in annual sales for over 10,000 online and in-store merchant partners. The company aims to help users shop and save smarter in an inflationary economy with a recession looming.

images.alt_text: Host Vanessa Ho speaks with co-founder and CEO of ShopBack Joel Leong, who shares how the cashback start-up vies for a share of consumers’ wallets across the region.

site_title: Intel warns US lawmakers factory plans hinge on stalled chip Bill
summary: Intel's US$20 billion chipmaking hub in Ohio may be delayed due to stalled chip Bill, with CEO Pat Gelsinger warning that the company's plans hinge on its passage. Intel had planned a groundbreaking ceremony, but cancelled it, and may lower its ambitions without legislative help. Gelsinger urged lawmakers to pass the Chips Act before the August recess, saying the company wants to build 8-10 fabrication sites, not 2, and become a major tech hub. The legislation is crucial for Intel's domestic expansion plans ahead of the midterm elections.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start Friday’s session on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.83% on Friday, driven by a rally on Wall Street, and are set for a healthy week. The Hang Seng Index increased to 21,450.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. This follows a broader positive trend in global markets, with US stocks near record highs despite tariff threats.

images.alt_text: A woman passes a sign showing the numbers for the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong on May 30, 2022. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as recession worries weigh on commodities
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.11% to 6,521.1 points on Friday, weighed down by losses in local miners and energy stocks due to rising recession concerns and declining commodity prices. Energy stocks fell 2.5%, with Woodside Energy and Santos declining 3% and 3.1%, respectively. Mining stocks also fell 1.9% amid base metal price tumbles. However, shares in Vulcan Energy surged 24.6% after announcing Stellantis as its second-largest shareholder, while Qantas Airways rose 1.6% after reporting lower net debt and profit expectations.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.31 per cent higher at 6,528.4.

site_title: Binance scores Cristiano Ronaldo as partner for NFT push
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has partnered with soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo to create a series of NFT collections for sale on its platform. As part of a multi-year agreement, the two will collaborate to produce digital art and collectibles. The first NFT collection is expected to be released later this year, marking a push into the NFT market. This partnership aims to promote Binance's NFT platform and expand its presence in the mainstream market.

site_title: Sheng Siong, Japfa among winners from food inflation: analysts
summary: Analysts predict that food inflation will benefit companies that can pass on costs to consumers without affecting demand. Winners include Sheng Siong Group, Japfa, and Wilmar International, which are expected to benefit from tighter food supplies and higher gross margins. Companies like Charoen Pokphand Foods and GFPT are also identified as potential beneficiaries due to their strong demand and pricing power. However, some companies, such as Sats' food business and restaurant operators, may struggle with margin pressure and declining customers.

images.alt_text: Malaysia and Indonesia are beneficiaries from rising energy prices as it allows these countries to sustain “generous fuel subsidies” to cushion the negative effects of higher food prices.
Industry players said the Energy Efficiency Grant would mainly benefit new entrants and firms which have not bought new equipment for years.
Palm oil slumped further into a bear market, dropping about 9% on Monday and another 1.8% on Tuesday, as top shipper Indonesia ramps up shipments.

site_title: JB Foods to expand presence in Ivory Coast with initial investment of 60 million euros
summary: JB Foods is expanding its presence in the Ivory Coast with a 60 million euro initial investment, set to complete a new cocoa processing factory in Abidjan by Q4 2024. The factory will increase annual bean processing capabilities, enhance logistical management, and support 7,000 farmers. The company aims to build capacity and momentum for sustainable growth through direct cocoa sourcing and increased sustainability efforts. summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) plans to invest £1 billion (S$1.7 billion) over a decade to develop vaccines and new medicines against infectious diseases such as malaria, tuberculosis, HIV, and antibiotic resistance. The investment will focus on lower-income nations and will be measured by health impact, not financial returns. GSK aims to speed work on over 30 assets targeting 12 diseases, including the first-ever malaria vaccine and a TB vaccine candidate. The company also plans to double production of an adjuvant for the malaria shot to meet demand.

site_title: Toyota recalls 2,700 electric vehicles
summary: Toyota has recalled 2,700 of its bZ4X electric SUVs due to a potential issue with loose wheels. The affected vehicles were distributed to Europe, the US, Canada, and Japan. The recall was submitted to Japan's transportation ministry, with 2,200 in Europe, 260 in the US, 20 in Canada, and 110 in Japan. The cause of the issue is under investigation.

site_title: Apple says US Bill would make App Store less secure, but its critics aren't so sure
summary: Apple claims a US Bill aimed at cracking open the app-store market would make iPhones less secure, citing the potential for malware and scams. However, critics argue this is a defense of Apple's business model, as some lawmakers and large firms already bypass the App Store using approved tools. Apple has allowed exceptions to its strict controls, including sideloading for Congress and large firms, raising questions about its claims of security risks. Experts say the real issue is protecting Apple's monopoly power, with some lawmakers introducing legislation to open up mobile app stores and give users more choice.

site_title: Nike leaves Russia entirely following Ukraine invasion
summary: Nike is leaving the Russian market entirely after suspending operations in March following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company had over 100 stores in Russia and halted sales due to concerns over guaranteed product shipments. Nike will scale down operations over the coming months, prioritizing employee support. The decision marks a significant move by the world's largest athletic-wear maker to distance itself from the conflict.

site_title: BMW 216i Gran Coupe review: Baby BMW beats rising prices
summary: The BMW 216i Gran Coupe is now the cheapest four-door car from BMW in Singapore, priced at S$199,888 with Certificate Of Entitlement (COE). The compact car boasts a fashionably digital interior, virtual instruments, and a big touchscreen, but falls short on space in the back for three people. Despite its modest 109 horsepower, the 216i excels in handling corners and is a stylish option for those seeking a BMW without breaking the bank. With its low price and comparable features to the more expensive 218i model, the 216i may be the best choice for those looking for a compact luxury car.

site_title: Rolex and Patek returns beat vintage cars and Bitcoin
summary: The luxury watch market experienced a significant price surge in 2022, with some Rolex, Patek Philippe, and Audemars Piguet references doubling or tripling in value. However, the market has since stabilized, with the Subdial50 index declining 6% in the past 30 days. Prices for vintage cars and cryptocurrencies have also declined, while the S&P 500 is poised for its worst first half since 1970. The surge was driven by new buyers entering the market, but as interest rates rise and tech stocks decline, some speculators are selling their timepieces, bringing prices back to more "sensible" levels.

site_title: Euro struggles to hang onto US$1.05 on gloomy PMIs
summary: The euro weakened 0.6% to US$1.0498 against the US dollar, its third decline below US$1.05 this week, following disappointing German and French PMI data that showed the euro zone economy struggling. The data prompted traders to trim bets on big interest rate hikes from the European Central Bank, with money markets pricing in about 30 basis points of rate hikes in July. Fed chair Jerome Powell's cautious comments on a recession also weighed on sentiment, sending the US dollar into positive territory against its rivals.

site_title: Instagram tests new tools for age verification
summary: Instagram is testing two new age verification methods for users in the US, in addition to allowing them to upload identity proof online. The methods include a video selfie verification with Yoti's technology, which estimates age based on facial features, and a mutual follower verification option, where a user must be at least 18 years old to vouch for their age. The move comes after Instagram paused the launch of Instagram Kids last year due to safety concerns and criticism from lawmakers and advocacy groups.

site_title: Companies weak in ESG more likely to be hit with scandals and lose market value: Moody’s
summary: Moody's Analytics found that companies with weak ESG records are more likely to face scandals and controversies, leading to short-term and long-term stock market losses. Moderate to severe ESG events can result in losses of 1.3-7.5% over 12 months. Companies involved in social controversies, such as child labor, suffer large and statistically significant losses, while those with environmental or governance-related scandals experience smaller losses. Companies with improved ESG policies and risk management culture are less likely to be hit by similar controversies again.

site_title: Toyota halved stake in Uber following self-driving unit sale
summary: Toyota has sold half of its Uber shares, reducing its stake from 5.13 million shares to 2.57 million, valued at $226 million. The sale follows Uber's separation of its self-driving division to Aurora Innovation. Toyota initially invested in Uber in 2016, with the goal of exploring autonomous driving technology. Despite the sale, Toyota maintains a good relationship with Uber and is open to future collaborations. Toyota now holds 47.6 million shares of Aurora, worth about $32.4 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's consumer prices rose 5.6% in May, up from 5.4% in April, with food inflation at 4.5% and a broader-based increase in consumer prices. This marks the 12th consecutive month of inflation in the country.

site_title: Macau keeps casinos open as bars, cinemas shut to tame virus
summary: Macau's government has implemented restrictions to combat its worst-ever Covid-19 outbreak, keeping casinos open but shutting bars, cinemas, gyms, and hair salons. The city has already shut schools and public venues, with mass testing underway to identify community transmission. Macau's casinos will remain open, but individual closures may occur if a case is found. The city's chief executive, Ho Iat Seng, cited concerns about the livelihood of casino workers and the need to maintain control over the industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.05 points to 1,431.05. The country traded 2.345 billion lots worth RM1.560 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 500 to 348.

site_title: Philippines abandons joint energy exploration talks with China
summary: The Philippines has abandoned joint energy exploration talks with China in the South China Sea, citing constitutional constraints and issues of sovereignty. Foreign Minister Teodoro Locsin said the talks, which were initiated in 2018, could not be pursued without violating the Philippine constitution or China's government renouncing its claims. The decision comes after three years of negotiations, during which the Philippines relied on fuel imports and sought partners to exploit its offshore energy reserves without compromising its sovereignty. The talks were terminated by outgoing President Rodrigo Duterte.

site_title: Air transport : Cap emissions, not growth
summary: The air transport industry has made significant progress in fuel efficiency, despite growing demand, through business-as-usual transformations in infrastructure and operations. Advances in lightweight materials, operational changes, and design enhancements have reduced fuel consumption and carbon emissions. The industry has been a pioneer in sustainability, with innovations such as biodegradable inflight products. These efforts demonstrate the industry's ability to balance growth with environmental responsibility, and it can be proud of its progress in reducing carbon abatement.

site_title: Analysts see rising risk of off-cycle central bank tightening as Singapore core inflation climbs
summary: Analysts predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may tighten policy settings earlier than expected due to rising core inflation, which reached 3.6% in May. The MAS is expected to steepen the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) in October, but some analysts believe it may do so even earlier, potentially as early as late July, if June's core inflation prints exceed 4.4%. This tightening could be driven by global supply chain bottlenecks and rising energy prices, with the MAS aiming to curb inflation.

site_title: Skoda Kodiaq RS review: Running a quick Czech
summary: The Skoda Kodiaq RS is a practical 7-seater SUV that combines a powerful 245 horsepower engine with a spacious body, making it suitable for those who prioritize utility over prestige. The car offers numerous features, including a panoramic glass roof, ventilated front seats, and adaptive cruise control. Although it may not be the fastest car, the Kodiaq RS handles predictably and securely, and its true strengths lie in its utility and practicality. With a price tag of S$285,900, the Kodiaq RS may be a worthwhile investment for those seeking a capable and feature-rich SUV.

site_title: India says will support crisis-hit Sri Lanka's economic recovery
summary: India's Foreign Secretary Vinay Kwatra held talks with Sri Lanka's President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, signaling India's willingness to provide additional support beyond its existing $4 billion in loans, swaps, and aid. Sri Lanka needs $5 billion in the next 6 months to cover basic necessities for its 22 million people, who are struggling with long queues, shortages, and power cuts. India aims to help Sri Lanka's quick economic recovery through investments, connectivity, and strengthening economic linkages.

site_title: SBF re-elects chairman Lim Ming Yan, welcomes 8 new council members
summary: SINGAPORE Business Federation (SBF) chairman Lim Ming Yan has been re-elected for a second term following the organization's 20th annual general meeting (AGM) on June 23. Eight new members, including representatives from trade associations and chambers, were also appointed to the 26-member council for the 2022-2024 term. Lim expressed gratitude for the support of past and present council members, business leaders, and industry partners, and vowed to work closely with the new council to address the evolving business landscape.

site_title: Leases starting to reflect fair tenancy code of conduct, but tenants still call for legislation
summary: Singapore's year-old fair tenancy code of conduct (COC) is being adopted by major landlords and government landlords, but smaller landlords and businesses are slower to follow. At least 8 major private sector retail landlords and all government landlords have committed to the COC, which came into effect in June 2021. However, industry players still call for legislation to enforce the code, citing concerns over the potential abuse of mutually-agreed deviations and the need for clear consequences for non-compliance. The government plans to make the COC mandatory via legislation this year, with the aim of strengthening relationships between tenants and landlords.

site_title: Fired Barclays CEO turns £1m into £600m startup
summary: Antony Jenkins, the former Barclays CEO, has turned £1m into £600m with his fintech startup 10x Banking Technology, which aims to provide technology behind global banking services. The company, backed by JPMorgan Chase, Blackrock, and Ping An Insurance Group, has raised £133m in funding, valuing it at £600m. Jenkins' ambitious goal is to serve 1 billion people with the technology, citing examples of corporate giants like Kodak and Blockbuster that were destroyed by startups. Despite competition, 10x has secured clients like JPMorgan and Westpac, and is considering partnerships with Ping An Bank.

site_title: UK hit by second rail strike in week of industrial action
summary: The UK's rail system experienced a second day of widespread strike action, with thousands of rail workers protesting over pay and working conditions. The RMT union claims wages have failed to keep pace with UK inflation, which has hit a 40-year high. Only a fifth of services operated, with many commutes disrupted. A third day of strikes is planned for Saturday, echoing the 1970s' stagflation period. Talks to avert the work stoppages have failed, with the government backing railway bosses' calls for modernization and greater flexibility.

site_title: US recession fears darken outlook for global factories
summary: Global factory growth is slowing due to supply chain disruptions from China's Covid-19 curbs and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and rising risk of a US recession. Demand for manufactured goods in the eurozone fell at the fastest rate since May 2020, with S&P Global's PMI falling to a near 2-year low. Japan's factory activity growth also slowed to a 4-month low, while other economies in Asia face headwinds amid growing risks. The global macroeconomic outlook has deteriorated, with Fitch Ratings slashing its global growth outlook to 2.9% and warning of the risk of stagflation, characterized by persistent high inflation and weak demand.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS expects Mercatus deal to support capital values for suburban retail malls
summary: DBS Group Research expects the potential sale of Mercatus Co-operative's stakes in AMK Hub, Jurong Point, Nex, and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza to support capital values for suburban retail malls in Singapore. The sale is estimated to be in excess of S$4 billion. DBS analysts predict that Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit will benefit from the sale, with "buy" calls on both counters. The potential sale could set a new record low for retail mall transactions based on its estimated net property income yield.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat amid cautious sentiment over Powell remarks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat, closing 0.02% higher at 3,092.8 points, despite Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's remarks on the possibility of a recession. The markets were cautious, with regional peers ending higher or flat, and local banks closing lower. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) and property stocks were among the best performers, with Mapletree Industrial Trust and Keppel DC Reit gaining 2.4% and 2.1% respectively. The STI has closed in the 3,090s for the fifth time in six sessions, with net institutional inflows totaling S$200 million.

site_title: BlackRock plans Singapore expansion with dozens more employees
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to expand its Singapore office with dozens of new employees. The firm aims to double its floorspace and add staff from local hiring and relocations from Hong Kong. As part of the expansion, around 30 staff will move to Singapore and at least 10 staff are expected to relocate from Hong Kong. The move reflects the trend of global firms considering a presence in Singapore due to its low taxes, stability, and developed financial systems, making it an attractive hub for finance professionals.

site_title: UK debt repayments soar on high inflation: data
summary: UK interest repayments on government debt soared to £7.6 billion in May, a 70% increase from the previous year, due to high inflation. This is the third highest amount on record and the highest for the month of May. The Office for National Statistics attributes the increase to higher inflation, which has reached 9.1% in May, the highest level in 40 years. The UK's net borrowing fell to £14 billion, but the government faces the prospect of recession due to the expected annual inflation rate of 11% by the end of the year.

site_title: India's Tata Motors investigates EV fire incident
summary: Tata Motors, India's largest electric vehicle manufacturer, is investigating an "isolated thermal incident" involving one of its electric cars, which caught fire in a suburb of Mumbai. The incident is believed to be the first of its kind for the company, which has sold over 30,000 electric vehicles, mostly its Nexon model. The investigation comes amid a spate of e-scooter fires that have triggered a government probe, with initial findings pointing to faulty battery cells and modules as the cause.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall over 1% after Fed chief’s comment; won hits 13-year low
summary: South Korean shares fell over 1% on Thursday, closing at a 13-year low, after US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged the possibility of a recession. The benchmark Kospi ended down 28.49 points, with the Korean won weakening below 1,300 per dollar for the first time since July 2009. Authorities vowed to minimize the impact on the economy and stabilize the foreign exchange market if necessary.

site_title: Record numbers of Chinese graduates enter worst job market in decades
summary: China is facing its worst job market in decades as a record 10.8 million university graduates enter the market this summer, with youth unemployment rates exceeding 18.4%. The tech sector, a significant employer of graduates, is trimming its workforce due to regulatory crackdowns and Covid-19 headwinds. Companies are offering subsidies and cheap loans to boost employment, but expected salaries are 6.2% lower, and new hiring is slow. The situation is particularly concerning for the Communist Party, as it challenges the social contract between the government and the people, and may lead to long-term social and economic consequences.

site_title: The man who helped create Singapore’s housing boom is getting worried
summary: Singapore's housing model, created by architect Liu Thai Ker, has come under scrutiny due to soaring property prices and concerns about growing inequality. Liu, who designed modern Singapore's housing, oversaw the development of over 500,000 public housing units and created a system that allows citizens to buy government-built apartments at a discount. However, the model has become a business venture, and Liu worries that it may compromise social mobility. He proposes maintaining a steady housing price increase and building highly self-sufficient new towns to ensure a sustainable housing model.

summary: London's Heathrow airport has revised its 2022 passenger forecast to 54.4 million, an increase from its previous estimate of 53 million. site_title: Rice and spice at The Coconut Club
summary: The Coconut Club, a popular nasi lemak eatery, has revamped its space and menu with a new 2-storey location in Beach Road. The restaurant serves a variety of dishes, including the signature ayam goreng berempah, which is a succulent, juicy, and deep-fried chicken dish. site_title: East-West design harmony
summary: A Singaporean couple purchased a 4,187 sq ft semi-detached home in Victoria Park Villas, a leasehold landed enclave off Bukit Timah Road, developed by CapitaLand. The couple, who have lived in Singapore for 40 years, wanted the home to be designed in a Barbara Barry style, characterized by feminine and elegant interiors. site_title: Fighting inflation : Scapegoating specific sectors won’t help
summary: US President Joe Biden's efforts to combat inflation have been misguided, with scapegoating specific sectors such as oil companies and shipping conglomerates not addressing the root cause of the issue. The root cause is the mismatch between consumer savings during the pandemic and slow supply increases. The administration's actions, including waiving environmental rules to increase ethanol production and tariffs on solar panels, have actually added to inflationary pressures and undermined its climate objectives. Relaxing the Jones Act and increasing foreign worker permits could help reduce costs and alleviate shortages, but these options have not been explored.

site_title: Macquarie in talks to acquire Kuwaiti lessor Alafco: sources
summary: Macquarie Group is in talks to acquire Kuwaiti plane leasing firm Alafco Aviation Lease & Finance, with a potential agreement expected within the next few weeks. Alafco shares rose 6.6% on the news, valuing the company at around $600 million. The acquisition would come as aircraft lessors seek to gain scale amid airline financing needs, following deals by AerCap and General Electric. Alafco has lease agreements with carriers including Aegean, Malaysia Airlines, and SAS, and its largest shareholders are Kuwait Finance House and Gulf Investment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall further at open
summary: Europe's stock markets fell at the open on June 23, 2022, as fears of a global recession intensified due to surging inflation and interest-rate rises. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.5%, while Frankfurt's DAX index fell 0.3% and the Paris CAC 40 lost 0.4%. The losses were attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade tensions also in focus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish higher
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.26% to 21,273.87, driven by bargain buyers following a tech sector sell-off. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.62% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumping 2.08%. The gains were attributed to hopes that China is easing its crackdown on the tech sector.

site_title: Bank Indonesia holds key rate steady to support economy
summary: Bank Indonesia held its 7-day reverse repurchase rate steady at 3.5% to support the economy, defying expectations of a 25 basis-point hike. The move maintains a record low interest rate and aligns with the central bank's goal to manage price pressures through state subsidies and reserve requirements. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that inflation will rise but remains manageable, with consumer prices expected to return to target next year. The decision sets Indonesia apart from regional central banks raising borrowing costs to combat inflation.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end little changed; recession fears stoke volatility
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average closed flat on Thursday, trading above the psychological 26,000 mark after a volatile day. The Nikkei rose 0.08% to 26,171.25, while the Topix index fell 0.05% to 1,851.74. Investors weighed recession fears against the Bank of Japan's unchanged monetary policy. Toshiba shares surged 3.54% after a potential takeover offer, while utilities led the Nikkei's best-performing sectors.

site_title: UK economy 'running on empty' as recession signals mount: PMI
summary: The UK economy is experiencing signs of stalling, with high inflation hitting new orders and businesses reporting concern levels that signal a recession. S&P Global's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) held steady at 53.1 in June, above the median forecast of 52.6. Companies are raising pay and passing higher costs to clients, a worry for the Bank of England. This development comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Rishi Starmer.

site_title: China's CATL to produce next-generation EV battery in 2023
summary: China's CATL will start mass-producing its next-generation EV battery, Qilin, in 2023, boosting its volume utilisation rate to 72%, the world's highest. The new battery increases energy density to 255 Wh/kg and is expected to extend electric car driving distances. CATL, the world's largest battery maker, aims to retain its top position amidst competition from rivals like BYD and Tesla. The company has not disclosed any orders for the new battery, but it's expected to supply cylindrical cells to BMW starting in 2025.

site_title: Uber is said to have explored a sale of Indian ride-hailing arm
summary: Uber explored a sale of its Indian ride-hailing arm, considering a stock swap with local companies or a pullout, but suspended discussions after tech startup valuations plummeted. The move came as the company recognized limited potential for profitable expansion in the country. Uber had been struggling to eke out a profit in India, where it competed with local rival Ola. The company disputed reports, stating it has never considered exiting India, but acknowledged it would consider alternative options.

site_title: Samsung Australia fined A$14m over false water-resistance claims
summary: Samsung Australia has been fined A$14 million by the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) for misleading buyers of its 'Galaxy' phones about the water-resistance level. The company made claims that its phones could be used in pools or seawater, but received hundreds of complaints from users saying the smartphones did not function properly after exposure to water. Samsung admitted to the misleading claims, which may have influenced the purchasing decisions of many consumers.

summary: Global bond yields have dropped to multi-year lows as recession fears and high interest rates prompt investors to seek safe-haven debt. US 10-year yields fell 3 basis points to 3.13%, while Australian and New Zealand yields also declined. The drop is attributed to growing concerns about the US economy and the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes, which may push the US into recession. Investors are betting that recessionary risks outweigh inflation risks, leading to a reversal in central-bank rate hikes.

summary: The Philippine central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 2.5% for a second consecutive meeting, amid accelerating inflation and a slumping peso. site_title: Australia: Shares rebound on boost from banks, tech
summary: Australian equities rose 0.59% to 6,546.7, driven by gains in financial and tech stocks, while losses in mining and energy shares were outweighed. Recession worries halting bond yield growth alleviated concerns about share market valuations.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.23 per cent lower at 6,508.5, declining for an eighth session in 9.

site_title: Twitter tests long-form text feature called 'Notes'
summary: Twitter is testing a new feature called "Notes" that allows users to share essay-like write-ups as a link on and off the platform. The feature, being tested by a small group of writers, is part of Twitter Write and includes the newsletter firm Revue. This comes as Twitter prepares for a US$44 billion buyout by Elon Musk, its new CEO. The "Notes" feature is the latest in a series of updates, following the introduction of a new edit feature in April. Twitter has not yet announced a wider roll-out of the feature.

site_title: World's biggest dairy exporter forecasts record milk prices
summary: Fonterra Cooperative Group, the world's biggest dairy exporter, has forecast a record milk price of NZ$9.50 (S$8.26) per kilogramme of milksolids for the new season, up 50 NZ cents from its previous forecast. This would be the highest price the company has ever paid to its 10,000 New Zealand farmer shareholders. The forecast also includes earnings guidance of 30-45 NZ cents per share for FY23, up from 25-35 US cents for the current year. The company attributes the forecast to strong global demand and a weaker New Zealand dollar.

images.alt_text: Milk bottles in crates wait in chiller waits to be loaded up at a Fonterra Factory in Takanini South Auckland , North Island of New Zealand Tue 7th Oct  2009 ,Photographer Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg News      in Auckland, New Zealand, on Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2009. Fonterra Cooperative Group Ltd., the world's largest dairy exporter, said increased demand from Middle East, African and South-east Asian buyers helped push whole milk powder prices to a 13-month high this month. Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg

site_title: A generation gap in ESG investing in Singapore
summary: A survey by Amundi and The Business Times found that Generation Z investors in Singapore are more likely to hold sustainability investments, with 82% of Gen Z investors (21-24 years old) making such investments, compared to 41% of Gen X and baby-boomer investors. Gen Z investors are also more concerned about social issues, citing global poverty and inequalities as top concerns. The survey, which polled 1,046 respondents, suggests that younger investors are driving the trend towards ESG investing and are more likely to consider social and environmental factors when making investment decisions.

images.alt_text: A generation gap - that’s what The Business Times - Amundi ESG Investing Report found when it comes to attitudes and actions towards sustainable investing. But while younger investors pay more attention to environmental, social and governance (ESG) issues, the survey also found that baby boomers plan to jump on this rising tide.
The floating solar solar photovoltaic (PV) testbed at Tengeh Reservoir on Dec 18, 2020.
AS criticism of the efficacy of ESG investing mounts over its acute susceptibility to greenwashing, one category has remained largely immune to calls for stricter regulation: clean-energy funds.

site_title: Tesla plans 2-week suspension of most Shanghai production for upgrade: memo
summary: Tesla plans to suspend most production at its Shanghai plant for two weeks in July to upgrade the site. After the upgrade, the company aims to increase output to a new record high by the end of July, targeting 22,000 cars per week. This move comes after a two-month Covid lockdown in Shanghai delayed production goals. Tesla's Shanghai factory currently produces 17,000 units of Model 3 and Model Y cars per week.

site_title: Limited edition of Citroen's mini EV sells out in under 18 minutes
summary: Citroen's limited edition mini electric car, the My Ami Buggy, sold out in under 18 minutes, with the fastest customer completing the purchase in 2 minutes and 53 seconds. The car, priced at 9,790 euros, is part of the brand's 22,000 Ami electric models sold since its launch in April 2020. The sale was a cheeky jab at Elon Musk, who has made high-profile bids for Twitter and other companies. The car is produced in Morocco and requires no driving license, sold exclusively online.

site_title: Dream big, start small: Investing in the future of food
summary: Singapore's food manufacturing industry is thriving, with over 1,000 companies producing various products. The country has emerged as the "Silicon Valley of food" in Asia, promoting innovation in novel foods such as alternative proteins. Singapore was the first country to approve lab-grown chicken in 2020. The government aims to support the industry through shared facilities like FoodPlant, which allows companies to produce small-batch food without significant investments. This approach enables innovation and growth in the sector.

images.alt_text: FoodPlant's general processing room, with the multi-function jacketed cooker.

site_title: Facilitating the expansion dream
summary: Epitex International, a Singapore-based bedlinen and bedding accessories company, expanded into Malaysia despite the COVID-19 pandemic due to the downtime providing an opportunity to plan for regionalization. The company turned to the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) for resources and support, which facilitated the setting up of a local office and provided valuable insights for market entry strategies. Today, Epitex has established an e-commerce team and logistics system in Malaysia and plans to venture into other regional markets, including Vietnam, Thailand, and the Philippines, with a focus on supply chain sustainability and social responsibility.

images.alt_text: SBF calls for 3-month extension of Jobs Support Scheme in Budget 2022 wishlist

site_title: Amazon has a plan to make Alexa mimic anyone's voice
summary: Amazon is developing a system to let Alexa mimic any voice after hearing less than a minute of audio. The goal is to "make the memories last" for customers who have lost loved ones, particularly during the pandemic. The feature will allow users to upload a voice clip, and Alexa will learn to mimic it. Amazon declined to share a release date for the feature.

images.alt_text: The famous family signed its first podcast deal with Spotify Technology in 2019.

site_title: As cyber threats rise, more SMEs going all out to protect their operations and clients
summary: A new Cyber Essentials certification programme launched in March aims to recognize SMEs with good cyber hygiene practices to protect against common cyber-attacks. The certification, launched by the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore, targets SMEs and commends those that have implemented good cyber hygiene practices to protect operations and clients. This move follows increasing digitalization and the growing importance of cybersecurity for businesses of all sizes. The certification aims to enhance awareness and implement better measures to protect against cyber threats.

images.alt_text: Almost 70 per cent - or S$2.6 billion - of the government’s infocommunications technology spending in FY2022 will go towards building new applications and upgrading existing ones, GovTech said.

site_title: US urges countries to reach out if having issues with Russian food, fertiliser exports
summary: The US is urging countries to reach out if they have issues importing Russian food and fertiliser, citing concerns about "so-called over compliance with sanctions". The US State Department's Assistant Secretary, Ramin Toloui, said that US sanctions do not apply to these goods. The US is supporting a UN-led effort to broker a deal allowing Russia to export grain and Ukraine to export grain from the Black Sea port of Odesa, aiming to mitigate the global food crisis sparked by Russia's war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The European Union will temporarily shift back to coal to cope with dwindling Russian gas flows without derailing longer term climate goals, an EU official said on Wednesday as a tight gas market and soaring prices set off a race for alternative fuels.
Jokowi will meet Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, having previously invited both to attend the G-20 summit on the island of Bali.

A surge in demand from Asia for discounted Russian oil is making up for the sharply lower number of barrels being sold to Europe, dulling the effects of the West’s efforts to punish Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine .

site_title: Qatar Stock Exchange plans short selling, draw listings
summary: Qatar's stock exchange plans to introduce short selling, securities lending, and borrowing, as well as derivatives, to attract more investors and boost valuations. The moves are part of a larger strategy to increase liquidity and are expected to be introduced in the next quarter. Smaller listings are also lined up for this year, with larger IPOs potentially in 2023. Foreign investor interest has surged, with demand for Qatari gas increasing following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and climate-focused investors are also being targeted.

images.alt_text: Dubai stock volumes dry up ahead of planned rush of listings

site_title: Supporting businesses over the years
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has been providing crucial support to businesses in Singapore, including trade missions, business networking sessions, and training courses. Companies such as Almarc Engineering, Allied eParts, and Completion Products have benefited from SBF's Industry 4.0 Human Capital Initiative and other programs, which have helped them navigate challenges like digitalization and talent management. SBF's support has enabled businesses to expand into new markets, adopt Industry 4.0 solutions, and improve operational efficiency, ultimately positioning them for future growth and success.

site_title: US hopes for positive Sweden, Finland Nato bid resolution
summary: The US is hopeful for a positive resolution in the issue between Turkey, Finland, and Sweden regarding their NATO accession bids, according to US Assistant Secretary for Europe and Eurasian Affairs Karen Donfried. The talks between the parties earlier this week were constructive, and the US is pushing for a resolution by the NATO summit on June 29-30. Turkey's opposition to the bids stems from its concerns over Finland and Sweden's support for Kurdish militants and arms embargoes on Ankara, but Donfried expressed confidence that the issue will be resolved in a positive way.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Joe Biden delivers remarks next to Sweden's Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson and Finland's President Sauli Niinisto, in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington.

site_title: The inflation blame game
summary: The US is experiencing a toxic politics of inflation, with the Federal Reserve and government attributing its causes to different factors. The Fed blames rising demand and supply, while the Biden administration attributes it to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Republicans, however, point to the stimulus policies as the main cause. The article argues that the true culprit is lockdowns, which led to pent-up demand and disrupted supply chains. This explanation is overlooked in partisan politics, with a focus on corporate greed or the war in Ukraine. A balanced understanding of inflation's causes is crucial to taming it.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that a US recession “is not inevitable” despite aggressive interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve to cool demand – moves that have prompted more economists to forecast a recession by 2023.

site_title: The next step for K-pop companies is diversification
summary: Shares of South Korean entertainment company Hybe Corporation plummeted $1.7 billion after members of K-pop sensation BTS announced a hiatus to focus on individual projects. This follows similar problems with YG Entertainment, another South Korean-listed entertainment company, due to speculations about its boy band Big Bang's disbandment. To diversify, companies like Hybe and YG are expanding into adjacent industries, including gaming, music labels, and cosmetics. While artistes still generate significant revenue, diversification may help sustain income in the longer run.

images.alt_text: Superstar pop band BTS’s announcement of a hiatus is the latest bad news to hit the nation’s entertainment sector, causing a 25 per cent plunge in the shares of its managing agency Hybe on Wednesday (Jun 15).
The singers said the time apart would be healthy for the band and urged fans not to view the development as negative.
Members of the K-Pop band BTS makes statements against anti-Asian hate crimes and for inclusion and representation during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, May 31, 2022.

site_title: JPMorgan lays off hundreds in mortgage business after rate surge
summary: JPMorgan Chase is laying off hundreds of home-lending employees due to rapidly rising mortgage rates, which have more than doubled from their record low in January 2021. The bank will also reassign hundreds more to other divisions. The move is part of a broader trend, with firms like Compass and Redfin also cutting jobs as the US housing market cools. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike is cited as a major factor, with the bank stating that cyclical changes in the mortgage market prompted the staffing decision. Over 1,000 workers will be affected.

site_title: Electric vehicles could take 33% of global sales by 2028: AlixPartners
summary: AlixPartners predicts electric vehicle sales will reach 33% of global sales by 2028 and 54% by 2035, up from less than 8% in 2022. Automakers and suppliers plan to invest at least $526 billion in EVs and batteries from 2022-2026, more than double the 5-year forecast of $234 billion. This acceleration in demand is driven by growth in most major markets, with the need for increased investment to support the increasing demand.

images.alt_text: The logo of an electric car is painted on the road during the opening ceremony of the first Latin American public charging station, at Santiago, April 20, 2011. REUTERS/Ivan Alvarado

site_title: World Cup officials target 'price-gouging' as 1.2m tickets sold
summary: Qatar's World Cup chief organiser Hassan Al-Thawadi announced that 1.2 million tickets have been sold for the November-December tournament, with about 40 million ticket requests received. The event is expected to draw a huge influx of visitors, putting pressure on infrastructure, but officials are working to limit "price-gouging" as accommodation costs soar. FIFA president Gianni Infantino assured that there will be enough accommodation, including glamping options, and that fans will be allowed to enter the country only with match tickets.

site_title: The bridge over troubled water
summary: The Singapore government implemented a circuit breaker in 2020, severely impacting the food and beverage (F&B) industry. Landlords and tenants faced challenges, with rentals proving rigid and immovable, leading to tensions. However, the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) facilitated a collective approach, helping to establish a Code of Conduct for Leasing of Retail Premises (CoC) to make lease negotiations fairer and more balanced. The Fair Tenancy Industry Committee (FTIC) was formed, and the SBF played a crucial role in rebuilding trust and refreshing the symbiotic relationship between landlords and tenants.

images.alt_text: Heritage food and beverage (F&B) brand Ka-Soh will close its flagship Outram outlet on Jun 26, after operating in the location for around 20 years.

site_title: Enabling the green economy
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has launched the Alliance for Action on Sustainable Spaces (AfA) to promote the use of low-emitting materials and furnishings in indoor spaces. In partnership with the Singapore Green Building Council (SGBC) and the Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC), the alliance aims to reduce formaldehyde emissions and improve occupant health. The initiative has resulted in 75 pledge organizations committing to practices that reduce formaldehyde use in their products, with the goal of creating healthier, more equitable, and environmentally friendly spaces.

images.alt_text: Smart buildings could have a competitive advantage, which could lead to retaining tenants longer and reducing letting voids for landlords, according to CBRE’s co-head of office services and occupier, David McKellar.

site_title: Google agrees to pay for Wikipedia content
summary: Google has agreed to pay Wikipedia for content displayed by its search engine, marking the first time a tech giant has paid for Wikipedia content. The Wikimedia Foundation, which oversees the online encyclopedia, launched a commercial venture called Wikimedia Enterprise last year. Google will pay for content used in its "knowledge panel" sidebar, which sources information from Wikipedia without always showing the source. The agreement does not affect individual users' access to Wikipedia, and the Internet Archive will receive the commercial services for free.

site_title: US consumer watchdog issues review of 'excessive' credit card fees
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has unveiled a measure to scrutinize excessive credit card fees, demanding card issuers disclose more data on revenue and expenses to stamp out abuses and boost competition. The advanced notice of proposed rulemaking assesses whether such fees are "reasonable and proportional" and their potential deterrent effect. The review aims to curb "junk fees" including late-payment fees, overdraft charges, and bounced cheque fees.

images.alt_text: AmEx added 3 million new proprietary cards, with US Consumer Platinum and Gold card and US Business Platinum card customer acquisitions reaching all-time highs in the quarter.

site_title: EU Parliament backs carbon market reform
summary: The European Parliament has backed a reform of the EU's carbon market, with 439 MEPs voting in favour of negotiations with member states to expand the Emissions Trading System (ETS) to include carbon from transport and construction. The compromise also includes a gradual phase-out of industry exemptions and a carbon tax on imports at EU borders from 2027. The vote reverses a previous rejection of a key part of the bloc's climate plan, with the EU aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 55% by 2030.

site_title: Employees of Katrina Group subsidiary under investigation by URA
summary: Employees of Katrina Group's subsidiary, ST Hospitality, are assisting in an investigation by the URA regarding possible breaches of minimum stay requirements in short-term accommodations. No charges have been filed against the group or individuals involved. The investigation is ongoing, and the company will make further announcements as needed. The announcement led to a 16.4% drop in Katrina Group's shares.

site_title: DBS clears the air about CEO compensation, reiterates stakeholder capitalism
summary: DBS Bank CEO Piyush Gupta's total compensation rose 48% in 2021, a normalization after a 2020 pay reduction. This increase reflects his role in leading the bank to a record FY2021 performance. DBS emphasizes its commitment to stakeholder capitalism, citing support for customers during the pandemic, job creation, and community aid. The bank also highlighted its additional $100 million commitment to DBS Foundation in early 2022.

site_title: ESG investing: How young investors are leading the way
summary: Younger investors in Singapore prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, with a generation gap found between younger and older investors. Despite this, Gen X and baby boomers are also embracing ESG investing. The report highlights the growing trend of ESG investing, with Singapore aiming to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by 2025. Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reached $46 billion in 2025, and the country is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines. This trend is expected to accelerate, with sustainable finance becoming a significant aspect of the industry.

site_title: Staying responsive to members’ needs key to SBF’s continued relevance: CEO
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) CEO Lam Yi Young emphasizes the importance of remaining responsive to members' changing needs to stay relevant. Established in 2002, SBF aims to champion the interests of the Singapore business community in areas such as trade, investment, and industrial relations. CEO Lam attributes SBF's positive responses from members and the wider business community to its adaptability and commitment to meeting evolving needs.

images.alt_text: fcsbfceo23 - Lam Yi Young, CEO of Singapore Business Federation

site_title: PropertyBT: Singapore strata office and shop lots - gems or duds? (Ep 8)
summary: Investing in strata commercial spaces in Singapore may pay off due to lower transaction costs. However, owning strata commercial property comes with challenges, such as managing shared expenses and navigating complex regulations. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's ban on strata subdivision of commercial properties in certain locations may impact the market. Experts warn that strata ownership of commercial property may be slowly dying due to restrictions and high transaction costs.

site_title: EU signals shift to coal, accuses Russia of 'rogue moves' on gas
summary: The European Union is considering temporarily shifting back to coal to cope with dwindling Russian gas flows, amid a tight gas market and soaring prices. This move is aimed at meeting energy demands without derailing longer-term climate goals. European leaders have criticized Russia for cutting gas supplies through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to 40% capacity, exacerbating the energy standoff following Ukraine's invasion. The EU must balance energy security with climate goals, with the International Energy Agency urging a replacement of Russian energy supplies and boosting efficiency and renewables.

images.alt_text: Germany faces certain recession if already faltering Russian gas supplies stop completely, an industry body warned on Tuesday.

site_title: Demand strong for multi-currency cards, foreign currencies, as holiday fever rages
summary: Singapore's leisure travelers are making preparations for foreign currency expenditure needs ahead of the holiday season, with demand for multi-currency cards and foreign currencies surging. Wise, a multi-currency card provider, reported a 60% increase in per-user transactions from April to May 2022 compared to pre-Covid levels. Digital banking platforms Revolut and YouTrip also saw significant growth in active users and travel-related spending. Brick-and-mortar forex dealers in Singapore reported brisk business, with some currencies selling out by 2pm daily. The recovery in leisure travel is attributed to the reopening of international borders and the removal of travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: Some 418,310 visitors arrived in Singapore in May, up from 295,100 in April, according to the latest figures from STB.
The Singapore Tourism Board's innovation platform Tourism Technology Transformation Cube (Tcube) has supported more than 1,000 local tourism businesses in their digital transformation efforts.
Sunil Tuli, president of the Asia Pacific Travel Retail Association.

site_title: Ikea stores owner Ingka hopeful of return to Russia one day
summary: Ikea's owner Ingka Group remains hopeful of returning to Russia one day, but the current conditions are not in place. The company operates 14 malls in Russia but has closed its 17 furniture stores, reducing its workforce by 15,000. Ingka Group cited the lack of preconditions for resuming sales, despite speculation that keeping its 'Mega' malls open could be a sign of intent to return. The company has maintained its commitment to keeping its malls open to ensure people have access to basic necessities.

site_title: Oil drops closer to US$100 as recession fears rattle market
summary: Oil prices dropped over 6% for the second time in less than a week, falling below $102 a barrel, as recession fears and sharply higher US interest rates erode demand. The US Federal Reserve's efforts to curb inflation have shaken investor confidence, making crude susceptible to massive swings. Despite this, refined-fuel markets remain robust, and US President Joe Biden is set to propose a gasoline tax holiday. Experts predict a volatile downtrend in oil prices, with Citigroup expecting further declines into the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged up on Tuesday on high summer fuel demand while supplies remained tight because of sanctions on Russian oil after its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Aspen Glove gets interim injunction to stop Multi Purpose Metal Tech from filing or presenting winding-up petition
summary: ASPEN Glove, a subsidiary of Aspen (Group) Holdings, obtained an interim injunction to prevent Multi Purpose Metal Tech (MPMT) from filing a winding-up petition against it. MPMT had issued a letter of demand claiming RM29.3 million, which Aspen Glove disputes, citing unresolved issues with the completion of contractual works. The injunction will be in place until an inter partes hearing is held. Aspen Glove is seeking a declaration that the notice received by MPMT is "null and void" and is also restrained from filing or presenting a winding-up petition.

a Glove, the glove making unit of mainboard-listed Aspen (Group) Holdings, is planning to significantly scale down its operations, the group said on Wednesday (Jun 8).

site_title: ADDX partners China Construction Bank to administer US$200m in QDLP funds quota
summary: ADDX, a private market exchange, has partnered with China Construction Bank to administer a US$200 million quota allocation under the Qualified Domestic Limited Partnership (QDLP) scheme, allowing Chinese domestic investors to buy into high-quality offshore assets. The partnership aims to drive further economic growth in China. ADDX CEO Choo Oi Yee said the move will enable domestic capital to participate in offshore investments, leading to increased economic growth.

Choo Oi Yee, CEO of private market platform ADDX.

site_title: Putin signs decree on new scheme to services Eurobonds as possible default looms
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a decree establishing temporary procedures to fulfill foreign debt obligations, as a potential default looms. The decree suggests that Russia will consider its debt obligations fulfilled when paying bondholders in roubles, rather than foreign currency. Putin had given the government 10 days to choose banks to handle Eurobonds payments, with a deadline of June 30. The move comes amid Western sanctions and allegations of an artificial default, with Russia arguing it has the funds to make interest payments. A default would be the first since the Bolshevik revolution over a century ago.

site_title: Ex-BOE governor Mark Carney's fund raises US$15b for energy transition
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has raised US$15 billion for a fund focused on investing in the global transition to a net-zero carbon economy. The Brookfield Global Transition Fund, led by former Bank of England governor Mark Carney, will invest in solar power and other technologies to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. The fund has over 100 investors and has already committed US$2.5 billion to various renewable energy projects, including solar power and battery developers, and a carbon capture-and-storage developer. The fund aims to accelerate the global transition to a net-zero carbon economy by 2050.

site_title: China approves plan for 'healthy' development of fintech sector
summary: China's President Xi Jinping approved plans to promote the "healthy" development of the payment and fintech sectors, easing curbs on tech companies like Ant Group. The central commission for deepening overall reform backed enhancing regulation of major payment platforms and encouraged companies to return to their roots. China aims to ensure payment and financial infrastructure security and prevent systemic financial risks. The move signals a shift towards supporting the industry, following recent pledges to unwind crackdowns on tech companies.

site_title: Hong Kong IPO gong is back for first listing ceremony since 2020
summary: Hong Kong is hosting its first in-person IPO listing ceremony since 2020, marking a sign of normalcy after two years of pandemic restrictions. Logistics startup GogoX Holdings will be listed, accompanied by a traditional gong ceremony where executives will strike the gong with mallets in red cloth, symbolizing good fortune and joy in Chinese culture. The ceremony comes as Hong Kong's IPO market is awaiting a rebound, with companies raising only a fraction of the US$26.2 billion raised in the same period last year.

site_title: The world’s bubbliest housing markets are flashing warning signs
summary: Global housing markets are flashing warning signs as central banks rapidly increase interest rates, squeezing homebuyers and adding risks of a slowdown. Countries such as Canada, the US, and New Zealand are experiencing sharp reversals in their once-hot residential real estate markets. With over 50 central banks raising interest rates by at least 50 basis points, the risk of a synchronized global tightening of monetary policy is increasing, potentially leading to a ripple effect that could deepen an economic slump. Experts warn that a slowdown in housing could erode household wealth, dent consumer confidence, and curb future development.

images.alt_text: Existing home sales fell 3.4 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.41 million units last month, the lowest level since June 2020 when sales were rebounding from the Covid-19 lockdown slump..
Rightmove said asking prices for homes put on sale between May 15 and June 11 were 0.3 per cent higher than a month earlier, down from a 2.1 per cent rise in its May data.

Sydney property prices are expected to fall by up to 20% as rising interest rates amplify affordability challenges in one of the world's most expensive markets.
Sweden's inflated housing market is teetering on the brink of a correction as price expectations turn south and buyers withdraw from a sector that hit record heights last year.

site_title: Afghanistan earthquake kills at least 1,000; toll expected to rise
summary: An earthquake in Afghanistan has killed at least 1,000 people, with the majority of confirmed deaths in the eastern province of Paktika. Over 600 people have been injured, and the toll is expected to rise as information from remote mountain villages becomes available. The quake, with a magnitude of 5.9, struck near the southeastern city of Khost, and rescue efforts are being aided by helicopters and international aid teams. The disaster comes as Afghanistan faces a severe economic crisis and recent flooding, and the Taliban government has welcomed international assistance.

images.alt_text: Earthquake of magnitude 5.8 strikes Vanuatu – EMSC

site_title: Fed 'strongly committed' to bring down inflation 'expeditiously,' Powell says
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the central bank is "strongly committed" to reducing inflation, which is at a 40-year high, and will continue to act "expeditiously" to achieve its objective of a 2% inflation rate. Powell emphasized the challenges in bringing down inflation without harming the labor market, citing the ongoing war in Ukraine and global supply concerns. The Fed's policy rate is expected to continue increasing, with Powell indicating that the pace of changes will depend on incoming data and the evolving economy outlook.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated his determination to curb the hottest inflation in 40 years and said the US central bank’s commitment encourages the world to hold and transact in dollars.

site_title: Indonesian president says new capital construction now underway
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo announced that construction on the country's new capital, Nusantara, is underway. The $32 billion project, which aims to move the capital from Jakarta to Borneo island, has faced skepticism from experts due to funding and management concerns. The construction of a dam and a new road to Nusantara is scheduled to begin next month. While a parliamentary bill approved in January provides the legal framework for development, nearly 60% of surveyed experts remain uncertain about the project's materialization.

images.alt_text: Pandu Sjahrir talks to The Garage about his journey and his "no asshole" rule

site_title: Carlsberg CFO to step down
summary: Carlsberg announced the departure of CFO Heine Dalsgaard, who led the company's cost-cutting efforts in Russia. Dalsgaard will continue in his role until December 31. The company will start searching for a new CFO. Shares fell 2.2% following the announcement, underperforming the Copenhagen benchmark index. Analysts described the move as "disappointing," citing Dalsgaard's instrumental role in driving efficiencies.

site_title: ESG loans with little transparency boom in China, Hong Kong
summary: China and Hong Kong firms signed a record $13.1 billion of sustainability-linked loans in 2022, surpassing the global total of $12.6 billion. However, the lack of transparency on disclosing targets and the industry's private nature are raising concerns. Experts call for greater target-setting convergence between loans and bonds, with some borrowers only disclosing targets to investors. The ESG industry is under increased scrutiny, and regulators are urging greater transparency to ensure the facilities are used effectively.

site_title: Euro, sterling knocked by global growth worries
summary: The euro and sterling fell due to concerns about global growth slowdown or recession as inflation rates surged. The euro dropped 0.1% to US$1.0524 and sterling fell 0.2% to US$1.2254, with the US dollar gaining ground as investors turned nervous about recession fears. The yen hit a 24-year low, and commodity currencies such as the Norwegian crown and Australian dollar also declined. Analysts expect no immediate end to a sell-off in the yen, which has weakened 18% this year.

images.alt_text: The euro was 0.4 per cent firmer at US$1.0554 after ECB chief economist Philip Lane said the ECB will raise interest rates by 25 basis points at its July meeting.

site_title: Delighted music fans get back to Glastonbury and Paul McCartney
summary: Glastonbury, the world's largest green field festival, has returned after a 3-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Tens of thousands of music fans, including Billie Eilish and Paul McCartney, attended the event on June 22, marking a relief for the live music industry. Michael Eavis, the festival's founder, welcomed the crowd, stating it was "absolutely marvellous" and "lovely to see you all." The event comes after the industry suffered significant losses due to the pandemic, with many venues refunding tickets and losing income.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower, Powell's testimony to Congress in focus
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on June 22, 2022, falling 0.58% due to investor focus on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's congressional testimony. site_title: Thyssenkrupp, Tata lose fight against EU veto of joint venture
summary: Thyssenkrupp and Tata Steel's proposed joint venture to tackle over-capacity and challenges in the steel industry has been blocked by the European Union due to concerns of significant price hikes. The European Commission had initially vetoed the deal in 2019, and after a challenge at the Luxembourg-based General Court, the decision was upheld. The companies can now appeal to the Court of Justice of the European Union. site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday

site_title: Sri Lanka sued by bondholder in US after historic default
summary: Sri Lanka has been sued by a US-based bondholder, Hamilton Reserve Bank, over the country's historic default on its debt. The default occurred after Sri Lanka failed to make interest payments on two sovereign bonds, and the bondholder claims that officials at the highest levels of government, including the ruling Rajapaksa family, orchestrated the default. site_title: Is the era of cheap money over?
summary: The era of cheap money may not be over as suggested by some, according to Paul Krugman. Interest rates have risen, but this is largely due to the Fed fighting inflation, which is expected to subside by the end of next year. The claim that the Fed kept interest rates artificially low to support bubbles is unfounded, as real interest rates have been declining since the 1960s. Instead, low interest rates were a response to "secular stagnation," driven by demographic factors such as a shrinking workforce. As a result, interest rates are likely to remain low in the future, potentially leading to more bubbles.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said recently that a US recession “is not inevitable” despite aggressive interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve to cool demand – moves that have prompted more economists to forecast a recession by 2023.

A US recession would land another blow on vulnerable parts of the global economy by curbing demand for their exports. Tighter monetary policy at the Fed and the resulting strength of the dollar would also compound what has already been the biggest sell-off in emerging-market bonds since 1994.

site_title: Obamas move audio deal to Amazon after Spotify friction
summary: The Obamas' production company, Higher Ground, has ended its 3-year deal with Spotify and signed an audio deal with Amazon's Audible. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it's reported that Higher Ground can now release shows on multiple audio services simultaneously. The partnership with Spotify, which began in 2019, had disagreements over strategy, leading to the deal's termination. Former President Barack Obama stated that Audible shares Higher Ground's vision of lifting up underrepresented voices, and they look forward to creating inspiring stories together.

site_title: Is America returning to the political centre?
summary: US politics may be shifting towards the center, with Democratic voters expressing dissatisfaction with progressive policies. The rise of Trumpism on the right has led to a backlash against left-leaning progressives, with some Democrats embracing centrist views. The election of centrist Mayor Eric Adams in New York and the recall of District Attorney Chesa Boudin in San Francisco demonstrate this shift. However, the Republican Party remains under Trump's influence, with many moderates hesitant to challenge the former president. The outcome of the 2024 presidential election and the midterms will determine whether the Democratic Party returns to its centrist roots.

Offices have also filled up, with 59% of office community returning to Raffles Place properties. Hotel revenues have recovered, with average daily rates increasing by 65.3% year-on-year. site_title: Deep tech startup NEU Battery Materials raises S$800,000 in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based startup NEU Battery Materials has raised S$800,000 in seed funding to build a pilot recycling plant in Singapore, focusing on recycling lithium batteries. Oil prices also dropped due to recessionary fears, and the yen hit a 24-year low against the dollar, putting pressure on the Bank of Japan to adjust its monetary policy.

The organizing committee, set to disband at the end of the month, attributed the costs to "unprecedented difficulties" and praised the successful execution of the Games. summary: Air ticket prices are expected to continue rising, driven by inflation and environmental pressures. The industry faces a challenge in balancing ambitious passenger growth targets with commitments to net zero carbon emissions, with the IATA estimating a $1.55 trillion transition cost. The sector is also under pressure to absorb the cost of sustainable aviation fuels, which are currently two to four times more expensive than fossil-based fuel.

summary: Japan's top potato chip maker Calbee plans to raise prices by 5-20% for snacks and cereals starting September due to increasing material costs. The company's shares rose 5.1% after the announcement, despite concerns about stagnant wages in Japan and the yen's slide to a 24-year low against the dollar. summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, G-20 chairman, will visit Ukraine and Russia next week to push for a peaceful resolution to the conflict. Several major Russian oil producers are evaluating Dubai for trading operations, and companies such as Lukoil and Gazprom Neft are already relocating staff to the city. The funds will be used to expand the company's talent pool, enhance technological capabilities, and develop its brand portfolio, including direct-to-consumer apparel and homeware brands. Founded in 2017, RPG Commerce currently operates on an end-to-end business model and is exploring incubation programs and acquisitions to expand its product range.

site_title: Crown Resorts gets conditional nod to open gaming operations in Sydney
summary: Crown Resorts has received conditional approval from New South Wales' gaming regulator to open its gaming operations in Sydney, following a 2-year conditional period. The Sydney casino's licence was suspended in 2020 due to alleged dealings with organised crime groups. As part of the approval, Crown must implement stringent measures to prevent money laundering and criminal infiltration.
