summary: Microsoft has scrapped some AI facial-analysis tools due to risk of bias, citing concerns over accuracy and fairness. Existing customers have a year to apply for continued access, while new customers must apply for access to facial-recognition features in Azure Face API. The company aims to ensure its technologies meet its ethical AI guidelines. This move comes after a two-year pause in facial-recognition sales to US police agencies and amid growing regulations and public concerns over the technology.

Speculative claims include allegations of thyroid cancer, advanced cancer, and even a method of longevity using deer antlers, but these cannot be verified. The Kremlin has denied all claims, with officials stating Putin appears in public "every day" and is in "rude health." The lack of transparency about Putin's health raises concerns about his ability to lead, particularly given his role as commander-in-chief of the Russian forces and his decision to invade Ukraine.

site_title: UK eyes cuts to food tariffs in trade talks with Gulf nations
summary: The UK is negotiating a free trade deal with the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), which could significantly reduce or remove tariffs on UK food and drink exports to the region. The agreement could include cuts on tariffs on cereals, chocolate, and other food products. The UK's Trade Secretary, Anne-Marie Trevelyan, said the deal could support jobs and grow the economy. Talks began on June 22.

State-run importers have cut LNG purchases from the spot market, potentially leaving a deficit that may not be filled by other sources. The prevalence of gas in Thailand's power mix raises the threat of rationing or blackouts, and the country is considering alternatives like diesel and fuel oil, which would increase greenhouse gas emissions.

This comes after the last talks between the two leaders on March 18, when Biden warned Xi against assisting Russia in its invasion of Ukraine. The exact timing of the conversation has not been set yet, but Biden hinted that it could happen "soon."

images.alt_text: Workers unload a FedEx plane carrying the second shipment of baby formula under Operation Fly Formula at Dulles Airport in Chantilly, Virginia, USA, 25 May 2022. The US is facing a shortage of baby formula when contamination forced Abbott Laboratories to stop production of several brands of formula in February.  EPA-EFE/JIM LO SCALZO
President Joe Biden will launch a global infrastructure initiative to counter China’s international ambitions, particularly in the Indo-Pacific.

site_title: European Central Bank takes rare step with sale of Adler bond
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) sold a corporate bond from its quantitative-easing portfolio, exiting the debt of embattled German landlord Adler Group. The bond, previously eligible for purchase, no longer met the Eurosystem's collateral framework eligibility criteria due to Adler's financial concerns. This move underscores investor concerns about Adler's financial position, following large-scale asset sales and a forensic probe. The ECB's decision is in line with its legal framework, allowing it to sell holdings in the event of a loss of eligibility.

images.alt_text: The ECB is preparing to raise interest rates in July for the first time in more than a decade to bring consumer prices under control.

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi gets US$250m credit line from FTX
summary: BlockFi, a major crypto lender, has secured a US$250 million revolving credit facility from FTX, a digital-asset trading powerhouse. The move comes amid concerns about liquidity in the crypto sector following recent price collapses. BlockFi had previously acknowledged liquidating a large client that failed to meet its obligations and had cut about 20% of its workforce. The deal aims to bolster BlockFi's balance sheet and ensure client funds are safeguarded, according to CEO Zac Prince.

images.alt_text: The BlockFi website on a laptop computer arranged in Little Falls, New Jersey, U.S., on Saturday, May 22, 2021. Elon Musk continued to toy with the price of Bitcoin Monday, taking to Twitter to indicate support for what he says is an effort by miners to make their operations greener. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

Crypto lending platform BlockFi said it continues normal operations and no client funds are impacted, in an apparent move to allay concerns over contagion risks from the suspected troubles at crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital.
Crypto lending platform BlockFi is looking to raise new funding that would value the company at about US$1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the plan.

site_title: Singapore startups taking a crack at recycling lithium batteries
summary: Singapore-based startups NEU Battery Materials and Green Li-ion are working to develop more sustainable methods for recycling lithium batteries from electric vehicles. Current methods involve smelting or leaching with acids, but these processes are energy-intensive and costly. NEU's process, which uses electricity to recycle batteries, costs 20% less than traditional methods and can produce lithium hydroxide, a valuable material. Green Li-ion's proprietary machine can process a wide variety of lithium batteries and has already sold 8 machines to battery-recycling companies and manufacturers. The market for battery recycling is projected to be worth $6.55 billion by 2028.

images.alt_text: THE number of car buyers worldwide looking to buy an electric vehicle (EV) has exceeded 50 per cent for the first time.

ALSYM ENERGY, a 7-year-old Massachusetts startup, aims to halve the cost of electric vehicle (EV) batteries with a new design that eliminates lithium and cobalt, 2 increasingly costly ingredients in many current EV batteries, the company said on Wednesday (Jun 15).

site_title: South Korea reports first two suspected monkeypox cases, tests underway
summary: South Korea has reported its first two suspected cases of monkeypox, with one foreign national and one Korean citizen showing symptoms after entering the country. Diagnostic tests are underway, and health authorities will hold a briefing once the results are complete. The foreign national is being treated in isolation in Busan, while the Korean citizen is being treated at Incheon Medical Center. The country is taking precautions, but no further information is available at this time.

site_title: Euro-area inflation isn't just imported, new ECB indicator shows
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing to raise interest rates in July for the first time in over a decade to control euro-area inflation. A new ECB indicator, the Low Import Intensity inflation indicator (Limi), shows that domestic inflationary pressures have increased, despite imported inflation being the main driver of the recent price rise. The indicator aims to provide an extra tool for the ECB to make informed decisions on monetary policy. The interest rate hike is intended to bring consumer prices under control and address supply shocks.

site_title: Singapore confirms imported case of monkeypox; 13 close contacts identified
summary: Singapore has confirmed an imported case of monkeypox, a 42-year-old British flight attendant who tested positive on June 20 after visiting the country between June 15-17 and June 19. Thirteen close contacts have been identified and are under quarantine for 21 days, with two low-risk contacts under phone surveillance. The case is stable, and contact tracing is ongoing for the affected flights and locations visited during his stay.

images.alt_text: Test tubes labelled "Monkeypox virus positive" are seen in this illustration taken May 23, 2022.

site_title: Antibiotic-resistant typhoid from Asia is spreading worldwide
summary: Antibiotic-resistant typhoid from Asia is spreading globally, with over 200 instances of international transmission in the past 3 decades. A new study analyzed 3,489 cases of S Typhi bacteria from 2014 to 2019, finding that resistance to macrolides and quinolones increased sharply and frequently spread to other countries. The study's lead author warns that prevention measures are needed, particularly in high-risk nations, as the spread of resistant strains underscores the need for a global approach to controlling antibiotic resistance.

images.alt_text: A photomicrograph of S. Typhi bacteria. Photographer: Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images

site_title: Oil ticks higher on strong demand, tight supply
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, driven by high summer fuel demand and tight supply due to sanctions on Russian oil. Brent crude futures settled 0.5% higher at $114.65 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude closed at $110.65, a 1% gain. Analysts predict further supply growth will lag demand, leading to higher oil prices. The US is in talks to impose a price cap on Russian oil, and the White House has asked oil company CEOs to discuss ways to reduce high energy prices.

images.alt_text: A surge in demand from Asia for discounted Russian oil is making up for the sharply lower number of barrels being sold to Europe, dulling the effects of the West’s efforts to punish Moscow over its invasion of Ukraine .
The airline industry requires huge investments in so-called sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), which are currently in short supply and far more expensive than conventional jet fuels.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend gains on Tuesday but recession risks hover
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% on Tuesday, extending its third consecutive gain, driven by chemical and resource-linked sectors. Despite recession fears, bargain hunters snapped up shares, while luxury stocks surged after a bullish report from Bain. However, growth worries lingered, with Germany's economic powerhouse potentially facing recession if Russian gas supplies halt. The European Central Bank reaffirmed plans to raise interest rates twice this summer, fueling concerns about the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: London's benchmark FTSE 100 index rose 0.4 per cent to 7,148.03 points compared with the closing level on Monday.

site_title: BT launches Generation Hustle video series to reach young audiences
summary: BT launches its first 5-episode video series, Generation Hustle, to reach young audiences. The series, airing every Thursday starting June 23, features 5 young adults sharing their views on work, life, and success, focusing on their unconventional career paths and hustling for meaning. The series aims to appeal to a younger generation of consumers, who prefer visual storytelling and informal content. BT's video team has been experimenting with various video content formats, and the launch of Generation Hustle is part of its efforts to diversify digital entry points and meet the evolving media consumption habits of young consumers.

images.alt_text: SPH assistant general manager Cheah Cheng Poh at a briefing to launch BT Online in June 1995.
BT strengthens ESG focus with dedicated reporting team
Senior correspondent Kenneth Lim will headline the new weekly ESG Insights newsletter, which will be free for a limited period.

site_title: Using Singapore as a stepping stone to Asean
summary: Singapore's stable and neutral government and economy make it an attractive location for companies, particularly in the textile industry. Dole Specialty Ingredients, a manufacturer, has a presence in Singapore, utilizing fruit side streams and unutilized parts to produce high-value natural products. This approach is seen as a model for Asean nations to follow, leveraging the region's economic and strategic advantages. The city-state's reputation as a low-risk location can reassure customers, especially in the wake of recent geopolitical tensions, making it an ideal stepping stone for Asean companies.

images.alt_text: Harnessing Asean's collective strength
The supply chain disruption has diverted global demand to Asean countries, including Singapore.
Shanghai, China’s financial hub with more than 28 million people, remains in lockdown for almost 2 months, though more residents are recently allowed to go out to shop for groceries.

site_title: UK sells new 2073 bonds with face value of £5.5 billion
summary: The UK sold £5.5 billion worth of government bonds maturing in 2073, receiving £43.5 billion of orders, but only raising £3.2 billion. Investors paid less than half the bond's face value, expecting a yield of 2.6358% if held to maturity, more than twice the initial 1.3% yield. This sale comes amidst surging interest rates and inflation, with two-year bond yields reaching their highest since 2008.

site_title: Facebook agrees to safeguards in ad discrimination case
summary: Meta, the owner of Facebook, has agreed to change its ad targeting technology and pay $115,000 to settle US government allegations of allowing discrimination in who saw housing advertisements. The company will use artificial intelligence to ensure ads reach people regardless of age, gender, or race. The deal must be approved by a court and will also prevent ads for jobs or credit from discriminating. Meta has already made changes to address housing ad discrimination concerns, which will remain in effect.

images.alt_text: A lawyer representing Meta on Monday (J told the court that refusing to block access to content and labelling state-controlled media were not activities that qualified as extremist.

site_title: TikTok to boost EU consumers' rights, averts possible sanctions
summary: TikTok has agreed to boost European Union users' rights, averting possible sanctions. The company will introduce an option for users to report ads targeting children, prohibit branded content promoting inappropriate products, and clearly label paid advertisements. TikTok also committed to clarifying its rewards system and will ensure commercial content is easily identifiable, including when promoted by influencers. The agreement was reached after over a year of dialogue with the European Commission and consumer protection authorities, addressing concerns raised by the European Consumer Organisation.

site_title: Exxon joins energy majors investing in Qatar gas project
summary: ExxonMobil is investing $29 billion in the North Field East project in Qatar, a 6.25% stake in the largest gas industry project, expected to start operating in early 2026. The expansion will increase Qatar's liquefied natural gas capacity to 110 million tons annually, helping balance global markets and meet growing demand in Europe. Exxon CEO Darren Woods sees the project as essential for the energy transition, citing cleaner fossil fuel gas over coal or oil.

site_title: US existing home sales drop to 2-year low in May
summary: US existing home sales dropped 3.4% to a 2-year low of 5.41 million units in May, the lowest level since June 2020. Sales were hindered by record-high prices and rising mortgage interest rates, sidelining first-time buyers. The median existing house price reached an all-time high of $407,600, with sales concentrated in the upper-price end. The housing market's slowdown could help bring supply and demand back into balance and lower prices.

site_title: Return of the superjumbo: A380 makes comeback despite high oil prices
summary: The Airbus A380, once considered a 21st-century "cruiseliner," is making a comeback despite high fuel prices, with airlines such as Singapore Airlines and Qantas Airways reviving their fleets. The return is driven by strong demand and delays in deliveries of new Boeing 777X airliners, forcing airlines to reconsider their capacity needs. However, analysts predict the fleet will never return to pre-pandemic levels, and the A380 will likely take on a more utilitarian role, covering busy periods rather than serving as a luxury flagship.

images.alt_text: Airbus sees pandemic as blip, with carbon goals driving demand for jets

site_title: US: Beaten-down stocks rally to end Tuesday higher
summary: US stocks ended a holiday-shortened week on a positive note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.2% to 30,530.25 and the S&P 500 jumping 2.5% to 3,764.79. Analysts attribute the rally to the market being "oversold" after heavy losses in 2022, and some predicting a 48% probability of a recession in the next two years. Individual companies like Kellogg and Lennar also saw gains, with Kellogg's plan to split into three companies sparking a 2.0% increase.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 185.91 points, or 0.62 per cent, at the open to 30,074.69.

site_title: Luxury sales to grow at least 5% this year: Bain
summary: Luxury goods sales are expected to rise at least 5% this year, reaching 305 billion euros, according to Bain's conservative estimate. Despite the conflict in Ukraine and soaring inflation, global sales of personal luxury goods are expected to rebound from pandemic lockdowns. The US has overtaken Europe as the largest luxury market, and domestic spending from Chinese consumers is expected to recover in the second half of the year. However, a decline in demand from affluent Russians following the Ukraine conflict is expected to negatively impact global sales.

site_title: Airlines warn oil companies to speed up alternative fuel production
summary: Airlines have warned oil companies to accelerate the production of sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) to meet the industry's 2050 net-zero emissions target. The airline industry requires significant investments in SAF, which are currently in short supply and more expensive than conventional jet fuels. If oil companies fail to develop and supply SAF, airlines risk losing business to companies that will meet the emissions target, according to Willie Walsh, head of the International Air Transport Association.

images.alt_text: Global airline industry body International Air Transport Association director-general Willie Walsh said that it is critical that the industry is supported by governments with policies that are focused on reaching the same decarbonisation goal - net-zero by mid century.

site_title: Are property valuations too conservative?
summary: Singapore's commercial property market is characterized by conservative valuations, which can lead to significant gains for investors when assets are sold at above valuation. Companies like City Developments and Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust have reported substantial gains from selling properties at premiums to book value. While conservative valuations can be misleading for equity investors, they also reflect the limited supply of prime commercial properties and strong demand from investors. The benefits of conservative valuations include reduced risk of economic recession and easier refinancing for property owners.

images.alt_text: CICT to divest JCube for S$340m
FLCT to divest Cross Street Exchange for S$810.8m

site_title: Asia buying discounted Russian oil, making up for Europe’s cutbacks
summary: Russia is selling discounted oil to Asia, largely to China and India, to make up for reduced sales to Europe due to sanctions over its invasion of Ukraine. Despite the sanctions, Russia's oil revenue has increased, with $1.7 billion more earned in May than in April. This surge in demand has allowed Russia to maintain its production levels, defying analysts' expectations. The shift also highlights China's support for Russia, with top leader Xi Jinping offering to deepen cooperation.

images.alt_text: Chinese firms, including state refining giant Sinopec and state-run Zhenhua Oil, have ramped up purchases of Russian oil, enticed by steep discounts after western oil majors and trading houses pulled back due to sanctions.

site_title: More than 30 of Sri Lanka's bondholders launch formal group for debt talks
summary: More than 30 asset managers holding Sri Lanka's international bonds have launched a creditor group to start debt restructuring talks with the island nation. The group, which includes Amundi Asset Management, BlackRock, and T Rowe Price Associates, aims to engage in talks with Sri Lanka's authorities and other creditors. The creditor group has called for Sri Lanka to implement "meaningful reforms and fiscal adjustments" to address its financial crisis, which has been exacerbated by economic mismanagement and the Covid-19 pandemic. The group's talks are part of Sri Lanka's efforts to renegotiate its complex web of creditors.

images.alt_text: A man sleeps on a folding bed on a pavement as he waits in queue to buy petrol due to fuel shortage, amid the country's economic crisis, in Colombo, Sri Lanka.

site_title: Google avoids more fines after ending French dispute over news
summary: Google has ended a French dispute over news, avoiding further fines after improving commitments to address concerns. The French competition authority said Google's new pledges, made binding, pave the way for payments for displaying news snippets on its platforms. This follows a 500 million euro fine for failing to negotiate fair deals with publishers. Google also agreed to withdraw its challenge against the penalty, and the regulator has established a dynamic framework for publishers to assess their earnings. The deal marks a positive outcome for Google and publishers.

site_title: Germany risks recession as Russian gas crisis deepens
summary: Germany risks recession as Russian gas supplies continue to dwindle, with the country's industry association cutting its economic growth forecast to 1.5% due to a halt in Russian gas deliveries. The EU's reliance on Russian gas has left a huge gap to fill in an already tight global gas market, driving record-high gas prices and inflation. European countries, including Italy, are considering offering financial backing to help companies refill gas storage facilities and cope with the crisis, which has prompted Germany to unveil new contingency plans, including an auction system to encourage gas consumption.

images.alt_text: The Dutch joined Germany and Austria in reverting to coal power on Monday following an energy crisis provoked by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Moon sculptures, NFTs at futuristic Art Basel fair
summary: The Art Basel fair in Switzerland has taken a futuristic turn with the incorporation of moon sculptures and non-fungible tokens (NFTs). Artist Jeff Koons plans to send 125 miniature sculptures to the moon with SpaceX, which will be sold as NFTs. The sculptures come with a photo of their lunar location and a gemstone marking their counterpart's place on the moon. This marks a significant shift in the art market, with NFTs experiencing a decline in sales after peaking in August 2021.

site_title: Thailand extends measures to tackle high oil prices, help tourism
summary: Thailand's Cabinet extended measures to support energy prices and tourism, amid a near 14-year high of 7.1% inflation in May driven by rising oil prices. Existing relief measures, including a monthly cooking gas subsidy and vehicle gas price freeze, will be extended for 3 months. The government will also seek contributions from refineries to boost the depleted oil fund. Additionally, a domestic travel scheme will be extended until October, and companies will be offered tax deductions on related expenses.

site_title: Saudi Prince seals US$7.7b in Egypt deals at start of Mid-East tour
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman signed $7.7 billion in investment deals with Egypt during his Middle East tour, aimed at promoting Saudi Arabia as a regional powerhouse. The deals cover sectors including renewables, pharmaceuticals, and e-commerce. The visit comes ahead of US President Joe Biden's trip to Saudi Arabia, where he'll attend a regional leaders summit. The crown prince seeks to reposition Saudi Arabia and himself as a key bridge-builder in the region, countering the UAE's growing influence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speaks during the Gulf Summit in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, December 14, 2021. Bandar Saudi Press Agency/Handout via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS PICTURE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY/File Photo
The PIF, as the $500 billion fund is known, continues to deepen its push into a gaming sector that continues to consolidate.

site_title: Responding to the Fed’s ‘shock-and-awe’ approach
summary: The US Federal Reserve's "shock-and-awe" approach to combat inflation has led to a rapid withdrawal of pandemic-era policy support, causing a decline in Western equity and credit markets. Despite a potential soft landing, fair value in the S&P 500 would still be near 3,400-3,800, 5-10% below current levels, due to new growth and interest rate outlooks. The European Central Bank is expected to join the Fed in interest rate hikes, exacerbating the headwinds for investors. Fixed income investors should prioritize risk management, while equities may face challenging return profiles, especially relative to credit.

images.alt_text: The Fed raised the federal funds rate by 75 basis points on June 15

site_title: 2.5m passengers handled by Changi Airport in May, higher than in April
summary: Changi Airport handled nearly 2.5 million passengers in May, a 30% increase from April, and nearly 7 million for the first 5 months of 2022, exceeding pre-pandemic levels. This represents a 10th of the 2020 passenger numbers but surpasses the 3.1 million passengers in 2021. The airport's recovery continues as passenger traffic rebounds from the pandemic impact.

images.alt_text: Some 418,310 visitors arrived in Singapore in May, up from 295,100 in April, according to the latest figures from STB.

site_title: Euro supported by ECB policy plans, yen falls to 24-year low
summary: The euro rose 0.4% to $1.0554 after the European Central Bank (ECB) announced plans to raise interest rates by 25 basis points at its July meeting, supporting the currency. The yen fell to a 24-year low of 135.835 per US dollar as the Bank of Japan maintained ultra-loose monetary policy. The ECB's interest rate hike aims to contain inflation, while the yen's decline was attributed to the Bank of Japan's monetary policy stance. The euro's rise also drew support from broad higher risk sentiment across markets, including US equity futures and European equity indexes.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui said to take 10% stake in SBI Holdings
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group is set to acquire a 10% stake in SBI Holdings, valued at approximately $443 million. The deal, which would give Sumitomo Mitsui a significant presence in Japan's online brokerage market, is part of a strategic alliance between the two companies. This marks the latest acquisition by Sumitomo Mitsui, which has spent over $3.3 billion in Asia in 2021. The partnership aims to collaborate on the securities business and strengthens investment banking capabilities.

images.alt_text: Sumitomo Mitsui

site_title: Malaysia to scrap subsidies for some cooking oil products
summary: Malaysia will scrap subsidies for 2 kg, 3 kg, and 5 kg cooking oil bottles, but continue subsidizing 1 kg packets, starting July 1. The move aims to ensure domestic supply and stabilize prices. This decision comes amid rising global edible oil prices due to supply disruptions caused by adverse weather and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The government expects to spend 30 billion ringgit on subsidies this year, more than double the estimated 4 billion ringgit in this year's budget.

site_title: China's Bilibili launches paywall as it seeks new revenue source
summary: China's video platform Bilibili has launched a paywall for some of its premium videos, seeking new revenue sources amid a crackdown on the tech industry. The move comes as the company diversifies its revenue streams, following a significant decline in its market capitalization. Bilibili's video gaming and live streaming businesses have been impacted by Chinese regulators' restrictions, leading to a deeper net loss of US$360.3 million in the first quarter. The company aims to publish only one game in China and one outside this quarter, and features premium videos starting at 30 yuan (S$6.2).

site_title: Over-optimism among China steel-makers behind iron ore’s plunge
summary: Iron ore plummeted 23% in an 8-day period, with futures in Singapore staging a mini-recovery. The decline is attributed to over-optimism in China's steel industry, which ramped up production despite a virus-induced slowdown in economic activity. The steel-making ingredient is expected to reverse direction at some point, but the exact timing remains uncertain. China's property market funk and government infrastructure spending pace are key factors in determining iron ore demand.

images.alt_text: Aluminium prices deepened losses on Tuesday as investors worried that renewed lockdowns in top consumer China and a potential global recession could slash demand for metals.

site_title: The Philippines could be South-east Asia’s startup dark horse
summary: The Philippines is emerging as a significant player in Southeast Asia's startup scene, attracting foreign investors and tech unicorns. The country has seen a surge in deal activity, with 18 deals recorded in Q1 2022, more than double the 8 in Q1 2021. Investors such as KKR, Andreessen Horowitz, and Tencent are taking notice, with the country's share of funding from the Philippines steadily rising. Fintech player Voyager Innovations recently became the Philippines' second unicorn, valued at over $1 billion. The country's unique blend of a young, tech-savvy population and educated, English-speaking workforce is making it an attractive destination for startups.

images.alt_text: GrowSari helps small stores in the Philippines (pictured) digitalise their operations.

site_title: IReit’s Sant Cugat Green bags new 12-year lease for 20.4% of property’s total lettable area
summary: IReit Global has secured a 12-year lease for 5,300 sq m of vacant data centre space at its Sant Cugat Green building in Barcelona, Spain, representing 20.4% of the property's total lettable area. The initial annual rent is approximately €0.7 million, and the lease includes a 2-year renovation phase and a break option. This deal is expected to push up the property's occupancy rate to 97.2% and improve the weighted average lease expiry to 5 years.

images.alt_text: Many Singapore-listed Reits that hold mainly overseas assets trade at substantial discount to book value.
With the lease extension, the manager estimates Bonn Campus’ weighted average lease expiry to improve from 1 year as at end-March 2022 to 7.1 years

site_title: Kellogg to split into 3 to focus on snacks
summary: Kellogg is splitting into three independent companies, focusing on its North American cereal business and plant-based foods, which generated $2.4 billion in net sales in 2021. The company's snacking portfolio, including international cereals and noodles, will remain intact. This move follows a shift in focus towards snacking, with the new companies expected to operate independently. Kellogg's shares jumped 7% in pre-market trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: KELLOGG raised its 2022 forecast on Thursday (May 5), banking on more price increases to help counter the impact of supply shortages stemming from a workers' strike at the company's US plants last year and the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise, tracking broad rally in Asian equities; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,117.48, following a broader Asian market rally. Gainers outnumbered losers 334 to 167, with energy company Sembcorp Industries leading the gainers. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surged 1.9%, Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.8%, and South Korea's Kospi climbed 0.8%. Analysts attribute the market boost to US index futures rising and a lack of negative headlines.

images.alt_text: Equities rose on Tuesday in Asia as some stability returned to markets after last week’s upheaval.
The Nikkei stock average ended the day up 1.84 per cent at 26,246.31, after gaining as much as 2.5 per cent during the session.

site_title: Malaysia’s new low-cost carrier MYAirline has licence to operate, but details remain scarce
summary: Malaysia's new low-cost carrier MYAirline has received a conditional approval to operate, with its air service licence valid until the end of 2022. The airline, owned by Malaysian entrepreneur Goh Hwan Hua and his associates, has RM2 million in paid-up capital and will operate on an ultra low-cost model. MYAirline has leased two Airbus A320 planes and is recruiting staff, but no specific routes have been announced. Industry analysts are skeptical about the airline's ability to compete, citing excess capacity in the market, but some see it as an opportunity for consumers to have more budget carrier options.

images.alt_text: Global airline industry body International Air Transport Association (IATA) director-general Willie Walsh and Qatar Airways chief executive officer (CEO) Akbar al Baker at the opening of the 78th IATA annual meeting in Doha, Qatar, on Monday (Jun 20).

site_title: 23% week-on-week increase in Covid-19 infections, spike driven by Omicron subvariants: MOH
summary: Singapore has seen a 23% week-on-week increase in Covid-19 community infections, driven by the spread of Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5. These subvariants now account for 30% of community cases, with BA.5 contributing to 25% of cases. The severity of BA.4 and BA.5 infections is similar to earlier Omicron strains. The Ministry of Health will maintain safe management measures, including mask-wearing and vaccination-differentiated measures, despite the surge in BA.4 and BA.5 cases.

site_title: Malaysia's Carsome is said to delay Singapore, US dual listing
summary: Carsome Group, Malaysia's most valuable technology startup, has delayed its planned dual listing in Singapore and the US due to concerns over deteriorating macroeconomic conditions. The company halted work on this year's offerings, but may revive the process next year if markets improve. Higher interest rates, slowing economic growth, and geopolitical tensions have hurt market sentiment and first-time share sales, with global IPOs raising about US$101 billion since the start of the year.

site_title: Dubai restaurants earn Middle East's first Michelin stars
summary: Dubai has earned the first Michelin stars in the Middle East, with 11 restaurants receiving the prestigious ratings. Two restaurants, Il Ristorante and STAY by Yannick Alleno, were awarded 2-star ratings, while nine gained 1-star ratings and 14 received the Bib Gourmand for value-for-money gourmet fare. The recognition is a historic moment for Dubai, with inspectors praising the city's diverse culinary scene and 90% expat population, which has created an "epicurean kaleidoscope".

site_title: Thai central bank asked to ease impact of any rate hike: finance minister
summary: Thai Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith asked the central bank to minimize the impact of any interest rate hike, ensure liquidity in the banking system, and maintain a stable baht currency. The Bank of Thailand is expected to raise interest rates to tame inflation, which hit a near 14-year high of 7.1% in May. The economy is forecast to grow 3.3% in 2022, and the minister urged the central bank to balance inflation management with economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore’s support package won’t solve inflation, but it’ll still help, analysts say
summary: Singapore's S$1.5 billion support package, unveiled by Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, aims to alleviate the impact of rising costs on businesses and households. The measures include enhanced business loans, hiring incentives, higher payouts to ComCare recipients, one-off grants for self-employed workers, and energy-efficient equipment subsidies. Analysts note that the package is "fiscally prudent" but may not address underlying drivers of inflation. Wong warned that price increases will continue, with energy prices likely to stay high for the rest of the year. The package is seen as a targeted approach to support vulnerable groups and is expected to have a marginal impact on economic growth.

images.alt_text: Price increases are expected to continue in the coming months, with energy prices likely to remain "elevated" for the rest of the year, Deputy Prime M
With energy prices possibly elevated into the second half of the year, certain small businesses will now get government funding of up to 70 per cent for energy-efficient equipment.
Abandoned by power retailers, SMEs zapped by electricity bill shock

site_title: Britain’s trial lawyers to strike in latest sign of discontent
summary: Britain's Criminal Bar Association, representing thousands of barristers, voted to strike in a dispute over government funding and fees. The 80% majority-backed 14-day strike, set to begin June 27, targets a record backlog of court cases and low pay. The lawyers demand a 15% fee increase, citing repeated government cuts to the legal aid budget and the exodus of barristers from the profession. The strike, if successful, could have a "dramatic impact" on the UK's criminal justice system.

site_title: BT Explains: What is cost-push inflation and how can governments address it?
summary: Cost-push inflation, fueled by global supply chain disruptions and bottlenecks, is driving rising prices globally. Supply-side measures, such as subsidies, deregulation, and research, are more effective in addressing cost-push inflation, but take longer to implement.

site_title: South Korea’s central bank sees 2022 inflation higher than previous projection
summary: South Korea's central bank has revised its inflation forecast for 2022, expecting it to exceed 5% due to the Ukraine crisis, global supply bottlenecks, and easing of social distancing rules. The Bank of Korea raised its forecast from 4.5% to 4.7%, citing upward pressures on oil prices and inflationary pressures from lifting social distancing rules and an extra budget. This marks the fastest annual inflation rate since August 2008, as the country scrapes all Covid-19-related curbs, except for mask mandates.

site_title: Japan’s latest unicorn is a Thailand mobile payments firm
summary: Japan's mobile payments firm Opn has become a unicorn after a $120 million funding round valued the company at $1 billion. Founded in 2013 in Thailand, Opn has successfully adapted to complex local regulations and now operates in several Southeast Asian markets. The company plans to expand its services to new markets, including Vietnam and the Philippines, and aims to reach 100 million transactions per year, doubling revenue annually since 2019. Opn's CEO, Jun Hasegawa, aims to make the company's services available in at least 36 major countries.

site_title: Macron to hold talks with French opposition parties over parliament deadlock: Elysee Palace
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron will hold talks with representatives of France's main political parties on Tuesday and Wednesday to find a way forward after his coalition failed to win a majority in parliamentary elections. Macron's coalition, led by him, failed to secure a majority, leaving him without an alternative majority to govern. Macron aims to "build solutions to serve the French" and has extended invitations to parties including hard-left leader Jean-Luc Melenchon and far-right chief Marine Le Pen.

site_title: Singapore joins other places with laws regulating online content
summary: Singapore has introduced new regulations to enhance online safety for users, mandating social media platforms to implement community standards and content moderation processes to minimize exposure to damaging online content. The rules aim to reduce harmful online content, including terrorist acts and abusive behavior. Public consultations on the regulations will begin next month. Singapore joins a growing number of territories with laws regulating online content, including Germany, Australia, and the European Union.

site_title: Moscow blasts West’s ‘destructive’ grain stance
summary: Russia blames the West's "destructive" stance for soaring grain prices, sparking global food crisis fears. The country's foreign ministry spokeswoman, Maria Zakharova, attributed the issue to Western regimes' "provoker and destroyer" actions and "systematic mistakes" in agricultural policy planning. The West's "short-sighted" financial and monetary mechanisms created during the Covid-19 pandemic are cited as causes of global inflation, leading to concerns of a global food crisis.

site_title: Bankers need to take on roles as green consultants to support transition finance, says DBS’s Muenkel
summary: DBS's Chief Sustainability Officer Helge Muenkel emphasizes the need for bankers to adopt a green consultant role, supporting transition finance to cut emissions and save the planet. The traditional banker role has evolved to be less financier and more consultant, focusing on ecosystem building and advising clients on sustainable practices. Muenkel highlights the importance of passion for sustainability in the rapidly changing field and notes that technical skills can become outdated quickly, making a consultant approach essential.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is seeking help to undo decades of dependence on coal, which still generates about 60% of its electricity.

If we want to secure a healthy planet, it will be an imperative to also support “brown” business and activities such as the production of steel and cement, or transportation to become less brown, and ultimately green.

site_title: China Evergrande sticks to restructuring plan target of before end of July
summary: China Evergrande Group has stuck to its original deadline to announce a preliminary restructuring plan, set for before the end of July, despite struggling with over $300 billion in debt. The embattled property developer is working on restructuring its debt, but its units have issued separate statements suspending trading due to pending financial results and an independent investigation into $2.8 billion pledged by its property services unit. Evergrande's financial crisis has become a poster child for China's property sector crisis.

site_title: Japan on alert for greenwashing as it lends US$40b for ESG
summary: The Development Bank of Japan (DBJ) plans to spend approximately US$40 billion on sustainable financing over the next 5 years, scrutinizing companies for potential greenwashing. The lender aims to allocate 40% of its lending and investments for environmental, social, and governance (ESG) purposes, with a focus on sustainability-linked and transition-linked loans. DBJ executive Fumiyo Harada warned that the bank will strictly review financing plans to prevent greenwashing claims, following global regulators' push for increased scrutiny of ESG credentials.

Over US$3 trillion has flowed into investments specifically touting their environmental, social and governance (ESG) credentials reported under scores of voluntary disclosures, stoking regulatory concerns about greenwashing.

site_title: Oil swings higher as tight supplies overshadow demand destruction
summary: Oil prices surged higher in volatile trading on Monday, driven by tight supplies and sanctions on Russian oil exports. Brent crude futures rose 0.9% to $114.13 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.56% to $110.17 a barrel. Despite slowing global economic growth, analysts believe supplies will remain tight, supporting high oil prices, with some predicting prices could reach $120 a barrel.

site_title: China scolds Sinopec after second fatal accident this month
summary: Chinese regulators summoned Sinopec Group executives after the oil giant suffered its second deadly accident this month, a fire at a Shanghai plant that killed one person and another blaze in Guangdong province that left 2 people missing. The accidents "seriously impacted people's sense of security" and fell short of expectations for state-owned enterprises. Strong measures are to be taken to address issues including ageing equipment and management shortcomings, amid concerns about social stability ahead of a major Communist Party congress.

site_title: Meta loses appeal in Russian court over 'extremist activity' tag: TASS
summary: A Moscow court rejected Meta's appeal, upholding its "extremist activity" ruling in March. The ruling restricts access to Meta's Facebook and Instagram platforms in Russia, which had been imposed after Russia sent troops into Ukraine. Meta claimed refusing to block content and labeling state-controlled media were not extremist activities. The ruling does not affect WhatsApp, which was initially exempt. The decision comes amid ongoing tensions between Russia and foreign social media companies over content moderation and labeling.

site_title: Tencent forms 'extended reality' unit as metaverse race gathers steam: sources
summary: Tencent Holdings has formed an "extended reality" (XR) unit, tasked with building the extended reality business, including software and hardware, as part of its metaverse efforts. The unit, led by Tencent Games Global's chief technology officer Li Shen, will initially have over 300 staff. This move comes as investors and tech giants worldwide focus on the metaverse concept, following Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg's announcement. Tencent's XR unit marks a rare foray into hardware for the company, which is known for its software and social media applications.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust falls to a confluence of headwinds – are more S-Reits at risk?
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT), a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (S-Reit), is set to be privatized by its sponsor group. The proposed scheme of arrangement involves paying S$0.70 in cash for each FHT stapled security not held by Frasers Property Limited (FPL) and TCC Group Investments. This move comes after a strategic review announced two months ago in April. The decision is attributed to headwinds faced by the trust, marking the departure of its managers after nearly eight years since its initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Malaysia-based fintech player Boost Credit doubles down on Indonesia’s MSME market
summary: Malaysia-based fintech company Boost Credit has doubled down on Indonesia's micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) market, growing 5 times in the past 12 months. Boost offers short-term financing to small-scale retailers and distributors, targeting the country's vast digital economy. With a strong local team and digital-first approach, the company has managed to keep non-performing loans under 1% and disburses upwards of 250 billion rupiah per month. Boost plans to scale up its operations and introduce new lending products, aiming to capture 15-20% of the market.

site_title: Bank of England's Mann says weak pound makes case for big rate hike
summary: Bank of England's interest-rate setter Catherine Mann says the weak pound is adding to inflation pressures in Britain, making a big rate hike necessary. Mann stated that a 50 basis-point rate hike was voted for by the Monetary Policy Committee, with two members supporting a 25 basis-point rise. Mann warned that a reversal in policy in the medium term could occur if domestic and external demand weaknesses intensify, adding momentum to the embedded inflation. Rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank would further weaken the pound and exacerbate inflation pressures.

site_title: No relief as heatwave in US moves east
summary: A heatwave that affected the US South-west and Mississippi Valley is moving eastward, bringing dangerously high temperatures. Forecasters warn of well above normal, near-record or even record-breaking heat in the central Plains to the Upper Midwest. The heatwave, which affected 120 million people last week, is expected to continue through Tuesday into the Great Lakes region, with highs in the mid-30s degrees Celsius. This is part of a larger weather pattern that has also caused widespread damage, including flooding and wildfires, and has led to the closure of Yellowstone National Park.

images.alt_text: In France, temperatures also climbed Friday with more than half of French departments at the highest or second-highest heat alert level by the afternoon.

site_title: Dubai to reopen world fair site as ‘city of the future’
summary: Dubai's Expo 2020 site will reopen as Expo City Dubai, a "city of the future" with housing, businesses, and leisure facilities. The $7 billion development, originally built for the 6-month Expo, will host offices for DP World and Siemens and feature 80% of the original infrastructure remaining. The new area, set to open on October 1, will prioritize sustainability, innovation, education, and entertainment, with a ban on single-use plastics. The Expo attracted 24 million visitors despite the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Banks, energy stocks fuel rebound in shares
summary: European stocks rose 1.0% on Monday after a 4.6% drop last week, fueled by gains in banking, energy, and travel stocks. The rebound came as recession worries eased, despite US interest rate hikes. French shares were capped after President Emmanuel Macron lost his parliamentary majority. The Stoxx 600 index reached over one-year lows last week due to global sell-off concerns, but recovered as battered sectors led the gains.

site_title: Europe may shift back to coal as Russia turns down gas flows
summary: Europe is considering a shift back to coal as Russia cuts gas supplies, threatening an energy crisis in winter. Russia's Gazprom has reduced gas flows to Italy and Germany, prompting countries to find alternative fuel sources. Germany plans to restart coal-fired power plants and Germany's economy ministry has announced measures to reduce gas consumption. The EU's gas inventories are still filling, but at a slower rate than expected. The crisis adds to challenges policymakers face as they tackle inflation and a worsening economic outlook.

site_title: VinFast parts ways with 4 top executives as it readies expansion
summary: VinFast, a Vietnam-based electric vehicle startup, has parted ways with four top executives, including deputy chief executive officers for global sales and product development, as the company prepares for its expansion into the US and European markets. The executives left their positions with the company's consent, with two resigning for personal reasons. The company is planning to launch its first overseas model and roll out a network of showrooms in the US and Europe, and is also seeking financing from the US government.

site_title: Berlin to host food security conference on Friday
summary: Germany will host a global food security conference on Friday, attended by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, to address the looming food crisis caused by the war in Ukraine. The conference aims to stabilize food supplies worldwide and follow a similar G7 meeting on June 26-28, where Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to join via video-link. The West demands Russia stop blockading Ukraine's ports, while Moscow blames Western sanctions for the crisis.

site_title: 3 Spackman directors resign, cite exploring ‘other corporate endeavours’ as a reason
summary: Three directors of Spackman Entertainment Group have resigned, citing a desire to explore "other corporate endeavours" as the reason. The directors, including Jessie Thong, Ng Hong Whee, and Richard Lee, will continue to assist with the company's independent review. The company will need to refresh its board and improve its capabilities and diversity. The resignations will leave Spackman with only one member each on the audit and risk management committee and the remuneration committee, which the company aims to fill within two months.

site_title: Euro rises with focus on ECB, US dollar retreats
summary: The euro rose 0.4% against the US dollar on Monday, as markets focused on the European Central Bank's efforts to combat fragmentation in the currency bloc. Analysts dismissed the French parliamentary election, where President Emmanuel Macron lost an absolute majority, as having limited market impact. The ECB's promise of a new anti-fragmentation tool and its interest rate hike are seen as key drivers of the euro's rise, while the US dollar index fell 0.3% to a two-decade high.

site_title: Court delays Garuda Indonesia's debt deal ratification for a week
summary: Garuda Indonesia's debt restructuring deal has been delayed for a week due to objections from two creditors, Greylag Goose Leasing 1410 and 1446, in a Jakarta commercial court. The creditors disputed the court-verified amount of their claims against Garuda, seeking recognition of an additional 5.99 trillion rupiah (US$403.91 million). The court panel has agreed to study the request, causing a one-week delay in ratifying the deal, which aims to restructure the airline's over US$9 billion debt.

site_title: Japan inflation cuts into Premier Fumio Kishida's support ahead of election
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support has slipped to 60% in a series of media surveys ahead of an upper house election on July 10. Dissatisfaction with his handling of rising prices has grown, with 69% disapproving of his inflation policies. The opposition Constitutional Democratic Party is calling for a rethink of the Bank of Japan's policy, but faces little support. Kishida's government is concerned about the yen's rapid fall and has provided handouts to alleviate the effect of price rises.

site_title: Marcos names himself agriculture chief to tackle food cost
summary: Philippines President-elect Ferdinand Marcos Jr has appointed himself agriculture secretary, aiming to tackle rising food costs. He expects higher food prices in the coming quarters and plans to increase farm output through loans and modern machinery. This move, a rare instance of an incoming leader taking on a concurrent role, comes as food inflation quickened to 4.9% in May. Marcos also discussed the need for environmentally neutral mining and targeted subsidies for fuel price-affected sectors.

site_title: Germany sticks to 2030 coal exit target despite energy crisis
summary: Germany remains committed to its 2030 goal to phase out coal power plants, despite an energy crisis sparked by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Following a recent surge in coal use, the country has power-up its coal plants, but the economy ministry insists the 2030 target is unchanged. The decision aims to reduce CO2 emissions, which would be higher if the government relied more on coal for electricity generation.

summary: A Hong Kong floating restaurant, Jumbo, sank in the South China Sea on Sunday after encountering adverse conditions and taking on water. The 1,000-meter-deep water made salvage efforts difficult. No crew members were injured. The restaurant, which closed in 2020 due to financial struggles, had been towed away from Hong Kong and was awaiting a new operator. Jumbo was once a luxury landmark, but its financial woes and closure were met with regret and nostalgia from Hong Kong residents.

site_title: Ryanair sees some relief as British pilots accept pay deal
summary: Ryanair's British pilots have accepted a revised pay offer, averting a potential strike and providing the airline with relief amid a wave of strikes across Europe. The pilots, members of the British Airline Pilots' Association (BALPA), voted to accept the deal, which restores pay after mitigation measures during the pandemic. However, Ryanair still faces strikes in Italy, Spain, Portugal, France, and Belgium on June 25, adding to travel woes and disruptions at airports such as London Gatwick and Amsterdam's Schiphol.

site_title: EasyJet cuts summer flights on staff shortages
summary: EasyJet has reduced its summer flight schedule due to severe staff shortages affecting the UK aviation sector. The airline expects to operate at 87% of pre-pandemic capacity in the third quarter and aims to reach 90% by the end of September. Despite this, EasyJet's bookings remain strong for July and August, and the company has apologized to customers for service disruptions. The airline is also seeking to build resilience amid delays to air traffic control and passport checks.

site_title: Starbucks Malaysia operator opts to sacrifice margin rather than raise prices
summary: BERJAYA Food, the operator of Starbucks and Kenny Rogers Roasters in Malaysia, plans to curb costs internally rather than raising prices due to rising production costs. Group CEO Sydney Quays stated that the company may sacrifice margin to avoid passing on costs to consumers, citing the impact of high commodity prices and supply chain issues. Despite concerns about inflation, Quays assured that the company has managed costs well and that its business operations remain unaffected.

site_title: Oscar-winning director Paul Haggis arrested in Italy on sexual assault charges
summary: Canadian film director Paul Haggis was arrested in Italy on charges of sexual assault and aggravated personal injury, allegedly inflicted upon a young woman. Haggis denied the accusations and claimed he would plead innocent and cooperate with authorities. The woman was reportedly forced to seek medical care and was left at Brindisi airport after the alleged non-consensual relations. Haggis, winner of Oscars for "Million Dollar Baby" and "Crash," is currently facing a possible trial.

summary: Volkswagen faces mounting scrutiny over its presence in the Chinese province of Xinjiang, where allegations of human rights violations and coercive labor practices have been raised by human-rights groups and UN experts. summary: Reenova Investment Holding, a suspended stock, received a compliance notice from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) due to changes in its board composition. site_title: Shanghai's weekend Covid testing blitz shows cases contained
summary: Shanghai reported 2 local COVID-19 cases on Monday, down from 13 cases on Sunday and 9 on Saturday, as a mass-testing drive found the virus seemingly contained. China is relying on frequent mass testing to stick to its COVID Zero stance, with 24 cases nationwide on Sunday, the fewest in over 3 months. Other cities, including Beijing and Macau, also reported cases, but with declining numbers and measures to contain the spread.

images.alt_text: Residents queue at a Covid-19 testing booth in Shanghai, China, on Monday, June 20, 2022. Shanghai’s weekend Covid-testing blitz found the virus seemingly contained, after a spike in cases last week had fanned concern the city would be plunged back into lockdown. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Intel seeks US$624m in interest from EU after antitrust fine win
summary: Intel has filed a claim for $624 million in interest from the European Commission, 5 months after winning an antitrust fine case. The claim is based on an interest rate equivalent to the European Central Bank's refinancing rate, ranging from 1.25% to 3.5% from May 2009 to February this year. This decision comes after the EU repaid Intel $1.2 billion in January, minus 38 million euros in interest. The European Commission refused to reimburse Intel for default interest, prompting the claim.

images.alt_text: Intel shares are down nearly 28 per cent over the past year and the company has told investors to brace for lower gross margins than it has historically earned as it spends heavily to catch up to rivals like TSMC.
Intel Corp shareholders rejected compensation packages for top executives, including a payout of as much as US$178.6 million to CEO Pat Gelsinger (pictured).
The global shortage of critical semiconductors is likely to last at least through next year and perhaps longer, US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo warned on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 15.50 points lower on Monday, at 1,441.24, amid a decrease in volume to 2.623 billion lots worth RM1.691 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 747 to 200, resulting in a lower market tone.

site_title: Shareholders should ask about succession planning at AGMs
summary: Shareholders attending annual general meetings (AGMs) are increasingly asking more pertinent questions of their managements, including those on corporate strategy and succession planning. However, this topic is rarely raised. A 2013 study by the National University of Singapore's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations found that family-owned firms often have family members holding leading board positions, with 42.8% combining CEO and chairman roles. Only 3% of family businesses are expected to make it beyond the third generation, and 62% reported not having chosen suitable successors. Shareholders should focus on succession planning and top management skills, particularly in an uncertain business environment.

images.alt_text: Board diversity through renewal, succession and mentorship

site_title: Hong Kong’s new health chief is staunch defender of Covid zero
summary: Hong Kong's new health chief, Lo Chung-mau, has expressed a strong stance against lifting the city's strict Covid-19 policies, echoing Beijing's "zero Covid" approach. Despite softening his tone in a press briefing, Lo pledged to implement "evidence-based" policies, potentially limiting Hong Kong's reconnection with the international community. The city's tough border controls, quarantine measures, and compulsory testing have been criticized by the international business community, with outgoing Chief Executive Carrie Lam urging a decision on relaxing policies soon.

images.alt_text: Lam says she would be “a bit worried”’ if the city were to stick to its border rules in the coming half-year.

HONG KONG’S outgoing leader Carrie Lam urged residents to avoid banquets and other large gatherings amid a resurgence of Covid-19 in the Asian financial hub, but held off from imposing new restrictions as serious infections remain low.
Macau’s government relies on casinos for over 80 per cent of its income, with most of the population employed directly or indirectly by the casino industry.

site_title: E-commerce brand aggregator Rainforest raises US$45m
summary: E-commerce brand aggregator Rainforest has secured US$45 million in funding led by Canopy Tropics, a subsidiary of private equity fund Southern Capital Group. The company, which has achieved US$30 million in annualized revenue, plans to continue hiring globally and expand its portfolio of brands. With total capital raised over US$100 million, Rainforest expects to reach profitability by the end of 2022, following the acquisition of baby care brand NatureBond in March 2022.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit to acquire 2 China data centres for 1.6 billion yuan
summary: Keppel DC Reit has entered into conditional transactions to acquire two data centers in Guangdong, China, for approximately 1.6 billion yuan (S$338.3 million). The acquisitions are expected to be accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit, increasing its portfolio occupancy rate to 98.9% and weighted average lease expiry to 8.8 years. The properties will be leased to Bluesea on a triple net basis for 15 years, with the handover expected to take place by Q3 2023.
