site_title: Nutryfarm’s non-executive independent director quits just after 8 months
summary: NutryFarm's independent director Low Chin Parn Eric is resigning effective September 13, citing personal reasons, after just over 8 months of appointment. This is the 9th cessation of appointment at the company in the past 12 months, following the voluntary suspension of its shares in April. Low remains an independent director of Catalist-listed OneAPEX.

site_title: Singapore civil servants to get mid-year bonus of 0.35 month, up from 0.3 month in 2021
summary: Singapore's civil service will pay a mid-year bonus of 0.35 months to all officers, up from 0.3 months in 2021, reflecting a forecasted economic growth between 3% and 4%. Junior officers will receive a one-time payment of S$200 or S$400, depending on their grade. The government aims to recognize the hard work of civil servants during the pandemic and will review National Wages Council guidelines later in the year to determine the year-end bonus.

images.alt_text: Revisions to the Civil Service generic schemes were last made in 2014, and since then, salary levels in the market have gone up, PSD said in a statement on Sunday (June 5).
Singapore is still likely to maintain real wage growth in 2022, according to the latest wage practices report by the Ministry of Manpower.

site_title: Chinese splash out on tech goods, camping gear in shopping fest
summary: Chinese shoppers prioritized high-end home appliances and camping gear during the "618" shopping festival, driven by lifestyle changes due to Covid-19 curbs. Despite weak consumption, e-commerce platforms like JD.com reported growth, with sales of gaming projectors, air fryers, and slim fridges increasing significantly. Camping gear and outdoor equipment also saw a surge in sales, fueled by the growing popularity of outdoor activities among city-dwellers.

images.alt_text: This year’s shopping festival growth was the slowest for JD.com, showing how consumer appetite in China has been hit by lockdowns.

“The impact in the Covid-stricken cities are obviously larger and we are seeing that at the end of the outbreaks, there is no rapid recovery, which is very worrying to us,” said Xin, who heads a subsidiary of JD.com.
Staff members wait at an entrance to enter a shopping mall after a Covid-19 lockdown was lifted in Shanghai, June 1, 2022.

site_title: China’s glut of graduates
summary: China is set to produce a record 10.8 million college graduates over the next few weeks, but job prospects are dire, with less than half having received a job offer as of April. State-funded universities are under pressure to keep unemployment rates down, as urban youth unemployment hit a record 18.4% in May. Many graduates are hoping the government can provide jobs, with state-owned enterprises being the most desired placements, but the number of new recruits remains stable at around 170,000 per year.

images.alt_text: The growing caution among young buyers in China’s battered property market, which accounts for a quarter of gross domestic product, presents a major challenge for policymakers in Beijing now scrambling to revive housing activity.

China is moving to spur spending that was depressed by Covid curbs in some of its biggest cities, but piecemeal measures such as vouchers, subsidies for car buyers and digital yuan payments have been modest compared with other big global economies.

site_title: Philippines closer to adding one of world's top solar sites
summary: SOLAR Philippines has submitted energy contract offers that could enable 10 gigawatts of solar projects to proceed, with a potential capacity of 9 terrawatt-hours per year. The projects, set to begin operation between 2025-2026, would significantly boost the nation's renewable energy generation and help address a potential power shortage. The development aims to aid a shift away from coal, with the Philippines currently relying on 57% of its electricity from coal. This move is part of the country's efforts to expand its renewables capacity.

site_title: Bank of England to get rid of mortgage affordability rules
summary: The Bank of England plans to scrap its mortgage affordability rules, effective August 1. The rules, introduced in 2014, tested borrowers' ability to repay mortgages in the event of significant interest rate rises. The Financial Policy Committee will withdraw the affordability test, but keep the loan-to-income flow limit, which limits borrowers to 4.5 times their annual income. Borrowers will still be assessed under wider lending rules on affordability. The decision aims to simplify and predict the UK financial system's resilience.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished higher on Monday, June 20, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.42% to 21,163.91. A rally in property firms offset losses in Chinese tech giants, despite concerns over rising inflation and interest rates. The Shanghai Composite Index was flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange rose 1.27%.

site_title: IMF delegation arrives in crisis-hit Sri Lanka as fuel runs out
summary: An IMF delegation arrived in crisis-hit Sri Lanka on June 20 to discuss a potential bailout, amid severe fuel shortages and economic crisis. The team held talks with Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe on structuring a 17th loan program with the global lender. Sri Lanka is struggling with its worst financial problems in 7 decades, and public disaffection grows due to the persistent fuel shortage, with 22 million people facing shortages of diesel and petrol. The IMF visit aims to provide clarity on debt restructuring and relief funds, but a protracted process is expected.

site_title: As technology matures, smart cities take a more nuanced, human-centred approach
summary: Smart cities are shifting towards a more nuanced, human-centered approach, prioritizing engagement with affected communities and evaluating the impact of emerging technologies such as AI and machine learning before deployment. Cities are recognizing the importance of citizen participation and trust in the success of smart city initiatives, with some implementing modular, agile development models and citizen engagement strategies. The Digital Cities Index 2022 highlights the need for cities to balance technological advancements with the needs and concerns of citizens, particularly in areas such as privacy and inclusion, as technologies continue to evolve and impact urban environments.

images.alt_text: An office set up with typewriters.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda and PM Kishida reiterate united front on forex
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated their united front on foreign exchange matters after a meeting, with Kuroda expressing concern over currency movements. The yen briefly strengthened to a 24-year low against the US dollar after Kishida spoke, before returning to its previous levels. The meeting shows the government and central bank will continue to monitor currencies and collaborate on policy responses, despite the BOJ's dovish stance contrasting with the hawkish Federal Reserve. The move aims to boost public support ahead of an upper house election on July 10.

images.alt_text: Fumio Kishida, Japan's prime minister and president of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), speaks during a pre-election event by the Reiwa Rincho in Tokyo, Japan, on Sunday, June 19, 2022. Defense and foreign policy are the top priorities for Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party in its election pledges, as it looks to keep control of the upperhouse of parliament in a July 10 vote. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: STI down 0.05% on Monday despite modest Wall Street gains last week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.05% on Monday, despite Wall Street's modest gains last Friday, with 273 losers outnumbering 233 gainers in trading. The benchmark index closed at 3,096.4 points, while major indexes in Japan, South Korea, and Australia fell between 0.6% and 2%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index bucked the trend, rising 0.4%. Despite US equities being down 4.8-5.8%, economists remain cautious, citing no clear catalyst for sustained recovery in risk sentiments.

images.alt_text: Price tags are seen as a woman shops at a local market in Nice, France, June 7, 2022.    REUTERS/Eric Gaillard
The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2 per cent or 6.88 points to 3,091.21 as at 9.02 am.

site_title: Airlines to return to profit next year, says IATA in industry update
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts that the airline industry will return to profitability by 2023, driven by pent-up demand for travel and sustained bookings. Despite challenges such as labor shortages, fuel prices, and emissions pressures, airlines are expected to see a rebound in traffic and revenue. IATA director-general Willie Walsh stated that the industry is emerging "leaner, tougher, and nimbler" and that most markets should see traffic reach or exceed pre-pandemic levels by the second quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Passenger numbers dropped by 60 per cent in 2020, and in 2021 it was still down 50 per cent. Airlines lost nearly US$200 billion over 2 years.

The time needed to get security badges for newly hired staff has risen from 3 to 4 weeks in Britain, for example, to as long as 3 months, Willie Walsh, director general of the International Air Transport Association (IATA), said.

FILE PHOTO: Willie Walsh, IATA director-general, says consumers have saved up during the 2 years when most air travel was barred, and are now prepared to spend on more comfortable seats during their flights.

site_title: Chelsea chairman Bruce Buck to step down following sale of club
summary: Chelsea chairman Bruce Buck is stepping down after almost 20 years in the role, following the completion of the Todd Boehly-led consortium's takeover of the club. Buck will continue as a senior advisor and expressed pride in the club's success on and off the pitch. Boehly praised Buck's service and commitment to the club, as Buck leaves his post at the end of June.

site_title: Nearly 1 in 4 European firms mulling shift out of China
summary: Nearly 1 in 4 European firms in China are considering moving their investments out of the country due to ongoing Covid outbreaks and lockdowns, according to a survey by the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China. The number of firms reassessing their options in China is the highest proportion in a decade, with 23% planning to relocate. The firms are looking at options in South-east Asia, the Asia-Pacific region, Europe, North America, and South Asia. China's zero-tolerance approach to combating infections is expected to last beyond this year, potentially chilling foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Macau’s government relies on casinos for over 80 per cent of its income, with most of the population employed directly or indirectly by the casino industry.

“The impact in the Covid-stricken cities are obviously larger and we are seeing that at the end of the outbreaks, there is no rapid recovery, which is very worrying to us,” said Xin, who heads a subsidiary of JD.com.

Shanghai residents will need to take nucleic acid tests at least once a week until the end of July, with workers at supermarkets, barbers, drugstores, shopping malls and restaurants required to undergo daily testing.

site_title: SP Group’s charity golf event raises S$500,000 for low-income seniors
summary: SP Group's annual charity golf event raised S$500,000 for low-income seniors supported by the SP Heartware Fund. The funds will benefit 25,000 vulnerable seniors through Community Chest's programs, including befriending, counseling, and caregiver support. Despite an uncertain economic climate, SP Group remains committed to providing uninterrupted care and support. The company expressed gratitude to business partners and the public for their support in sustaining these critical programs, enabling more resilient communities to overcome challenges.

site_title: Widening ripples: The war in Ukraine and inflation in Asean+3
summary: The war in Ukraine is causing significant economic ripple effects in the Asean+3 region, comprising 10 ASEAN nations and China, Japan, and Korea. Energy and food prices have surged by over 25% due to supply disruptions, leading to higher inflation rates. Despite limited trade links with Russia and Ukraine, the region has not been spared from the economic fallout. Economies are struggling to balance demand-pull pressure from post-pandemic reopening with cost-push pressure from higher prices. Policymakers face challenges in mitigating inflation without harming economic recovery, and some measures, such as export bans, may exacerbate the problem.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group sees a nascent rate-hike cycle to tackle price pressures flattening its yield curves the most in the developing world.
The Bank of Korea raised its inflation forecast for this year to 4.5 per cent, from a 3.1 per cent projection made in February.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drop 2% on recession worries, won weakens
summary: South Korean shares fell 2% on Monday, ending at a 19-month low, amid global recession concerns. The benchmark Kospi dropped 49.9 points, or 2.04%, to 2,391.03. The won touched its 27-month low, while foreign investors sold 662.4 billion won worth of shares. Finance minister reiterated the need to stabilize the currency market.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi slipped 10.48 points or 0.43 per cent to 2,440.93, marking its lowest close since Nov 6, 2020.

site_title: Don’t raise the eurozone’s public-debt limit
summary: The European Commission is reconsidering the eurozone's public-debt limit, amid calls to increase debt ceilings to address climate change and other challenges. However, experts argue that this approach would be misguided, given the already high levels of national debt and rising inflation. Instead, the focus should be on reallocating public expenditure to increase its quality, rather than quantity. The current rules, which include ceilings on budget deficits and public debt, remain a useful point of reference for discussion and coordination of national policies, but should be reformed to focus on fiscal sustainability and pan-European considerations.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on April 29, 2020 shows a customer pushing a shopping cart past the shelves during  purchases at a supermarket in Duesseldorf, western Germany, on April 29, 2020. - A surge in eurozone consumer prices, propelled even higher by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, is "very close" to reaching its peak, European Central Bank vice-president Luis de Guindos said on April 28, 2022. (Photo by Ina FASSBENDER / AFP)
The ECB faces challenges in German courts over the PEPP programme, while a previous challenge over the public sector purchase programme saw the ECB have to provide information to justify the policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends at more than 5-week low; chip, energy shares drag
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 0.74% to 25,771.22, its lowest level since May 12, due to losses in chip-related and energy stocks. Oil explorers tanked 9.13% and refiners fell 5.5% amid tumbling oil prices. Technology and growth stocks declined due to concerns over rising interest rates. Auto and part makers rose, with Subaru gaining 2.55%.

images.alt_text: Asian markets fell again on Monday and oil prices extended losses on growing fears that central bank moves to rein in soaring inflation will induce a recession.

site_title: Mounting crypto liquidations make DeFi go to extremes
summary: DeFi apps, where users trade, borrow, and lend cryptocurrencies without intermediaries, are facing unprecedented measures to protect themselves from cascading liquidations triggered by the recent crypto price rout. Token holders of Solend and MakerDAO, among others, have voted to take over large user accounts to avoid massive liquidations, employing unconventional measures such as temporary account takeovers and increased governance voting time. These efforts aim to mitigate the risks of interconnected DeFi protocols and prevent further damage to the industry.

images.alt_text: While Celsius is one of the big participants in the DeFi space, the company itself is more like a centralised bank or other financial middleman than a collection of DeFi smart contracts and algorithms governed by the democracy of token holders spread out throughout the world.

site_title: Euromoney gets £1.6b possible cash offer
summary: A consortium of Astorg Asset Management and Epiris LLP has made a possible cash offer to London-listed Euromoney Institutional Investor, valuing the company at around £1.6 billion. The offer is a premium of about 34% to Euromoney's closing share price, and the consortium is in discussions with the company. Euromoney had previously received four separate cash offers, ranging between £13.50 and £11.75 per share, and has until July 18 to either make a formal offer or walk away under UK Takeover Panel rules.

images.alt_text: In the event Sanjuro's privatisation offer fails, Hwa Hong’s share price could “trade down significantly” if there is no competing offer, UOBKH said.
Under the preliminary non-binding proposal, a new entity will be incorporated to acquire assets of Zilingo Pte Ltd while an investor group will commit US$8 million in the new entity.
The company said that the deal offers shareholders an opportunity to exit their investments since the trading suspension on its counter was imposed.

site_title: Disney’s Lightyear misses estimates in box office debut
summary: Disney's animated film "Lightyear" underperformed in its debut weekend at the North American box office, earning an estimated $51 million, falling short of forecasts. The film's poor performance marks one of the worst domestic openings for a Pixar film, with the worst being "Cars 3" in 2017. The film faced competition from "Jurassic World: Dominion" and "Top Gun: Maverick," and its marketing strategy may have contributed to its lackluster opening.

images.alt_text: Cast members (from left) Jeff Goldblum, Bryce Dallas Howard and Chris Pratt attend a premiere for Jurassic World: Dominion in Los Angeles on June 6, 2022.

site_title: Decoding greenwashing in climate investing
summary: A growing number of investors are turning to climate-themed investments, but the issue of "greenwashing" - the over-representation of an investment's environmental impact - is becoming a major concern. To combat this, investors should engage with companies, adopt internal carbon pricing mechanisms, and consider Just Transition principles, which prioritize the impact on local communities and ecosystems. This approach can help ensure that investments drive real, positive impact and competitive financial returns. By combining these strategies, investors can effectively decode greenwashing and make a meaningful contribution to the fight against climate change.

images.alt_text: Most rich countries have announced they will be net zero by 2050, while China and India have vowed to reach that point by 2060 and 2070, respectively. But the devil is in the details.

Over US$3 trillion has flowed into investments specifically touting their environmental, social and governance (ESG) credentials reported under scores of voluntary disclosures, stoking regulatory concerns about greenwashing.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses as miners plunge
summary: Australia's shares plummeted for a seventh consecutive session, ending 0.64% lower at 6,433.4, due to a decline in commodities and fears of a global recession. The country's top three miners, Rio Tinto, BHP, and Fortescue, lost roughly A$26.1 billion in market value, with shares falling between 5.1% and 8.6%. Energy stocks also slid 5.2%, while financials rose 0.55%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate policy cues are expected to be closely watched by investors.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average fell 0.74 per cent to 25,771.22, its lowest closing level since May 12, after gaining as much as 0.7 per cent in early trade.
Asian markets fell again on Monday and oil prices extended losses on growing fears that central bank moves to rein in soaring inflation will induce a recession.

site_title: Europe: Equities ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% to 7,047.25 points, Frankfurt's DAX index up 0.3% to 13,162.57 points, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.1% to 5,887.14 points. However, gains were limited by concerns over the economic impact of rising global interest rates.

site_title: Britain set for biggest rail strike in decades
summary: Britain is set for its largest rail strike in over three decades, with over 50,000 workers from the RMT union planning a three-day national strike over pay. The strike coincides with major events like the Glastonbury music festival and will affect thousands of teenagers taking national exams. Rail operators warn of disruption throughout the week, despite lines not affected by strike action reducing services. The government and RMT have engaged in a war of words, with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps accusing the union of refusing to meet for talks and RMT general-secretary Mick Lynch saying strikes will go ahead due to no viable settlements.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 1, 2022, a notice advises commuters that there are no Transport for London (TfL) London Underground Tube train services running from Walthamstow in east London, during a day of strike action. - Strikes are planned for Tuesday, 21, June, Thursday, 23, June and Saturday 25, June this week in the biggest dispute on Britain's railway network since 1989, according to the RMT. The union has also announced a 24-hour walkout of its members on the Tube, London's underground railway network, planned for Tuesday. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)
With the national strike looming, train operators have issued warnings against making unnecessary journeys.

site_title: China keeps lending benchmarks unchanged, wary of policy divergence risks
summary: China's central bank kept benchmark lending rates unchanged, with the one-year loan prime rate at 3.70% and the five-year LPR at 4.45%, amid concerns over policy divergence risks and potential yuan depreciation. Policymakers are cautious about further monetary easing, as global central banks, including the Federal Reserve, are raising interest rates to combat inflation. The decision reflects China's reluctance to loosen monetary policy at a time of a weak domestic economy and a strong renminbi.

images.alt_text: China’s financial regulators pledged to keep credit growth stable in the property sector and help homebuyers affected by Covid-19 outbreaks to defer their mortgage payments.
China’s central bank is expected to keep unchanged for a fifth straight month on Wednesday the borrowing costs on its medium-term policy loans.

site_title: Uneven recovery and uncomfortably high inflation to dog markets
summary: Global commodity markets and central banks' efforts to withdraw pandemic-driven stimulus are expected to sustain high inflation for the rest of the year, according to Moody's Analytics. The forecasted global GDP growth is 2.8% in 2022 and 3.1% in 2023, with Asia and the US supporting growth. However, central banks' aggressive rate hikes may slow growth and elevate recession risks for some countries, particularly emerging market economies reliant on energy imports.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell reiterated his determination to curb the hottest inflation in 40 years and said the US central bank’s commitment encourages the world to hold and transact in dollars.

A person walks through the Wall Street subway station near the New York Stock Exchange. On Jun 15 at the end of the central bank’s 2-day policy meeting, Fed chairman Jerome Powell’s rate-setting committee boosted interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, the largest hike since 1994.
The Federal Reserve is now expected to hike interest rates by 75 basis points Wednesday, just weeks after Chair Jerome Powell and his team repeatedly advertised a half percentage point move.

site_title: Australia needs coal, gas to back up renewables: regulators
summary: Australia's Energy Security Board proposed paying coal- and gas-fired generators for buffer supply on the grid, while offering longer-term contracts for new back-up capacity, such as batteries. The plan aims to encourage investment in renewable energy and energy storage to fill the gap as coal-fired plants retire. The proposal seeks to make revenue more predictable for non-wind and solar power providers, addressing the highly volatile wholesale electricity market. A final recommendation is due by the end of 2022, with the goal of smoothing the transition to cleaner energy and reducing blackout risks.

images.alt_text: Climate action has been politically fraught in Australia, a country where fossil fuels still dominate much of the economy and the domestic energy market.
Australian coal-fired generators have brought 1,900 megawatts (MW) of capacity back on line since Wednesday.

site_title: China's May oil imports from Russia soar 55% to a record, surpass Saudi supply
summary: China's crude oil imports from Russia surged 55% in May to a record high, surpassing Saudi Arabia as the top supplier. The imports totaled nearly 8.42 million tonnes, equivalent to 1.98 million barrels per day. Chinese firms, including Sinopec and Zhenhua Oil, bought Russian oil at discounted prices due to sanctions on Moscow. This marks a reversal after Russia was displaced by Saudi Arabia in the previous month. China is now the world's largest crude oil importer.

images.alt_text: Screens promoting the use of green hydrogen at an airport in Santiago. Major oil companies still spend the bulk of their money on oil and gas, but are devoting a growing proportion to low-carbon energy.

site_title: Australia power crisis forces manufacturers to eye offshore moves, production cuts
summary: Australia's largest building materials manufacturers are cutting back operations, hiking prices, and considering offshore moves due to soaring power and gas bills amid a coal-fired generation shortage. The crisis has driven up demand for gas-fired generation and record-high global coal and gas prices, leaving the $100 billion manufacturing sector exposed to soaring costs. Companies such as Brickworks and Boral are considering moving production offshore to manage costs, with Brickworks' CEO stating that it would "pretty easily" shut down plants and move production if the current spot price were higher than its US-based gas price.

images.alt_text: Australia's Energy Security Board proposed on Monday paying coal- and gas-fired generators for buffer supply on the grid but offering longer-term contracts for new back-up capacity.
Australia’s two biggest airlines, Qantas Airways and Virgin Australia,  are operating domestic capacity above pre-pandemic levels as demand rebounds.
Australian coal-fired generators have brought 1,900 megawatts (MW) of capacity back on line since Wednesday.

site_title: Sembmarine doubles down on merger narrative after minority shareholder revolt
summary: Sembcorp Marine reiterated its proposed merger with Keppel Offshore and Marine (Keppel O&M), despite a minority shareholder revolt. The company claims the merger will offer increased agility, technical strength, and operational efficiencies, and better position it to compete in the new energy era. However, minority shareholder Philip Loh has launched an online campaign against the deal, citing unfair terms. The combined entity would have a combined net loss of S$1.3 billion, but narrower loss per share.

images.alt_text: The general wariness among investors is arguably as much of an obstacle to Sembmarine coaxing its minority shareholders to support the proposed merger as the dilutive nature of the deal.

Sembmarine on Monday (Jun 6) responded to shareholders’ queries on its proposed merger with Keppel O&M, a deal expected to create a combined entity offering offshore renewables, new energy and cleaner solutions in the O&M space, with an indicative net order book of more than 50 jobs worth S$6.4 billion.
With the progressive completion of projects, Sembmarine said it has redeployed freed-up resources for other projects under execution as well as to take on new projects.

site_title: UK-based Deliveroo names Scilla Grimble as next finance chief
summary: Deliveroo has named Scilla Grimble as its new chief financial officer, expected to start in June 2023. Grimble, currently finance chief of MoneySupermarket.com Group, will succeed Adam Miller, who is stepping down on September 17. David Hancock will serve as interim CFO until Grimble takes over. Deliveroo, a London-based online delivery firm operating in several countries, has made the appointment to address future financial challenges.

summary: Zilingo's co-founders, Dhruv Kapoor and Ankiti Bose, have proposed a management buyout to avoid liquidation, with a new entity to acquire the company's assets and an investor group committing US$8 million. The proposal, facilitated by financial advisor Strand Hanson, aims to revive the company's operations and repay outstanding debt. The plan includes a 5-year business plan, a scheme of arrangement in court, and a debt moratorium. Existing shareholders may still have a say in the company's future, with the possibility of negotiating equity grants.

site_title: S&P 500 in a bear market
summary: The S&P 500 Index (SPX) entered a bear market on June 13, 2022, with a decline of 23% year-to-date, marking its first bear market since March 2020. The Nasdaq 100 index (NDX) is deeper in the bear market with a 31.8% decline. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike to 1.5-1.75% aims to tame inflation, with a target of 3.4% by the end of the year. The SPX's price-to-earnings ratio is 15.48x, lower than its past averages, and technical indicators suggest further weakness, with the Relative Strength Index (RSI) approaching oversold levels.

site_title: Macau to hold mass testing after finding 12 Covid infections
summary: Macau is conducting mass COVID-19 testing after 12 community cases were detected, the first in over 250 days. Non-essential businesses have been urged to close and residents are advised to stay at home. Schools have been suspended until further notice. The source of the infections is still under investigation. This comes after Macau eased quarantine requirements for arrivals from Hong Kong and other places. The city's casino industry has been severely impacted by the pandemic, with revenue dropping 68% in May.

site_title: Decisive people aren’t better decision-makers
summary: Research by Wojciech Zajkowski suggests that indecisive people don't make worse decisions, but rather, lack confidence in their choices, which can lead to discouragement and low commitment. State-oriented individuals, who take more time to deliberate, are less flexible and more prone to abandoning efforts, but can still produce high-quality decisions. The study highlights the importance of "metacognitive" skills, or thinking about one's thinking, over cognitive skills in decision-making, and recommends focusing on confidence and commitment rather than just the quality of choices.

site_title: Far-right sends shockwaves in France after electoral breakthrough
summary: Marine Le Pen's National Rally (RN) secured a historic breakthrough in France's legislative elections, winning between 85-90 seats and potentially becoming the second-largest party in parliament. This marks a significant shift for the far-right, which has increased its number of lawmakers almost tenfold since 2012. Le Pen's party tapped into widespread discontent with President Emmanuel Macron, winning 42% in the presidential election and vowing to be a respectful opposition. Despite not being the largest party, the RN will have significant influence in parliament, enabling it to challenge the government and shape policy.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines nearing decision on replacing 21 A330s: CEO
summary: Malaysia Airlines is nearing a decision on replacing 21 of its Airbus A330 widebodies with more fuel-efficient planes by mid-to-late July. CEO Izham Ismail stated the airline is considering a one-to-one replacement plan, with options including the A330neo, A350, and Boeing 787. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions and comes after the airline reported positive cash flow since October, with a goal of returning to profit in 2023, having cut its debt burden by over half last year. A decision is expected to be made in the coming weeks.

site_title: Bank of Japan should stick to easing policy: PM Kishida
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida urged the Bank of Japan to maintain its easing policy, citing concerns about its impact on smaller companies. The current policy, which weakens the yen, may increase interest rate burdens for small businesses, but Kishida also emphasized the need to stem rising prices. The Bank of Japan maintained its yield curve control programme last week, which was seen as a move against speculation of policy tightening. Kishida's approval rating fell to 48% in a recent poll, with respondents citing rising prices as a major concern.

site_title: Warehouse business red hot, boosted by pandemic, e-commerce
summary: The US warehouse business has experienced a surge in demand driven by the pandemic and e-commerce growth, with big investment funds taking note. Available space has dwindled, and vacancy rates are at 3.4%, with demand exceeding supply for 18 months. Technologically advanced warehouses are required to meet same-day delivery demands, and companies are investing heavily in the sector. Private equity firms, such as Blackstone, have invested heavily in warehouses, but some experts warn of a potential correction in the market due to tightening credit conditions and Amazon's decision to sublet or renegotiate warehouse space.

The company wants to its warehouses to be in urban centres so that orders by online shoppers can be delivered in shorter time - crucial now that online shopping is losing some of its shine as the world reopens after the pandemic.

site_title: Duterte's daughter sworn in as Philippines vice-president
summary: Philippines Vice-President-elect Sara Duterte-Carpio, 44, was sworn in on June 19, 2022, as the country's 15th vice-president. She was the running mate of Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who won the May 9 elections and will become president on June 30. Duterte-Carpio called for national unity and praised her parents for their support. She will serve as Marcos' education secretary and is the daughter of outgoing President Rodrigo Duterte. Both Duterte-Carpio and Marcos scored landslide victories, marking a crucial alliance and a message of unity.

site_title: Private-market investments among individuals set to grow, says Blackstone
summary: Blackstone's Private Wealth Solutions sees significant growth in private-market investments among high net worth individuals (HNWIs), driven by increasing adoption of alternative assets and innovations in access and education. HNWIs have allocated less than 5% of their portfolios to private markets, with a focus on private debt and equity. The firm's global retail business has nearly reached its 10-year target of $250 billion in assets, with a current value of $222 billion, and is expected to double to $500 billion. Blackstone attributes the growth to a shift in investor appetite for uncorrelated assets and a growing awareness of the need for income and inflation protection.

The company has also expanded its portfolio through acquisitions and is looking to grow its number of medical clinics in the heartlands to make pain care treatment more accessible.

summary: Fertiliser stockpiles are swelling globally as farmers shun high prices, easing concerns of reduced crop yields and worsening food inflation. The fertiliser shortage caused by the Russia-Ukraine invasion has largely subsided, with supplies piling up in ports and warehouses. Wholesale fertiliser prices are declining, with North American prices at their lowest since January, after soaring to multi-year highs. The US government is encouraging the purchase of Russian fertiliser, and shipments are entering the US, reducing concerns of a complete shutdown. This may ease some of the concerns about farmers skipping fertiliser applications, potentially reducing food inflation and hunger.

site_title: China tests tech that could beam solar power from space to Earth
summary: China's researchers successfully tested a full-system model of technology that wirelessly transmits solar power from space to Earth. The model, developed at Xidian University, captures sunlight, converts it into microwave beams, and transmits them through the air to a receiver station on the ground, generating electricity. The technology eliminates the limitation of solar power not being able to operate in darkness, as panels can be placed in orbit. China is not the only country exploring this technology, with researchers in the US, India, Russia, the UK, France, and Japan also working on similar projects.

summary: The UK is facing its biggest train strike in 30 years, with 40,000 staff and 10,000 London Underground workers set to walk out on June 21. summary: Corporate loan rates in Europe are expected to rise due to increasing borrowing costs, with corporate issuers paying almost twice as much in the second quarter compared to the first for 5-year transactions in euros. site_title: Crypto, houses, sneakers, Rolexes: How FOMO drove the economy
summary: A recent economic phenomenon is attributed to the fear of missing out (FOMO), driving up prices for luxury items such as high-end watches, sneakers, and houses. Cryptocurrencies, like Bitcoin, have also experienced significant price increases during the pandemic, with some assets seeing growth rates exceeding those of the S&P 500. However, experts argue that these investments often lack intrinsic value, and DeFi technology, which aims to replicate traditional finance, is not necessarily better than its traditional counterpart. summary: The luxury handbag market is shifting towards appreciation and investment value, driven by the increasing spending power of high net worth and ultra-high net worth women. Historically considered frivolous, luxury handbags are now being seen as assets with potential for long-term value and resale. Brands like Hermès and Chanel are capitalizing on this trend by making certain models scarce and only offering them to select customers, increasing their resale value. summary: Opec+, a 23-nation coalition, is grappling with its next move as US officials pressure Saudi Arabia and the UAE to increase oil production to ease prices above $110 a barrel. summary: Revlon has borrowed $375 million in bankruptcy to shore up its supply chain, citing raw material shortages as the cause of dwindling cash and inability to meet sales demands. Revlon will use $300 million for day-to-day operations and $75 million to pay off foreign subsidiary debts, with the remaining $200 million to be sought in a future hearing.

summary: China's aluminium imports in May fell 16.4% year-over-year to 188,469 tonnes, amid high overseas prices and weaker domestic consumption. Exports of unwrought aluminium and products surged 54% to 676,605 tonnes, the highest in 9 years. summary: Analysts at Wells Fargo and Bank of America have downgraded homebuilders' stocks due to surging mortgage rates and accelerating inflation eroding pandemic-era demand. Public health officials say vaccinations can help prevent hospitalizations and deaths due to waning natural immunity, despite a recent winter surge of cases.

summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is developing a new tool to prevent a repeat of the continent's sovereign-debt crisis, with officials announcing work on the instrument will be sped up. site_title: Eight lessons from the Ukraine war
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war has revealed eight key lessons, including nuclear deterrence's dependence on relative stakes, economic interdependence not preventing war, and the importance of soft power in shaping outcomes. Sanctions can raise costs for aggressors but do not determine short-term outcomes, while information warfare and cyber capabilities are crucial in modern warfare. The war's unpredictability is also a significant takeaway, as it has proven more destructive than anticipated. Ultimately, the outcome will be determined by facts on the ground, and conclusions about the war's end are premature.

To prepare for these events, investors should consider taking only as much risk as they can tolerate, diversifying their portfolios, and keeping emergency funds in safe places, such as high-yield savings accounts or Treasury securities.

He emphasized that raising interest rates aggressively would not stop short-term inflation pressures and could add to economic slowdown risks.

China's vulnerability to floods has increased due to deforestation, wetland reclamation, and water storage for power generation. summary: SpaceX fired at least 5 employees after they drafted and circulated a letter criticizing founder Elon Musk and urging executives to make the firm's culture more inclusive. The firings came after a report by The New York Times on June 16, which stated SpaceX had fired employees associated with the letter, citing 3 employees with knowledge of the situation.

The company, once valued at $46 billion, has also laid off 10% of its employees to cut costs, following a dramatic change in fortunes since its 2021 valuation as Europe's most valuable startup.

site_title: Yen tanks after BOJ sticks to stimulus, caps volatile week for FX
summary: The Japanese yen fell 2% on Friday after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-accommodative stance, bucking a trend of tightening and contributing to soaring volatility in currency markets. The BOJ's decision comes amid a series of rate hikes this week, including a 0.5% increase by the Swiss National Bank, which sent the euro and franc tumbling. Currency markets face the biggest run of monetary policy tightening in decades, with a massive drop in risk sentiment leading to a decline in equity markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday, June 17, 2022, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 16.03 points to 1,456.74. Losers outnumbered gainers 726 to 267, with 3.057 billion lots traded worth RM3.019 billion.

site_title: After 118 long years, Keppel Club bids Bukit Chermin goodbye
summary: Keppel Club, Singapore's oldest golf club, has bid farewell to its Bukit Chermin site after 118 years, marking the end of a golfing chapter. The club's lease expired on June 30, and its members have moved to a new 18-hole course at the Singapore Island Country Club's (SICC) Sime Course. A farewell golf game was held on June 17, featuring Ministers Ng Eng Hen and S Iswaran, and showcased the club's rich history and nostalgic elements. The site will be redeveloped into 9,000 public and private housing units.

site_title: UK gives go-ahead to US extradition of WikiLeaks' founder Julian Assange
summary: The UK's interior minister Priti Patel has approved the extradition of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to the US to face 18 counts, including a spying charge, related to the release of confidential US military records and diplomatic cables. Assange's supporters claim his prosecution is a politically-motivated assault on journalism and free speech. The decision can be appealed, with Assange's wife stating it's only the beginning of a new legal battle, and an appeal must be approved by London's High Court within 28 days if he is to be extradited.

site_title: China to implement minimum purchase price for early indica rice ahead of schedule
summary: China's National Food and Strategic Reserves Administration will implement a minimum purchase price for early indica rice ahead of schedule, without specifying an exact date. This move comes as the country aims to increase rice production to ensure food security. The decision was made earlier in the year, with the original start date set for August 1. The minimum purchase price was raised from last year's, indicating increasing support for the crop's production. This is part of China's efforts to expand rice production and reduce land left fallow.

site_title: Cathay Cineplexes to cease operations at The Cathay
summary: Cathay Cineplexes will cease operations at its iconic location, The Cathay, after June 26, 2022, as part of a cost rationalization. Local independent cinema operator The Projector will take over the space as a pop-up from August 23, 2022, screening film, live theatre productions, and live music.

summary: Glencore is expected to report its first half-profit from trading commodities exceeding $3.2 billion, surpassing its entire 2022 record profit of $3.7 billion. The company's trading profit is on course to break through its previous record due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, sparking wild swings in markets that were already at or near record highs. summary: ByteDance has shut down its Shanghai-based game development studio, 101 Studio, cutting over 100 jobs and marking a setback in its expansion into mobile gaming. The studio, acquired just three years ago, was part of ByteDance's efforts to challenge Tencent Holdings in the market. The closure is a significant retreat from the once-booming gaming industry and comes amid severe content and licensing constraints. ByteDance has downsized other gaming units in the past, and the move is seen as a result of China's crackdown on big tech and the economic slowdown affecting its core ad business.

Ant's long-awaited licence could be secured soon, with the company awaiting final feedback from financial regulators on the set-up of the financial holding firm.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher

The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.96% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbing 1.16%.

site_title: Layoffs, hiring freezes ripple through tech ecosystem as investors push for cost discipline
summary: Tech companies are cutting costs due to investors' pressure to maintain cash runways. Layoffs and hiring freezes are widespread, with notable cases including Meta, Coinbase, Crypto.com, Shopee, StashAway, and iPrice. Investors are urging startups to reduce costs and prepare for a potential "venture funding winter." Some founders see layoffs as an opportunity to right-size departments and focus on core markets, while others are cautious about haphazardly cutting costs. Companies in a better financial position are snapping up experienced talent, and demand for certain roles remains strong.

summary: China's state-controlled oil companies, CNPC and Sinopec, are in advanced talks with Qatar to invest 5% each in two separate export trains of the North Field East expansion project, a $30 billion LNG project. The deal would give China direct access to the globalized project and allow it to diversify its LNG imports, creating a buffer against price volatility. The agreement, worth up to 4 million tonnes per annum, would be linked to the global oil market and is seen as a strategic move to replace coal on China's path to carbon neutrality by 2060.

summary: Thailand has announced it will abolish its pre-registration process for foreign visitors and no longer require face masks to be worn in public, effective July 1, in response to a slower COVID-19 spread. The "Thailand Pass" system, which required prior approval from Thai authorities, will be halted. The decision aims to boost tourism, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic, with the country's tourism sector accounting for about 12% of its GDP. The move also marks a shift towards a more voluntary approach to mask-wearing.

site_title: Euro zone inflation confirmed at record high 8.1% in May
summary: The Euro zone inflation rate reached a record high of 8.1% in May, exceeding the European Central Bank's (ECB) target of 2% and prompting the bank to raise interest rates in July and September to tame price growth. Inflation is driven by post-pandemic supply shortages, soaring energy prices, and broad price increases across various sectors. The ECB projects price growth of 6.8% this year, 3.5% in 2023, and 2.1% in 2024, as inflation becomes increasingly entrenched through second-round effects.

site_title: AusGroup to sell and leaseback Australian property

Despite inflation remaining above the RBI's tolerance band for a fifth month, Das expressed confidence that the RBI can exit ultra-loose monetary policy smoothly, targeting a soft landing.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam urges caution but refrains from new Covid curbs

site_title: European leaders talk up EU prospects for Ukraine in first visit since war began
summary: European leaders, including France's Emmanuel Macron, Germany's Olaf Scholz, Italy's Mario Draghi, and Romania's Klaus Iohannis, have backed Ukraine's bid for European Union (EU) candidate status, with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky urging them to send more weapons and impose tougher sanctions on Russia. The EU leaders expressed support for Ukraine's path to membership, but also emphasized the need for Ukraine to comply with democratic and rule-of-law requirements. The decision comes ahead of a European Commission recommendation on Ukraine's status as an EU candidate, which is due to be made on Friday.

images.alt_text: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin on Wednesday urged Western allies to redouble their military aid to Ukraine, warning that it “is facing a pivotal moment on the battlefield” in the nearly four-month war with Russia.

site_title: Philippine chicken output set to decline as cost of feed rises
summary: The Philippines is expected to produce fewer chickens due to rising costs of lower-quality feed and poor weather conditions. The industry's president, Elias Jose Inciong, attributed this to the war in Ukraine disrupting chicken feed supplies and the country's high humidity, which makes it difficult to obtain good-quality feeds. This may lead to higher chicken prices, with a 25% increase in whole chicken prices in Manila since the start of the year. The country's total chicken output fell 3.6% last year to 1.7 million metric tons.

site_title: Europe: Shares plunge after trio of hikes
summary: European stocks plummeted 2.3% on Thursday after a trio of rate hikes from the Fed, SNB, and BoE fueled fears of a global recession. The Stoxx 600 fell 18% from its January high, with France's CAC 40 and Germany's DAX also declining. Switzerland's SMI dropped 2.9% after the SNB's rate hike, while all sectors finished in the red, with tech and chemicals lagging. Analysts say the combination of high inflation and slowing growth makes the rate hikes particularly challenging.

images.alt_text: EUROPE'S stock markets opened lower on Thursday (Jun 16)  as investors digested a sharp Federal Reserve interest rate hike to tackle soaring inflation, and before a widely-expected increase from the Bank of England (BOE).

site_title: VW US chief warns of industry challenges with EV battery shift
summary: Volkswagen's US chief executive, Scott Keogh, warns of major industry challenges in ramping up battery production for electric vehicles. The US faces difficulties in attracting skilled workers, mining key metals, and addressing supply chain issues. Keogh estimates the US needs to produce 8.5 million batteries annually by 2030, a massive investment compared to the current 150,000-200,000 batteries produced per year. The shift to electric vehicles is seen as the single biggest "industrial transformation in America," requiring a broader investment in labor, infrastructure, and education.

images.alt_text: VOLKSWAGEN is offering pay-offs to its employees at a car assembly plant in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia, if they agree to quit voluntarily, the carmaker said on Thursday (Jun 9).

site_title: Singapore exports up by 12.4% in May on year-ago low base
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 12.4% year-over-year in May, exceeding expectations, driven by strong growth in electronics and non-electronics sectors. Shipments to Indonesia and Malaysia surged, while exports to China inched up despite lockdowns. NODX demand was led by Indonesia and Malaysia, with non-monetary gold and measuring instruments contributing to the growth. The strong export performance is expected to support Singapore's GDP growth in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Container trucks ply along the pier at Pasir Panjang terminal port in Singapore on June 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: US: Wall Street closes sharply lower, S&P 500 falls 3.2%
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.4% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 741.5 points to 29,927.07, its first close below 30,000 since January 2021. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, falling 3.2% and 4.1% respectively. The Federal Reserve's 3-quarter point interest rate hike aimed to combat inflation, which has strengthened and consumer confidence weakened.

images.alt_text: US stock indexes opened sharply lower on Thursday (Jun 16), with growth shares taking the biggest hit, after the Federal Reserve's biggest interest rate hike since 1994 fanned recession worries.

site_title: Europe's central banks jack up interest rates to fight inflation surge
summary: European central banks raised interest rates to combat inflation, with the Swiss National Bank and Hungarian National Bank making significant moves. The Bank of England also raised rates, despite being more cautious, to combat inflation rates above 11%. The rate hikes aim to tame soaring inflation, which has reached double-digit levels in some parts of the continent, and are expected to lead to higher borrowing costs. The European Central Bank has also agreed plans to contain borrowing costs in the bloc's south, paving the way for further rate rises in July and September.

images.alt_text: Managing Director of the European Stability Mechanism Klaus Regling at the start of the Annual Meeting of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) Board of Governors in Luxembourg, 16 June 2022.

site_title: Euro zone finance ministers fail to choose new head of bailout fund
summary: EU finance ministers delayed voting on a new head of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) bailout fund due to a lack of qualified majority. The position, currently held by retiring Klaus Regling, is being contested by Luxembourg's Pierre Gramegna, Portugal's Joao Leao, and Italy's Marco Buti. Italy's reluctance to withdraw Buti from the race contributed to the stalemate, but the Italian finance ministry has informally suggested a potential trade-off involving the ESM's seat in exchange for money laundering agency. The ESM, a lender of last resort for euro zone governments, has a lending capacity of 500 billion euros.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens sharply lower on recession worries
summary: US stocks opened sharply lower on June 16, 2022, due to recession worries following the Federal Reserve's largest interest rate hike since 1994. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.18%, the S&P 500 dropped 1.63%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 2.64%. Growth shares were hit the hardest, as investors expressed concerns about the potential economic impact of the rate hike.

site_title: EU leaders criticised for tepid support bring 'message of unity' to Ukraine
summary: EU leaders, including German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, French President Emmanuel Macron, and Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi, made a joint visit to Ukraine, sending a message of unity to the country amidst Russia's ongoing invasion. The visit comes ahead of the EU's expected recommendation to support Ukraine's bid to join the bloc. Despite past criticism from Ukraine, the leaders pledged to provide more aid and support, including additional weapons and economic assistance, to help Ukraine counter Russia's firepower advantage.

site_title: US jobless claims edge lower, reflecting tight labour market
summary: US jobless claims decreased by 3,000 to 229,000 in the week ended June 11, indicating a tight labor market. Continuing claims remained steady at 1.31 million. The robust labor market, with 2 job openings for every unemployed worker, contrasts with growing recession fears and job cuts. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates, signaling aggressive policy tightening to curb inflation, with the unemployment rate projected to reach 4.1% by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: A man walks past a "now hiring" sign posted outside of a restaurant in Arlington, Virginia on June 3, 2022. - US employers added 390,000 jobs last month, the government reported on June 3, 2022, a sign of a slowdown in hiring but still a better-than-expected result. The jobless rate held steady at 3.6 percent for the third consecutive month, just a tenth of a point above the pre-pandemic level of February 2020, the Labor Department said. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)

site_title: WTO provisionally agrees to extend e-commerce tariff moratorium: sources
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has reached a provisional agreement to extend a moratorium on applying duties to electronic transmissions until the next ministerial meeting, likely in 2023. The moratorium, which has exempted data flows from cross-border tariffs since 1998, was backed by major players including the US, UK, and EU, who argued that its expiration would undermine global recovery. The deal was reached after India, Indonesia, and other countries threatened to block an extension, but now needs to be backed by the WTO's 164 members.

site_title: US housing starts decline to lowest level in more than a year
summary: US housing starts declined 14.4% in May to a 1.55 million annualized rate, the lowest in over a year, due to ongoing supply chain challenges and rising mortgage rates. Single-family housing starts dropped 9.2% to a 1.05 million rate, while multifamily dwellings plummeted 23.7% to a 498,000 rate. Builder backlogs remain elevated, and the Federal Reserve's rate hike may slow home price growth, according to Chair Jerome Powell.

images.alt_text: THE average interest rate on the most popular US home loan climbed to its highest level since the 2008 financial crisis and purchase applications were down more than 15 per cent from last year, Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) data showed on Wednesday (Jun 15).

site_title: Ford recalls 2.9 million vehicles over flaw in securing gear shift in park
summary: Ford has recalled 2.9 million vehicles due to a potential defect in securing the gear shift, which could enable the vehicle to move even if it appears to be in park. The affected models include 1.7 million Ford Escape SUVs from 2013-2019, as well as other models such as the Edge SUV, Fusion sedan, C-Max van, and Transit Connect van. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration reported 1% of vehicles may have the defect, resulting in 6 reports of property damage and 4 reports of potential injuries.

A manufacturing problem at a company that makes fuel lines forced Ford to recall 11,500 of its brand-new Escape small SUVs and tell owners to stop driving them right away. site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps 4-day losing run on Wall Street gains after Fed move
summary: The Nikkei stock index in Japan ended the day up 0.4% at 26,431.20, snapping a 4-day losing streak, after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points to combat US inflation. The move was seen as a positive for stocks, but investors remain cautious due to a murky global economy outlook. The broader Topix index gained 0.64%.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rose on Thursday as traders cheered a sharp Federal Reserve interest rate hike that signalled it is intent on driving inflation down.

site_title: MSCI launches equity factor models featuring sustainability, crowding and machine learning
summary: MSCI launched four new equity factor models featuring sustainability, crowding, and machine learning factors, enabling institutional investors to build diversified portfolios and compare against industry peers and benchmarks. The models include a sustainability factor assessing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) and carbon efficiency, and a machine-learning component analyzing relationships between variables. The new models provide enhanced transparency and will be available through multiple distribution channels, expanding investment opportunities for investors.

images.alt_text: Investors should continue to take a longer-term view on energy transition and sustainability, say finance specialists.

site_title: Meta, Google, Twitter vow to fight fake news better as EU gets tougher
summary: Major tech companies Meta, Google, Twitter, and Microsoft have agreed to take a tougher stance against disinformation in the EU, committing to limit deep fakes, fake accounts, and political advertising under an updated code of practice. Failure to comply could result in fines up to 6% of their global turnover. The updated code aims to combat the spread of misinformation, following the EU's crackdown on fake news following Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Musk, Tesla, SpaceX sued for alleged Dogecoin pyramid scheme
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla, and SpaceX are being sued for allegedly running a pyramid scheme to inflate the value of Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency. Plaintiff Keith Johnson claims the companies falsely promoted Dogecoin as a legitimate investment, resulting in losses for those who traded in it since 2019. Johnson seeks $258 billion in damages, including $86 billion in direct losses and $172 billion in triple damages. The lawsuit aims to block the companies from promoting Dogecoin and declare it constitutes gambling under US and New York law.

images.alt_text: coins, bitcoin, dogecoin

site_title: Toyota to halt more Japan production in June, July
summary: Toyota Motor plans to halt additional domestic factory line production in June and July due to semiconductor shortages and a Covid-19 outbreak at a supplier. This is the third production adjustment for the month, reducing its global vehicle production target to 750,000. The company did not disclose July production plans, but its global target remains at roughly 9.7 million vehicles for the year. Toyota cited staffing disruptions and a production equipment defect at suppliers as the reasons for the production changes, following previous disruptions caused by parts shortages and Covid-19 lockdowns in China.

site_title: BOE raises rates to highest since 2009, warns more to come
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) raised interest rates for a fifth consecutive time, increasing the benchmark lending rate by 25 basis points to 1.25%, the highest level since 2009. The move aims to tame inflation, which has hit a 4-decade high of 9% and is expected to peak at "slightly above" 11% this year. The BOE also expects the economy to contract in the current quarter, and warned that more rate hikes may be necessary if inflation continues to soar.

images.alt_text: Economists widely forecast that the Bank of England will hike borrowing costs by a quarter-point to 1.25 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Global gas prices have increased significantly since September 2021 due to high demand and tight gas supply. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore will extend its Temporary Electricity Contracting Support Scheme until March 31, 2023. The US Federal Reserve is set to hike interest rates, potentially pushing the US into recession. AEM Holdings plans to add 300 jobs in Singapore, Malaysia, and the US. The Russia-Ukraine conflict may lead to secondary oil sanctions, and Singapore's stock market closed 0.3% down on Thursday.

images.alt_text: The value of all residential property assets held by Singapore households swelled 13.5 per cent year on year in Q4 2021, followed by a 10.4 per cent jump in Q1 2022.

site_title: June is the month for emerging artists
summary: Six emerging artists in Singapore are gaining attention for their unique styles and themes. Yeo Tze Yang's figurative paintings capture intimate moments of people in public places, while Priyageetha Dia's show "Forget Me, Forget Me Not" explores the history of Indian labor migration to Malaya. Masuri Mazlan's wall sculptures reinterpret traditional Malay embroidery, and Johann M Fauzi's oil paintings subvert Western depictions of Singapore. Luke Heng's abstract works and Liu Liling's photographic installations also showcase their artistic talents, with shows running until July 23.

images.alt_text: ART SG Co-Founder Magnus Renfrew and Director Shuyin Yang.

site_title: Super-sized Fed rate hikes look set to push US into recession
summary: The US Federal Reserve has raised interest rates by 3/4 of a percentage point, the largest hike since 1994, to combat the highest consumer price increases in 4 decades. The move, in response to a 8.6% rise in consumer prices, is seen as a direct response to the US Labor Department's report. The drastic measure has raised concerns of a potential recession, with some strategists warning that the economic expansion cannot survive the shock of the rate hikes. The Fed's determination to stop inflation spiraling out of control has led to a super-sized rate hike, which may lead to more collateral damage on the stock market.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 closed 0.2 per cent lower at 6,589.4 after rising as much as 1 per cent earlier in the session, extending its fall to a fifth session.
The benchmark Kospi ended up 4.03 points or 0.16 per cent to 2,451.41, snapping a 7-day losing streak.
The Nikkei ended the day up 0.4 per cent at 26,431.20, rebounding from its lowest close since May 12.

site_title: Shanghai to mass test whole city weekly to keep Covid at bay
summary: Shanghai, China, will conduct mass testing drives every weekend until the end of July, requiring residents to take nucleic acid tests at least once a week and workers in certain industries to undergo daily testing. The city, which reported 16 Covid-19 cases on Wednesday, will also impose temporary lockdowns on residential complexes where a case is detected. The measures aim to maintain a zero-tolerance approach to the coronavirus and avoid economically-crushing lockdowns. The city's residents will spend up to 613 million yuan for weekly tests, part of China's increasing reliance on frequent mass testing to combat the omicron variant.

images.alt_text: epa10007303 A woman in quarantine takes PCR Coronavirus test, amid new round of COVID-19 lockdowns and cases, in Shanghai, China, 11 June 2022. Shanghai starts weekend PCR screening to curb rising community COVID-19 cases. Only 10 days after the city lifted the 2-month lockdown in order to eliminate the community spread of COVID-19, residents of 15 out of 16 districts will need to participate in mandatory PCR testing this weekend. site_title: Porsche to pay US$80m to resolve fuel economy claims on US vehicles: court documents
summary: Volkswagen's Porsche unit has agreed to a class-action settlement worth at least $80 million to resolve claims it skewed emissions and fuel economy data on 500,000 US vehicles. The settlement covers 2005-2020 model year Porsche vehicles and will provide owners with payments of $250 to $1,109 per vehicle. The automaker allegedly physically altered test vehicles to reduce emissions and fuel efficiency. This settlement follows Volkswagen's $20 billion settlement in 2017 after it was found to have used software to evade emissions requirements in nearly 11 million diesel vehicles worldwide.

site_title: Sterling drops, Swiss franc jumps after BOE and SNB rate hikes
summary: The Swiss franc surged to a 2-month high against the euro after the Swiss National Bank raised interest rates by 25 basis points, its first rate hike in 15 years. The move followed a surprise 50 basis point rate hike by the European Central Bank and a 75 basis point rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Meanwhile, sterling dropped 0.8% to a 2-year low after the Bank of England raised interest rates by 25 basis points to fight inflation.

site_title: Art SG will finally open  – and it looks splendid
summary: Singapore's ART SG art fair is set to debut in January 2023, featuring over 150 galleries from 30 countries, including mega galleries like Gagosian and White Cube. The fair, initially envisioned as a mid-size event, has doubled in size and will now occupy two floors at Marina Bay Sands. Despite initial struggles due to the COVID-19 pandemic, ART SG has attracted top galleries and collectors, with some galleries considering Singapore as an alternative base to Hong Kong. The fair will run from January 12-15, 2023, amidst Singapore Art Week, and will feature various sectors, including galleries, solo/duo artist programs, and digital art.

site_title: Singapore households, businesses to brace for interest rate ‘shock’; Fed hike to slow Asean recovery: Economists
summary: The US Federal Reserve's historic 75-basis-point rate hike to combat inflation will dampen growth in Singapore and ASEAN economies, with economists warning of increased pressure on households with mortgages and businesses looking to borrow. Interest rates are expected to rise to near 4% by the end of this year and 4.5% in 2023, with mortgage rates climbing to a level not seen for almost 2 decades. Economists predict a slower domestic consumption and reduced global trade and exports from ASEAN, with some expecting a recession in Singapore and the US.

site_title: CFM Holdings sells Ang Mo Kio property at 73% over book value for S$13.35 million
summary: CFM Holdings is selling a property in Ang Mo Kio for S$13.35 million, a price 73% over its book value of S$7.73 million as of Dec 31, 2021. The property is currently used as the office and warehouse for Cheong Fatt Holdings, with some units subletted. The sale brings potential proceeds to over S$5.6 million, and the company will receive S$5.57 million after deducting costs.

images.alt_text: The development located 1 Ang Mo Kio Street 63

site_title: Ferrari promises 'even more unique' cars in shift to electric
summary: Ferrari plans to produce 80% of its sales as electric or hybrid models by 2030, with 5% of sales as fully-electric cars in 2025 and 40% by 2030. The company aims to launch 15 new models between 2023 and 2026, including its first electric model in 2025. Ferrari will develop its own electric motors and components, while outsourcing non-core parts to partners. The company expects to invest 4.4 billion euros by 2026, with a focus on product development and delivering core earnings of 2.5-2.7 billion euros.

site_title: Taiwan central bank raises benchmark rate again to curb inflation
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its benchmark discount rate by 12.5 basis points to 1.5% for the second time this year, aiming to curb inflation. The move follows the US Federal Reserve's largest rate increase in over a quarter century and is in line with economists' expectations. The bank also trimmed its 2022 growth outlook to 3.75% and raised reserve requirement ratios to combat inflation. Despite a relatively mild rate hike, the decision reflects concerns about inflation and the potential for a recession.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An engineer holds a chip at the Taiwan Semiconductor Research Institute in Hsinchu, Taiwan, February 11, 2022.  REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

Taiwan is poised to implement back-to-back interest-rate increases for the first time since 2011 as the central bank seeks to tame consumer prices expected to rise to their highest in more than a decade.

site_title: London Stock Exchange pours cold water on merging listing segments
summary: The London Stock Exchange is cautioning that merging its two company listing segments could put existing listings at risk. The Financial Conduct Authority has proposed merging the standard and premium listing categories to attract more technology companies, including chip designer Arm, which is being courted to list in London instead of on Wall Street. The move aims to boost London's competitiveness in company listings post-Brexit.

images.alt_text: London Stock Exchange buys TORA to boost digital drive

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.72 points to 1,472.77 on Thursday, with 2.476 billion lots worth RM1.840 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 556 to 392.

site_title: US bond market losses just beginning as Fed sets path to 4% yields
summary: The US bond market is experiencing significant losses, with yields surging around 10 basis points after the Federal Reserve's largest rate hike since 1994. The Fed's benchmark rate is expected to reach 3.8% by the end of next year, potentially increasing Treasuries' worst losses since the 1970s. Investors anticipate higher rates, with some predicting yields could exceed 4%. The market's volatility is fueled by the unwinding of central banks' massive bond portfolios and rising inflation, with consumer prices surging to a 4-decade high.

images.alt_text: A person walks through the Wall Street subway station near the New York Stock Exchange. On Jun 15 at the end of the central bank’s 2-day policy meeting, Fed chairman Jerome Powell’s rate-setting committee boosted interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, the largest hike since 1994.
The Fed raised its target interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, the most by the US central bank since 1994, as it seeks to tame red-hot inflation.

site_title: Shell to build ships to carry more CO2 over longer distances for CCS hubs
summary: Shell is building larger vessels to carry more carbon dioxide (CO2) over longer distances for carbon capture storage (CCS) hubs, aiming to improve economies of scale for these projects. The company is constructing two ships with a capacity of 7,500 cubic meters and plans to build larger vessels with capacities of 36,000, 40,000, and 70,000 cubic meters. The ships will be powered by liquefied natural gas and are expected to be ready for delivery in 2024. This expansion supports Shell's CCS business globally, which aims to decarbonize heavy industries such as refining and cement production.

images.alt_text: Shell said the project would help its Asian customers move from coal to gas, and also provide a secure supply source, a key factor following the imposition of sanctions on Russia.

Climate issues are set to take centre stage at Shell's annual general meeting on Tuesday, with a key group saying the energy giant isn't abiding by a landmark court order requiring it to cut emissions by 45 per cent by 2030.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower on recession fears after Fed hike
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% lower at 6,589.4, extending a fifth consecutive decline, amid fears of a recession after the US Federal Reserve's 75-basis-point interest rate hike to curb inflation. The rate hike, the largest in 28 years, was widely expected but still sparked market volatility.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians are reflected in the window of the Australian Securites Exchange in Sydney on March 13, 2020, as Australian stocks were down 7.3 percent in early trading. - Global stock markets suffered historic falls as panic spread on March 13 over the spiralling coronavirus crisis that has killed nearly 5,000 and infected sport, schools and society across the planet. (Photo by Saeed KHAN / AFP)

site_title: Capital A evaluating all fundraising options ahead of planned New York listing
summary: Capital A, Malaysia's aviation group, is evaluating various fundraising options ahead of a planned listing in New York. CEO Tony Fernandes expressed confidence that the group can stave off its PN17 status, a list of financially distressed firms, by raising funds. The company is considering options such as private placement, direct listing, or a merger with a special purpose acquisition company to list its airline or digital businesses in the US market, citing its attractiveness for liquidity and diverse investor reach.
