site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won, T-bonds tumble on faster tightening fears
summary: South Korean stocks, won, and treasury bonds plummeted on June 15 due to concerns over aggressive monetary tightening. The Kospi index fell 1.83% to its lowest close since November 2020, while the 10-year treasury bond yield surged 11.5 basis points to 3.812%. Investors expect the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates by 75 basis points, increasing pressure on the Bank of Korea to follow suit. Retail investors' leveraged holdings also contributed to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended down 11.54 points or 0.46 per cent at 2,492.97, after falling as much as 1.88 per cent in early trade.

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals continue to rebound strongly in May
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals rebounded strongly in May, reaching a new record since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 418,310 visitors, up from 295,100 in April. This marks the fourth consecutive month of growth, but still lags behind pre-pandemic levels. Analysts expect visitor arrivals to continue rising, but not return to pre-pandemic levels by year-end, with some predicting a return to normal levels in 2023 or 2024.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists at Singapore's Merlion Park in February 2018, before the pandemic. Travellers from Greater China used to make up nearly one-quarter of international visitor arrivals.
Singapore hosted more than 150 events attended by more than 37,000 people in the first 3 months of 2022.
The Singapore Tourism Board's innovation platform Tourism Technology Transformation Cube (Tcube) has supported more than 1,000 local tourism businesses in their digital transformation efforts.
Local tourist demand is still present and staycations can help hotels fill rooms, JLL analyst Sashi Rajan told The Business Times.

site_title: How it came to this: The Fed and White House's slow inflation awakening
summary: The US Federal Reserve and the Biden administration were slow to address inflation, which reached 40-year highs, by dismissing initial price increases as "transitory." The Fed, led by Jerome Powell, is now willing to hike interest rates to control inflation, even if it means courting a recession. The administration's efforts to address inflation, such as the Build Back Better Act, failed in Congress. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen later admitted her mistake in calling inflation "transitory." The Fed's response has been criticized for being too slow, and some experts warn that the Fed's modest rate hikes may not be enough to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building is seen before the Federal Reserve board is expected to signal plans to raise interest rates in March as it focuses on fighting inflation in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022.      REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: Condo, HDB rents continue surge in May but volumes down year on year: SRX, 99.co
summary: Residential property rentals in Singapore continued to rise in May, with condo and HDB rental prices increasing 2.8% and 16.2% year-on-year, respectively. Condo rental volumes rose 11.7% to 4,185 units, while HDB rental volumes increased 8.4% to 1,617 units. Experts predict continued demand for private rentals, particularly in the suburbs, as tenants opt for smaller units or those away from the city centre. The reopening of international flights and potential foreign students' housing demand may also contribute to the surge.

images.alt_text: The value of all residential property assets held by Singapore households swelled 13.5 per cent year on year in Q4 2021, followed by a 10.4 per cent jump in Q1 2022.
Generic property landscape in Singapore
Some demand for resale HDB flats was likely diverted to the Build-To-Order (BTO) market – which saw the launch of 5 new projects in May, noted property analysts.

site_title: Jokowi names new trade minister after palm oil ban controversy
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo appointed Zukifli Hasan, chairman of the National Mandate Party, as the country's new trade minister amid controversy over palm oil exports. The move comes after former trade minister Muhammad Lutfi faced pressure over a series of policy flip-flops, including a ban on palm oil shipments. The ban, lifted in May, sparked global market shockwaves and led to arrests. The Cabinet reshuffle also includes changes to the agrarian and spatial planning ministry. Hasan's appointment is seen as a move to appoint a PAN member to the cabinet.

images.alt_text: Indonesia allowed palm shipments to resume from May 23 following a 3-week ban designed to boost cooking oil stocks and keeping runaway prices in check amid growing domestic discontent.

site_title: Credit Suisse shuffles Apac banking team: memo
summary: Credit Suisse has reshuffled its top Asian investment banking team following the promotion of Edwin Low to regional chief executive. Zeth Hung will become vice-chairman of Asia Pacific investment banking and capital markets, while Tan Kuan Ern and Joe Lai have been appointed as new co-heads of the Apac IBCM team. Tan will remain based in Singapore, and Lai in Hong Kong. Rehan Anwer will become chief executive for South-east Asia, replacing Helman Sitohang.

site_title: India plans to auction 5G airwaves by end-July to spur rollout
summary: India plans to auction 5G airwaves by the end of July, with three private operators - Reliance Jio, Bharti Airtel, and Vodafone Idea - expected to compete. The government will sell 72 gigahertz of spectrum for a 20-year tenure, with the auction to be held in various frequency bands. The sale aims to boost the exchequer and support the rollout of 5G technology-based services. Affordable airwaves are seen as crucial for telecom companies to invest in expanding services and ensuring faster network speeds, helping India catch up with other Asian countries in 5G network rollout.

images.alt_text: HIGH global energy and raw material prices combined with a weak rupee fueled the fastest annual rise in India's wholesale prices in more over 30 years, raising expectations for the central bank to order more interest rate hikes.

site_title: The scam of authenticity
summary: A growing emphasis on authenticity in business has led to a proliferation of "authentic" products and leaders, but the concept is increasingly slippery. Experts argue that authenticity is often used as a marketing tool to sell brands and experiences, rather than a genuine quality. The rise of "authenticity decay" – where companies water down their authentic offerings to fit into a corporate culture – is also on the rise. As author Alice Sherwood notes, the idea of authenticity is often at odds with reality, and its desirability is being manipulated by marketers and management gurus.

images.alt_text: Kindness is a strength, a management tool.
Breaking the boardroom bias: a case for women in leadership

site_title: China says it may have detected signals from alien civilisations
summary: China's Sky Eye telescope, the world's largest radio telescope, may have detected signals from alien civilizations. The signals, detected in 2020 and 2022, differ from previous ones and require further investigation. The team, led by Zhang Tonjie, chief scientist, is exploring the possibility of extraterrestrial life. However, the signals could also be radio interference, and the findings have not been officially confirmed. The report was initially deleted from the Science and Technology Daily website, but the news had already spread on social media and other outlets.

images.alt_text: The Gaia space probe unveiled its latest discoveries on June 13, 2022, in its quest to map the Milky Way in unprecedented detail, surveying nearly 2 million stars and revealing mysterious "starquakes" which sweep across the fiery giants like vast tsunamis.

This video grab image obtained April 28, 2020 courtesy of the US Department of Defense shows part of an unclassified video taken by Navy pilots that have circulated for years showing interactions with "unidentified aerial phenomena" .

site_title: China's banks scramble to raise capital and answer calls to support economy
summary: China's banks are scrambling to raise capital and support the economy by lending to small firms and sectors affected by Covid-19 containment measures. The country's four biggest state lenders have issued nearly 400 billion yuan in subordinated bonds, a 42% increase from last year. The move comes as interest rates are being pushed down by monetary easing, and banks face tougher capital rules. The banks plan to sell additional debt in overseas markets to replenish capital, with the goal of stabilizing the economy and meeting regulatory demands.

images.alt_text: The property sector, a pillar of growth for China, fell sharply last year and deteriorated further in recent months as the world's second-biggest economy weakened.

China's economy showed a mixed recovery in May, with industrial production unexpectedly increasing while the property market continued to slump and consumer spending declined as Covid restrictions curbed sentiment.

The Ministry of Finance will auction 7.5 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) of the central government bonds across 2, 3 and 5-year maturities on Wednesday, the first of 4 batches totaling 23 billion yuan planned for this year in Hong Kong, denominated in the offshore currency.

site_title: UK inflation expert warns BOE should halt hikes before recession
summary: UK inflation expert Tim Congdon warns the Bank of England (BOE) to halt interest-rate hikes before a likely recession early next year. Congdon, a veteran UK monetarist, cites a collapse in money-supply growth as a sign that the BOE should only stay "a little more" above the 1% benchmark. He argues that an economic slump is probable and necessary, and that wage restraint among workers is "wicked." Congdon's views, which align with those of Nobel-Prize winner Milton Friedman, have regained traction as inflation hits 40-year highs in the UK and 8.6% in the US.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve is now expected to hike interest rates by 75 basis points Wednesday, just weeks after Chair Jerome Powell and his team repeatedly advertised a half percentage point move.
Official data showed the UK jobless rate edged up to 3.8 per cent in the 3 months to April from 3.7 per cent in the previous labour market report for the 3 months to March.
Were it not for a drop in services output, the UK economy would have grown 0.1 per cent in the month.

site_title: Golden age of buses? Buyers hop on UK transport firms
summary: The UK is experiencing a "golden age of electric buses" as private capital and investors show keen interest in bus companies. The government's £3 billion investment in policies to encourage environmentally-friendly vehicles and incentives for operators to convert to electric or hydrogen-powered buses is driving takeover interest. Three out of four major London-listed bus operators have attracted takeover interest, with StageCoach, FirstGroup, and Go-Ahead being targeted by infrastructure funds and other investors. The favorable policy environment and low valuations are attracting long-term investors, with some analysts predicting increased sales and revenue for the sector.

images.alt_text: Go-Ahead Group, the biggest operator of London’s commuter trains and iconic double-decker buses, accepted a £648 million (S$1.09 billion) takeover bid from an investor group backed by Australian transportation firm Kinetic Holding.
CDC Darwin will be the sole operator of public bus transport in Darwin, Palmerston, rural areas and special needs services in the region.

site_title: Touch ‘n Go e-wallet expands cross-border payment service to Singapore
summary: Touch 'n Go eWallet, a Malaysian e-wallet service, has expanded its cross-border payment service to Singapore, allowing users to pay for ComfortDelGro taxi fares. This is made possible through a collaboration with Alipay+, operated by Ant Financial Group. Users can receive a discount of between RM4 to RM6 (S$1.26 to S$1.80) on their total ComfortDelGro taxi fare, capped at 300 transactions daily. This expansion aims to increase acceptance points for the Touch 'n Go e-wallet in Singapore, with plans underway to launch more.

site_title: Why the US Federal Reserve’s options are limited
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise its target for short-term safe nominal interest rates by 50 basis points, from 0.75-1% to 1.25-1.5%, at its upcoming meeting. This decision is based on the Fed's previous forward guidance and to steer the economy in the desired direction. The Fed aims to maintain confidence in the economy's nominal price-level anchor, rather than hitting its inflation target on a year-by-year basis. The decision will also be influenced by bond-market expectations, which suggest the federal funds rate will average around 2.75% over the next two years before falling to 2.5%.

images.alt_text: Investors have dramatically raised their bets that the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates by 75 basis points (bps) rather than 50 bps on Wednesday.

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy post-rout calm as traders await Federal Reserve hike
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed session on Wednesday, with some markets rising and others falling, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Investors are anticipating a steeper rate hike than expected, which could fuel worries about a US recession next year. Despite this, many observers believe the Fed must act quickly to control inflation and prevent stagflation. Markets are expected to remain volatile in the short term, with some analysts predicting a potential relief rally if the Fed announces a more aggressive rate hike, while others warn of the risk of a recession.

images.alt_text: Equity markets tumbled again on Tuesday.

site_title: End of Internet Explorer era spells trouble for Japan businesses
summary: Microsoft is retiring Internet Explorer, ending a quarter-century-old app, and sparking a panic among Japanese businesses that rely on it. A survey found 49% of Japanese companies still use IE, primarily for in-house management and data exchange systems. Many have procrastinated, and businesses now must swiftly transition to alternative software. Microsoft's Edge browser, built on Chromium, is compatible with Chrome extensions and supports IE functionality through an integrated IE mode. The retirement marks the end of IE's dominance and a shift to faster, more compatible browsers.

site_title: Singapore-based crypto hedge fund’s cryptic tweet fuels speculation over losses
summary: Singapore-based crypto hedge fund Three Arrows Capital's co-founder Zhu Su tweeted about potential stress amid a deep selloff in digital assets, fueling speculation over losses. The fund's estimated $10 billion in assets, primarily staked Ether, have declined 35% in the past week. The total cryptocurrency market value has plunged to $984 billion from $3 trillion in November. Three Arrows' trading strategies and current position in the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust are unclear, adding to speculation about its financial health.

images.alt_text: Market watchers have become preoccupied with figuring out which cohorts of investors are getting hurt the most during the current crypto winter.

Billionaire Bill Gates dismissed cryptocurrency projects such as nonfungible tokens as shams "based on the greater-fool theory" at a climate conference Tuesday, reviving past criticisms of digital assets.
CRYPTOCURRENCY exchange Coinbase Global said on Tuesday (Jun 14) it would slash 18 per cent of its workforce, or about 1,100 jobs, as part of efforts to rein in costs amid volatile market conditions.

While Celsius is one of the big participants in the DeFi space, the company itself is more like a centralised bank or other financial middleman than a collection of DeFi smart contracts and algorithms governed by the democracy of token holders spread out throughout the world.

site_title: Sinovac’s 10 billion yuan plans include new facility, global HQ in Singapore: Lianhe Zaobao
summary: Chinese vaccine maker Sinovac Biotech is investing 10 billion yuan (S$2 billion) to open a research facility and its international headquarters in Singapore. The facility will develop vaccines for Covid-19 and severe hand, foot and mouth disease, with plans to hire 100-200 local and overseas scientists. Sinovac aims to leverage Singapore's technology and talent pool to focus on Asian diseases and export products worldwide. The company is also studying the feasibility of setting up a factory in Singapore and plans to open an office in early 2024 as its international headquarters.

MOH working to bring in more non-mRNA Covid-19 vaccines, studying use of Novavax for under-18s

site_title: US rate markets price in aggressive 75-bps hike on Wednesday
summary: US investors have dramatically shifted their expectations to a 75-basis-point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday, up to 89% from 3.9% a week ago. This has led to a violent selloff across world markets, with US stocks confirming a bear market and yields spiking to their highest levels since 2007. The Fed is set to raise its Fed Funds rate to 3% on Wednesday, with investment banks predicting 75-bps hikes in June and July, and 50-bps hikes in September.

images.alt_text: Prices paid to US producers surged in May, underscoring persistent inflationary pressures across the economy that are likely to keep the Federal Reserve aggressively raising interest rates.
US stocks sank both Friday and Monday following a grim consumer price report that undermined hopes that inflation was peaking.

site_title: Australian consumers in a dark mood as inflation, rates bite
summary: Australian consumer sentiment slumped 4.5% in June from May, matching pandemic lows, due to an outsized rise in interest rates and surging inflation. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index fell to 86.4, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. A separate ANZ survey showed a 7.6% drop in confidence index, the lowest since the pandemic start. The Reserve Bank of Australia raised interest rates by 50 basis points, warning more hikes are needed to restrain inflation. Consumers expressed concerns over rising costs, economic outlook, and employment prospects, but were relatively upbeat about their own employment.

images.alt_text: Australia's minimum wage rose to A$21.38 (S$20.50) an hour from July 1, up from the current rate of A$20.33, the Australian Fair Work Commission said after its annual review.
Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe said consumer price inflation was now likely to reach 7 per cent by the end of the year, from the current 5.1 per cent pace.

site_title: Bitcoin rout hits ‘darkest’ phase with entire market underwater
summary: Bitcoin has plummeted over 30% this month, marking its ninth consecutive day of losses, with a 24% decline over the past 3 days, its steepest drop in history. The cryptocurrency is now trading roughly $1,000 below its current realised price of $23,430, putting even long-term holders under extreme pressure. Strategists warn that the current bear market has entered its "deepest and darkest" phase, with newer entrants being significantly impacted and potential signs of capitulation from Bitcoin miners being monitored.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Bill Gates dismissed cryptocurrency projects such as nonfungible tokens as shams "based on the greater-fool theory" at a climate conference Tuesday, reviving past criticisms of digital assets.
CRYPTOCURRENCY exchange Coinbase Global said on Tuesday (Jun 14) it would slash 18 per cent of its workforce, or about 1,100 jobs, as part of efforts to rein in costs amid volatile market conditions.
Bitcoin fell as much as 7.2 per cent to US$20,816 its lowest since Dec 2020, extending Monday’s 15 per cent plunge.
Singapore-headquartered Crypto.com announced layoffs of about 260 staff, or 5 per cent of its workforce.

site_title: Australia hikes minimum wage by 5.2% amid inflation pressure
summary: Australia's minimum wage has risen by 5.2% to A$21.38 (S$20.50) an hour, effective July 1, in line with inflation. The decision aims to alleviate living cost pressures, with the lowest-paid employees benefiting from the increase. The Fair Work Commission cited rising inflation and unemployment at 3.9% as reasons for the decision, which will affect over 2 million workers. The move has been welcomed by trade unions but warned by businesses that it may add significant expenses.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on August 21, 2021 shows workers walking along the quiet George Street in Sydney as the city extended its two-month-old lockdown and introduced a partial curfew to contain a fast-spreading coronavirus outbreak. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)
Tuesday’s (Jun 14) survey from National Australia Bank (NAB) showed its index of business conditions eased 3 points to +16 in May, but remained well above its long-run average.

site_title: Asia's energy crunch turns from bad to worse on US export fire
summary: A US liquefied natural gas export plant in Texas, Freeport, faces a 90-day delay in restarting after a fire, exacerbating a global energy crunch. The plant's extended outage threatens a shortage of liquefied natural gas (LNG) this winter, prompting Asian buyers to compete with Europe for spare supply. Global LNG futures surge, with Asian buyers seeking alternative supplies from the US, Nigeria, Qatar, and the UAE, and European utilities considering spot market purchases. The supply crunch risks pushing up electricity bills and inflation.

images.alt_text: French energy group TotalEnergies CEO Patrick Pouyanne told AFP on Sunday that more projects are needed and consumers will still have to “turn down the heating” to ease the growing price crisis.
With ample LNG imports, European storage sites are now almost 50 per cent full, within a 5-year average for the time of the year, data from GIE show.

site_title: AirAsia X to add long-haul routes, including London, as demand rebounds
summary: Malaysia's budget carrier AirAsia X plans to add long-haul routes to London, Dubai, and Istanbul by the end of the year, following the lifting of travel curbs. The airline aims to resume 4 routes to Japan and Hawaii from July 1 and increase its fleet to 15 planes by year-end. AirAsia X had previously stopped flying to London in 2012 due to soaring taxes and fuel prices. The airline has adopted fuel surcharges and will charge higher fares due to the current high fuel environment.

images.alt_text: WITH the major tourism market of China still mostly sealed off from the rest of the world, AirAsia, the budget carrier of Capital A, is turning to India to make up the shortfall.

site_title: China May property sales fall at slower pace as policies buoy demand
summary: China's May property sales fell 31.8% from a year earlier, a slower decline than in April, as easing measures taken by cities to boost demand took effect. The decline in property sales was partly due to Covid outbreaks, but the market showed some positive developments, with shares of developers surging. Since the beginning of the year, around 200 cities have taken easing steps, including smaller down payments and subsidies. Despite the downward trend, financing conditions remained challenging for developers, and credit demand remains weak.

images.alt_text: Shanghai’s long shutdown, which brought food shortages and protests, has driven some to reconsider staying in a country where livelihoods and lifestyles can vanish at the whim of the state.

China's economy showed a mixed recovery in May, with industrial production unexpectedly increasing while the property market continued to slump and consumer spending declined as Covid restrictions curbed sentiment.

site_title: Singapore new private home sales more than doubled to 1,356 units in May
summary: Singapore new private home sales surged in May, with 1,356 units sold, more than doubling from April's 660 units. This marks a 6-month high since cooling measures were introduced in December. The rebound was attributed to improved market sentiment and major launches, including the 407-unit Piccadilly Grand and 298-unit Liv @ MB. Prices also trended upwards, with 43.5% of transactions above S$2 million. Foreigners and permanent residents made up a significant portion of sales, and analysts expect new home sales to continue picking up in the coming months.

images.alt_text: OrangeTee & Tie's Christine Sun is expecting more private rental tenants to opt for either smaller units or those located away from the city centre.
The value of all residential property assets held by Singapore households swelled 13.5 per cent year on year in Q4 2021, followed by a 10.4 per cent jump in Q1 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong's rate hikes to drive down costly housing prices
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is facing a significant impact from rising interest rates, which are driving up costs for homeowners and threatening to drive down prices. The Federal Reserve's aggressive rate hikes have forced Hong Kong to follow suit, resulting in higher debt for consumers and a cooling of the economy. Analysts expect demand for home loans to fall, leading to further price drops. With mortgage rates linked to the city's interbank market rate, rising rates are causing monthly repayments to increase by 12.8% for a homeowner with a HK$5 million mortgage.

images.alt_text: An aerial photo shows Hong Kong's Jumbo Floating Restaurant, an iconic but aging tourist attraction designed like a Chinese imperial palace, being towed out of Aberdeen Harbour on June 14, 2022, after its popularity dimmed in recent years even before the coronavirus hit. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)
HONG KONG saw Covid-19 infections detected among overseas travellers jump to a pandemic record after an easing of border restrictions led to a surge in international flights.

site_title: World's central banks got it wrong, and economies pay the price
summary: Central banks, including the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and Reserve Bank of Australia, are facing criticism for misjudging inflation and credibility, leading to increased interest rates and potential economic slowdown. Despite recognizing past errors, they continue to expand their balance sheets and keep rates near zero, fueling concerns of recessions. Global stocks have entered a bear market, and investors are questioning central banks' ability to restore price stability. The loss of credibility may necessitate further policy action to defuse price pressures, raising concerns about the long-term impact on economies.

images.alt_text: “It is a structural inflation situation that is going to produce stagflation,” Dalio told the AFR.
The Bank of Korea raised its inflation forecast for this year to 4.5 per cent, from a 3.1 per cent projection made in February.

site_title: Toyota heads into AGM under pressure from pension funds over climate
summary: Toyota heads into its annual general meeting under pressure from New York City and Danish pension funds over its commitment to battery vehicles and lobbying on climate policy. The funds, which own over $200 million in Toyota shares, have criticized the company's slow transition to battery electric vehicles and its lobbying activities, which they say undermine the transition to full electrification. Toyota has committed to electrifying its cars by 2030 but expects only a third of its sales to be battery electric vehicles by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Well known as the world’s second-biggest auto-parts maker, Denso has also quietly built up a presence in automotive chips.
Toyota has managed to continue outpacing VW, despite coming up short of a production target last month that the company had pared back due to the spread of Covid-19 in Japan and overseas.

site_title: China industrial output rebounds while consumers still wary
summary: China's economy showed a mixed recovery in May, with industrial production unexpectedly increasing 0.7% from a year ago, while the property market continued to slump and consumer spending declined. Retail sales fell 6.7% and fixed-asset investment grew 6.2% in the first 5 months of the year. The government's efforts to ease Covid restrictions and stimulate economic growth are seen as a positive step, but the outlook remains uncertain due to ongoing outbreaks and curbs.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Finance will auction 7.5 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) of the central government bonds across 2, 3 and 5-year maturities on Wednesday, the first of 4 batches totaling 23 billion yuan planned for this year in Hong Kong, denominated in the offshore currency.
China’s central bank is expected to keep unchanged for a fifth straight month on Wednesday the borrowing costs on its medium-term policy loans.

site_title: Bill Gates blasts crypto, NFTs as based on 'greater-fool' theory
summary: Bill Gates criticized cryptocurrency projects like non-fungible tokens (NFTs) as "shams" based on the "greater-fool theory" at a climate conference. He dismissed NFTs as expensive digital images with no practical impact, sparking a 20% drop in Bitcoin prices. Gates also defended digital banking efforts, calling them "hundreds of times more efficient" than cryptocurrencies, while backing Breakthrough Energy Ventures, a climate-focused fund he co-founded.

site_title: China’s middle class looks to flee as Covid-19 policies bite
summary: China's COVID-19 policies have driven a growing number of its middle class to reconsider staying in the country, with some planning to emigrate to Europe or other countries. Harsh lockdowns in Shanghai have decimated businesses, upended education, and left the country out of step with the rest of the world. Many are frustrated with Beijing's growing controls and seeking better opportunities abroad. Immigration consultants report a surge in enquiries, with some seeking to escape the "zero-Covid" isolation. The Chinese government has tightened exit policies, banning all "unnecessary" travel and restricting passport renewals, but some are finding ways to leave, including on the black market.

images.alt_text: Buyouts in China slowed sharply in 2022, as the 2-month Shanghai lockdown and other Covid restrictions in many parts of the country hurt the economy and brought potential transactions to a grinding halt.
Less than two weeks after tentative reopening began in Shanghai, the city began locking down several districts once more, to conduct mass testing.
High net worth investors from China have been setting up family offices in Singapore.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia warns inflation too high, ‘decisive’ action needed
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe warned that inflation is expected to reach 7% by the end of the year, up from the current 5.1% pace, and called for "decisive" action to bring it back to the 2-3% target range. The RBA delivered a 50 basis point rate hike in June, with more tightening expected, and investors are betting on further hikes, potentially reaching 3.5% by the end of the year. Lowe expressed confidence that tighter policy will ultimately bring inflation under control.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.5 per cent in early trade on Wednesday, extending losses to a fourth straight session.
Australia's minimum wage rose to A$21.38 (S$20.50) an hour from July 1, up from the current rate of A$20.33, the Australian Fair Work Commission said after its annual review.

site_title: Grab buys, relaunches food review site HungryGoWhere
summary: Grab has acquired and relaunched food review site HungryGoWhere, which was previously owned by Singtel. The new HungryGoWhere aims to reconnect users with Singapore's local food scene, providing reviews, deals, and restaurant reservations. The site will also highlight up-and-coming personalities and food origins. Grab plans to leverage its superapp data to inform content and promote relevant stories on its app and marketing channels. The move is part of Grab's strategy to establish itself as a go-to source for food recommendations and F&B brands.

site_title: Goldman investigation tarnishes ESG halo as investors bail
summary: Retail investors are increasingly scrutinizing the US$40 trillion environmental, social and governance (ESG) industry, with many disapproving of its practices. Goldman Sachs Asset Management and Deutsche Bank's investment arm have faced greenwashing allegations, while demand for ESG funds has cooled, with global flows slumping 36% in the first quarter. This trend is reflected in the biggest-ever monthly redemptions from US exchange-traded ESG funds in May.

site_title: Global ETFs achieve 36 straight months of net inflows, hit second-highest YTD record of US$417.9b
summary: Global exchange-traded funds (ETFs) achieved 36 consecutive months of net inflows, with year-to-date net inflows reaching a record $417.9 billion in June. The total net inflows over the past 12 months reached $1.14 trillion, with equity ETFs and exchange-traded products (ETPs) globally seeing $35.6 billion in net inflows in May. This marks a 1% increase in global ETF assets, now totaling $9.46 trillion, a 7.9% decrease from 2021 levels.

images.alt_text: Relative to its price, the S&P 500 “pays out” just under 5 per cent in earnings as of Thursday (Jun 9), data compiled by Bloomberg show.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) has gained 3.5 per cent in the year to date, with reinvested dividends boosting the total return to 5.6 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 19.81 points, or 1.34%, to 1,461.47, with 220 losers outnumbering 121 gainers. The market opened lower on Wednesday, with 232.6 million lots traded at RM94.9 million.

site_title: BP buys into Australian wind, solar, hydrogen mega-project
summary: BP has agreed to purchase a 40.5% stake in the Asian Renewable Energy Hub (AREH) project in Western Australia, becoming the operator of the project that could produce 1.6 million tonnes of green hydrogen annually or 9 million tonnes of ammonia. The project aims to develop 26 gigawatts of wind and solar power capacity, making it one of the world's biggest producers of green hydrogen. The deal comes after Australian government concerns about wetland damage delayed the project's progress. BP's involvement is seen as a key step in jumpstarting the project.

images.alt_text: BP has reported its strongest quarterly earnings  amid soaring oil and gas prices.

site_title: Japan government hopes Bank of Japan takes ‘necessary’ action on yen, inflation
summary: Japan's government is urging the Bank of Japan to take "necessary measures" to stabilize the yen, which has fallen to a 24-year low due to the central bank's ultra-low interest rates. Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno stated that Tokyo is ready to respond as needed and will communicate closely with G-7 counterparts. The BOJ's two-day policy meeting ends on Friday, with expectations of no rate changes but rising US interest rates may further weaken the yen. The government hopes the BOJ will address the issue to mitigate the impact on the economy and cost of living.

site_title: South Korea jobless rate stays low in sign of economic resilience
summary: South Korea's jobless rate remained low at 2.8% in May, edging up from 2.7% in the prior month, as the economy added 935,000 positions. The jobless rate defied expectations, suggesting the labour market's resilience despite accelerating inflation and rising interest rates. The Bank of Korea is concerned about a wage-price spiral, while the government is considering a potential "big-step" rate hike to combat inflation, which hit 5.4% in May, the highest reading since 2008.

site_title: Disney+ could lose 20 million subscribers after ceding cricket
summary: Walt Disney Co. may lose up to 20 million subscribers after being outbid for Indian Premier League cricket streaming rights. The loss could hinder its goal of reaching 260 million global Disney+ subscribers by 2024. Cricket has been a significant driver of Disney+ Hotstar's 50 million subscribers, primarily in India and other South Asian nations. Despite retaining broadcast rights for traditional TV networks, the company faces challenges in justifying high yearly IPL rights fees, with annualized revenue of less than $500 million.

site_title: Julius Baer Index identifies bikes and whisky among life’s dearer luxuries
summary: The Julius Baer Index reports that high-end bicycles and whisky have seen significant price increases, with bicycles rising 31.4% and whisky prices increasing 27.4% over the past year. Technology and lawyer's fees also saw significant price hikes, with technology rising 41% and lawyer's fees increasing 32.6%. In contrast, wine prices fell by 26.1%, while MBA degrees and health insurance experienced a decline of 11.7% and 24.4%, respectively. The report also found that Asian cities remain the most expensive, with Shanghai retaining the top spot, followed by London and other Asian cities.

summary: BTS, a K-pop group, announced they will focus on individual projects for a while, causing Hybe's shares to plummet 27% and reach their lowest close on record. The decision, made in a YouTube video, aims to be healthy for the band and does not imply a negative view from fans. However, analysts predict sharp downgrades to Hybe's profit and revenue estimates for the year and next year due to the change.

site_title: Singapore households’ net worth grows as residential asset values climb
summary: Singapore households' net worth rose 8.7% year-over-year to S$2.43 trillion in Q1 2022, driven by a 13.5% surge in residential assets and a 10.4% jump in private home prices. This growth is expected to continue, albeit at a slower pace, bolstering household net worth. However, tightening measures and rising interest rates may weigh on housing affordability. Experts attribute the property market's resilience to rising liquid assets per household and the wealth effect, which promotes expenditures and generates economic multipliers.

site_title: Bank of America aims to grow corporate cash management with new tool
summary: Bank of America is launching a new cash management tool in the US to gain market share in the $300 billion corporate cash management business. The virtual account management (VAM) tool helps companies manage multiple accounts online, providing a virtual ledger of account balances and transactions. The tool, already available in Europe, can be opened and used within a day, reducing costs and complexity for clients. Bank of America aims to capitalize on the accelerated use of electronic payments in the US, following the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Gut-biome startup AMILI raises US$10.5m Series A round led by Vulcan Capital
summary: Biotech startup AMILI has secured a US$10.5 million Series A round led by Vulcan Capital, with other investors including Seeds Capital, Emtek Group, and Capital Code. The funding will be used to develop a proprietary analytics engine, AMILI PRIME, and expand the company's presence in South-East Asia. AMILI aims to build a data and sample repository of Asian-centric microbiome and accelerate microbiome research partnerships and discovery. The company's direct-to-consumer precision gut health brand BIO & ME plans to launch in the rest of South-East Asia and Hong Kong in 2022.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's top banks are experiencing a downturn due to the Russia-Ukraine war, macroeconomic headwinds, and excessive valuations. Top students in Singapore are shifting their focus towards courses in data science, food science, and environmental sustainability. The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) market crossed the S$100,000 threshold, causing pain for buyers. An Indonesian family is in exclusive due diligence to buy 22 units at Draycott Eight for nearly S$168 million. Meanwhile, Sembmarine shareholders are opposing the company's merger with Keppel O&M. Global economic concerns, including US tariffs and China's slowing GDP growth, are also affecting markets.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,112.19 on Wednesday, driven by a slight edge in the local market despite global stocks falling overnight due to investor anticipation of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 50, with active index counters including Singapore Airlines and Mapletree Logistics Trust. The US market weakened, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing 0.5% lower, while European shares continued their sell-off amid recession worries.

site_title: China will test markets with biggest offshore bond sale since 2016
summary: China will conduct its largest offshore yuan sovereign bond sale since 2016, auctioning 7.5 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) in 2, 3, and 5-year maturities. The sale aims to test global appetite for Chinese government bonds amid a debt market rout and outflows of funds. The move is seen as a test of market appetite and a bid to drain offshore liquidity and stabilize the currency, which has slid to become Asia's worst-performing currency.

site_title: India sticks to fishing demands as WTO tries to avoid impasse
summary: India has refused to budge on its demands for extensive exceptions on government fishery subsidies and food-purchasing programs, threatening a potential multilateral agreement at the World Trade Organization (WTO) ministerial conference. The country's Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal stated that India would not agree to a 25-year phase-in period or a 200-nautical-mile exclusion for artisanal anglers, which has raised concerns among other delegates. The WTO's efforts to conclude a package of small deals are now at risk, potentially shifting the global trade landscape and reducing the organization's effectiveness as a consensus-based forum.

images.alt_text: HIGH global energy and raw material prices combined with a weak rupee fueled the fastest annual rise in India's wholesale prices in more over 30 years, raising expectations for the central bank to order more interest rate hikes.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street lower ahead of Federal Reserve rate decision
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% in early trade on Wednesday, extending losses to a fourth straight session, amid a weak finish on Wall Street overnight. Investors await the outcome of the US Federal Reserve meeting, where a 50-bp hike is expected, although some analysts predict a 75-bp hike due to higher-than-expected US retail inflation data.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell more than 5 per cent on Tuesday and were headed for their worst session in over two years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly at the open on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.21% or 43.33 points to 21,111.32. The gains followed a week of heavy losses. Markets are watching the Federal Reserve's policy decision later in the day for further direction. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.23%.

site_title: Japan’s April core machinery orders post unexpected double-digit growth
summary: Japan's core machinery orders surged 10.8% in April, exceeding economists' median forecast of a 1.5% dip. This unexpected growth suggests business spending remains robust despite uncertainties such as higher energy prices and China's Covid-19 lockdowns. The data indicates a positive outlook for Japan's corporate sector and broader economy, which faces global inflation and the yen's rapid decline.

site_title: Revolut launches in five more countries
summary: Revolut, a digital banking platform, has launched a streamlined version of its app in five new countries: Sri Lanka, Chile, Ecuador, Azerbaijan, and Oman. This expansion allows customers to transfer money to over 50 countries using 30 currencies. There is no fee for transfers to other Revolut customers, but a 1% fee applies to transfers to non-Revolut accounts, with a US$1 minimum. Revolut aims to build a global financial "super app" and plans to be in up to 90 countries by the end of 2022, with over 18 million customers and 500,000 businesses using its products.

site_title: SoftBank plans additional London listing for Arm IPO: sources
summary: SoftBank plans to list a portion of its stake in chip designer Arm on the London Stock Exchange, shifting from an earlier plan to only use the US market, according to people familiar with the matter. The company is seeking a valuation of at least $60 billion for Arm and aims to list the majority of its shares on US exchanges. The move is seen as a boost to the UK government and capital market, following a statement from the UK's Minister for Tech and the Digital Economy expressing support for a UK listing.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group trimmed borrowing from its main bank Mizuho Financial Group by 4.5 per cent in the year ended March to 812 billion yen (S$8.7 billion).

site_title: Australia global competitiveness rank climbs on commodity surge
summary: Australia's global competitiveness ranking has improved by 3 places to 19th out of 63 countries, driven by strong commodity prices, employment numbers, and pandemic recovery. Despite this, the country still scores poorly on technology, productivity, and entrepreneurship. Australia ranked 61st in entrepreneurship and 41st in workplace productivity. The nation needs to boost efficiency and outcomes in health and education, and better tax its resource bounty to sustain its competitiveness. The country's export concentration remains a vulnerability, requiring diversification of trading partners and building new markets.

site_title: European natural gas prices jump on long Texas plant outage
summary: European natural gas prices surged to nearly 100 euros per megawatt/hour, the highest in nearly three weeks, after a key US export terminal in Texas, Freeport LNG, announced a full restart is months away following a fire. The terminal outage will reduce US natural gas exports, forcing European industrial users to increase orders for petroleum products, straining an already tight market. The loss of US natural gas imports will further minimize Europe's reliance on Russia amid the Ukraine invasion.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$1.81, or 1.48 per cent, to US$120.20 a barrel by 0443 GMT on Monday.

site_title: European, US regulators to hold meeting with Boeing on 777X
summary: US and European aviation safety regulators plan to hold a meeting with Boeing next week to discuss the certification of its 777X airplane. The meeting aims to share information and agree on common safety targets, following concerns raised by regulators about the aircraft's safety. The 777X was initially expected to be released for airline use in 2020, but production has been halted until 2023 due to certification delays. Certification is needed before Boeing can begin deliveries, which are now expected to occur in 2025.

images.alt_text: Boeing, a major US defence contractor, plans to develop a research and technology hub in the Arlington area, home to the Pentagon and across the Potomac River from the US capital.

site_title: Looming debt crunch positions Laos as next possible Asia default
summary: Laos is facing a looming debt crisis, with public debt reaching $14.5 billion and nearly half owed to China, according to the World Bank. The country's cash reserves are dwindling, and inflation is at a 13% high, making it difficult for the secretive communist regime to meet its debt obligations. The International Monetary Fund warned of "elevated" debt distress risks, and Moody's downgraded Laos' credit rating to Caa3 due to weak governance, high debt burden, and insufficient foreign exchange reserves. The government is trying to navigate the situation, but a default is a possibility, with China's influence being a key factor.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of US Federal Reserve action
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.16% in the benchmark Nikkei 225 index, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's key decision and expected tougher rate hike. The broader Topix index also fell 0.18%. The cautious trade follows rising expectations for a significant interest rate hike, which may impact global markets.

site_title: US panel recommends Moderna Covid-19 vaccine for children six and up
summary: A US medical panel of 22 experts unanimously recommended the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 6-17. The vaccine's benefits outweigh its risks, demonstrated in clinical trials involving thousands of participants. The panel's decision comes after the FDA's concerns about myocarditis, a rare heart inflammation, were alleviated. This recommendation is expected to be followed by formal authorization, providing families with a second Covid-19 vaccine option. The approval is also seen as a way to mitigate production and inventory shortages.

site_title: Oil prices settle down on fears of Federal Reserve hike and oil profit tax
summary: Oil prices settled down 0.9% to $121.17 a barrel on Tuesday amid fears of a higher-than-expected Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The US central bank's meeting on Wednesday is expected to see a 75 basis point rate hike, driving down equities and oil prices. A 21% surtax on oil company profits considered excessive is also being introduced, further pressuring oil prices. Global oil demand is expected to exceed pre-pandemic levels in 2022, but growth is expected to slow next year due to surging oil prices and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: OPEC has kept to its forecast that world oil demand will exceed pre-pandemic levels in 2022, but said Russia's invasion of Ukraine and developments around the coronavirus pandemic pose a considerable risk.

site_title: Ford recalls 48,924 Mustang Mach-Es in setback for EV plans
summary: Ford is recalling 48,924 Mustang Mach-E electric vehicles due to a potential safety defect involving overheating high-voltage battery main contactors, which can cause vehicles to lose power or fail to start. The issue is being corrected with a software update that owners can receive over the air or by visiting a dealer. This recall is a setback for Ford, which is trying to fortify its position as a leader in electric vehicles, and comes as the company aims to build 2 million EVs annually by 2026.

images.alt_text: Ford will add more than 6,200 hourly jobs and convert 3,000 temporary workers into full-time employees who will receive health-care benefits and higher pay.

Ford Motor needs to overhaul its century-old business model - from slashing advertising spending to reworking its dealer network - if it is to earn enough profit on electric vehicles to compete with Tesla and others, the automaker's chief executive said on Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Far East Orchard, Hwa Hong

site_title: Aluminium extends losses on fears recession would hit demand
summary: Aluminium prices dropped 1.1% to $2,599 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange due to concerns about a potential global recession and reduced demand in top consumer China. Fresh Covid-19 lockdowns in China have rekindled worries about the metal's demand. Investors also await the Federal Reserve's interest rate meeting, which may lead to a rate hike. Despite falling prices, inventory levels remain low, creating a conundrum for the market.

site_title: Netflix plans 'Squid Game' reality show with big cash prize, no fatal consequences
summary: Netflix has announced plans to create a reality show called "Squid Game: The Challenge" with a cash prize of $4.56 million, the largest in reality TV history. Unlike the original series, where contestants played games with fatal consequences, the new show will feature games inspired by the original show, but with no fatal outcomes. The competition will be filmed in the UK and will only feature English speakers. The show is part of Netflix's efforts to capitalize on the success of its popular series, which holds the record for most-watched series on the platform, with over 1.65 billion hours viewed in its first 28 days.

site_title: Japan manufacturers’ mood improves on resilient demand: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japanese manufacturers' sentiment is expected to improve over the next three months due to resilient demand, despite high raw material prices and a weaker yen. site_title: Europe: Stocks post six straight days of losses
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index declined 1.3% on Tuesday, extending a six-day losing streak, amid concerns over aggressive US interest rate hikes and a potential recession. The benchmark index hit three-month lows on Monday. Healthcare and industrial stocks led sectoral losses, while battered banks edged higher. The US Federal Reserve's policy decision on Wednesday is expected to influence the market, with many predicting a 3.75% rate hike. The Stoxx 600 has shed 17% since its all-time high in January due to record-high inflation, tightening financial conditions, and a slowdown in China's economy.

site_title: Floods, fires, heat waves: US struggles with climate catastrophes
summary: The US is experiencing a surge in climate-related catastrophes, including raging wildfires, devastating floods, powerful thunderstorms, and a heat wave affecting nearly a third of the population. A heat dome has brought record-breaking temperatures to the Upper Midwest and Southeast, with over 120 million people under some sort of advisory. Flooding in Yellowstone National Park has also caused widespread destruction, with roads washed out and bridges affected. Scientists attribute the increase in extreme weather events to global warming, which is being driven by humanity's burning of fossil fuels, making such events more likely.

site_title: AEW’s S$675m Westgate Tower purchase adds to Singapore office deals momentum
summary: US-based real estate investment manager AEW is purchasing Westgate Tower, a 20-storey office block near Jurong East MRT station, for about S$675 million. The deal adds to the momentum in Singapore's office investment sales market, which has seen transactions totaling close to S$4 billion year-to-date. site_title: Singapore climbs back to 3rd place from 5th in global competitiveness ranking
summary: Singapore has regained its position as the world's 3rd most competitive economy, according to the 2022 Institute for Management Development (IMD) World Competitiveness Ranking. The country climbed back up from 5th place in 2021 due to strong economic performance, gross domestic product growth, and improvements in domestic economy, international trade, and technological infrastructure. However, concerns over hybrid work models and the attractiveness of the city-state to foreign talent may hinder its long-term competitiveness.

site_title: Apple to stream Major League Soccer as sports ambitions grow
summary: Apple has secured a 10-year deal to stream Major League Soccer (MLS) matches, starting next year. The tech company will offer the games through a new subscription-based product on Apple TV, with some matches available for free to Apple TV+ subscribers. The deal is worth a minimum of $250 million per year, with MLS aiming to increase revenue after deals expire this year. The agreement is part of Apple's growing sports broadcasting ambitions, following its recent deal with Major League Baseball.

site_title: Global nuclear spending surges to US$82.4b as superpower tensions rise
summary: Global nuclear spending surged to $82.4 billion in 2021, a 9% increase, as superpower tensions rise. The US led the spending with $44.2 billion, followed by China ($11.7 billion) and Russia ($8.6 billion). The International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons reported that nuclear spending has not improved security, citing the Russian invasion of Ukraine as evidence. The group argues that billions invested in nuclear weapons could be better used to address current security challenges and the ongoing global pandemic.

images.alt_text: The number of nuclear weapons in the world is set to rise in the coming decade after 35 years of decline as global tensions flare amid Russia’s war in Ukraine, researchers said on Monday.

site_title: Beijing in 'race against time' to contain Covid surge
summary: Beijing is in a "race against time" to contain a Covid-19 surge linked to a 24-hour bar, with at least 287 cases reported. Authorities have identified 10,000 close contacts and are conducting mass testing in the city's largest district. The surge has raised concerns about the city's ability to manage the outbreak, which comes just days after widespread curbs were lifted. The city's 22 million residents are facing mandatory testing and targeted lockdowns, with police investigating the bar's owner and others suspected of interfering with epidemic prevention.

site_title: Walmart seeks UK sellers for its online marketplace
summary: Walmart is seeking UK retailers to join its online marketplace, providing an alternative to Amazon and eBay. Approved sellers will have access to Walmart.com, visited by 120 million people monthly, and services such as 2-day US shipping. The US retail giant is hosting a UK Sellers Summit in London, inviting manufacturers and exporters from various sectors. This move aims to help British businesses reach £1 trillion in exports by 2030, following the UK government's non-EU market focus. UK companies like Statsports and Pertemba already sell on Walmart's platform.

summary: China's zero-Covid policy appears to be a major obstacle to the country's economic recovery, as Shanghai re-imposed lockdowns and mass testing amid rising cases. Despite a tentative reopening, China's stance on zero-Covid seems unlikely to change, with the country's defence minister praising the policy as a global contribution. As vaccination rates decrease severity and the virus mutates, a zero-Covid policy becomes increasingly incongruous, with no clear exit strategy in sight, leading to economic, societal, and human costs.

site_title: Design firm Space Matrix to acquire India-based B2B e-commerce platform Pursuite
summary: Space Matrix, a Singapore-based design consultancy, is acquiring Pursuite, an India-based B2B e-commerce platform, for an undisclosed sum. summary: South Korean truckers ended a weeklong strike after reaching a settlement with the government, easing strain on global supply chains. The agreement includes extending a freight rate system that guarantees minimum wages and providing subsidies to alleviate pressure from rising fuel costs. The strike, which started on June 7, had disrupted industries and production, causing estimated losses of 1.6 trillion won (S$1.7 billion). Deliveries of key goods, such as cars and petrochemical products, were suspended or delayed.

site_title: Indonesian fintech startup Flip raises US$100m following second close of Series B funding
summary: Indonesian fintech startup Flip has raised US$100 million in its second close of Series B funding, led by Tencent, Block, and existing investor Insight Partners. The new capital will be used to ramp up its workforce and invest in product and technology development to improve service quality. Flip has driven significant growth in user volume and served over 10 million users in various financial transactions. The startup aims to further accelerate its business expansion, capitalizing on Indonesia's vast digital economy opportunities.

site_title: Shipping's wish list for pandemic recovery
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has published a paper outlining its "manifesto" for pandemic recovery, calling for governments to take 10 calls to action (CTA) to support the global shipping industry in recovering from COVID-19. The CTA includes efforts to maintain collaborative, multilateral structures and uphold principles of international shipping policy. site_title: Barclays says climate disaster will collapse major currencies
summary: A new study by Barclays predicts severe climate shock in the next 50 years will wreak havoc on the global economy and currency markets, potentially leading to a 50% drop in the Chinese yuan and Japanese yen by 2070. The study's worst-case scenario assumes rising sea levels, air pollution, and crop failure will devastate densely populated cities, particularly in Japan and China. Analysts warn that policy action, such as carbon taxes, can reduce emissions and mitigate the economic toll of climate change.

images.alt_text: TWO European Parliament committees on Tuesday (Jun 14) backed an attempt to stop the EU labelling gas and nuclear energy as climate-friendly investments, setting the stage for a full parliament vote that could reject the rules next month.

site_title: White House says discussing 'irresponsible' tariffs imposed by Trump
summary: The White House is discussing possible changes to tariffs imposed by former President Donald Trump on Chinese goods, which raised costs on US families and businesses. Press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said internal discussions are continuing, but no details have been released. The Biden administration has noted that some Trump-era tariffs were "irresponsible" and aims to align them with national security priorities to safeguard workers and critical industries. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that tariff cuts would have a limited effect on inflation, which is at its highest in over 40 years.

site_title: WHO set to decide if monkeypox represents health emergency
summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) is set to convene an emergency committee to assess whether the monkeypox outbreak represents a public health emergency of international concern. With 1,600 confirmed and 1,500 suspected cases and 72 deaths in 39 countries, the virus is behaving unusually, affecting more countries than usual, and a coordinated international response is needed. The WHO's decision comes as the virus typically spreads in parts of Africa, but this year's outbreak has seen cases in both endemic and non-endemic regions.

site_title: Famed Hong Kong floating restaurant towed away after half a century
summary: Hong Kong's iconic Jumbo Floating Restaurant, a 76-meter-long, 2,300-diner capacity eatery, was towed out of Aberdeen Harbour on June 14, 2022, after years of declining popularity and financial struggles. The restaurant, designed like a Chinese imperial palace, had drawn celebrities and featured in films, but its operators cited the Covid-19 pandemic as the reason for its closure in March 2020. The restaurant will now await a new operator at an undisclosed location.

images.alt_text: An aerial photo shows Hong Kong's Jumbo Floating Restaurant, an iconic but aging tourist attraction designed like a Chinese imperial palace, being towed out of Aberdeen Harbour on June 14, 2022, after its popularity dimmed in recent years even before the coronavirus hit. Cathay reported a HK$7.6 billion (S$1.3 billion) deficit for the 6 months ended Jun 30, 2021.

site_title: BA says 3,000 hires stuck in system as UK travel chaos continues
summary: British Airways reported that around 3,000 potential recruits are stuck in background checks taking up to four months, contributing to travel chaos in the UK. Airlines, including British Airways, EasyJet, and TUI, have faced staff shortages due to the pandemic, resulting in cancelled flights and long lines at airport security. The Civil Aviation Authority and Department for Transport have set expectations for airlines to review schedules and airports to establish working groups to ensure smooth operations, amid criticism of the travel sector's handling of the crisis.

images.alt_text: Airline lobbyist Willie Walsh stepped up a war of words over disruption at UK airports, lambasting a government minister who blamed the industry for hundreds of canceled flights.

site_title: US small-business sentiment dips in May: NFIB
summary: US small-business confidence dropped 0.1 points to 93.1 in May due to persistent worries about high inflation. The National Federation of Independent Business reported a record-low share of owners expecting better business conditions over the next 6 months. Demand for labor remained strong despite rising interest rates and tighter financial conditions, with 51% of businesses reporting job openings they could not fill. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise its policy interest rate by another 50 basis points, fueling concerns about slow growth or a recession next year.

site_title: EU cartel raids target fashion designers proposing sales periods, discount changes: sources
summary: EU antitrust regulators conducted dawn raids targeting fashion designers who proposed changes in sales periods and discounts, potentially violating EU cartel rules. The European Commission is investigating signatories of an open letter from 2020, including prominent designers, for possible price-fixing and restrictive business practices. The open letter aimed to make the fashion industry more environmentally and socially sustainable by altering sales periods and discounts. Companies found breaching EU cartel rules face fines up to 10% of their global turnover.

site_title: EU warns drug problem is ‘Everywhere, Everything, Everyone’
summary: The European Union's European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction has reported that the drug problem is widespread, affecting "everywhere, everything, everyone." The report notes a rise in drug use, with 83.4 million people in the EU estimated to have used an illicit drug at some point. Innovation has led to a surge in new substances and trafficking routes, making the situation more complex. Cocaine use has returned to pre-pandemic levels, with signs of a rise in crack cocaine use. The report highlights the need for a more effective response to the growing drug problem.

site_title: Singapore poultry importers see reprieve as Malaysia’s chicken export ban partially lifted
summary: Malaysia has partially lifted its blanket suspension on chicken exports, allowing some poultry players in Singapore to bring in live kampung and black chickens. The export ban on commercial broiler chickens remains in place, but exports of poultry products such as nuggets or sausages can resume. This move comes after Malaysia halted exports of up to 3.6 million chickens per month to stabilize domestic supply and prices. At least two Singapore companies have obtained permits to bring in live chickens, which will be sold to wet markets, hawkers, and restaurants starting from Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Labour shortages and hot weather have worsened the broiler chicken production in Malaysia.

site_title: Amid greater digitalisation, SMEs must contend with issues such as cyber attacks and finding talent: panel
summary: South-east Asian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in digitalisation, including talent acquisition, digital literacy gaps, and cyber attacks. A recent report projects the digital economy in the region will more than double in size by 2025 and reach $1 trillion by 2030. SMEs must reskill and upskill their labor population to participate in the digital economy, and companies must invest in cybersecurity measures to protect against cyber attacks. Digital literacy gaps and the need to make digital technologies accessible to the less privileged also need to be addressed.

images.alt_text: (From left) Tan See Leng (Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry - Singapore); and Jeffrey Jaensubhakij (Group Chief Investment Officer of Government of Singapore Investment Corporation/ GIC Private Limited) speaking on 'Renewables as Key Growth Engines in the Post-Covid Economy' during Indonesia - Singapore Business Forum at Hilton Singapore Orchard Hotel on June 14, 2022.

site_title: Opec sticks to forecast of 2022 oil demand exceeding pre-pandemic levels but sees risks
summary: OPEC maintains its forecast that 2022 oil demand will exceed pre-pandemic levels, rising 3.36 million barrels per day. However, the organization notes risks from Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the ongoing pandemic, which may worsen inflationary pressures. Despite these concerns, OPEC expects world consumption to surpass 100 million barrels per day in the third quarter and reach a 2022 average of 100.29 million barrels per day, just above the pre-pandemic rate in 2019.

site_title: Proposal for Frasers Property to take hospitality trust private may raise expectations for sponsors
summary: Frasers Property plans to take Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) private at S$0.70 per stapled security, offering investors a choice to cash out at 1.07 times book value. The move comes after FHT's net asset value and distributions per stapled security have been in decline, with the Reit trading at a 25% discount to its NAV since its IPO in 2014. The proposal is seen as a positive development for FHT's holders and may set a precedent for sponsor groups to reposition failing Reits, raising the bar for investor treatment.

images.alt_text: Frasers Property Hospitality Trust Holdings, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Frasers Property, is proposing to privatise Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) through a trust scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Thailand under pressure to hike as price, currency risks mount
summary: Thailand's central bank faces pressure to raise interest rates to combat the country's highest inflation in almost 14 years, amid a weakening currency and rising imported inflation. The Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee is expected to consider an emergency rate hike, with some analysts predicting a 25 basis point increase next month. The baht has tumbled to a multi-year low, fueling concerns about the impact on retail fuel prices and inflation, which is forecast to peak in the third quarter.

site_title: Falling yen might not lower car prices
summary: The weakening Japanese yen may not lead to lower car prices in Singapore, despite the currency's near 24-year lows. Car distributors attribute the lack of price drops to high freight charges, rising microchip prices, and manufacturers passing these costs on to consumers. Additionally, import duty and registration fees are based on the car's open market value, which has not necessarily decreased with the yen's fall. As a result, car prices remain stable, with some models even experiencing price increases, such as the Toyota Camry Hybrid.

images.alt_text: Fuel-efficient cars now come in all shapes and (up to a point) sizes, and balance a small appetite for petrol with competence in other areas.

Barring an event that puts a large dent in demand — say, a recession — there is reason to think that more pain for car buyers is on the horizon because the COE supply, the so-called COE Quota, looks set to tighten.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Monday's rout
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday, a day after the S&P 500 confirmed it was in a bear market, as investors took relief from a smaller-than-expected rise in core producer prices. The Dow Jones rose 0.25%, the S&P 500 opened 0.37% higher, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.82%. The S&P 500's bear market confirmation follows a 20% decline from its peak.

site_title: US producer prices rise at a brisk pace, adding to Fed pressure
summary: US producer prices surged 10.8% in May, driven by a 5% increase in energy costs and nearly two-thirds of the rise attributed to goods prices. The core PPI rose 0.5% and 8.3% from a year earlier. This data, combined with consumer inflation accelerating to its highest level in four decades, is likely to lead the Federal Reserve to aggressively raise interest rates, with some banks now expecting a 75-basis-point hike. Inflationary pressures persist due to global supply chain disruptions, including Russia's war in Ukraine and China's COVID-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: US small-business confidence edged down in May as worries about high inflation persisted, according to a survey on Tuesday (Jun 14), which also showed demand for labour remained strong despite rising interest rates and tighter financial conditions.

site_title: Western Australia to shut coal power stations by 2030, invest A$3.8 billion in renewables
summary: Western Australia plans to shut its coal-fired generators by 2030 and invest A$3.8 billion in renewables, citing the "overwhelming uptake" of rooftop solar. The state will close two power stations, Collie and Muja's D unit, by 2027 and 2029, respectively. The move aims to reduce electricity prices and prevent major hikes or taxpayer-funded subsidies. The decision follows a decline in coal-fired generation, which now accounts for less than 60% of the domestic energy market, driven by rising global gas prices and increasing demand for gas-fired generation.

site_title: Euro zone spreads hit fresh highs amid rising yields
summary: Euro zone government bond yields hit fresh multi-year highs, with Italy's 10-year yield rising 4.5 basis points to 4.204%, and the Italian-German spread widening to 252.9 basis points, its widest level since April 2020. The widening spreads are amid concerns about accelerated central bank monetary tightening, with investors expecting 175 basis points of ECB rate hikes by year-end. Market experts argue that forecasts might be excessive, citing investors rushing to hedge loan portfolios. The ECB's policy meeting on Thursday sparked the widening spreads, and investors will look to other central banks' policy meetings this week for further direction.

site_title: Coinbase to cut 1,100 jobs amid turmoil in crypto markets
summary: Coinbase Global announced it will cut 18% of its workforce, approximately 1,100 jobs, to reduce costs amid volatile cryptocurrency market conditions. The layoffs follow a day of significant market downturn, including a 14% drop in Bitcoin, and come after the company extended its hiring freeze and rescinded accepted job offers earlier this month.

site_title: Buoyed by robust consumption, Malaysia’s retail industry beats Q1 forecasts
summary: Malaysia's retail industry saw a 18.3% year-on-year growth in Q1 2022, beating forecasts of 16.5%. Shoppers are returning to physical stores, with higher traffic volumes in major shopping districts. This growth is attributed to gradual consumer recovery.

summary: Weakened investor sentiment in the local market may lead to more privatization deals, according to industry players. The recent offer for Frasers Hospitality Trust is the latest in a string of such deals, driven by perceived under-valuation of companies. Bankers expect continued mergers and acquisitions activity as companies and funds seek to deploy capital, with privatisations being the main trend in Singapore over the past couple of years. This trend is expected to continue amid current market volatility.

site_title: Far East Orchard to make 4th investment in student hostel in Bristol
summary: Far East Orchard, a real estate company, has acquired a plot in Bristol to develop a student hostel with at least 690 beds, its 13th property in the UK. The project, a joint venture with Woh Hup Holdings and Way Assets, is expected to be completed in 2027. This marks Far East Orchard's fourth investment in Bristol, with the company holding a 42.5% stake in the development. The UK remains a top study destination, with international undergraduate applicants expected to increase by 46% through 2026.

site_title: EU lawmaker committees object to 'green' label for gas investments
summary: European Parliament committees have backed a resolution to block the EU's plan to label gas and nuclear energy as climate-friendly investments, citing concerns over emissions and confusing investors. The resolution, set to be voted on by the full parliament in early July, would reject the European Commission's proposal to include these energy sources in the EU's taxonomy. The move is in response to disagreements among EU countries over the sustainability of these energy sources, with some citing concerns over waste disposal and others arguing they are crucial to meeting climate targets.

site_title: Sri Lanka gives public workers extra day off to grow food
summary: Sri Lanka has approved a 4-day work week for public sector workers to help cope with a chronic fuel shortage and encourage them to grow food. The move aims to alleviate the country's worst financial crisis in decades, caused by a severe foreign exchange shortage and rising food inflation. The government has also secured a potential bailout package with the International Monetary Fund and the United States is ready to provide assistance, with the US Secretary of State stating the country stands ready to work with Sri Lanka during these challenging times.

site_title: China set to keep medium-term rate unchanged on Wednesday, poll shows
summary: China's central bank is expected to keep borrowing costs unchanged for a fifth straight month on Wednesday, according to a Reuters survey of 31 traders and analysts. The poll showed nearly 97% of respondents predicted no change in the interest rate on the one-year medium-term lending facility. This expectation comes despite policymakers' pledge to support the economy, which has been hit by Covid-19 disruptions. Investors believe US Federal Reserve's hawkish monetary tightening may limit Beijing's policy manoeuvers, potentially limiting China's scope for further support.

images.alt_text: CHINA'S Cabinet unveiled some steps on Monday (Jun 13) to improve the allocation of resources among local governments to help ease their growing fiscal strains and debt risks, amid efforts to support the slowing economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Early-stage startups continue to attract investors despite the funding slowdown in the later stages. Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea, has left Spain, marking its third market exit this year. Crypto.com is cutting 260 jobs amid a market meltdown, while BlockFi reduced its headcount by 20%. A standalone island site was sold for S$25.9m, and Singapore's Straits Times Index improved slightly after a decline the previous day. The transition to renewable energy requires collaboration, clarity, and confidence, according to panellists.
