site_title: Cryptocurrency market value slumps under US$1 trillion
summary: The global cryptocurrency market value fell below US$1 trillion for the first time since January 2021, reaching US$926 billion, according to CoinMarketCap. The market has lost US$1 trillion in value in the last 2 months, driven by high inflation and fears of interest rate hikes. Bitcoin and ether, the largest cryptocurrencies, dropped 10% and 15% respectively, reaching 18-month lows of US$23,750 and US$1,210. Investors are shifting away from riskier assets, with analysts attributing the decline to inflation concerns.

site_title: Huge selloff rocks Treasury markets, yield curve inverts
summary: US Treasury yields rose above 10-year borrowing costs on June 13, signaling a curve inversion that often precedes economic recession. This move was driven by expectations of faster and further interest rate hikes to contain inflation. The inversion occurred despite the Federal Reserve's potential for an even larger rate hike this week to combat inflation. The event raised concerns about recession risks, with some investors anticipating a more aggressive rate hike.

site_title: EV-truck startup Electric Last Mile to liquidate
summary: Electric Last Mile Solutions Inc, an EV-truck startup that merged with a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC), plans to liquidate through a Chapter 7 bankruptcy process. The company's stock has plummeted 93% this year, and its CEO and chairman resigned in February. Despite efforts to secure funding and attract new investors, the startup's struggles, including a failed product launch and SEC investigation, led to the decision. The company's liquidation makes it the first EV startup to go out of business after merging with a SPAC amid market slump.

site_title: US$17 b loss puts Indian IPO among top Asia wealth losers

The 29% decline since its listing has put it second in terms of market capitalization loss, behind South Korea's LG Energy Solution. The IPO's poor performance is attributed to rising interest rates and inflation globally, as well as selling pressure by foreigners, with the benchmark S&P BSE Sensex down 9% this year.

summary: CATL, the world's largest electric car battery maker, has initiated an A-share private placement worth approximately 45 billion yuan (S$9.3 billion). The placement includes a greenshoe option that could increase the deal size to about US$6.87 billion. CATL has set a floor price of 339.67 yuan for the placement, which is expected to be priced on Wednesday.

site_title: Seletar Airport marks reopening as Firefly resumes daily KL-Singapore flights
summary: Firefly, the low-cost arm of Malaysia Aviation Group, has resumed daily flights between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore's Seletar Airport after a nearly 2-year hiatus due to the pandemic. The 72-seater turboprop plane landed at Seletar on June 13, marking the airport's reopening to commercial flights. Firefly will operate 4 flights a day between Subang and Singapore, with advance bookings strong, and plans to introduce a new route between Changi Airport and Penang International Airport in the future.

site_title: Put CBDCs on the back burner for now
summary: Central banks should focus on fighting inflation rather than introducing digital currencies. As inflation rates approach 10% in advanced economies and 70% in emerging economies, central bankers should prioritize monetary and financial stability over digital innovation. The debate on central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) has been overshadowed by the inflationary storm, and experts argue that the case for CBDCs has yet to be made. With the private sector offering alternative digital payments solutions, central banks should put CBDC research on the back burner for now.

The probe has also detected 2.9 million other galaxies and 1.9 million quasars, and has calculated the orbits of over 156,000 asteroids in our Solar System with precision. The data will fuel thousands of studies and provide a global observation of the positions of anything that moves in the sky.

The Federal Reserve may consider a 75 basis point interest rate hike next week, but a bigger increase could be seen as "panicky."

site_title: Oil consumers face a summer of pain
summary: Opec+ officials warn of limited supply additions, exacerbating fuel price increases. Global refineries face constraints, driving prices up faster than crude. Consumers face rising fuel costs, with Americans paying $5 a gallon and Brits spending over $170 to fill a normal car. China, the world's largest crude importer, is emerging from Covid-19 restrictions, potentially boosting consumption and market growth.

images.alt_text: Oil’s inflation-inducing rally could get supercharged with China’s biggest driller betting on a demand rebound if lockdowns ease as the US summer driving season starts.
An oversupply of naphtha at a time of poor demand has squeezed the product's Asian margins to their weakest levels since the 2008 global financial crisis, traders and analysts said.

Oil prices dipped on Thursday but still hovered near 3-month highs after parts of Shanghai imposed new Covid-19 lockdown measures, as strong gains in refined products contributed to an ongoing bullish backdrop for crude oil.

site_title: Jeweller Blue Nile set to return to public market via SPAC deal
summary: Blue Nile, an online jeweller, agreed to go public via a merger with Mudrick Capital Acquisition Corp. II, valuing the combined company at $873 million. The deal is expected to generate $450 million of capital and will list on Nasdaq under the name Blue Nile. The company, led by current management, will retain its existing leadership team, including CEO Sean Kell. Blue Nile was previously taken private in 2016 by Bain and Bow Street for $500 million.

site_title: ‘Exxon made more money than God’: Biden rips high gas prices
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized ExxonMobil for its high profits amid soaring inflation, stating "Exxon made more money than God last year" with net income of $23 billion in 2021. Biden pressured domestic oil companies to increase production, citing their focus on share buybacks instead. Exxon responded by announcing plans to increase production and expand refining capacity in the US, with a 25% increase in production expected this year. The company also reported $40.6 billion in total taxes in 2021.

site_title: US SEC investigating Goldman Sachs over ESG funds: WSJ
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Goldman Sachs over its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) funds. The investigation focuses on the firm's mutual-funds division, which manages at least 4 ESG-themed funds. This comes as the SEC proposed rule changes earlier this year to standardize ESG disclosures and prevent unfounded claims. Goldman Sachs has not commented on the investigation.

site_title: Tesla files to split shares 3-for-1 as investors bail on stock
summary: Tesla plans to ask shareholders to approve a 3-for-1 stock split at their August annual meeting, according to a proxy statement filed on June 11. The proposal comes amid a sharp selloff in the company's shares, which have dropped nearly 35% this year. The stock split, in the form of a dividend, is seen as a gesture to investors following the stock's underperformance. The move is expected to briefly boost the stock price, but its long-term impact remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Tesla has cancelled 3 online recruitment events for China scheduled this month, the latest development after chief executive Elon Musk threatened job cuts at the electric car maker, saying it was "overstaffed" in some areas.
Tesla vehicles waiting for shipping transport in Shanghai; the carmaker's factory there produced 33,544 vehicles in May, up 212 per cent from April.
Musk, the chief executive, said in an email seen by Reuters last week that he had a “super bad feeling” about the economy and needed to cut 10 per cent of salaried staff at the electric car maker.

site_title: China, US defence ministers hold talks in Singapore
summary: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin met Chinese Defence Minister Wei Fenghe in Singapore, marking their first face-to-face talks since Austin took office. The meeting comes amid strained relations between the two countries, with issues including Taiwan, the South China Sea, and cybersecurity on the agenda. The US has sought to shift its foreign policy focus back to Asia, while China views Taiwan as its territory and has vowed to seize it by force if necessary. The talks were seen as a step towards easing tensions, but the relationship between the two countries remains volatile.

images.alt_text: From Friday until Sunday, 42 countries, with 37 Ministerial-level delegates and more than 30 senior defence officials including Chief of Defence Forces as well as prominent academics will attend the premier defence and security conference for the Asia-Pacific region, according to Mindef.

site_title: How to run a business at a time of stagflation
summary: US CEOs are struggling to cope with stagflation, a period of high inflation and stagnant economic growth. To maintain profitability, they must pass on cost inflation to customers without dampening sales volumes. Companies are cutting expenses, but labor costs remain high due to tight labor markets. CEOs are also exploring automation and labor efficiencies. However, raising prices without dampening demand is riskier due to softer consumer sentiment. Effective management of working capital and a long-term view on price increases are crucial to navigating stagflation.

images.alt_text: Subdued growth will likely persist throughout the decade because of weak investment in most of the world.

site_title: Gold rebounds in roller coaster trade as economic fears grow
summary: Gold prices rebounded 1.4% to $1,873.58 per ounce after economic fears grew following elevated US inflation readings and a record-low consumer sentiment survey. The rebound came despite high interest rates and strength in the dollar, with investors assessing the economic repercussions. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are expected to continue through September, but gold's haven appeal has been boosted by growth warnings and a softening physical market.

images.alt_text: Gold edged down on Friday and headed for a weekly fall, as Treasury yields rose, with investors awaiting key monthly US inflation data that is due later in the day for cues on the future of monetary policy.
Gold inched lower on Thursday, with prices restrained by rising Treasury yields ahead of key US jobs and inflation data this week.
Bullion is down about 10 per cent from a peak in mid-March.

site_title: US inflation quickens to 40-year high, pressuring Fed and Biden
summary: US inflation hit a 40-year high in May, reaching 8.6% from a year earlier, exceeding forecasts. The core CPI, which strips out food and energy, rose 6% from a year ago, further pressuring the Federal Reserve to extend aggressive interest-rate hikes. This accelerates the Fed's stance, which may require maintaining higher rates through the September gathering, driven by record gasoline prices and geopolitical factors. The increase in inflation poses significant challenges for President Biden, who faces declining approval ratings ahead of midterm elections.

images.alt_text: The United States is unlikely to suffer an economic downturn, despite sky-high inflation, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said Thursday.

site_title: Indefinite suspension of fights in Mexican bullring
summary: A judge in Mexico City ordered an indefinite suspension of bullfighting at the 50,000-capacity Plaza Mexico, pending a lawsuit against the practice. This ruling comes after an animal welfare commission in Mexico City's legislature approved a proposal to prohibit bullfighting in the capital. The suspension is the latest in a series of court decisions against bullfighting, with only a handful of Mexico's 32 states having banned the practice. The city council has vowed to continue defending bullfighting as a "Mexican custom and tradition."

site_title: Mighty Asian financial institutions are reshaping global capital flows
summary: Asian financial institutions, including private pension funds and insurers, are increasingly shaping global capital flows, with their holdings surpassing those of official foreign investors. The share of Treasuries owned by private investors has risen from $1.1 trillion to $2.8 trillion over the past decade, while official investors' holdings have fallen to 58% of all Treasuries held abroad. This shift is partly driven by the growing influence of Asian private institutions, which are attracted to dollar-denominated assets due to their higher yields, and may complicate the picture of capital flows as the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates.

site_title: Revlon is preparing to file for bankruptcy: sources
summary: Revlon is preparing to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy as early as next week due to supply chain problems and a heavy debt load. The cosmetics giant, which owns over 15 brands, including Elizabeth Arden and Elizabeth Taylor, and markets in nearly 150 countries, has more than $3 billion of long-term debt. Revlon's shares plummeted 53% last Friday, and the company has narrowly avoided multiple defaults by cutting debt deals with creditors. The potential filing is subject to change, but talks with creditors and a possible change in equity ownership are underway.

site_title: US health authority says Moderna vaccine effective in children under 5
summary: US health authorities confirmed that Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine is effective in children under 5, with 51% efficacy in babies aged 6 months to less than 2 years old and 37% in children aged 2 to 5 years. The vaccine remains effective in preventing severe cases of the disease. The FDA is expected to authorise two doses of the vaccine in children aged 6 months to 5 years, with varying doses for different age groups.

site_title: Singapore’s role in Covid-19 vaccine production and future pandemics
summary: Singapore is poised to play a key role in Covid-19 vaccine production and future pandemics, thanks to its competitive advantage in manufacturing capacity and regulatory agility. The country has already attracted major vaccine producers, including BioNTech and Sanofi, and is working to foster innovation and address imbalances in manufacturing capacity. The World Trade Organization's proposal to waive intellectual property rights for Covid-19 vaccines could hinder future pandemic preparedness, and Singapore is urging WTO member-countries to reject the proposal. Ensuring equitable access to vaccines and treatments is crucial, and Singapore is advocating for real-time allocation of vaccine production capacity for vulnerable populations in lower-income countries.

images.alt_text: Pfizer and BioNTech are currently testing other versions of the vaccine targeted at the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.
Expect new outbreaks caused by both known and unknown pathogens; there have been at least seven in the past 20 years.

site_title: Netflix shares slide as Goldman downgrades on grim economic picture
summary: Netflix shares fell 5% on June 10 after Goldman Sachs downgraded the company due to a slowdown in consumer spending and tough competition from Amazon and Walt Disney. The downgrade, which slashed the price target to $186, comes as the streaming pioneer faces its first subscriber loss in over a decade and is suspending services in Russia. Analysts predict high levels of churn and expect some streaming services to pivot towards yearly discounted bundles to increase loyalty.

site_title: Huge Muslim protests in Asia after India prophet row
summary: Muslims in Asia have taken to the streets in huge protests after Indian ruling party officials made blasphemous comments about Prophet Mohammed, sparking a diplomatic storm. Over 100,000 people were estimated to have protested in Bangladesh, while thousands more gathered in Pakistan and India. The protests have led to calls for death penalties for those responsible and have strained relations between India and several Muslim-majority countries. India has suspended the official from its ranks and apologized, but tensions remain.

site_title: Timing is everything
summary: Entrepreneur James Quan, co-founder of Bynd Artisan, has a unique approach to watch collecting, focusing on timing and opportunity. Quan's journey into watch collecting began after joining the workforce, influenced by peers and seniors. He has amassed a collection of luxury watches, including a Rolex Submariner and Panerai Radiomir 1940 Blue Dial Special Edition, and also collects Casio G-Shock pieces. Quan emphasizes the importance of timing and not overpaying for watches, and his dream watch is a Patek Philippe Nautilus.

site_title: A paradigm shift in investing — are you ready?
summary: A paradigm shift in investing is underway, driven by three key changes: environmental, social, and governance (ESG) influences and investing with a stakeholder mindset, diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) as an alpha generator, and advancements in data and technology. These developments are being amplified by demographic changes, particularly among millennials and Generation Xers, who are more progressive on ESG, DEI, and stakeholder capitalism. The shift will require asset management firms to adapt and lead the way, embracing a new stakeholder paradigm that prioritizes purpose, inclusivity, and accountability.

images.alt_text: James Penny, who has been running ethically focused funds for about a decade and is currently the London-based chief investment officer at TAM Asset Management, says  several companies owned by ethically focused funds will struggle to refinance their debt, but did not name  specific firms.

site_title: We should pay less attention to Current Thing-ism
summary: Elon Musk's tweet about "The Current Thing" has gone viral, sparking a discussion about the transitory nature of moral causes and shallow allegiance. The meme, which features an NPC waving a Ukraine flag, has been embraced by some, including tech entrepreneur Marc Andreessen, who has tweeted about "The Current Thing" over 100 times. Critics argue that the phenomenon is a form of slacktivism, where individuals signal their support for a cause without taking action. Experts say that the attention economy's incentives encourage quick shifting between ideas, leading to a "zero-sum game" where attention is divided among multiple issues. The article concludes that the problem with "Current Thing-ism" is that new issues are not given time to be scrutinized and analyzed before being staked out, and that individuals should learn to slow down and think critically.

site_title: Indonesian family in exclusive due diligence to buy 22 units at Draycott Eight: sources
summary: An Indonesian family is in exclusive due diligence to buy 22 units at the Draycott Eight condominium in Singapore for nearly S$168 million, or S$2,570 per square foot. The units, which include a duplex penthouse, are fully leased and generate a 2.5% gross yield. The sale is expected to be transacted through a sale of shares in the company owning the units, avoiding additional conveyance duty. The property was developed by Wing Tai on a 99-year leasehold site and received Temporary Occupation Permit in 2005.

site_title: US says Switzerland exceeds currency thresholds, no manipulator tag
summary: The US Treasury Department announced that Switzerland continues to exceed thresholds for possible currency manipulation under the 2015 US trade law, but refrained from branding it a currency manipulator. The department will continue enhanced bilateral engagement with Switzerland to discuss options to address underlying causes of its external imbalances. Switzerland faces unique challenges, including occasional safe haven inflows, which affect its current account balance.

site_title: Kishida unveils shift in diplomacy to meet external challenges faced by Japan
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced a shift in diplomacy to address external challenges, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine and growing Chinese military activity in the East China Sea. Kishida emphasized the need for a "realistic" approach to strengthen Japan's diplomacy and security, including increasing defense spending and aid to Asian countries. He also expressed concerns over North Korea's nuclear and missile tests and called for reform of the UN Security Council to address the challenge. Japan is considering acquiring counterstrike weapons to deter potential enemies.

site_title: China will 'not hesitate to start war' over Taiwan, Beijing tells US
summary: China's Defence Minister General Wei Fenghe warned the US that Beijing will "not hesitate to start a war" if Taiwan declares independence, during a meeting with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. The warning came amid escalating tensions over democratic, self-ruled Taiwan, which China views as its territory and vows to seize by force if necessary. The US reaffirmed its commitment to peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and called on China to refrain from destabilizing actions towards Taiwan.

site_title: US to drop Covid testing for incoming international air travellers
summary: The US will drop pre-departure Covid-19 testing requirements for international air travelers effective June 12, 2022, after heavy lobbying from airlines and the travel industry. The decision was made by the Biden administration after a reassessment of the need for the requirement, which was previously in place since December. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will reassess the decision in 90 days, and the administration emphasized that they would reinstate the requirement if necessary.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust to acquire 3 logistics, industrial properties in Australia
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) is set to acquire three prime logistics and industrial properties in Victoria, Australia, for A$61 million, with a total cost of A$65.9 million including fees. The properties, fully leased to four tenants, have a total lettable area of 25,089 sq m and a weighted average lease expiry of 6.6 years. The acquisition will not impact FLCT's portfolio WALE and occupancy rate, and is funded by divestment proceeds from Cross Street Exchange in Singapore.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust seeks S$1.4m in unpaid rent from Natural Cool unit
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) is seeking over S$1.4 million in unpaid rent from its subsidiary Natural Cool Investments (NCI), which operates from a 29 Tai Seng Avenue facility. NCI has received a letter of demand from MLT's solicitors and is in discussions with MLT to resolve the matter amicably. No legal proceedings have been initiated at this stage, and NCI is seeking professional advice. MLT's units closed 1.8% lower at S$1.67 following the announcement.

site_title: Ship regulator clamps down on dirty fuel in Mediterranean
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has set a new limit of 0.1% sulfur content for marine fuel in the Mediterranean Sea, effective from spring 2025, to reduce air pollution and improve human health. This decision is part of the IMO's efforts to clean up the shipping industry, which has been criticized for its environmental impact. The new limit is expected to prevent over 1,000 premature deaths and 2,000 cases of childhood asthma annually. The rule is set to be implemented after a 12-month transition period, with sufficient fuel supply available to meet market demands, according to industry experts.

site_title: US consumer sentiment slumps to record low on inflation woes
summary: US consumer sentiment plummeted to a record low in June, falling to 50.2 from 58.4 in May, amid soaring inflation. Inflation expectations surged, with 46% attributing negative views to price pressures, and only 13% expecting income growth to surpass inflation. This decline in sentiment may lead to reduced consumer spending, potentially slowing economic growth. The data coincides with a fresh 40-year high inflation rate and adds to political challenges for President Joe Biden ahead of the midterm elections.

images.alt_text: The United States is unlikely to suffer an economic downturn, despite sky-high inflation, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said Thursday.

site_title: UN warns Sri Lanka could face 'full-blown humanitarian emergency'
summary: The UN has warned Sri Lanka is at risk of a "full-blown humanitarian emergency" due to its economic crisis, which has left millions in need of aid. The crisis, caused by months of daily blackouts, long queues for petrol, and record inflation, has already led to widespread shortages of food, fuel, and essential goods. The UN is appealing for $47 million to address the immediate needs of 1.7 million vulnerable people, as families face going without adequate food and children's education and health services are at risk.

images.alt_text: A power sector union in Sri Lanka said on Wednesday it will go on an indefinite strike from midnight in protest against new government legislation.

site_title: Median rent in Manhattan hits new high in May
summary: The median rent in Manhattan reached a new high of $4,000 in May, a 2% increase from April and 25% higher than May 2021. This surge in rent prices, driven by increased demand due to people returning to the city, high mortgage rates, and remote work, has raised concerns about affordability and potential dislocation. Experts predict that rents will continue to rise, but eventually, rates will have to stabilize or decrease to accommodate renters.

images.alt_text: More New York apartment renters are declining to renew leases as they're being presented with post-pandemic rate increases, landlord Equity Residential said.

site_title: Google hit with UK probe into suspected competition breaches
summary: The UK's antitrust watchdog, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), launched an investigation into Google's suspected anticompetitive conduct in its UK app store, alongside a study targeting Alphabet and Apple's dominance in mobile technologies. The CMA is probing restrictions on in-app payments, app stores, and browser market power. CEO Andrea Coscelli stated that the tech giants' strong grip on mobile ecosystems stifles competition and limits choice. The CMA is also examining Apple's cloud gaming and mobile browsers, with the goal of enforcing more types of intervention to promote competition.

site_title: Russia, China unveil first road bridge
summary: Russia and China unveiled the first road bridge over the Amur River, linking the Russian city of Blagoveshchensk with the Chinese city of Heihe. The 1-kilometer bridge, costing 19 billion roubles, was completed two years ago but postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic. The bridge's inauguration marked a significant step in Moscow's pivot to Asia amid its confrontation with the West. The move aims to counterbalance US global dominance, as both countries have strengthened economic cooperation over the past few decades.

site_title: Saudi cuts crude supply to some Chinese refiners in July, sources say
summary: Saudi Aramco has notified at least 5 North Asian refiners, mostly Chinese, that it will supply less than contracted volumes of crude oil in July. This move comes amid rising demand for Saudi crude in Europe, where the European Union is phasing out Russian crude, and depressed Chinese oil demand due to Covid-19 restrictions. Saudi Arabia's oil supply cuts to China follow a recent price hike and OPEC+ production increase to offset Russian output losses. The cuts are expected to keep global markets tight during peak summer demand.

site_title: BT correspondent Kelly Ng wins prize at inaugural Singapore Press Club Awards
summary: Correspondent Kelly Ng of The Business Times won the Young Journalist Award at the inaugural Singapore Press Club Awards 2022. The award recognizes journalists under 35 for their "excellent storytelling and impactful journalism that has resulted in promoting profound change". Ng expressed gratitude to her co-workers and mentors for their support, particularly for debating on issues close to their hearts.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value falls 6% to S$28.6 billion in May
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities turnover value fell 6% to S$28.6 billion in May, with a 11% drop in total market turnover volume to 31.5 billion securities. Despite this, derivatives-traded volume rose 23% year-over-year to 22.3 million contracts. The Straits Times Index gained 3.5% in the year to date, driven by reinvested dividends. NIO Inc's debut on the mainboard contributed to the highest trading activity on record for a listing by introduction.

site_title: Russian central bank cuts key rate as inflation eases
summary: Russia's central bank cut its key interest rate to 9.5% from 11% as the country's economy recovers faster than expected due to sanctions imposed over its military action in Ukraine. The rate cut is the third in two weeks, following a 3-point decrease in April. Despite the rebound of the ruble, the central bank considers the external environment challenging and constrains economic activity. The next rate review meeting is scheduled for July 22.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 ends the worst week in 1 month
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index ended its worst week in a month, falling 2.7% on Friday and 4% for the week. The decline was driven by hawkish expectations of aggressive rate hikes and concerns over the economic impact of the war in Ukraine and a zero-Covid policy in China. Investors fear a potential recession, with bank stocks suffering the most significant daily and weekly decline since March. Oil stocks posted a 0.5% weekly fall despite steady crude prices.

site_title: High inflation warrants 'resolute' ECB action, says Bundesbank
summary: The head of Germany's Bundesbank, Joachim Nagel, urged the European Central Bank to take "resolute action" to combat soaring inflation, which he forecasted to reach 7.1% in 2022, up from 3.6% in December. Nagel also predicted inflation would reach 4.5% in 2023 and 2.6% in 2024. The ECB has announced plans for interest rate hikes, with its first hike expected on July 21, to tame inflation.

site_title: Singapore’s Kacific in talks for US$1b SPAC merger, sources say
summary: Kacific Broadband Satellites, a Singapore-based satellite operator, is in advanced talks for a $1 billion merger with Pegasus Asia, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) led by CEO Neil Parekh. This would be the first blank-cheque merger in Singapore, with Kacific's valuation expected to be around $1 billion. The deal comes after months of negotiations, with Pegasus Asia securing exclusivity due to its deep-pocketed backers and Singapore location. Terms are preliminary, and talks could still break down.

images.alt_text: LITHIUM-ION battery manufacturer EoCell, an associate of Asti Holdings, has entered into a non-binding letter of intent with an unnamed publicly-traded SPAC for a potential combination.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, June 10, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 15.76 points to 1,493.95. The market saw a volume of 2.262 billion lots worth RM1.693 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 667 to 254.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as rising gas prices keep inflation high
summary: US stock indexes fell sharply at the open on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting 219.27 points or 0.68% to 32,053.52. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 opening 43.43 points or 1.08% lower at 3,974.39 and the Nasdaq Composite falling 210.34 points or 1.79% to 11,543.88. The decline came amid rising consumer prices in May, which dashed hopes that inflation is peaking and raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's aggressive steps to tame inflation.

site_title: Singapore to relax Covid curbs further, including for nightspots, migrant workers
summary: Singapore is relaxing COVID-19 curbs, including removing capacity limits for nightlife establishments with dancing starting June 14. Patrons will no longer need a negative Antigen Rapid Test result to enter these venues. However, enforcement officers will continue to conduct random checks to ensure only fully vaccinated individuals enter.

images.alt_text: Some, like Zouk, one of the country's largest, reopened, only to be shut temporarily by the authorities days later for flouting "intermingling" rules among club-goers.

site_title: Former Broadway Industrial Group CFO Tan Chee Keong jailed for insider trading
summary: Former Broadway Industrial Group CFO Tan Chee Keong has been jailed for 3 months and 2 weeks for insider trading and acquiring benefits from criminal conduct. Tan pleaded guilty to sharing insider information about Broadway shares with friends, who subsequently made profits from the trading. He also received S$30,000 from one friend and paid S$30,000 to the state as disgorgement of his share of the profits. The conviction was a result of a joint investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department of the Singapore Police Force.

images.alt_text: 2 companies that the Broadway had planned to sell its manufacturing business to have initiated arbitration after the deal fell through in July last year.

site_title: China new bank loans nearly triple in May as Beijing steps up policy support
summary: China's new bank loans nearly tripled in May, reaching 1.89 trillion yuan, as policymakers stepped up support for the slowing economy amid easing Covid-19 lockdowns. Household loans, including mortgages, rose to 288.8 billion yuan, and corporate loans surged to 1.53 trillion yuan. The central bank cut its benchmark reference rate for mortgages by a wide margin to boost the contracting housing market. Despite a jump in credit growth, analysts remain cautious due to potential virus disruptions and business impact.

images.alt_text: China’s bond traders are dumping short-term debt on concerns that easing Covid-lockdowns may boost demand for cash and lead to a liquidity crunch.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish on a down note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.29% on Friday, June 10, 2022, due to concerns over inflation and rising interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,806.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.42%. This move overshadowed gains in tech firms and slowing Chinese price growth.

site_title: Malaysia agrees to end mandatory death penalty, minister says
summary: Malaysia's cabinet has agreed to abolish the mandatory death penalty, giving judges discretion to mete out other punishments for capital crimes. The decision, made three years after a previous government made the same, will require amendments to relevant laws. Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin announced the move, stating that draft laws would be presented to Parliament for approval. The Law Minister added that further research is needed to ensure the changes align with principles of proportionality and constitutionality.

site_title: Sembmarine shareholder campaigns against merger with Keppel O&M
summary: A minority shareholder of Sembcorp Marine, Philip Loh, is urging other shareholders to vote against the company's proposed merger with Keppel O&M. Loh claims the deal is "highly disadvantageous" and points out that Sembmarine shareholders will end up with a smaller stake in the combined entity despite contributing the bulk of the assets. He also criticizes Keppel O&M for excluding certain assets from the combination and for not contributing enough cash to the combined entity. Loh argues that the merger is unfair and could set a bad precedent for the Singapore finance sector.

site_title: Philippines’ bourse shuts trading floor as punters favour digital
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange will permanently close its trading floor due to the pandemic's acceleration of "floorless trading" and a digital shift in capital markets. The exchange cited a 23.8% growth in online stock market accounts to 1.16 million in 2021, accounting for 71.5% of total accounts. This shift aims to provide a more "efficient and responsive" set-up to meet the needs of the investing public, according to bourse President Ramon Monzon.

images.alt_text: Philippines' stock exchange cancels trading on technical glitch

site_title: Even with chicken export ban, Malaysia’s F&B players struggle with shortage and higher prices
summary: Malaysia's food and beverage industry struggles with a chicken export ban, despite efforts to control prices. Labour shortages and hot weather have worsened broiler chicken production, leading to higher prices and shortages. F&B operators and wholesalers report increased costs, with some spending more to source kampung chicken from smaller farms. The government's subsidy programme for poultry farmers has seen a poor response, and the ceiling price for broiler chickens has been extended to the end of June. As a result, prices remain high, with some wholesalers paying up to RM17 per kg for broiler chickens.

images.alt_text: Chickens inside a poultry farm in Sungai Panjang, Selangor, Malaysia, on Wednesday, May 25, 2022. Malaysia will halt exports of 3.6 million chickens a month from June 1, and investigate allegations of cartel pricing, Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob said Monday. The move is likely to hit Singapore, which sources a third of its supply from Malaysia, as well as in Thailand, Brunei, Japan and Hong Kong. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
Supermarkets said that they had not seen any spike in consumer demand that might have been fuelled by shortage fears, and are supplementing supplies with frozen chicken.

site_title: Philippines’ Globe Telecom seeking  US$1.5b for Towers
summary: Globe Telecom is considering selling around half of its 6,000 telecommunications towers in a deal worth up to US$1.5 billion. The company, which has 87.4 million mobile subscribers, is weighing the sale with its adviser to gauge interest from potential bidders. This comes after its rival PLDT sold its towers for US$1.5 billion in April. The decision is part of Globe Telecom's efforts to divest its tower assets, which have become increasingly attractive for deal activity in the region.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 and T2's southern wing will reopen in September and October, respectively, to meet pre-Covid-19 passenger traffic. SportSG will take over the Singapore Sports Hub's ownership from December 9, terminating the public-private partnership. The government will spend S$3.8 billion on ICT procurement this year, with 80% of contracts open to small and medium-sized enterprises. Climate tech startups are experiencing a surge in customers, but funding is slow to materialize. Eat Just's cultivated meat division broke ground on a S$61 million facility in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week in red; STI down 0.9% on Friday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.9% on Friday, closing at 3,181.73, marking the third consecutive day of declines and a 1.6% weekly loss. Shares of Jardine Matheson led the decline, while Hongkong Land rose 1.6%. In other markets, South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong, and Australia fell between 0.3 and 1.5% on Friday, while China stocks rose 1.4% following benign inflation data.

images.alt_text: China's factory-gate inflation dropped to its lowest in a year in May, official data showed Friday (Jun 10), while consumer prices were stable despite Covid-linked transport disruptions.

Asia extended losses across world markets on Friday after the European Central Bank laid the groundwork to join others in a programme of interest rate hikes, while attention turns to the release of key US inflation data.

site_title: Sports Hub to come under SportSG from Dec 9 after stat board terminates deal with consortium that runs the facilities
summary: Singapore's Sports Hub will be taken over by SportSG on December 9, marking the end of a public-private partnership (PPP) with consortium SportsHub Pte Ltd. The move comes after SportSG reached a "mutual agreement" with SHPL to terminate the partnership without penalty. The government will pay SHPL an amount comprising the outstanding loan for construction and a fair market value of the property. SportSG plans to integrate the Sports Hub with the Kallang Alive master plan, support Healthier SG, and hold community programs, including the National School Games.

images.alt_text: Singapore Sports Hub CEO Lionel Yeo
Sports Hub ready to stage much larger events, but only if it makes economic sense: CEO

site_title: Changi Airport T4 and T2’s Departure Hall to reopen in coming months
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 (T4) and Terminal 2 (T2) will reopen in the coming months. T4 will reopen for both departure and arrival flights in September, while T2 will commence departure operations in the southern wing in October, coinciding with the Northern Winter Season. New stores, including The Shilla Duty Free and Lotte Duty Free, will open in T2's arrival hall in August and September, and a cluster of food and beverage outlets will open in October. The airport's passenger traffic has recovered strongly, with volumes reaching 48% of pre-Covid-19 levels in June, and the International Air Transport Association forecasts that air travel may recover to pre-Covid levels by the end of next year.

images.alt_text: T2 terminal to reopen in phases from this year as Changi Airport expects more travellers

site_title: Striking South Korean truckers target chips, put brakes on port activity
summary: South Korean truckers, protesting soaring fuel costs, have launched a broader and more aggressive strike, halting deliveries of raw materials for semiconductors and petrochemical products. The strike, which began on June 7, has disrupted shipments for companies like Hyundai Motor and Posco, and slowed container traffic at ports to a third of normal levels. The strike, involving about 35% of truck drivers, aims to secure pay increases and an extension of an emergency measure guaranteeing freight rates. The government has taken a neutral stance, and negotiations between the union and government have yet to yield an agreement.

site_title: China set to put tycoon seized in Hong Kong on trial: WSJ
summary: Chinese-Canadian tycoon Xiao Jianhua is set to go on trial in Shanghai for allegedly collecting public deposits illegally. Prosecutors plan to charge him with this offense, which could result in jail terms of less than 3 years to over a decade. Xiao has been missing since 2017 when he was taken from his Hong Kong hotel room. His business empire was significantly reduced after the Chinese government took control of several financial firms linked to him. His family has expressed faith in the Chinese government and law.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio to make self-developed battery packs from 2024
summary: Chinese EV maker Nio plans to start producing self-developed 800-volt battery packs in the second half of 2024, aiming to improve profitability and competitiveness against rivals like Tesla. Nio's chairman William Li also announced plans to use a combination of self-produced and externally sourced batteries in the long run. The company's new mass-market models, expected to be priced around $200,000-$300,000, will utilize the self-produced battery packs. Nio's net loss narrowed to 1.8 billion yuan in the first quarter, but the company forecasts deliveries of 23,000-25,000 vehicles in the upcoming quarter.

site_title: Amazon plans to pull out of US$7.7b race for India cricket streaming rights: sources
summary: Amazon is planning to withdraw from the bidding for Indian Premier League (IPL) cricket streaming rights, estimated to be worth US$7.7 billion, due to concerns about a potential bidding war. The US giant has already invested over US$6 billion in the country, but deemed further spending on online streaming rights as not making business sense. This move leaves the field open to rivals including Reliance Industries, Walt Disney, and Sony Group, which could bolster their positions in the Indian market.

images.alt_text: Disney+ launched its streaming service in the Middle East and North Africa on Wednesday, vying for market share in a region where the population is young but few people so far use such services.
Amazon.com is shuttering its gig economy delivery service in Germany.
Amazon.com shares rose on Monday, in the first trading session following a 20-for-1 stock split, the e-commerce company's first such move in more than 2 decades.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower ahead of key US data
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Friday, June 10, 2022, losing 1.49% or 422.24 points to 27,824.29, after US equities sank overnight due to soaring US consumer prices and inflation concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.32% or 25.96 points to 1,943.09. Investors await key US inflation data and track global sell-offs amid rate fears.

images.alt_text: Asia extended losses across world markets on Friday after the European Central Bank laid the groundwork to join others in a programme of interest rate hikes, while attention turns to the release of key US inflation data.

site_title: The highs and lows of the Sports Hub
summary: The Singapore Sports Hub, a S$1.33 billion facility, will be owned and managed by government agency Sport Singapore from Dec 9, 2022. The hub, which opened in 2014, has experienced highs and lows, including issues with the National Stadium pitch, sound systems, and leaks. Despite these challenges, the hub has hosted various international events, including the SEA Games and the Ultimate Fighting Championship. The change in ownership marks a new era for the Sports Hub, as Sport Singapore takes over from the consortium that ran the facility.

site_title: Chinese traders, warehouses probed for aluminium fraud
summary: An investigation into aluminium stock fraud in China has expanded to three Shanghai-based companies, Shanghai Juyi International Trade, Shanghai Haishirong Industrial, and Shanghai Ruiguang International Trade, suspected of repeatedly pledging aluminium stocks as collateral. This practice is considered fraud, potentially leaving multiple creditors holding claims to the same asset. The case has involved over 20 companies and delivery warehouses worth billions of yuan, sparking a decline in spot aluminium prices before they steadied. Authorities have sealed off implicated warehouses and some firms are taking metals from them.

site_title: Indonesia eases export rules further to 'flush out' palm oil stocks
summary: Indonesia has further eased export rules for palm oil, allowing more companies to ship the commodity and reducing inventories. The country had previously imposed a 3-week ban to boost cooking oil stocks and control prices. Now, companies that had not joined a government bulk cooking oil distribution program can export palm oil, paying a $200 per tonne charge. The government aims to export at least 1 million tonnes of palm oil products by July 31 under a new "acceleration program".

images.alt_text: CPO stocks in the region enjoyed higher average selling prices and stronger demand for the commodity.
A worker loads freshly harvested palm fruits on a truck at a palm oil plantation in North Sumatra, Indonesia. In May, a month-long ban on crude palm oil exports was lifted as prices stabilised.

site_title: Rolex worn during WWII 'Great Escape' sells for US$189,000 in New York
summary: A Rolex watch worn by a British prisoner during the 1944 "Great Escape" from Nazi Stalag Luft III concentration camp sold for US$189,000 at an auction in New York. The watch, worn by Gerald Imeson, helped calculate escape time and guard patrol schedules. Imeson ordered the watch from Rolex in Switzerland and received it via the Red Cross. The watch was sold along with other items, including a Royal Air Force whistle and a membership card, to an anonymous buyer. The sale was less than expected, but still a significant find for the auction house.

site_title: SEC investigating UST stablecoin blowup in fresh threat to Terra: source
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating whether Terraform Labs, the firm behind the TerraUSD stablecoin, broke federal investor-protection regulations in marketing the coin before its collapse. The SEC is examining whether the stablecoin's algorithmic mechanism and trading incentives constituted securities and investment products. The investigation may pressure Terraform and its CEO Do Kwon, who are already facing scrutiny for offering the Mirror Protocol. The collapse of TerraUSD sent shockwaves across crypto markets, wiping out tens of billions of dollars in value.

images.alt_text: The stablecoin market shrank between end-March and end-May, largely due to the collapse of algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD, said Fitch Ratings in a report on Tuesday (Jun 7).

THE ongoing cryptocurrency rout, triggered in part by the collapse of popular stablecoin TerraUSD, has sent regulators around the world scrambling to strengthen investor protection.

site_title: Eat Just’s cultivated meat division breaks ground for S$61m facility in Singapore
summary: Eat Just's cultivated meat division, Good Meat, broke ground for a S$61 million facility in Singapore, the largest cultivated meat facility in Asia. The 30,000 square-foot facility will produce "tens of thousands of pounds" of lab-grown meat per year and is expected to open in Q1 2023. The facility will house a 6000-litre bioreactor, the largest in the industry, and is seen as a significant step towards making meat using sustainable approaches, with potential to produce other types of protein such as beef and pork.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest weekly drop in 2 years amid broad sell-off
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index ended the week at 6,932.0, marking its biggest weekly drop in 2 years, with a 4.2% decline. Global equities sell-off was attributed to weak commodity prices and investors' anticipation of US inflation data. Key sectors, including gold, mining, and financials, suffered losses. If US inflation numbers are high, market pain could persist, according to an analyst.

site_title: Japan voices concern over sharp yen fall in rare government, central bank statement
summary: Japan's government and central bank jointly expressed concern over the recent sharp falls in the yen, citing moves that are "unusual" and "unstable." The Bank of Japan's counterpart, Masato Kanda, hinted that Tokyo may intervene in the market to stabilize the currency, which has reached near 20-year lows. The joint statement comes as Japan escalates its warnings against the yen's decline, with the government vowing to take "appropriate action" as needed to address the issue.

site_title: BOE says UK’s biggest banks are no longer too big to fail
summary: The Bank of England has concluded that the UK's biggest banks are no longer too big to fail, following a review of their emergency planning. The review found that the banks' systems for critical functions can avert the need for a public bailout in the event of a crisis. The assessment, which was initially delayed due to the COVID-19 outbreak, found that the resolution regime "successfully reduces risks to depositors and the financial system." The report's findings are seen as a positive step towards reducing the risk of a repeat of the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Shanghai returns to lockdowns for mass testing amid Covid fears
summary: Shanghai will briefly lock down almost everyone in the city this weekend for mass testing amid rising Covid-19 cases, causing disruption and triggering a renewed run on groceries. The lockdown, which affects 25 million residents, follows a two-month shutdown in late March and is part of China's Covid Zero strategy. The move aims to root out silent transmission of the virus, reflecting ongoing concerns about the city's Covid situation.

images.alt_text: Shanghai's mini-lockdown is raising concerns that the city’s reopening is backsliding as officials fear a rebound in cases.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tumble ahead of US CPI data
summary: South Korean stocks tumbled on Friday, falling for a fourth consecutive session and posting their worst weekly performance in nearly 5 months, due to inflation concerns ahead of the US CPI data. The benchmark Kospi ended down 29.57 points, or 1.13%, at 2,595.87. The Korean won also dropped, ending the week with its worst performance in 10 months, while the benchmark bond yield rose.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended slightly lower by 0.71 point, or 0.03 per cent, at 2,625.44, after falling as much as 0.74 per cent to hit the lowest intraday level in 2 weeks.

site_title: Hiring crunch prompts UK companies to rethink expansion plans
summary: UK companies are scaling back expansion plans due to chronic labour shortages, with job vacancies and placements slowing in May. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation and KPMG report found the downturn in candidate supply eased only slightly, with recruiters citing reluctance to apply due to economic uncertainty. Starting-salary inflation remains close to record highs, raising concerns about inflation at the Bank of England. The report warns of a potential cost to the economy in unrealised potential, as employers struggle to hire despite offering bumper pay increases.

images.alt_text: A fall in the prices of a few key global commodity indicators has raised hopes that the world economy may have reached peak inflation.

site_title: Japan's May wholesale price rise slows as fuel spike moderates
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 9.1% in May from a year earlier, slowing from the previous month's increase, as fuel costs moderated. The yen's decline pushed up raw material costs, with import prices spiking 43.3% in May. This followed a 9.8% increase in April. Core consumer prices rose 2.1% in April, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the first time in 7 years, as companies gradually pass on higher costs to households.

site_title: Japan business community seeks further relaxation of border controls
summary: Japan's business community has issued a joint statement urging further relaxation of border controls, seeking to facilitate free movement of people, goods, and digital technologies. The country begins a gradual easing of Covid-19 travel restrictions, with tourists allowed in packaged tours accompanied by guides. The statement, signed by US and European business lobbies, advocates for restoring visa waiver eligibility for Japan's Groups of Seven trading partners and lifting daily caps on international arrivals.

site_title: Tesla cancels 3 June online hiring events for China
summary: Tesla has cancelled three online recruitment events for China scheduled for June 16, 23, and 30, amid concerns of being "overstaffed" in some areas. The decision comes after CEO Elon Musk threatened job cuts in an email. However, Musk did not comment specifically on staffing in China, which produces over half of the company's vehicles and a quarter of its revenue. The company still allows resume submissions for over 1,000 openings, and hourly headcount is expected to increase despite a reduction in salaried headcount.

images.alt_text: Tesla vehicles waiting for shipping transport in Shanghai; the carmaker's factory there produced 33,544 vehicles in May, up 212 per cent from April.

site_title: Asia: Markets track global sell-off on inflation, rate fears
summary: Asia markets extended losses on Friday as investors tracked global sell-offs due to inflation and interest rate fears. The European Central Bank's move to end its bond-buying program and signal interest rate hikes prompted selling, with the ECB also sharply upgrading its inflation forecasts. US consumer price data later in the day is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's decisions, with a strong reading likely to prompt aggressive rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong dropped, even as tech firms continued to benefit from hopes that China’s crackdown was almost over.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open, before US inflation data
summary: European stocks dropped at the open on Friday, June 10, following losses in Tokyo, ahead of US inflation data that may influence interest rate hikes. The FTSE 100 in London fell 0.5%, the DAX in Frankfurt dropped 0.7%, and the CAC 40 in Paris lost 0.7%. The European Central Bank plans to raise interest rates next month to combat high inflation, with economists warning of a possible recession if inflation surges.

site_title: Japan repeats warning on sliding yen, keeps mum on FX intervention chance
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned against rapid fluctuations in the yen, keeping mum on potential government intervention, as the currency hit a 20-year low against the dollar and a 7-year low against the euro. The weak yen trend has boosted imported commodities and living costs in resource-deficient Japan, with the yen losing over 14% against the dollar this year. Authorities are watching currency market movements with urgency, but there's no clear consensus on the trigger point for intervention, with some analysts citing 125 yen to the dollar as a possible threshold.

images.alt_text: The euro hit a seven-year peak against the yen on Wednesday, getting a lift after an upward revision to first quarter growth and ahead of a European Central Bank meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Millennials far more likely to quit jobs than Gen Z, bosses say
summary: Millennials are more likely to quit their jobs than Gen Z, according to a survey of 72 executives whose firms employ about 400,000 staff. Two-thirds of bosses say millennials have the highest churn rate, while a third say Gen Z staff are the most likely to depart. The main reasons cited for departures are a lack of appreciation, desire for more flexibility, and frustration with career progression. This trend is partly driven by the pandemic, which has made workers feel that life is too short to stay in unsatisfying jobs.

site_title: Oil’s inflation-inducing rally could get supercharged with  demand rebound
summary: China, the world's largest crude importer, is expected to see a 12% jump in consumption in the third quarter, driven by easing Covid restrictions and government stimulus, potentially supercharging oil's inflation-inducing rally. This could boost demand by 1.6 million barrels a day, with annual growth expected to be 5%. However, some analysts, such as Goldman Sachs, remain cautious due to rolling lockdowns, while others predict a quick rebound. The increased demand, combined with a drop in Russian output, has led to a raised Brent price forecast for the latter half of 2022 and the first half of 2023.

site_title: Oversupply, weak China demand depress Asia naphtha margins to 2008 lows
summary: Asian naphtha margins have hit 2008 lows due to an oversupply and weak demand, primarily from China, which is the world's largest petrochemical consumer. Refiners in the region have boosted output of more lucrative products like petrol and diesel, leading to increased naphtha production. China's economic slowdown has reduced demand for naphtha, causing margins to drop by over 201% since May, with Asian naphtha margins trading at a discount of $84.23 per tonne to Brent crude.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped on Thursday but still hovered near 3-month highs after parts of Shanghai imposed new Covid-19 lockdown measures, as strong gains in refined products contributed to an ongoing bullish backdrop for crude oil.

site_title: Top Toyota supplier Denso mulls 420b yen chip unit spinoff
summary: Denso, a top Toyota supplier and world's second-biggest auto-parts maker, is considering spinning off its automotive chip business, generating around 420 billion yen in sales. The company's CTO, Yoshifumi Kato, mentioned the possibility of selling semiconductors externally, but no decision has been made. Denso's focus remains on meeting internal chip demand, and the company is not considering using a potential spin-off to raise funds for other investments. Demand for automotive semiconductors is expected to continue growing amid the industry's shift to electric and autonomous cars.

images.alt_text: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) chief executive officer Lisa Su on Thursday flagged a slowdown in personal computers (PC) this year after 2 years of a "very strong PC market".

site_title: Hong Kong must reopen globally to keep hub status, Lam says
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam stated that the city cannot function as a global financial hub if quarantine controls remain, adding pressure on the next administration to relax border curbs. She emphasized that if Hong Kong cannot travel freely to other places and into the mainland, it cannot be considered a hub. This suggests that easing border curbs could bolster Hong Kong's international reputation and is being considered by the next administration.

images.alt_text: Carrie Lam's 5-year tenure as Chief Executive coincided with massive and often violent pro-democracy protests, Beijing's imposition of a draconian national security law and a coronavirus outbreak that left more than 9,000 dead.

site_title: Climate tech startups report flood of customers, but funding is trickling in
summary: Climate tech startups are experiencing a surge in demand, with companies like Green Koncepts and Terrascope seeing a significant increase in enquiries and revenue. However, funding for these startups remains relatively weak in South-east Asia, with smaller cheque sizes compared to other regions. This is attributed to the lack of strong climate tech startups in the region, with many innovations coming from the US. Despite this, venture capital firms like Wavemaker Impact are targeting the region, focusing on startups that can generate revenue and remove significant carbon emissions. The region's economies are prioritizing climate issues, with Indonesia and Vietnam making net-zero pledges, presenting opportunities for climate tech startups willing to move early.

site_title: US Capitol riot probe puts Trump at heart of 'attempted coup'
summary: A US congressional panel investigating the 2021 Capitol riot has concluded that former President Donald Trump was at the center of an "attempted coup" to overturn the 2020 presidential election. The panel's findings, presented in a series of hearings, suggest that Trump's claims of a stolen election were a key factor in the violence. The investigation, which has gathered testimony from Trump's advisors and witnesses, aims to demonstrate that Trump's actions were part of a broader effort to cling to power and undermine the US democracy.

images.alt_text: Few American voters are going to support the Republican Party as a way to help heal Trump's injured pride.

site_title: Seoul police probe allegation of embezzlement by Terraform staff
summary: Seoul police are investigating an allegation of embezzlement by Terraform Labs staff, the company behind the collapsed TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin. The probe centers on a "suspicious" crypto wallet allegedly used to embezzle Bitcoin to defend the token's dollar peg. The allegedly embezzled Bitcoin belonged to Luna Foundation Guard, which had amassed $3.5 billion in crypto reserves. The collapse of TerraUSD and its sister coin Luna wiped out $40 billion in market value, sparking efforts to regulate stablecoins globally. The investigation is ongoing, with no clear amount of Bitcoin possibly stolen.

site_title: Asteroid samples contain 'clues to origin of life': Japan scientists
summary: Scientists studying asteroid Ryugu samples found organic material that may have formed building blocks of life in space. The pristine material, collected in 2020, contains dust and dark rocks from the 300 million-kilometer asteroid. Researchers are analyzing small portions of the 5.4g sample, which may hold clues to the origin of life on Earth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following falls on Wall Street, with investors cautious ahead of US inflation data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.03% and the Topix index fell 1.01%. This decline tracks global market trends and investor sentiment ahead of key economic data releases.

site_title: South Korea April current account logs first deficit in 2 years
summary: South Korea's current account balance became a deficit in April for the first time in 2 years, with a US$0.08 billion shortfall. The trade surplus shrank to US$2.95 billion from US$5.64 billion in March, while dividend income turned to a US$3.82 billion deficit. For the January-April period, the current account balance stood at a US$15.31 billion surplus, down from US$22.52 billion in the same period last year.

site_title: China factory inflation eases to lowest in a year
summary: China's factory-gate inflation eased to its lowest in a year in May, with the producer price index (PPI) rising 6.4% on-year. Consumer prices remained stable, despite Covid-linked transport disruptions, at 2.1% on-year. International crude oil prices contributed to higher costs in related industries, but overall supply chains remained stable. This easing of inflation is attributed to the efficient coordination of epidemic prevention and control measures.

site_title: 'Nothing to suggest' US will have a recession: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated there's "nothing to suggest" the US will experience a recession, despite high inflation and supply chain issues. The economy has recovered from Covid-19 damage, and Yellen expressed confidence in a "soft landing" through the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Analysts expect a modest slowdown in inflation, and Fed Chair Jerome Powell has said the economy is strong enough to weather higher borrowing costs, further easing recession fears.

site_title: Government to spend S$3.8b in ICT in FY2022; 80% of contracts open to SMEs
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to spend S$3.8 billion on infocommunications technology (ICT) procurement in FY2022, with 80% of contracts open to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The majority of the spending, S$2.6 billion, will go towards application development and upgrading existing systems. The government aims to increase its use of emerging technologies and cloud computing, with a goal of having 70% of eligible systems on the cloud by 2023. This will involve collaborations with industry partners and the use of the Singapore Government Technology Stack (SGTS) to streamline development.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS prefers Sea compared to Grab amid market share competition
summary: DBS Group Research analyst Sachin Mittal has upgraded his rating on Sea to "buy" and revised the target price to $126, citing the company's clearer path to profitability, particularly in its e-commerce and fintech businesses. Sea is expected to turn positive in Ebitda by 2024, while Grab's adjusted Ebitda is predicted to turn positive by 2025. Mittal attributes Sea's improved e-commerce Ebitda margins to lower incentives and expects the company's Ebitda to reach $8.6 billion by 2027.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares kick off day with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.58% on Friday, June 10, 2022, following a global sell-off sparked by the European Central Bank's dim outlook for the region's economy. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,522.50, while China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Traders await a key US consumer prices reading.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% or 20.18 points to 3,189.44, following a decline on Wall Street ahead of a key inflation report. The decline was attributed to losses in local banks and a few heavily traded securities, including Yangzijiang Financial Holding and MarcoPolo Marine. The US stock market also sank, with the Dow shedding over 600 points, and European shares hit 2-week lows after the ECB raised interest rate hike expectations.

site_title: After veto on North Korea, China says 'let's see' on UN action over a nuclear test
summary: China's UN envoy, Ambassador Zhang Jun, stated that Beijing doesn't want to see North Korea carry out a new nuclear test, but warned against making presumptions on Beijing's reaction if such a test occurs. China vetoed a US-led bid to impose new UN sanctions on North Korea, citing concerns over humanitarian grounds and a desire to ease sanctions through dialogue. Zhang emphasized that sanctions don't solve problems and urged the US to engage in talks with North Korea without preconditions. China remains committed to denuclearization, but is open to dialogue with North Korea.

images.alt_text: China and Russia vetoed on Thursday a US-led push to impose more United Nations sanctions on North Korea over its renewed ballistic missile launches, publicly splitting the UN Security Council for the first time since it started punishing Pyongyang in 2006.

site_title: Australia's A$5b Snowy hydro project faces delay to 2028
summary: Australia's A$5 billion Snowy Hydro project, a massive energy storage project, faces a delay of up to 19 months, pushing its start-up to 2028. The project, built by Italy's Webuild, aims to add 2,000 megawatts of capacity to replace coal-fired power stations set to close by 2028. The expansion is crucial for Australia's power market, which will need the project's supply to meet energy demand.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was in Indonesia on Monday to meet its President Joko Widodo and shore-up relations between the 2 neighbours, in his first bilateral visit since being elected last month.

site_title: Nasa to form scientific team to study UFOs
summary: NASA plans to form a scientific team to study "unidentified aerial phenomena" (UAPs), commonly referred to as UFOs. The team, led by David Spergel, will examine existing data and develop a public report on its findings after a 9-month study. The effort, costing between $50,000 to $100,000, aims to advance scientific understanding of UAPs and their potential impact on national security and air safety. The announcement follows a 2021 report by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which found that UAPs remain unexplained and pose a national security issue.

images.alt_text: SpaceX Starlink 5 satellites are pictured in the sky seen from Svendborg on South Funen, Denmark, April 21, 2020.

site_title: Disney+ takes on rivals in Middle East streaming market
summary: Disney+ launched its streaming service in 16 Arab countries, vying for market share in the Middle East and North Africa. The service offers Arabic subtitles on popular content and aims to compete with Netflix, which leads the region with over 6.8 million subscribers. Disney+ director Tamim Fares sees the region as an opportunity for growth, with forecasts predicting Netflix will reach 11 million subscribers by 2027 and Disney+ will take the second spot with nearly 6.5 million.

images.alt_text: Peter Rice, 55, was chairman of general entertainment content and oversaw a vast swath of shows carried across Disney networks, including ABC and the Disney Channel.

site_title: Apollo among possible suitors for Just Eat's Grubhub: sources
summary: Apollo Global Management is reportedly considering a bid for Just Eat's US unit Grubhub, joining other private equity firms in preliminary interest. The valuation is uncertain, with some suitors considering offers near $1 billion, significantly lower than the $7.3 billion paid for Grubhub last year. This comes as Just Eat Takeaway's shares have dropped 74% in the past year due to growth slowdown and economic concerns. The company has also faced internal turmoil, with a chairman stepping down and an investigation into the chief operating officer's conduct.

site_title: Virgin Australia mulls IPO in 2023 in fast rebound from collapse
summary: Virgin Australia is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in 2023, a year ahead of expectations, following its rapid recovery from collapse at the start of the pandemic. The airline, now owned by Bain Capital, reported profitability in April and is in discussions about listing on the Sydney Stock Exchange. This move comes as air passenger traffic in Australia approaches pre-Covid levels, according to the competition regulator.

site_title: AMD flags slow market for PCs in 2022
summary: AMD's CEO Lisa Su flags a slowdown in the PC market in 2022 after two years of strong sales, citing market saturation and inflation concerns. Despite this, AMD sees growth in cloud computing, data centre chips, and AI applications. The company expects a gross margin of over 57% and an operating margin of mid-30s in the near future, surpassing previous estimates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 13.29 points or 0.9% to 1,496.42. Volume was 341.3 million lots worth RM226.9 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 416 to 98, marking a negative start to the day.

site_title: Gold eases as higher yields weigh before US inflation data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,846.22 per ounce, heading for a weekly decline, as Treasury yields rose and investors awaited US inflation data for cues on monetary policy. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields increased, reducing demand for zero-yield gold. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates, potentially impacting gold prices, which are often seen as an inflation hedge.

images.alt_text: Gold inched lower on Thursday, with prices restrained by rising Treasury yields ahead of key US jobs and inflation data this week.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut Top Glove target prices after earnings disappoint
summary: Analysts have cut their target prices for Top Glove after the company reported a 99.3% drop in third-quarter net profit to RM15.3 million, missing expectations due to normalization in demand and rising cost pressures. UOB Kay Hian lowered its target price to RM1.15 from RM1.50, while CGS-CIMB trimmed its target price to RM1 from RM1.30, implying a potential downside of 10.7%. The analysts differ on whether incoming headwinds have been priced in, with UOB Kay Hian believing much of the downside has been accounted for and CGS-CIMB seeing further potential for decline.

images.alt_text: Top Glove cited factors such as rising production costs and higher natural gas and electricity tarriffs that have compressed its margins.

site_title: Expected Xi visit to Hong Kong boosts optimism in city's stocks
summary: Hong Kong's stocks are rebounding at the fastest pace in the world, with a possible visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping in a few weeks potentially boosting buying momentum. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index has gained 15% since a mid-May low, outperforming major benchmarks globally. Xi's visit, which has not been confirmed, may indicate central government support for Hong Kong, boosting investor optimism and government policies. The city's economy is showing signs of improvement, with a better outlook for the tech industry and easing Covid Zero measures.

summary: Australian shares are set to record their worst week in over 1-1/2 years, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.9% at 6,959.90, following the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-decade-high interest rate hike to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.9 per cent at 7,058.80 by 0039 GMT on Thursday..

site_title: Online US inflation slows again, but groceries rise most of all
summary: US online inflation slowed to 2% in May, down from 2.9% in April and 3.6% in March, according to Adobe. Grocery prices surged 11.7% from a year ago, the most on record, while 10 of 18 tracked categories saw price drops, indicating reduced discretionary spending. Despite this, overall demand remains strong as consumers dip into savings and load up on credit cards.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit acquires shopping centre in Pennsylvania for US$85.7 million
summary: United Hampshire US Reit acquired a grocery-anchored shopping centre in Pennsylvania for US$85.7 million, expanding its Eastern seaboard footprint. The 400,674 sq ft Upland Square has a 100% committed occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 6.3 years. summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust has divested a 4-storey data centre in Michigan, US, for US$10 million, its manager stated in a bourse filing. site_title: From the curry puff to the digital and green transitions: Portugal is reshaping globalisation
summary: Portugal is reshaping globalization by strengthening its position as a main innovation hub and top investment destination. The country is driving the green and digital transitions, with a focus on sustainability and digital transformation. Portugal's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic has been consistent above the Eurozone average, and the country is consolidating a knowledge-based economy within the EU's single market. Lisbon will host the Web Summit and the United Nations Ocean Conference, solidifying its role in global innovation and ocean governance. Portugal aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and is investing in green energy, with a goal of 62% of electricity from renewables.

site_title: Alibaba slips as big hopes on Ant IPO revival quickly fade

Analysts say the setback may not deter investors, who are optimistic about a potential turnaround in the China tech sector, with some strategists citing cheap valuations and a more supportive regulatory environment.

site_title: Philippine Chamber of Commerce set up to advance business ties
summary: The Philippine Chamber of Commerce in Singapore (PhilChamSG) was registered on April 29, 2022, aiming to promote stronger economic and people-to-people relations between the Philippines and Singapore. Founded by Cristy Mendoza Vicentina, the chamber seeks to welcome individuals and corporations doing business between the two countries, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises. The establishment has been welcomed by the Philippine Ambassador to Singapore, Joseph del Mar Yap, who expects the chamber to boost bilateral business ties, particularly in trade and tourism.

site_title: Disney's embattled CEO flexes muscle with firing of TV chief
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek fired chairman of general entertainment content Peter Rice, citing lack of teamwork. Rice, 55, was overseeing shows on ABC and Disney Channel after 21st Century Fox acquisition in 2019. Chapek replaced Rice with Dana Walden, another Fox alum. The move follows a tumultuous year for Chapek, including a dispute with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis. Disney shares have fallen 33% this year due to streaming losses.
