site_title: Oil slips on China lockdowns, but bullish trends intact
summary: Oil prices slipped on Thursday, falling 0.4-0.5% to near 3-month highs, despite parts of Shanghai imposing new Covid-19 lockdown measures. Brent crude futures settled at $123.07 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $121.51 a barrel. Strong gains in refined products and tight refining supply contributed to the ongoing bullish backdrop for crude oil. site_title: US: Stocks sink ahead of key inflation report
summary: US stocks sank on Thursday, with the Dow shedding over 600 points ahead of the Labor Department's consumer price index report for May. The European Central Bank joined the Federal Reserve in ending its bond-buying stimulus and hiking interest rates to combat inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.9%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 2.4% and 2.8%, respectively.

site_title: Meta unfriends FB ticker in final farewell to Facebook era
summary: Meta, the social media giant, is shedding its old corporate avatar as it begins trading under the ticker symbol 'META'. After a decade of trading as Facebook, the company rebranded in October 2021, betting on the metaverse. Meta shares have fallen 42% this year due to criticism from lawmakers and regulators. Meta's co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg established Facebook in 2004, which expanded to include Instagram and Whatsapp. The company is pouring billions into the metaverse, a shared virtual realm.

images.alt_text: Meta has paused development of its dual-camera smartwatch, with the internal code name Milan.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide 1% after ECB signals rates lift-off
summary: European shares plummeted 1% on Thursday after the European Central Bank (ECB) signaled a higher interest rate hike in September, citing a higher inflation forecast and reduced economic growth expectations. The ECB raised its inflation forecast to 6.8% for the year and cut its growth forecast to 2.8%. This led to a 1.6% drop in the Stoxx euro zone stocks index and 1% losses across major European bourses.

images.alt_text: EUROZONE stock markets fell at the open on Thursday (Jun 9) with all eyes on the outcome of the European Central Bank's (ECB) latest monetary policy meeting.

site_title: IAEA warns of 'fatal blow' to nuclear deal as Iran removes its cameras
summary: Iran has removed essentially all International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) monitoring equipment installed under the 2015 nuclear deal, a move described by IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi as a "fatal blow" to reviving the deal. Iran had warned of retaliation if the IAEA's Board of Governors passed a resolution criticizing Tehran's continued failure to explain uranium traces found at undeclared sites. The move leaves a 3-4 week window to restore monitoring equipment or risk losing the ability to piece together Iran's most important nuclear activities.

site_title: Zilingo board approves debt repayment to creditors: sources
summary: Zilingo's board has authorized the repayment of $40 million in debt to creditors, following weeks of uncertainty after the ouster of CEO Ankiti Bose. The move is seen as a step to stave off a liquidity crisis, with the company facing money-losing operations and limited access to fresh capital. The repayment is a result of negotiations between Kapoor and creditors, who had proposed liquidation but are now considering other options. The company's future remains uncertain, with key investors and top management debating the best course of action.

site_title: Philippine-Singapore ties to grow stronger under new president

site_title: Coinbase retracted job offers to recruits from some of Wall Street's biggest banks
summary: Coinbase Global rescinded employment offers to at least 300 individuals from 10 major financial firms, including Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and BlackRock, who had left Wall Street to join the company. The move, citing market conditions and business prioritization efforts, comes as the company's shares have plummeted by over 70% since its 2021 IPO. The affected individuals were part of a talent hub created by Coinbase to support those who left Wall Street to join the company.

site_title: US approves US$120m sale to maintain Taiwanese warships
summary: The US has approved a possible $120 million sale of parts to help Taiwan maintain its warships, which will enhance its combat readiness in the face of China's frequent activities near the island. The sale covers unclassified spare and repair parts, logistical technical assistance, and US government support. Taiwan's defence ministry said the deal will come into effect within a month and expressed gratitude to Washington for its support. The sale is part of the US's efforts to provide Taiwan with means to defend itself amid China's increasing military presence.

images.alt_text: The announcement follows the administration’s efforts to build an Asia-Pacific economic bloc, known as the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework, that includes 13 countries and excludes Taiwan.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on inflation, rate hike angst
summary: US stocks opened lower on June 9, 2022, due to rising bond yields and concerns over inflation and interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones fell 82.28 points, or 0.25%, to 32,828.62, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 14.12 and 69.80 points, respectively, or 0.34% and 0.58%. The decline was attributed to pressure on technology and growth stocks, as well as sapped risk appetite.

site_title: Empowering corporate boards
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of empowering corporate boards to effectively monitor and create value for stakeholders. Recent reforms aim to restore trust in governance by increasing board independence and diversity. The Code of Corporate Governance now requires boards to have at least one-third independent directors, and IDs serving beyond nine years must seek approval. Empowered boards can balance oversight and value creation, and effective collaboration with management is enabled through diversity. The article highlights the growing importance of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, and boards must undergo training on sustainability and navigate the digital revolution to create value for stakeholders.

site_title: PGA Tour suspends players in Saudi-backed league including Mickelson, Dustin Johnson
summary: The PGA Tour has suspended 17 golfers, including Phil Mickelson and Dustin Johnson, for participating in the Saudi-backed LIV Golf league. The suspension comes after the golfers chose to join the league for financial reasons, despite the PGA Tour's stance against it. The suspension affects players' ability to compete in PGA Tour tournaments, while the LIV Golf league offers significant purses and a $50 million prize for the season's final event. The move is seen as a hard-line stance against players who choose to join the breakaway league.

site_title: China's Xi urges efforts to balance Covid Zero with the economy
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged his government to maintain the Covid Zero policy while striking a balance with the economy, amid growing concerns over the policy's impact on economic growth. Xi emphasized the need for stability, as China's economy is expected to miss its 5.5% growth target this year due to virus curbs. The call comes as Xi seeks to secure an unprecedented third term in power, with the Communist Party congress approaching in the autumn.

site_title: Microsoft Xbox brings cloud gaming to Samsung smart TVs without console
summary: Microsoft is partnering with Samsung to allow Xbox game streaming directly on smart TVs without a console, starting June 30. Hundreds of cloud-enabled games attached to Xbox Game Pass Ultimate will be available through Samsung's Gaming Hub. This expansion aims to reach more gamers and boost Game Pass subscription numbers, which currently stand at 25 million. The partnership also includes a new program for independent game developers to promote upcoming titles and track performance.

site_title: China's smartphone makers chip away at Samsung, Apple's Russian market share
summary: China's smartphone manufacturers, including Xiaomi, Realme, and Honor, saw a significant increase in market share in Russia, accounting for 42% of sales in May 2022, up from 28% the previous year. Samsung and Apple's market share dropped due to paused new sales and Western sanctions, with Samsung losing its lead and Apple's share falling to 9% from 12%. Overall smartphone sales in Russia declined 26% year-on-year, as the country's consumer economy was severely impacted by Western sanctions and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: The Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 phone.

site_title: Singapore, China sign defence agreements to boost professional, academic exchanges
summary: Singapore and China signed two agreements to boost defence cooperation, including a renewed professional course exchange agreement and a memorandum of understanding on academic exchanges between their military academies. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Chinese Defence Minister Wei Fenghe reaffirmed their commitment to strengthen bilateral defence cooperation through regular exercises and dialogues. The agreements come under the enhanced Agreement on Defence Exchanges and Security Cooperation, which was signed in 2019 to step up bilateral defence cooperation.

site_title: Air New Zealand raises annual earnings forecast on improved demand
summary: Air New Zealand has raised its annual earnings forecast due to improved demand following the reopening of domestic and international borders. The airline now expects an annual loss of less than NZ$750 million, down from a prior forecast of less than NZ$800 million. Improved passenger bookings for short haul and international services, as well as a return to 90% of pre-Covid domestic business demand, have contributed to the revised forecast. However, the airline remains cautious of uncertain macroeconomic conditions, including Covid-19 travel restrictions and high jet fuel prices.

site_title: UK mortgage market review seeks lower buyers’ deposit requirements
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a comprehensive review of the mortgage market to improve access to low deposit mortgages. The review aims to make it easier for renters to access low-cost, low-deposit finance such as 95% mortgages. Johnson stated that high deposit requirements are preventing many working people from saving enough to buy a home, with deposit requirements now exceeding 10%. The review will report back this autumn with recommendations for the government and industry to support more first-time buyers into homeownership.

images.alt_text: Nationwide, another mortgage lender, has also said a slowdown in the housing market is likely.

site_title: US ready to deliver millions of Covid vaccines to youngest children
summary: The US is set to deliver 10 million doses of Covid vaccines to children under 5 by June 20, pending FDA clearance. The FDA will convene a panel on June 15 to consider recommending the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines for children aged 6 months to 4 years and 6 months to 5 years, respectively. Both vaccines have shown safety and effectiveness in clinical trials, and the US is the only country where children under 5 are not yet eligible for Covid immunization.

site_title: Euro holds near 7.5-year high vs yen before ECB decision time
summary: The euro is trading near a 7.5-year high against the yen, at 142.76 yen, ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) rate decision, which is expected to mark the end of its monetary stimulus and promise an interest rate hike for July. The ECB's decision, influenced by a hawkish US Federal Reserve and soaring inflation, could lead to more substantial gains for the euro. The yen has weakened more than 4% against the euro this month, while the US dollar index remains steady.

images.alt_text: The euro hit a seven-year peak against the yen on Wednesday, getting a lift after an upward revision to first quarter growth and ahead of a European Central Bank meeting on Thursday.

site_title: 5 cars that beat high fuel prices

site_title: Regional palm oil stocks book solid Q1, but cost pressures, CPO price correction loom
summary: Southeast Asian companies in the crude palm oil (CPO) space have reported solid Q1 earnings, driven by higher prices and demand. site_title: 8 people arrested for involvement in phishing scams targeting DBS customers
summary: Eight people have been arrested in an islandwide operation for their involvement in phishing scams targeting DBS Bank customers, resulting in over 60 victims losing more than S$60,000. site_title: US jobless claims rise by most since July during holiday week
summary: US jobless claims rose by 229,000 in the week ending June 4, the largest increase in nearly a year, according to Labor Department data. Economists attribute the rise to modest layoffs, which could signal a slowing economy as the Federal Reserve tries to curb inflation.

site_title: ‘Really difficult’ for smallholder farmers to join the carbon market: Verra CEO
summary: Smallholder farmers face significant barriers to participating in the carbon market due to stringent accounting standards, making it "really difficult" for them to offer real carbon credits. The cost of monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) is a major hurdle, but Verra CEO David Antonioli notes that emerging technologies may bring down costs. To make the market more inclusive, Verra is working to streamline rules and automate methodologies, but a higher carbon price is needed to make land use economically viable for farmers.

images.alt_text: Mikkel Larsen, chief executive officer of Climate Impact X.
The Singapore government on Thursday (Jun 9) launched a governance framework for sovereign green bond issuances under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act 2021 (Singa).
Controversies to do with unclear rules in the carbon market still occasionally make headlines.

site_title: ECB signals rates lift-off, eyes bigger move in September
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) signaled its first interest rate hike since 2011, ending a long-running stimulus scheme on June 9. The ECB will raise interest rates by 25 basis points in July and potentially 50 basis points in September to combat inflation at a record-high 8.1%. ECB President Christine Lagarde aims to return inflation to 2% target over the medium term, and markets expect 143 basis points of rate hikes by the end of this year.

site_title: Kering outlines plans to grow Gucci sales to 15 billion euros in mid-term
summary: French luxury group Kering plans to increase Gucci sales to 15 billion euros in the medium term, up from 9.73 billion euros in 2021. The company aims to grow sales through increased store traffic, expanded store networks, and higher prices. Gucci's profits nearly quadrupled and revenue almost tripled between 2015 and 2019, driven by a focus on local consumers. The brand plans to accelerate business in China and the US, with a focus on higher-end products and store openings.

site_title: Becoming anti-fragile in the age of chaos
summary: The article discusses the concept of "antifragility" in the face of chaos and uncertainty, as exemplified by the Covid-19 pandemic and Ukraine invasion. Antifragility refers to systems that strengthen and benefit from shocks, unlike fragile systems that break or resilient ones that only withstand them. The author cites examples of Singapore's founding story and historical figures who were molded by harsh circumstances to demonstrate antifragility. Three strategies to achieve antifragility are outlined: anticipating and preparing for systemic changes, planning for both good and bad times, and learning from failures and mistakes. By adopting an antifragile approach, individuals and systems can thrive in an era of extreme uncertainty and recurring disruptions.

site_title: Investor and activists critical of DWS at AGM amid greenwashing claims
summary: Investor Union Investment, a large shareholder in DWS, plans to vote against the fund manager's management and supervisory board at the annual general meeting, citing allegations of "greenwashing" and misleading investors about the environmental impact of its investments. This move comes amid a week of high-profile departures and investigations into DWS, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and German financial watchdog BaFin launching separate investigations into the allegations. The move is seen as a vote of no confidence in Deutsche Bank, which controls DWS, and underscores investor frustration with the fund manager's practices.

site_title: Volkswagen offers pay-offs for employees who quit major Russia plant
summary: Volkswagen is offering pay-offs to employees at its Nizhny Novgorod, Russia plant, with around 200 workers eligible for financial compensation and medical insurance until the end of 2022. The offer was made after production at the plant was suspended due to Western sanctions, with vehicle exports to Russia also stopped. Employees who agree to quit before June 17 will receive 6 months' salary, according to union sources.

site_title: Strikes ground flights, shut runways at Paris airport
summary: Around 100 flights at Paris-Charles de Gaulle airport were scrapped on Thursday morning due to a strike by workers demanding higher wages. The strike, involving around 800 workers, forced the closure of 2 runways and caused average delays of 30-45 minutes for passengers. The airport operator ADP said it expected the delays to last all day, affecting some long-haul flights operated by Air France. The strike is part of a broader trend of staff shortages in Europe's aviation sector, exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa has scrapped 900 German and European flights for July at its hubs in Frankfurt and Munich on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays — around 5 per cent of its normal weekend capacity.

site_title: ADB approves up to US$4.3b loan for Philppine railway project
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved a loan of up to $4.3 billion for a 55-km South Commuter Railway project in the Philippines, aiming to halve travel time between Manila and Calamba city. This is ADB's largest infrastructure financing in the Asia and Pacific region. The project will feature disaster-resilient infrastructure and is part of the country's efforts to upgrade its ageing rail network, with a total of 1,209 km of railways planned upon completion.

site_title: Goldman-backed beauty startup becomes India’s newest unicorn
summary: Purplle, an online beauty retailer backed by Goldman Sachs, has raised US$33 million in Series E financing at a US$1.1 billion valuation, becoming India's second billion-dollar company this week. The company, which handles US$180 million of gross merchandise value, plans to invest in technology, private labels, and products. With 70% year-on-year volume growth, Purplle is a prominent rival to Nykaa, valued at US$8.7 billion, and is part of India's growing unicorn market, now over 100 companies.

images.alt_text: A total value of US$52.97 billion across 1,652 entries were recorded by PE and VC firms for the month of May.

The round saw participation from existing and new investors such as Pantera Capital, 6th Man Ventures, IOSG Ventures, Folius Ventures, Morningstar Ventures, Th3ia Capital, Sky9 Capital, and Play Ventures.

site_title: Lufthansa axes hundreds of flights over staff shortages
summary: Lufthansa has cancelled 900 German and European flights in July due to staff shortages, affecting around 5% of its normal weekend capacity. The move comes as the airline industry attempts to recover from the pandemic, with increased demand but infrastructure not fully recovered. This has led to bottlenecks and staff shortages in Europe, impacting airports, ground services, air traffic control, and airlines.

Germany’s Lufthansa wants to acquire a 20 per cent stake in state-owned Italian airline ITA Airways.

site_title: Singapore corporate earnings lower in Q1, weighed down by glovemakers, banks
summary: Singapore's corporate earnings declined 8.7% in Q1 2022, with banks and glove makers taking the biggest hit. The average selling price of disposable gloves fell 61.3% due to increased supply and competition. Top glovemakers, such as Sri Trang Gloves and Riverstone, saw their net profits tumble 90% and 79.2% respectively. Meanwhile, the financial sector was impacted by weaker market sentiment, with OCBC's insurance subsidiary halving its net profit to S$220 million. However, plantation-focused players, such as Golden Agri-Resources and Wilmar International, saw improved net profits and revenue, driven by higher Indonesia domestic crude palm oil prices.

site_title: Nio posts 1.8 billion yuan loss in unaudited Q1 results
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, reported a 1.8 billion yuan (S$370 million) loss in its unaudited Q1 results, narrowing 62.6% year-over-year. Despite the loss, the company saw a record high quarterly delivery of 25,768 vehicles, a 28.5% increase from the year-ago period. Revenue rose 24.2% year-over-year to 9.9 billion yuan, driven by higher vehicle sales. The company attributed a significant increase in research and development expenses to new product and technology development.

Nio has a primary listing of American depositary shares on the New York Stock Exchange. It has listed in Singapore by way of introduction.

site_title: Singapore’s Tessa Therapeutics raises US$126m led by Polaris Partners
summary: Singapore-based biotech company Tessa Therapeutics has raised US$126 million in a Series A funding round led by Polaris Partners to advance its clinical development of immune cell therapies for cancer, particularly CAR-T therapy. The company's lead asset, TT11, showed promising efficacy in patients with relapsed or refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma, and its proprietary platform, TT11X, overcomes toxicity challenges common to off-the-shelf cell therapies. Tessa expects to initiate a pivotal clinical trial of its TT11 programme later this year.

site_title: Shanghai bucks trend as China land demand sinks
summary: China's land demand from developers decreased in the first round of auctions held by major cities this year, with fewer cities seeing price gains. However, Shanghai's sales rebounded after exiting a 2-month lockdown, with all 36 lots sold. Prices averaged 2.32 billion yuan (S$477.2 million) per lot, a 33% increase from the previous sale in 2021. State-owned developers led the sale, buying 30 of the lots, while cash-strapped private developers were cautious on new land purchases.

site_title: Petronas to double capex to RM60b on project 'catch-up'
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's national oil company, plans to double its capital expenditure to RM60 billion this year, as business activities normalize following the lifting of Covid-era restrictions. The company expects to post a "triple-digit" growth in revenue this year due to high oil prices. Despite elevated oil prices, Petronas is diversifying its revenue streams, focusing on non-oil and gas, hydrogen, renewable energy, and green mobility. The company is basing its projects at $50-$60 per barrel and aims to get a sizable chunk of its revenue from non-oil and gas over the next 5-6 years.

site_title: 2022 Audi SQ7 review: Ready for take-off
summary: The Audi SQ7 is a powerful 7-seater SUV with a 4.0-litre V8 engine producing 507 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100km/h in 4.1 seconds. Despite its fuel efficiency of 13.3L/100km, the car's high fuel costs may be a drawback. The SQ7 offers impressive handling, all-wheel drive, and a high-end cabin with carbon fibre trim. Its third-row seats are spacious, but less practical due to limited storage space. Priced at S$493,951, the SQ7 is a luxurious option for those seeking a thrilling driving experience.

images.alt_text: The RS 3 isn’t just fast, it’s the kind of car that can bloody the nose of just about anything else it shares the tarmac with.
The car  has a fastback silhouette and smooth front end. with only a slender opening for cooling air to slip into the engine bay.
Something this trip revealed is that a powerful EV can feel as effortlessly powerful on an inter-city highway as it does in town.

site_title: China's May imports from Russia jump nearly 80% amid Western sanctions on Moscow
summary: China's imports from Russia surged 79.6% in May, up from 56.6% in April and 26.4% in March, amid Western sanctions on Moscow. This growth is attributed to China's purchases of Russian oil at bargain prices, filling the vacuum left by Western buyers. Shipments to Russia fell 8.6% in May from a year earlier. Despite China's refusal to call Russia's actions an invasion, Moscow expects commodity flows with China to grow and reach $200 billion by 2024. This development benefits Russia amidst the economic impact of Western sanctions.

images.alt_text: After 2 years of record exports, Chinese manufacturers are turning downbeat as consumers in their biggest markets curb spending and Covid lockdowns drive customers to competitors in the region.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida to make official visit to Singapore, deliver keynote at Shangri-La Dialogue
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida will visit Singapore from June 10-11, delivering the keynote address at the Shangri-La Dialogue 2022. The visit marks the 55th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries. Kishida will attend a welcome ceremony, meet with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and participate in a dinner hosted by President Halimah Yacob. The dialogue, attended by 42 countries, will focus on regional stability and security. A new orchid hybrid will be named in Kishida's honor during his visit.

site_title: Hong Kong leader delivers defiant swansong speech
summary: Hong Kong's outgoing leader Carrie Lam delivered a defiant final speech to the legislature, stating she is not ashamed of her record despite low approval ratings. Her 5-year tenure was marked by pro-democracy protests, Beijing's national security law, and a coronavirus outbreak that left over 9,000 dead. Lam cited Beijing's support and her family as reasons for staying on, and defended the government's handling of the pandemic, prioritizing a zero-COVID strategy over international travel. She also dismissed the possibility of reopening the border with mainland China in the near future.

site_title: Shanghai locks down parts of city again as coronavirus fears return
summary: Shanghai, China is imposing a mini-lockdown in the Minhang district, with a mass Covid-19 testing drive starting on June 11, amid concerns of a rebound in cases. The lockdown could last up to two weeks if infections are discovered, and residents face restrictions on leaving their homes and daily Covid testing. This move comes as Shanghai slowly emerges from a 2-month lockdown, and the city's reopening appears to be backsliding. Mass testing has also been resumed in Beijing, with officials urging a more targeted approach to prevent Covid spread.

images.alt_text: Parts of Shanghai began imposing new lockdown restrictions on Thursday.

site_title: Garuda Indonesia plans to resolve its debt with new bonds
summary: Garuda Indonesia plans to issue new debt to cover its liabilities, as part of a restructuring proposal made in a Jakarta court. The airline, currently operating only 20% of its pre-pandemic fleet, aims to raise funds to repay debts and compete with rivals. Holders of existing sukuk bonds will receive another sukuk with a 6.5% return, while banks will receive a 0.1% interest rate. Creditors are set to vote on the plan next week.

site_title: Changi Airport Group narrows losses to S$838 million on return of travel
summary: Changi Airport Group narrowed its losses to S$838 million for FY2021/22, down from S$954 million, due to a rebound in air travel as restrictions ease. Passenger traffic reached 5.2 million, about 8% of pre-Covid levels, and March 2022 saw a 20% increase in passenger numbers to 1.14 million. The group registered significant losses due to deconsolidation, write-downs of investments in Russia, and depreciation charges. Despite this, the group raised S$750 million through bond issuances and secured a S$2 billion revolving credit facility to strengthen its liquidity position.

site_title: Brokers’ take: OCBC cuts Yanlord Land target to S$1.37 on Shanghai exposure
summary: OCBC Investment Research lowered its target price for Yanlord Land Group to S$1.37 from S$1.44, citing concerns about the developer's exposure to the Shanghai market due to Covid-19-related lockdowns. The research team believes a potential miss in contracted sales is possible, but notes Yanlord's solid balance sheet will allow it to weather industry headwinds. The new target implies a 28% upside from Yanlord's current price, and the research team maintains its forecast for the group's full-year contracted sales target of 68.5 billion yuan.

site_title: China to consider reviving Ant Group’s IPO
summary: China's financial regulators are discussing a potential revival of Ant Group Co's initial public offering (IPO), which was suspended in 2020. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has established a team to reassess the fintech giant's share sale plans. The decision comes after Ant Group's lucrative online lending business faced tighter scrutiny following a meeting with regulators. The team's findings will determine whether to proceed with the IPO, which was initially valued at $37 billion. The move could be a significant development for Ant Group, controlled by billionaire Jack Ma.

site_title: Companies must focus on diversity, equity and inclusion to attract and retain talent: panel
summary: Companies in Southeast Asia are emphasizing diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) to attract and retain talent, despite potential costs to profits. Panelists, including executives from Thailand's Stock Exchange and Maybank, noted that DEI efforts can lead to social recognition and increased competitiveness for talent. Women empowerment is a key area of focus, with a goal of increasing female board members to 30% in listed companies. Stock exchanges are also working to enhance requirements for listed companies to have more female board members, with Thailand's aiming for 30% and Malaysia's at 18%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.15 points to 1,509.71. Volume reached 2.885 billion lots worth RM2.060 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 601 to 315.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 0.66% on June 9, 2022, following losses in Asia and a drop on Wall Street, as fears about inflation outweighed optimism about Chinese tech firms. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,869.05, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.76% to 3,238.95.

site_title: Thailand’s TCC seeks loan for Frasers Hospitality Trust privatisation: sources
summary: Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's TCC Group is seeking a $500 million loan to take Singapore-listed Frasers Hospitality Trust private. The conglomerate is in talks with banks to finance the deal, with an announcement possible as early as this week. Frasers Hospitality Trust oversees 15 properties across Asia, Australia, and Europe, with concerns that its share price doesn't reflect its value. Deliberations are ongoing, and there is no certainty that the deal will proceed.

site_title: Rising inflation, food scarcity are main threats to Indonesia’s economic growth: panellists
summary: Indonesia faces economic threats from rising inflation and food scarcity despite its trade surplus, current account balance, and fiscal space. Experts warn that a prolonged war between Russia and Ukraine could escalate oil and commodity prices, affecting the country's lower-middle class. The government has taken measures, such as a ban on crude palm oil exports, to mitigate the impact of rising fuel and food costs. Economists predict a 5.1% GDP growth in 2022 and 5.2% in 2023, with growth driven by regions outside Java.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has launched an export acceleration scheme aimed at shipping at least 1 million tonnes of crude palm oil and derivatives following a recent export ban, according to a trade ministry regulation made public on Thursday.

site_title: Fifa's 'very bad year' helps explain payment delay, Blatter says
summary: Former Fifa president Sepp Blatter testified that the delay in a $2.1 million payment to French football icon Michel Platini was due to the organisation's "very bad year" in 2001, which left it unable to pay Platini as a technical director. Blatter claimed the payment was an administrative matter that should have been handled as a civil case, not a corruption trial. The trial is part of a larger investigation into Fifa's finances and corruption allegations, which have tarnished the organisation's reputation and led to several high-profile resignations.

site_title: A hat-trick to close Sifa 2022
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2022 concluded with three standout productions: "Bangsawan Gemala Malam," a Malay-language adaptation of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" that blended bangsawan opera, jazz, and vogue; "The Once And Future," a multidisciplinary epic featuring film, theatre, laser display, and live music by the Berliner Philharmoniker; and "Devil's Cherry," a mysterious and hallucinatory play about two Singaporeans lost in the Australian Bush. These productions received critical acclaim for their innovative storytelling and artistic fusion.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Thursday, tracking regional decline; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, following a regional decline, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,209.62. The decline was attributed to fresh lockdowns in Shanghai and inflation concerns, which dampened risk sentiment. Decliners outnumbered gainers 254 to 210, with shares of Hongkong Land and local banks leading the declines. Meanwhile, DFI Retail Group was the top gainer, climbing 2.5%.

site_title: Tesla sold 32,165 China-made vehicles in May - CPCA
summary: Tesla sold 32,165 China-made vehicles in May, including 22,340 for export, according to the China Passenger Car Association. The company's Shanghai factory produced 33,544 vehicles, a 212% increase from April. This marks a significant growth in Tesla's China sales, with total passenger car sales in China reaching 1.37 million in May, down 17.3% from last year.

site_title: Global private equity deal value hits 12-month low in May
summary: Global private equity deal value hit a 12-month low in May, totaling $52.97 billion across 1,652 entries, a 30% decline in deal value and 18% drop in entries year-over-year. The US and Canada led deal activity, accounting for 565 deals worth $27.36 billion, while technology, media, and telecommunications led deal value with $17.74 billion. Healthcare deals plummeted 53% year-over-year to $7.62 billion, and the industrial sector saw a 44% increase in deal value.

site_title: Thailand legalises growing, consumption of marijuana
summary: Thailand has legalized the growing and consumption of marijuana for medicinal and recreational purposes, becoming the first Asian country to do so. The move aims to boost the agriculture and tourism sectors, with the government giving away 1 million plants to encourage farmers to cultivate the plant. However, recreational smoking is still prohibited, and products containing more than 0.2% THC are banned. Authorities have approved 1,181 cannabis-infused products, which are expected to generate up to $435 million by 2026.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore launched a governance framework for sovereign green bond issuances under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act 2021. The framework outlines the use of proceeds from green bonds to finance expenditures in support of the Singapore Green Plan 2030. This move aims to promote sustainable development and reduce the country's carbon footprint. The framework will guide the issuance of sovereign green bonds, ensuring transparency and accountability in the use of funds.

site_title: For family offices, a one-stop art concierge
summary: Family Office For Art (FOFA) has been launched by former investment banker Chong Huai Seng and his daughter Ning Chong to cater to the growing demand for a one-stop art concierge from family offices in Singapore. The service, founded by the father-daughter duo, offers a range of services including acquiring new artworks, deaccessioning existing collections, and assisting with financial arrangements such as borrowing against art assets. With the surge of new family offices in Singapore, FOFA aims to provide a broad range of services to help collectors build their art collections and share their legacy through art.

site_title: E-commerce aggregator iPrice cuts 20% of staff amid looming downturn
summary: Malaysia-based e-commerce aggregator iPrice is laying off 20% of its 250 employees due to mounting economic uncertainty. The cuts affect business units developing new initiatives, such as a price-watch service and loan brokerage. The company cited a lack of funding to break even in today's environment. This move comes as startups in South-east Asia face a tumultuous time with venture capitalists tightening their purse strings and relooking valuations. iPrice had recently announced US$5 million in funding in March.

site_title: South Korean production and shipping disrupted as truckers strike for third day
summary: Thousands of South Korean truckers went on strike for a third day, disrupting production, slowing port activity, and posing risks to the global supply chain due to rising fuel costs. About 7,200 members, or roughly 30% of the Cargo Truckers Solidarity union, are on strike, seeking pay increases and an extension of an emergency measure guaranteeing freight rates. The strike has impacted steel and cement shipments, with Posco unable to ship 35,000 tonnes of steel products daily. The government is meeting with industry officials to prevent a significant disruption in logistics.

site_title: ANA to fully restore domestic flights for Tokyo airport, first time post-Covid
summary: All Nippon Airways (ANA) will restore full domestic flight services to Tokyo's Haneda airport starting next month, marking the first time since March 2020. The airline plans 23,830 flights in and out of the airport for July-August, exceeding pre-pandemic numbers. Demand for domestic flights is expected to return to 80% of pre-pandemic levels, driven by Japan's lifting of coronavirus-related restrictions.

site_title: Higher BTO supply leaches demand for HDB resale flats in May; volumes drop 5.1%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's resale HDB flat market saw a 0.5% month-on-month increase in May, but volumes dropped 5.1% to 2,156 transactions, according to SRX and 99.co. Demand may have shifted to the Build-To-Order (BTO) market, which launched 5 new projects in May. Prices rose 0.6% for mature estates and 0.4% for non-mature estates, with 4-room flat prices gaining 11.9% year-over-year. Analysts expect demand to moderate as buyers resist high prices and confidence in BTO delivery times is restored.

site_title: Thailand ready to scrap last of pandemic-era curbs on tourists
summary: Thailand plans to scrap the mandatory pre-travel registration for foreigners, known as the Thailand Pass, as part of its efforts to boost tourism and economic recovery. The move, proposed by the Tourism Ministry, would go into effect next month and has the backing of the Health Ministry. The measure aims to make it more convenient for tourists to visit the country, with the goal of attracting 1 million tourists a month from October. The removal of the registration program is seen as a significant step towards restoring Thailand's tourism sector, which previously accounted for about a fifth of the country's economy and jobs.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as inflation woes offset upbeat China data
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi ended flat on June 9, down 0.03% at 2,625.44, despite China's exports growing at a double-digit pace in May, a positive sign for the world's second-biggest economy. However, concerns around US inflation data and new lockdown restrictions in Shanghai weighed on sentiment, leading to a 0.25% decline in the Korean won. Heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell, while LG Energy Solution lost 0.71%. Foreigners were net sellers of 946.4 billion won worth of shares, marking the biggest daily sell-off since March 7.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended flat at 2,626.15, reversing a 0.5 per cent rise in early trade.

site_title: Technology through the decades
summary: A new exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore, "Off/On: Everyday Technology that Changed Our Lives, 1970s-2000s," showcases Singapore's progress through electronic gadgets from the past. The exhibition features a collection of items, including typewriters, pagers, and early computer models, and allows visitors to interact with some artefacts. Themed rooms recreate different decades, such as an office set in the 1980s and a coffeeshop with a coin phone. The exhibition aims to document technology's role in Singapore's transformation and encourages visitors to share their own technological objects and stories.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB lowers price targets on Boustead stocks while maintaining ‘add’ calls
summary: CGS-CIMB analyst Ong Khang Chuen lowered its target prices on Boustead Singapore and Boustead Projects to S$1.30 and S$1.25, respectively, while maintaining "add" calls on both stocks. The analyst attributed the downgrade to weaker order wins and a drop in revenue, but expects structural tailwinds ahead, particularly in Singapore's smart-city trend and growth of the income-yielding portfolio.

site_title: Tesla goes ahead with China hiring event after Musk job warning
summary: Tesla is proceeding with an online hiring event in China, adding 24 new job postings for "smart manufacturing" roles. Despite CEO Elon Musk's warning of job cuts, citing a "super bad feeling" about the economy, the company is recruiting staff for key positions at its Shanghai plant, which produces over half of its cars. The event is the latest in a series of online hiring events in China, where Tesla has 224 current openings.

images.alt_text: Tesla's share of global electric vehicle sales fell to the lowest in more than 3 years due to Shanghai's lockdown, which cost the carmaker weeks of output from its most productive plant.
Musk tweeted on Saturday that “total headcount will increase, but salaried should be fairly flat”.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as oil rises and inflation fears ramp up
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday as oil prices surged, fueling inflation concerns. The OECD cut its global growth outlook to 3% and doubled its inflation forecast to 8.5%, citing the Ukraine war's impact. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates to combat inflation, which is expected to remain elevated. Despite some optimism over China's tech crackdown nearing an end, investors remain cautious, citing the need for crude oil prices to stabilize before a prolonged risk rally can be sustained.

site_title: Indonesia launches scheme to speed up palm oil exports
summary: Indonesia has launched an export acceleration scheme to ship at least 1 million tonnes of crude palm oil and derivatives, following a recent export ban. The scheme, effective immediately, aims to maintain production stability and prices. The government has also lowered the export tax and levy for crude palm oil to encourage shipments. Companies participating in the program must provide data on their storage inventory. The scheme is in place until July 31, and a larger shipment quota can exceed the 1 million limit if needed.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's policy changes have resulted in red tape and slow issuance of export permits, which helped keep global palm oil prices high amid weak output from rival Malaysia.

site_title: High risk of rupiah depreciation likely to hurt Indonesia property developers: Moody’s
summary: Moody's warns that a rupiah depreciation could severely impact Indonesian property developers due to increased unhedged US dollar borrowings. The weakening rupiah would increase principal amounts and interest expenses, making it harder for developers to service their debt obligations. However, most developers have sufficient liquidity to cover higher interest expenses and are protected by financial hedges. Only a few developers, such as Agung Podomoro, may require external borrowings to supplement their liquidity if the rupiah weakens significantly.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Joko Widodo on the Trans-Sumatra Toll Road, Sumatra island's first highway targeted to be completed by 2024 which will connect Aceh province on the northern tip to the southernmost province of Lampung.
Employees fry sliced tempe, a traditional Indonesian food made from fermented soybeans, at a home industry that produces chips in Jakarta, May 18, 2022.

Indonesia's inflation rate accelerated slightly in May due to rising food prices and airfares, official data showed on Thursday, roughly in line with market expectations and within the central bank's target range.

site_title: SICCI elects Neil Parekh as chairman and new board of directors
summary: The Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has elected Neil Parekh as its new chairman, taking over from T Chandroo, who served for two terms. Parekh, a partner and head of Asia, Australia, and New Zealand at Tikehau Capital, was previously vice-chairman. He will be joined by 16 new board members, including 2 vice-chairmen, to form the new board of directors, which will take office on June 15. Parekh aims to help businesses "survive and thrive" in a challenging environment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop before ECB update
summary: Europe's stock markets dropped on June 9, 2022, with the Frankfurt DAX index falling 0.6% and the Paris CAC 40 losing 0.5% ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) monetary policy meeting. The ECB is expected to announce the end date of its bond-buying stimulus and may hike interest rates for the first time in over a decade, addressing concerns over accelerating eurozone inflation. The euro steadied against the US dollar and British pound amidst the market volatility.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit slumps to RM15.3m amid higher costs, moderating demand
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a leading glove manufacturer, reported a 99.3% decline in its Q3 net profit to RM15.3 million, amid rising production costs, higher natural gas and electricity tariffs, and moderating demand. Revenue fell 64.8% to RM1.5 billion, compared to the same quarter last year. The company cited an "oversupply situation" and aggressive pricing by Chinese glovemakers, which have driven down average selling prices (ASPs). Top Glove has deferred major capital expenditure and plans to expand capacity when demand and supply balance out.

images.alt_text: DBS does not expect a repeat of Riverstone's recent high payout of its a special and final dividend per share of 12.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: A vineyard’s comeback, 200 years in the making
summary: Bénigne Joliet, the 6th generation of his family to lead Clos de la Perrière, a 200-year-old vineyard in Fixin, France, is making a comeback. In the 19th century, the vineyard was mentioned alongside Musigny and Chambertin as a great Burgundy vineyard, but it fell out of favor. Now, its wines are excellent and getting better, with Joliet's efforts reviving its reputation.

images.alt_text: At Wine School, we may come to the wines with certain questions in mind, like whether these Mâconnais wines speak more of the grape, chardonnay, or the place, the Mâcon region of southern Burgundy.

site_title: ApeCoin owners vote against leaving the Ethereum blockchain
summary: ApeCoin owners have voted 54% in favor of keeping the token on the Ethereum blockchain, despite high transaction fees. The decision was influenced by the network's fee spikes during the sale of virtual land Otherdeeds in May. The ApeCoin community has considered moving to a different blockchain, but a proposal states that migrating to another chain is a costly, risky, and complex endeavor. The decision does not preclude owners from exploring Layer 2 blockchain options with lower transaction costs.

images.alt_text: Ethereum, the world's most used cryptocurrency blockchain network, passed a milestone test ahead of a highly anticipated technical upgrade without any major glitches.

site_title: Deloitte denies media reports on restructuring plans
summary: Deloitte has denied media reports that the company is exploring a plan to split its global audit and consulting practices, calling the claims "categorically untrue". The news comes after Ernst & Young announced it is evaluating strategic options to improve audit quality. Deloitte stated it remains committed to its current business model and has reached out to investment bankers at Goldman Sachs Group, with talks still in the early stages.

images.alt_text: Ernst & Young is evaluating options to improve their audit quality, chief executive Carmine Di Sibio said on Thursday (May 26) in an internal memo.

KPMG in Singapore is investing S$25 million this financial year into pay adjustments and bonuses for employees, including as much as a 20 per cent increase in starting pay for eligible entry-level professionals.
The formal complaint alleged that “false and misleading information” was provided by certain employees in 2 Carillion audits carried out by KPMG, including for 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends at 2-1/2-month high as tech stocks rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached a 2-and-a-half-month high, closing at 28,234.29, driven by technology stocks and firmer oil prices. The Nikkei rose 1.04% and marked a 4-day winning streak, led by Daikin Industries, SoftBank Group, and M3. Oil explorers added 4.7% as US Treasury yields fell. Real estate shares rose 2.82%, while insurers and banks fell 0.91% and 0.85%, respectively.

site_title: Family offices unstopped by tougher tax rules but face staffing hurdles, longer wait times
summary: Super-rich families seeking to park wealth in Singapore remain committed to setting up family offices despite tougher tax rules, which include stricter criteria for qualifying for tax breaks. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has raised minimum requirements for capital, asset under management, and local investments. Industry players acknowledge regulations change, but staffing and approvals may pose roadblocks for these families.

images.alt_text: Tycoons from around the region, along with their families, are reportedly flocking to Singapore, with interest in immigration rising during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Singapore has seen an influx of wealth from Greater China in recent years.

site_title: Indonesian navy officers ask for US$375,000 to release tanker: sources
summary: Indonesian naval officers allegedly demanded US$375,000 to release a fuel tanker, Nord Joy, that was detained for anchoring illegally in Indonesian waters off Singapore. The tanker was boarded on May 30, and its master was told to arrange payment or face court action and lost income. This incident follows a dozen similar detentions last year, where ship owners made unofficial payments of around US$300,000 each to release vessels. The Indonesian navy has denied making the request, citing its strict prohibition on collecting unofficial payments.

site_title: A US$7.2b China ETF just added the most cash since 2011
summary: A US-listed China ETF, iShares MSCI China ETF (MCHI), drew in a record $270 million in cash on June 7, following the easing of China's Covid restrictions and signs of an end to the regulatory crackdown on tech companies. This influx of cash marks the biggest daily inflow since 2011, as investors bet on a market rebound. Analysts at banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America have made positive calls on Chinese stocks, citing optimism over the economy's growth and the potential for beaten-down stocks to rebound.

images.alt_text: Live-streaming platform Bilibili jumped 6 per cent.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat on Thursday after recent rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened nearly flat on Thursday, edging down 0.02% after a four-day winning streak and overnight US share falls. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 28,229.51, and the Topix index fell 0.15% to 1,967.11.

site_title: Zuckerberg staying at Meta helm for years ‘makes sense’: Clegg
summary: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta's 38-year-old CEO, is expected to remain at the helm for "many, many years," according to the company's global affairs director Nick Clegg. Despite criticism over privacy scandals and misinformation, Clegg believes Zuckerberg's continued leadership is natural due to his role as the founder and architect of Meta's metaverse plans. The metaverse, a virtual world, promises opportunities in education, medicine, entertainment, and more, with hardware improving and accessibility increasing. Clegg sees Zuckerberg's involvement as essential to building this new chapter for the company.

site_title: Slash airline emissions to meet Paris targets: report
summary: A new report by the International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT) finds that airlines must cut emissions by 22.5 billion tonnes by 2050 to meet the Paris Agreement's 1.75C warming goal. To achieve this, airlines must start reducing emissions before the end of the decade and by 2025 if possible. The report's most optimistic model assumes widespread investments in zero-carbon aircraft and fuels, peaking fossil fuel use in 2025, and zeroing it out by 2050. Aggressive policies are needed to peak emissions by 2030 to put aviation on track to meet the goal.

images.alt_text: European Parliament lawmakers on Wednesday narrowly voted to back a European Commission proposal for a total ban on new CO2-emitting vehicles by 2035.

CHINA'S finance ministry on Wednesday (Jun 8) said it would allocate 3.29 billion yuan (S$684.6 million) in the first batch of cash subsidies to airlines this year, part of the government's efforts to rescue the battered aviation industry.

site_title: Australia's biggest bank sees RBA cutting interest rates in 2023
summary: Australia's largest lender, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, expects the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to cut interest rates in the second half of 2023 due to aggressive monetary policy tightening weighing heavily on the economy. The bank forecasts the economy will expand 3.5% this year, down from 4.7%, and then slow to a "below-trend" 2.1% in 2023. The RBA is aiming to quickly drop inflation to its 2-3% target band, but this may come at the expense of economic growth.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank raised interest rates more than expected Tuesday and warned of more increases as officials try to rein in "significantly" high inflation.

site_title: Meta halts development of Apple watch rival with 2 cameras
summary: Meta has halted development of its dual-camera smartwatch, codenamed Milan, due to technical issues and cost-cutting measures. The device, designed for at least 2 years, featured dual cameras, activity tracking, and messaging capabilities. However, the presence of the second camera caused problems with electromyography, a key feature for translating nerve signals into digital commands. Meta is still working on other wrist-worn devices, and some features developed for Milan may appear in future products. The company cited a broader business slowdown and cost-cutting measures as reasons for halting the project.

images.alt_text: Mark Zuckerberg has shown no sign of giving up the reins – despite raging criticism over privacy scandals and the rampant spread of misinformation across Facebook.

site_title: Parts of Shanghai return to lockdown, Beijing district shuts entertainment venues
summary: China's zero-Covid policy continues to restrict cities, with Shanghai imposing new lockdown restrictions and Beijing shutting entertainment venues. Parts of Shanghai, including the Minhang district, will conduct nucleic acid tests and order residents to stay home for 14 days. The measures come as China reported 240 new coronavirus cases on June 8, with 70 symptomatic and 170 asymptomatic. The lockdowns have heavily impacted the Chinese economy, with business chambers expressing concern over uncertainty and increased risk for foreign firms.

images.alt_text: SHANGHAI officials are seeking to revive confidence among multinational firms bruised and frustrated by the city’s Covid-19 lockdown, by holding multiple meetings with foreign firms and easing a key border requirement for overseas workers.

site_title: Hong Kong Rugby Sevens decision looms in test of city’s revival
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Rugby Sevens tournament is at risk of being cancelled due to COVID-19 concerns. Authorities are reviewing the event's safety and logistics, which could limit attendance and party atmosphere. If cleared, the tournament would be held in November under tighter conditions, with a closed-loop system for players and officials to minimize contact with the public. The event's cancellation would be a test of Hong Kong's commitment to reopening and reestablishing itself as a vibrant international hub.

images.alt_text: HONG KONG won't tighten Covid curbs before the city's Jul 1 handover anniversary, Chief Executive Carrie Lam said, despite speculation President Xi Jinping will attend the celebrations.
Hong Kong's private sector expanded in May at the fastest pace in more than a decade as the city continues to recover from its deep, Covid-fuelled economic slump.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.63 points or 0.17% to 1,526.49 on Thursday, driven by higher trading volumes of 215.3 million lots worth RM99.8 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 174 to 140.

site_title: Gold slips as rise in US bond yields dent demand
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $1,852.21 per ounce, restrained by rising US Treasury yields ahead of key jobs and inflation data. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields firmed, lowering the appeal of zero-yield gold. Despite being seen as a hedge against inflation, gold prices were also influenced by the Reserve Bank of India's interest rate hike and a downbeat global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were little changed on Wednesday as investors awaited the US inflation report this week for further cues on the economy as central banks worldwide seek to cool surging prices.

site_title: Australia: Financials drag Australian shares down; Crown Resorts rises on takeover approval
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.9% to a three-week low, weighed down by banking stocks, which hit multi-month lows after the central bank raised interest rates. Crown Resorts rose 1.9% after regulators approved a $6.3 billion takeover by Blackstone. The MSCI world equity index fell 0.56%, while Japan's Nikkei rose 0.2%. Australia's Big Four banks hit their lowest levels in over a year, while energy stocks rose 0.8% on oil price gains.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,219.32, following overnight US losses amid inflation worries. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8%, while European shares declined 0.6% due to economic growth concerns. Asian stocks, including Tokyo's Nikkei 225, remained nearly flat. Banking stocks in Singapore were mixed, with DBS down 0.5% and OCBC slipping 0.3%.

site_title: Vietnam blockchain GameFi startup raises US$6m funding led by Makers Fund, C² Ventures
summary: Vietnam-based GameFi startup Ancient8 has raised US$6 million in funding led by Makers Fund and C² Ventures. The round saw participation from existing and new investors, including Pantera Capital, 6th Man Ventures, and Morningstar Ventures. Founded in July 2021, Ancient8 builds GameFi infrastructure software products for blockchain-based game development. The funding will support the company's growth and expansion in the GameFi industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.49% on Thursday, driven by a pick-up in tech firms, despite a drop on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 22,121.53, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.13% and 0.24% respectively. Traders appear to be brushing off US tariff threats, which have been a concern for the market.

site_title: Tesla's share of EV sales hits 3-year low on Shanghai lockdown
summary: Tesla's global electric vehicle sales dropped to a 3-year low in April, with the company registering 39,650 vehicles, down 78% from March. The decline was attributed to Shanghai's lockdown, which affected production at Tesla's most productive plant. The lockdown resulted in a significant loss of output, with thousands of workers working 12-hour shifts to restore production. Tesla's share of global EV sales fell to 10% from 27% in March.

site_title: Australian banks slide further as RBA view raises housing market concerns
summary: Australian banks' shares plummeted to multi-month lows as the Reserve Bank of Australia's 50 basis point interest rate hike earlier this week sparked concerns about a housing market sell-off. Home prices snapped a 20-month winning streak in May, and the banks' profitability is under pressure. The benchmark index fell to a three-week low, with Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, Westpac, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group losing between 2.6% and 3.7%. Rising interest rates and a cost-of-living crunch are seen as major factors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yangzijiang Financial, Aspen, Asti
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding (YZJFH) is buying up to S$200 million of its shares after shareholders approved a share buyback mandate. Aspen Group Holdings is scaling down its glove-making operations amid market headwinds. Asti Holdings' lithium-ion battery manufacturer, EoCell, is in talks for a potential SPAC acquisition. Frasers Hospitality Trust and Frasers Property have called for trading halts pending an announcement.

site_title: BOJ's rock-bottom rates are crucial for Kishida's spending plans
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is relying on the Bank of Japan to keep borrowing costs low to fund his government's spending plans, which include increased defense spending. The BOJ's current policy stance, which caps 10-year government debt yields, is expected to remain unchanged, with yields staying near rock-bottom lows. This allows the government to continue spending without significantly increasing public debt. Kishida's plan appears to align with former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies, and his government is dropping its target to balance the books by 2026, citing a need for fiscal flexibility.

Japan’s consumer inflation must achieve 2 per cent on average, not in a temporary way driven by cost-push factors such as surging fuel and raw material costs, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said.

site_title: Spotify aims for a billion users by 2030
summary: Spotify aims to reach 1 billion users by 2030, with an annual revenue of $100 billion by the same decade. The company reported $15 billion in revenue for 2021 and currently has 422 million users. Co-founder Daniel Ek plans to expand the platform's portfolio of podcasts and audiobooks, and provide resources for 50 million artists and creators to grow and monetize their work. Spotify aims to increase its gross margin to 40% and operating margin to 20% within the next decade.

images.alt_text: THE audio streaming service Spotify Technology will host its first investor day since going public in 2018 on Wednesday (Jun 8), hoping to stoke Wall Street's enthusiasm despite the slowing global economy.

site_title: EU lawmakers pass ban on new petrol, diesel cars by 2035
summary: European Parliament lawmakers have narrowly voted to back a proposal to ban new CO2-emitting vehicles by 2035, aligning with the European Commission's climate target to cut emissions by more than half over the decade and 90% by 2035. The measure, which was narrowly defeated by conservative opposition, will limit future sales to emissions-free all-electric models, accounting for 12% of EU CO2 emissions. The vote marks an important victory for climate neutrality and will impact the automotive sector.

site_title: Razer Fintech acquires Indonesian digital payments company E2Pay
summary: Razer Fintech, the financial technology arm of gaming hardware maker Razer, has acquired E2Pay Global Utama, a digital payment facilitator and e-money player in Indonesia. The acquisition will facilitate cross-border payments for Razer's 60,000 merchants in Indonesia and complement its B2B unit. E2Pay serves over 500,000 registered users and has notable merchants like Tokopedia and Traveloka. The deal aims to accelerate Razer's entry into Indonesia's digital economy and position it as the single partner for regional and global merchants.

site_title: UK should not raise hopes that peak inflation is imminent
summary: A recent drop in global commodity prices has raised hopes that peak inflation may have been reached, but UK economists caution against getting carried away. The price of semiconductors, shipping containers, and fertilizers has decreased, indicating a potential easing of external shocks that contributed to the UK's 40-year high inflation rate of 9%. However, experts warn that the Bank of England's 2% target is still a long way off, and the latest inflation data is expected to confirm further increases.

site_title: Singapore launches framework for upcoming sovereign green bond issuance
summary: Singapore has launched a governance framework for sovereign green bond issuances under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act 2021. The framework, known as the Singapore Green Bond Framework, sets guidelines for green bonds issued by the public sector, with proceeds to be used to finance expenditures in support of the Singapore Green Plan 2030, focusing on renewable energy, energy efficiency, and climate change adaptation. The Ministry of Finance will curate and review eligible projects before allocating proceeds, with the goal of facilitating Singapore's transition to a low-carbon economy and advancing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Crypto's in-the-money traders dwindle, hinting at capitulation
summary: Crypto investors are experiencing significant losses, with the number of anonymous Bitcoin addresses in the money hitting a low not seen since March 2020. This "points to capitulation" as investors, particularly those who bought in recent months, may be selling their assets. Crypto prices have declined by over a third this year, with Bitcoin losing 4.8% on Wednesday, and sentiment remains sour, with traders buying puts to protect against price declines. Experts attribute the decline to the Federal Reserve's rate hikes and the end of easy-money policies, which benefited crypto prices in the past.

images.alt_text: Investing in the future of the crypto industry doesn't need to require buying digital currencies, according to a PGIM executive.

site_title: Blackstone wins key approvals for US$6.3b Crown Resorts buyout
summary: Blackstone has secured key approvals for its US$6.3 billion takeover of Crown Resorts, an Australian casino operator. Regulators in Victoria and New South Wales have given the green light, with Western Australia's approval pending. The deal could give billionaire founder James Packer a way out of the troubled company, which has faced scandals and regulatory setbacks. Crown's Melbourne casino will continue to operate with a government-appointed supervisor, and the license for its Sydney flagship remains suspended.

images.alt_text: BLACKSTONE said on Thursday (Apr 21) its first-quarter distributable earnings jumped 63 per cent as a strong performance from its real estate and credit businesses offset a weak showing from its hedge funds unit.

site_title: WhatsApp has until July to comply with EU consumer law, EU says
summary: The European Commission has given WhatsApp until July to demonstrate compliance with EU consumer law regarding its January 2022 privacy policy update. The update was criticized for not being explained in plain language, prompting complaints from consumer bodies across Europe. National enforcers have the power to impose sanctions on companies found breaching consumer laws. WhatsApp has stated that its update did not change its commitment to user privacy, but has yet to respond to the Commission's letter.

site_title: Invest in crypto ecosystem, just not the coins, PGIM COO says
summary: PGIM COO Taimur Hyat advises investors to focus on the infrastructure of the crypto industry, such as blockchain, smart contracts, and companies using these technologies, rather than buying cryptocurrencies. He believes these investments offer portfolio diversification benefits and can be less correlated with equities. Hyat also sees potential in the metaverse, citing companies like Meta Platforms as examples of value creation in this space, despite the short-term losses.

site_title: Aspen to significantly scale down glove business
summary: Aspen Glove, a unit of Aspen (Group) Holdings, plans to significantly scale down its operations due to headwinds in the medical glove market, including reduced demand, high inventory levels, and rising production costs. The company expects further margin compressions and is evaluating options, including recapitalisation, joint ventures, and disposal. The scale-down is expected to have a material impact on its results for the current financial year.

site_title: Asian industrial Reits to continue outperformance: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Industrial Reits in Asia-Pacific recorded a 24.7% annualised total return over the past 3 years, driven by e-commerce growth. This outperformance has continued over the past decade, with Reits beating hotel, retail, and office Reits. Healthcare Reits followed with a 22.3% return, while apartments, mixed-use, and office Reits trailed with 19.1%, 13.9%, and 16.1% returns, respectively.
