site_title: Baidu's electric vehicle firm Jidu unveils first 'robot' car
summary: Baidu's electric vehicle arm, Jidu Auto, unveiled its first "robot" car concept, featuring autonomous Level 4 capabilities and voice recognition control. The vehicle, set to be mass-produced in 2023, will be 90% similar to the concept car and will utilize Qualcomm's 8295 chips. Jidu plans to manufacture the vehicle in China and has hired key industry professionals to oversee its development. The car's price is expected to be above 200,000 yuan, targeting users who prefer cutting-edge technologies.

images.alt_text: Baidu's ride-hailing service will deploy cars without humans behind the wheel on Chinese roads for the first time, a symbolic victory in a years-long quest to carve out businesses beyond Internet advertising.

site_title: Intel freezes hiring in PC chip division for at least 2 weeks
summary: Intel has frozen hiring in its PC chip division for at least 2 weeks as part of cost-cutting measures. The company cited increased competition from rivals like TSMC and macroeconomic uncertainty. Despite this, Intel plans to onboard 23,000 recently hired employees over the next 90 days. The move comes as Intel's shares have declined nearly 28% over the past year due to spending heavily to catch up to competitors.

images.alt_text: Intel, the largest maker of computer processors, dragged down chip industry stocks after executives said a weaker economy will affect demand and hurt financial performance.

site_title: OCBC prices US$750m in Tier 2 notes at 4.602%
summary: OCBC has priced US$750 million in Tier 2 notes at 4.602% per annum, with an expected rating of "A2" by Moody's, "BBB+" by Standard & Poor's, and "A" by Fitch Ratings. The notes will be issued on June 15, 2022, and will reset to a fixed rate if not redeemed by June 15, 2032. The move is part of OCBC's capital-raising efforts, with the bank closing 0.1% lower at S$11.89 on the day.

site_title: Singapore’s top students gunning for courses in hot sectors of analytics, food science and environment
summary: Singapore's top students are shifting towards courses in data science, environmental sustainability, and food science, indicating a decline in interest in traditional fields such as accountancy and chemical engineering. Recent A-Level grade profiles show a decrease in competitiveness for these courses, with some universities requiring lower grades to secure spots. Students are drawn to fields with strong job prospects and opportunities for making a difference in society and the environment. Experts attribute the shift to the growing importance of data analysis and sustainability in the business world.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Up till 2016, at least 90 per cent of students that picked and got into National University of Singapore’s (NUS) accountancy course scored straight As for their A-Levels. With the drop in interest since, ABB/B was enough to secure a spot last year.

KPMG in Singapore is investing S$25 million this financial year into pay adjustments and bonuses for employees, including as much as a 20 per cent increase in starting pay for eligible entry-level professionals.
Ernst & Young is evaluating options to improve their audit quality, chief executive Carmine Di Sibio said on Thursday (May 26) in an internal memo.
Energy experts say if Asean really wants to swing the needle on decarbonisation efforts, it should pay just as much attention on retiring its polluting fossil-fired plants

site_title: ESG risks pose 'clear and present danger' to banks, EBA says
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) chairman, Jose Manuel Campa, warns that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks pose a "clear and present danger" to banks. A recent study by the European Central Bank found it unclear whether ESG practices are truly helping the planet. Campa calls for more action from regulators, banks, and non-financial corporates to address these risks. Regulators have cracked down on inflated ESG claims, and the EBA is seeking feedback on how to address ESG concerns through a consultation process.

images.alt_text: A review of over 2,200 empirical studies found that a strong positive link between ESG investing and stable corporate financial performance.

site_title: Ethereum moves closer to blockchain revamp after milestone test
summary: Ethereum, the world's most used cryptocurrency blockchain network, successfully completed a milestone test ahead of its highly anticipated technical upgrade, known as the Merge. The test, run on Ropsten, a realistic technical environment, was completed without major glitches. The upgrade, expected to take place as soon as August, will transition the network from proof-of-work to proof-of-stake, significantly reducing its carbon footprint and addressing environmental concerns. The successful test has been seen as a bullish signal for the network and its token, Ether.

site_title: US regulator favours revamp of stock market trading system
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chair Gary Gensler has endorsed a revamp of the stock market trading system to better protect retail investors. The proposed changes aim to address the issues revealed in the 2021 GameStop saga, where extreme volatility and sudden trading restrictions affected investors. Gensler believes the current system, which routes most trades to electronic trading wholesalers, creates conflicts of interests and encourages "gamification" on online platforms. He has asked the SEC staff to consider steps to enhance order-by-order competition and mitigate the risks of payment for order flow.

site_title: Sanctions wiping out 15 years of economic gains in Russia: report
summary: Russia's economy is expected to contract by 15% this year and another 3% in 2023, wiping out 15 years of economic gains, according to the Institute for International Finance. Sanctions imposed over the Ukraine invasion are rolling back economic progress and integration with the West. The impact is a "moving target" as new sanctions are added, and Russia could retaliate, notably on energy. Economists caution that sanctions do not work like a "flipping a switch" and have a "mixed track record" of driving policy shifts.

site_title: Microsoft’s HoloLens future in question after project leader departs
summary: Microsoft's HoloLens project is in question after its project leader, Alex Kipman, departed the company amid allegations of inappropriate behavior. Kipman, who led the HoloLens initiative since 2001, will be replaced by Panos Panay and Jeff Teper. The project's future is uncertain, particularly as Microsoft waits on a $21.9 billion contract with the US Army, which could determine the product's development. If the contract doesn't materialize, Microsoft may re-evaluate its hardware production, potentially shifting focus to software development for the metaverse.

site_title: Apple to fund pay-later loans off its own balance sheet
summary: Apple plans to fund its pay-later loans for the Apple Pay Later service off its corporate balance sheet, using its treasury department to decide the exact mechanism. The loans will have zero interest and no fees, and will be handled by a wholly owned subsidiary, Apple Financing LLC. To assess creditworthiness, Apple will use a soft pull of customer data, including purchase and payment history. The service will launch later this year, competing with existing buy-now, pay-later firms like Affirm and Block's Afterpay.

images.alt_text: The Apple service “creates a really nice tailwind for us” by informing more people about buy now, pay later services, Affirm CEO Levchin said.
The service, called Apple Pay Later, presents a direct challenge to Afterpay-owner Block, PayPal Holdings and Affirm Holdings - the biggest BNPL player in the United States.

site_title: Twitter to share data at heart of Musk deal dispute: report
summary: Twitter will share its internal data associated with the hundreds of millions of tweets posted daily at the service, ending a major standoff between Elon Musk and the platform's board over fake accounts. The data, known as the "firehose," includes records of tweets and information about accounts and devices used to post them. The decision comes after Musk threatened to back out of his $44 billion bid due to concerns over the accuracy of Twitter's bot detection. Twitter's board will now allow Musk to access the data, paving the way for the deal's completion on original terms.

site_title: US sees path to more sway in Asia as Xi's efforts stall
summary: US officials see an opportunity to strengthen ties in Asia as China's efforts to assert its influence stall due to President Xi Jinping's Covid-zero policies and assertive foreign policy. The US will use meetings with counterparts from Australia and Japan to reinforce the Quad partnership, aimed at curbing illegal fishing in the Pacific. Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin's visit to Singapore for the Shangri-La Dialogue will include a meeting with China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe, with a focus on establishing guardrails for military relations and countering China's growing military presence in the region.

images.alt_text: A screen displays a live news broadcast of Chinese President Xi Jinping at the National People's Congress in Beijing, China, on March 5. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Peru's President Pedro Castillo and first lady Lilia Paredes arrive at Los Angeles International Airport to attend the ninth Summit of the Americas in Los Angeles, California, US.

site_title: More than 1,000 monkeypox cases reported to WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported over 1,000 monkeypox cases globally, with 29 countries affected, excluding Africa where the virus is more common. The risk of monkeypox becoming established in non-endemic countries is real but preventable, according to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus. No deaths have been reported, and cases are mostly among men who have sex with men, with some cases in women also reported. The WHO recommends isolation and post-exposure vaccination, and is assessing vaccine potency and contacting manufacturers and countries with pledged vaccines.

images.alt_text: The WHO said on Sunday that monkey pox constitutes a “moderate risk” to overall public health at global level after cases were reported in countries where the disease is not typically found.

site_title: Foreign enrolment in Singapore private schools picks up as borders reopen
summary: Foreign students are expected to enroll in Singapore private education institutions (PEIs) as borders reopen, but a full recovery may take until 2023. International student numbers rose by 10% from 2021 to 2022, reaching 65,400, with 40% of student pass holders in PEIs. Industry watchers expect growth to be gradual, with increased numbers in the second half of 2022 and a more significant impact in 2023. Some institutions, like James Cook University and Singapore K-12 international school UWC Southeast Asia, have seen continued interest and expect to welcome more international students as borders ease.

images.alt_text: Private school enrolments dive amid Covid and border curbs

site_title: Alibaba, Bilibili extend gains as China approves more game
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks rose for a third day after China approved a second batch of video games this year, easing regulations and boosting the tech sector. Alibaba Group Holding jumped 15% and live-streaming platform Bilibili rose 6% as the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index gained 5.7%, hitting a 3-month high. The approval marks a further softening in Beijing's stance toward Internet firms, with regulators preparing to wrap up their investigation into Didi Global and restore its ride-hailing apps to mobile stores.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding replaced Lazada group chief executive officer Chun Li with the head of its Thailand business and one-time business assistant to Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang as competition in South-east Asia intensifies.

site_title: Russia unexpectedly poor at cyberwar: European military heads
summary: European military heads agree that Russia has been ineffective in employing digital combat capabilities in its offensive against Ukraine, contrary to expectations. Despite numerous cyber attacks, Ukraine was prepared and "withstood attacks from Russia," according to General Karol Molenda. Lithuania's head of cybersecurity, Colonel Romualdas Petkevicius, also stated that Russia is "not ready to wage coordinated cyber and kinetic war." Experts attribute the disconnect to Russia's lack of defensive capabilities and the involvement of independent hacker groups and foreign aid.

site_title: Airbus deliveries fell 6% in May amid supply chain pressure
summary: Airbus delivered 47 jets in May, a 6% decrease from the same period last year, due to supply chain pressure. The total for the year so far is 235, a 7% increase from 2021. Despite this, Airbus remains confident in its future output projections, aiming for 720 deliveries this year. The company is also reporting new orders, including four more A350s from Turkish Airlines. Airbus aims to lift A320 output to 65 a month by mid-2023 and 75 a month by 2025.

site_title: Time to make ESG disclosures work
summary: A review of over 2,200 empirical studies found a strong positive link between ESG investing and stable corporate financial performance. This suggests that investors can better assess ESG performance and make informed investment decisions. Faster adoption of a universally accepted ESG reporting system is crucial for this increased transparency. The study's findings support the growing trend of businesses and organizations prioritizing environmental, social, and corporate governance.

images.alt_text: James Penny, who has been running ethically focused funds for about a decade and is currently the London-based chief investment officer at TAM Asset Management, says  several companies owned by ethically focused funds will struggle to refinance their debt, but did not name  specific firms.

site_title: Intel drags down chipmakers with views on weakening demand
summary: Intel, the largest maker of computer processors, dragged down chip industry stocks after executives said a weaker economy will affect demand and hurt financial performance. CFO Dave Zinsner stated that a weaker economy will impact the company, as well as the global semiconductor industry. This led to a 5.3% decline in Intel shares, with other semiconductor stocks also falling. The company's annual projections remain unchanged, but executives are cautious due to inflation and reduced consumer and corporate spending.

images.alt_text: Intel Corp shareholders rejected compensation packages for top executives, including a payout of as much as US$178.6 million to CEO Pat Gelsinger (pictured).

site_title: Credit Suisse shares spike on reported State Street takeover interest
summary: Credit Suisse shares surged 3.8% after a report from Swiss financial blog Inside Paradeplatz claimed US-based State Street is planning a takeover bid. State Street denied the claim, stating it's focused on its pending acquisition of Brown Brothers Harriman's Investors Services business. Analysts questioned the likelihood of a deal, citing State Street's existing acquisition plans and Credit Suisse's legal and business challenges. The move comes as Credit Suisse delivered a third consecutive quarterly profit warning and faces ongoing scandals and restructuring efforts.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall on growth fears ahead of ECB meeting
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday amid concerns about economic growth slowdown and Credit Suisse's forecast of a group-wide loss in the second quarter. Banks, including Credit Suisse, HSBC Holdings, and UBS Group, dropped 0.9%, 1.7%, and 2.6%, respectively. Investors are bracing for the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday and the US Federal Reserve's next week. Money markets are betting on 75 basis points of rate hikes by September to combat record-high inflation.

site_title: Singapore’s economy poised for further growth as global demand shifts to Asean: panellists
summary: Singapore's economy is poised for further growth as global demand shifts to Asean countries due to supply chain disruptions, geopolitical conflicts, and China's zero-Covid policy. The country's GDP grew 3.4% in the first quarter, with analysts expecting stronger growth in the second quarter. Despite rising inflation, with core inflation accelerating to 3.3% year-on-year, experts say Singapore's active involvement in global trade pacts and its low-base effect will drive growth. Tightening monetary policy may be necessary to curb inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: After 2 years of record exports, Chinese manufacturers are turning downbeat as consumers in their biggest markets curb spending and Covid lockdowns drive customers to competitors in the region.
Private-sector economists now expect headline inflation to hit 5 per cent, and core inflation to reach 3.4 per cent for the full year.

site_title: Oil jumps to 13-week high on rising US petrol demand
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% to a 13-week high on Wednesday, reaching $123.58 a barrel, as US demand for petrol continued to rise despite record pump prices. The US Energy Information Administration reported a surprise increase in commercial crude oil inventories, while crude in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve fell by a record amount. Analysts expect fuel demand to recover in China, but supply concerns, including Iran's nuclear programme and potential shutdowns, may limit output.

site_title: US: Festering inflation worries dog stocks
summary: US stocks retreated on Wednesday due to festering worries about inflation, with oil prices jumping and the White House warning of a potentially gloomy consumer price report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.1% and 0.7%, respectively. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose above 3%, reflecting expectations of Federal Reserve monetary tightening. The Dow and S&P 500 are near record highs, but the recent jump in oil prices and inflation concerns are casting a shadow over the market.

site_title: US unveils new Latin America economic plan at reboot summit dogged by dissent
summary: The US has unveiled a new economic plan, the "Americas Partnership for Economic Prosperity," aimed at countering China's growing influence in Latin America. The plan, proposed by President Joe Biden, seeks increased US investment, strengthened supply lines, and enhanced trade deals with like-minded partners. However, it stops short of offering tariff relief and will initially focus on existing trade accords. The plan was unveiled at a US-hosted summit in Los Angeles, where regional leaders are gathering, despite a partial boycott by leaders upset at Washington's decision to exclude Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua.

site_title: Amazon's CEO of worldwide consumer business to join Flexport
summary: Amazon's CEO of worldwide consumer business, Dave Clark, is set to join logistics technology startup Flexport as chief executive in September. Clark will leave his role at Amazon on July 1, following a series of reports that Flexport serves and seeks to compete with Amazon. Clark stated in a LinkedIn post that he aims to "build solutions for the most complicated supply chain problems through world-class technology for the physical world." This move comes after Flexport more than doubled its valuation to $8 billion in February after securing funding from venture capital firms.

site_title: Manufacturing upturn : Gearing up for growth - and security risks
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector remains cautious due to ongoing geopolitical tensions and pandemic impacts, despite optimism around post-Covid recovery. The latest business sentiment polls show a darkened outlook for the April-September 2022 period, with rising costs putting pressure on manufacturers to stay cautious. The sector faces new security risks as it gears up for growth amidst increased digitalisation, which brings both benefits and threats.

images.alt_text: Medtronic Inc. heart pacemakers are produced at Medtronic Singapore Operations (MSO), the company's new manufacturing facility in Singapore, on Thursday, March 10, 2011. Medtronic, the world's largest maker of heart devices, plans to hire about 600 people in India and China as it seeks to double the sales contribution from emerging markets within five years. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg
The threat of cybercrime in Asia has reached an all-time high as we face fifth-generation cyber attacks that have grown in complexity and magnitude.
Of the respondents from Singapore, 80 per cent reported that they had been hit by a ransomware attack in the last 24 months.

site_title: Hasbro defeats board challenge from activist investor Alta Fox
summary: Hasbro successfully defeated a board challenge from activist hedge fund Alta Fox, with shareholders re-electing all 13 directors. Alta Fox had nominated one director and pushed for a spinoff of Wizards of the Coast and Digital Gaming, but Hasbro stated a spinoff would be unlikely to create value. The hedge fund owns a 2.5% stake in Hasbro, which has seen its shares fall nearly 13% this year.

site_title: Supporting the repair economy
summary: Singapore companies are embracing the repair economy, catering to eco-conscious consumers seeking to reduce waste and recycle. Alteration and repair services, as well as pre-owned children's clothes, are in high demand. This shift aligns with the growing trend of consumers choosing to repair and reuse existing items instead of buying new ones, supporting a more sustainable lifestyle.

site_title: World's richest families invest more in private equity amid volatile markets: UBS
summary: The world's wealthiest families invested more in private equity in 2021, boosting returns, as they sought to diversify their portfolios amid volatile markets. This shift came as traditional asset classes like fixed income and stocks faced challenges, with near-zero interest rates and high valuations deterring investors. Direct allocations to private equity rose to 13% from 10% in 2020, while indirect allocations increased to 8% from 7%. The trend reflects a desire for active manager strategies and a need to diversify portfolio risk, with 63% of family offices surveyed no longer relying on high-quality fixed income for diversification.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment’s ex-CFO made or asked for document alterations to ‘simplify’ audit process, review finds
summary: The former CFO of Singapore Kitchen Equipment, Chow Mei Ling, altered the company's documents to "simplify" the audit process, according to a fact-finding review. Eight transactions worth approximately S$1.4 million were made without proper controls, and Chow instructed document alterations to justify the payments. The altered documents were only shown to external auditors, and no evidence suggests a criminal breach of trust or fraud. The company has taken steps to strengthen internal controls and is reviewing the findings. Singapore Kitchen Equipment is under investigation by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority for possible breaches of the Companies Act.

site_title: StarHub trying to avoid own goal with EPL offering, amid saturated content market
summary: StarHub is launching a contract-free English Premier League (EPL) offering with prices ranging from S$19.99 to S$39.99 per month, in an effort to attract fans amid a crowded content market. The telco has introduced interactive elements, such as match statistics and rewinds, and will also offer a library of historic games and behind-the-scenes content during the off-season. However, the move comes as pay-TV subscription numbers decline and piracy and illegal streaming rise, posing a challenge for telcos to monetize content.

images.alt_text: StarHub EPL rights could pose short-term cost challenge: Analysts

site_title: Asti associate EoCell in talks for potential SPAC combination
summary: Lithium-ion battery manufacturer EoCell, an associate of Asti Holdings, has entered into a non-binding letter of intent with an unnamed publicly-traded SPAC for a potential combination. If a definitive agreement is reached, EoCell's shareholders will become shareholders of the SPAC through a reverse triangular merger. Asti Holdings, which has an indirect interest in EoCell, will also have an indirect interest in the SPAC if the transaction is completed. No assurance has been given that a definitive agreement will be entered into or that the transaction will be completed.

images.alt_text: WATCH-LISTED semiconductor manufacturing services company Asti Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore bourse.
Asti Holdings chief executive officer Michael Loh Soon Gnee (pictured) was dismissed by the company after more than 8 years as chief last December.

site_title: Honda and LG Energy are eyeing Ohio for new electric-car battery plant: sources
summary: Honda Motor and LG Energy Solution are considering Ohio as the location for a new North American battery plant, with the Midwestern state being a strong candidate due to Honda's existing automaking presence. The companies are planning to invest in the plant, which would produce batteries for over 600,000 electric cars annually. Honda aims to launch 30 electric models by 2030, with production volume of over 2 million vehicles per year, as part of its drive to phase out fossil-fuel vehicles by 2040.

images.alt_text: A woman using her mobile phone walks past a logo of Honda Motor Co outside the company's dealership in Tokyo October 28, 2014. REUTERS/Yuya Shino

site_title: UK wants to regulate tech firms deemed 'critical' to finance
summary: The UK Treasury is proposing to regulate tech firms deemed "critical" to the finance industry, which has shifted heavily to cloud computing. The proposal would grant regulators powers to oversee these firms, set minimum resilience standards, and enforce compliance. The move aims to address concerns about the growing dependence of banks on cloud services from a handful of firms, including Amazon and Microsoft. The plan is seen as a response to the Bank of England's earlier call for additional powers to police the finance industry's switch to cloud computing.

site_title: Lakepoint condo S$640m en bloc tender closes without bids
summary: The Lakepoint Condominium in Jurong, Singapore, closed its en bloc tender without bids, with the reserve price remaining unchanged at S$640 million. The site, comprising 304 residential units and 5 shop units, is now entering into private treaty negotiations with interested parties. The total quantum, including development charges and lease top-up premium, would likely exceed S$800 million, making potential buyers cautious. The condominium's owners had recently obtained approval for a higher height redevelopment, allowing for a mix of 5- and 12-storey residential blocks.

images.alt_text: Located at 9E and 9F Yuan Ching Road, the site spans 12,465.4 square metres (sq m) with a plot ratio of 2.1.
Lakepoint up for en bloc again at same S$640m reserve price

site_title: HSBC shuts down Hong Kong-based trade start-up Serai
summary: HSBC is shutting down its Hong Kong-based trade start-up Serai, a platform launched 3 years ago to connect small-and-medium-sized apparel makers with component suppliers worldwide. Despite progress, it failed to build a commercially viable business, prompting the decision to wind down operations. The move is described as a "purely commercial decision" by HSBC, following a thorough business review.

site_title: Risk of delay to carbon market reforms after surprise EU vote
summary: The European Parliament rejected a proposal to upgrade the EU's carbon market, exposing divisions over climate policy and potentially delaying negotiations. The rejection means votes on two climate policies, including a CO2 levy on imports and a fund for low-income citizens, were postponed. The proposal aimed to reform the Emissions Trading System (ETS) and cut net planet-warming emissions by 55% by 2030. A new compromise must be forged, with lawmakers urging a quick resolution to meet the EU's 2023 deadline.

site_title: UK lenders to pay annual levy that will raise £200m for BOE running costs
summary: The Bank of England will require large UK lenders to pay an annual levy, raising over £200 million, to cover its running costs. The levy will replace a complex funding model that failed to cover costs last year, with banks with over £600 million in assets expected to contribute. The scheme aims to ensure the BOE no longer needs to draw down reserves to cover its costs, replacing an existing £300 million annual charge. The Treasury has assured that the levy will be approved by the BOE's Court of Directors and will not be subject to political interference.

images.alt_text: epa09927931 The Bank of England in London, Britain, 05 May 2022. The Bank of England has announced it is to increase the UK interest rates to one percent from 0.75 percent to help curb inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Police warn against latest round of SMS scams; 60 DBS customers duped
summary: DBS customers have been targeted by a recent phishing scam, with approximately 60 customers losing between S$60 to S$3,000 each. The scammers sent unsolicited SMS messages claiming bank accounts were frozen, directing victims to verify their identity via a spoofed link. The victims were then asked to input their online banking details and one-time password. The police and DBS have recovered an additional S$173,000 from the scammers through joint efforts. The bank and police warn against clicking on links from unsolicited messages claiming to be from banks.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial to buy back up to S$200m of shares
summary: Yangzijiang Financial Holding has announced it will buy back up to S$200 million worth of shares after shareholders approved a share buyback mandate. The company plans to repurchase up to 395 million shares, with the intention of holding them as treasury. The purchase price will not exceed 105% of the average market price for on-market shares and 120% for off-market shares. The move follows an extraordinary general meeting held on June 8, where shareholders voted in favor of the mandate.

site_title: US wholesale inventories revised slightly up in April
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 2.2% in April, slightly more than initially reported, with sales moderating growth. The Commerce Department revised March inventories to 2.7% increase. Wholesale motor vehicle inventories rose 1.3% and non-automotive inventories increased 2.2%, suggesting inventory investment could support economic growth. The revised numbers follow a 1.5% annualized GDP drop in the January-March quarter, with estimates for the second quarter ranging from 4.8% growth.

site_title: 1 dead, 5 seriously hurt after car smashes into crowd on Berlin shopping street
summary: A car crashed into a crowd of people on a shopping street in Berlin, Germany, killing one person and injuring over a dozen others. Five people were left with life-threatening injuries. The incident occurred near the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church, a popular landmark in western Berlin. Police are investigating whether the incident was a deliberate attack or an accident with a medical cause. The driver, who received medical treatment, was detained by bystanders before being handed over to authorities.

images.alt_text: NEWTOWN, CONNECTICUT - JUNE 03: People attend a rally for National Gun Violence Awareness Day on June 03, 2022 in Newtown, Connecticut. Across the nation people are wearing orange and joining rallies as they demand change to America's gun laws.

site_title: Sri Lanka power union announces strike, raising risk of blackouts
summary: A power sector union in Sri Lanka announced an indefinite strike from midnight, protesting against new government legislation that could lead to power blackouts. The strike, affecting 900 out of 1,100 engineers, comes as the country faces its worst economic crisis in decades. The union opposes amendments to legislation governing the power sector, which include removing restrictions on competitive bidding for renewable power projects. The strike may bring back power outages, with no breakthrough in talks between the union and government authorities.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka will need US$5 billion over the next six months to ensure basic living standards,

site_title: Singapore must continue to make friends, manage inflation and commit to climate goals
summary: Singapore must balance its global relationships, manage inflation, and commit to climate goals, said MAS board member Alvin Tan. The near-term outlook has become uncertain due to external headwinds, with growth for external-facing sectors expected to slow this year. Tan emphasized the need for diversification and investment in other parts of the world, citing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) as a key milestone. The MAS has taken pre-emptive steps to tighten monetary policy to slow inflation momentum, which is expected to moderate this year. Climate change plans and green finance initiatives will also be prioritized.

images.alt_text: Businesses which are successfully validated by any Asean country will have reduced documentary and cargo inspection across all Asean countries, said Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong on Tuesday at the opening ceremony of the 31st Asean Directors-General of Customs meeting in Singapore.

Standard Chartered’s Patrick Lee and Andrew Chia say that instead of focusing their strategy on a single country or business area, companies should recognise that Asean offers the best advantages when businesses take a regional approach.

site_title: Yen tumbles against euro as central bank policy diverges
summary: The euro reached a seven-year peak against the yen, gaining 0.2% against a stronger dollar, as the European Central Bank is set to end bond purchases and likely implement rate hikes later this year. The Bank of Japan remains with ultra-loose monetary policy, causing the yen to fall for 10 consecutive sessions against the euro. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points next week, further weakening the yen and strengthening the dollar.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US dollar against a basket of 6 currencies including the yen, rose as much as 0.39 per cent, extending on Monday's (Jun 6) 0.26 per cent advance and hitting its strongest level since May 23, before trimming its advance.

site_title: Disney pulls blockbuster from French cinemas in streaming row
summary: Disney will not release its animation "Strange World" in French cinemas due to the country's strict streaming rules, which require a 17-month wait after cinema release. The company will instead send the film straight to its streaming platform, Disney+, in protest. The decision was made by Disney France President Helene Etzi, who described the rules as "unfair, constraining and poorly adapted to audience demands." This move comes amid a broader debate over cinema and streaming release windows in the film industry.

site_title: Moderna's new booster produces stronger response against Omicron
summary: Moderna's new coronavirus vaccine booster, mRNA-1273.214, has shown a stronger immune response against the Omicron variant in a study, with virus-neutralizing antibodies increasing 8-fold. The company expects to submit the data to regulators and obtain clearance in late summer, paving the way for use in a fall inoculation drive. The updated vaccine targets both Omicron and the original strain, addressing waning immunity and variant evasion. Moderna's CEO, Stephane Bancel, believes it offers more durable protection against variants of concern.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed Moderna logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as tech-driven rally eases
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Wednesday, as a rally in technology and growth stocks eased, and higher oil prices raised inflation concerns. The Dow Jones fell 93.07 points, or 0.28%, to 33,087.07. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 down 13.56 points, or 0.33%, and the Nasdaq down 27.95 points, or 0.23%. The declines were attributed to a decrease in tech-driven stocks and concerns over global inflation.

site_title: More pain on the way after COEs cross S$100,000
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) market in Singapore has crossed a psychological threshold of S$100,000, with premiums for two categories, B and E, rising to S$100,684 and S$100,697, respectively. Strong demand and a tight supply of COEs, driven by a low number of deregistrations, are expected to continue putting pressure on prices. The COE supply is expected to tighten in 2023, but will expand in 2024 and beyond, providing relief to car buyers.

images.alt_text: COE premiums ended mixed at the latest tender exercise which closed on Thursday (May 19), rising for larger cars and motorcycles and falling for smaller cars as well as commercial vehicles.
This was the first tender  exercise to include the new 110kw power categorisation for EVs, which was announced in March.

site_title: Toyota supplier Toyoda Gosei asks employees to take leave as lockdown bites
summary: Toyoda Gosei, a major Toyota Motor supplier, has asked employees to take a day off with reduced pay in June due to the impact of the chip shortage and China lockdowns. The move follows production suspensions by Toyota and other automakers. The company and its union are considering similar measures in July or beyond.

site_title: China's central government to allocate 3.29 billion yuan to struggling airlines
summary: China's central government will allocate 3.29 billion yuan (S$684.6 million) in cash subsidies to struggling airlines, part of a 2-month support policy to rescue the battered aviation industry. The subsidies will be provided when average daily flight numbers are lower than 4,500, resulting in lower payouts. Despite the recovery in airline capacity, Chinese airlines will not receive subsidies for the week of June 4-10 due to conditions not being met. This move aims to support the industry's recovery amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: ACRA investigates Astaka’s employees following SGX disciplinary action last year
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore (ACRA) is investigating current and former employees of Astaka Holdings following the Singapore Exchange Regulation's (SGX) disciplinary action against the company's former CEO Zamani Bin Kasim and CFO Lee Shih Yi in August 2021. ACRA has asked Astaka for more information and may include interviewing employees and producing documents as part of the investigation. Astaka's shares have been suspended from trading since 2019, and the company is seeking clarification on the investigation's nature and scope.

images.alt_text: Suspended stock Astaka inks MOU to jointly undertake land development projects with RM1b development value

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.07 points to 1,523.86. Volume reached 3.261 billion lots worth RM1.964 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 524 to 388.

site_title: SAF Chief of Army Goh Si Hou appointed PUB’s new CEO
summary: Singapore's PUB appoints Goh Si Hou as its new CEO, effective July 22, succeeding Ng Joo Hee. Goh, former Chief of Army in the Singapore Armed Forces, has been part of PUB's board since April 2021. Ng, who will retire from the Administrative Service, led significant water infrastructure developments during his tenure. The Ministry of Sustainability and Environment expressed appreciation for Ng's leadership and welcomed Goh.

site_title: Why do Reits chase scale?
summary: Singapore Reits are pursuing consolidation through mergers and acquisitions (M&As) to achieve scale, mirroring the US Reit market's trend in the 1990s. Since the first Reit emerged in Singapore 20 years ago, the market has grown exponentially, with S-Reits now valued at S$113.56 billion. Large Reits enjoy economies of scale, commanding market power in leasing and negotiating favorable terms with tenants. Consolidations create value for unitholders through higher cash flows, lower discounting factors, and increased liquidity. However, S-Reits should be mindful of unitholders' interests while chasing scale, balancing the interests of investors, sponsors, and Reit managers.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) will merge to create one of Asia’s 10 largest Reits.

site_title: India raises local rice paddy purchase price by 5.2% to encourage farmers
summary: India has raised the price at which it will buy new-season common rice paddy from local farmers by 5.2%, the largest increase in five years, to encourage farmers to boost acreage and output. The new price is set at 2,040 rupees (S$36.11) per 100 kg, as the country aims to maintain its preeminent position in the global rice trade. The move is seen as a response to the heat wave that hit output and the recent ban on wheat exports, and is expected to boost rice output in the country, the world's second-largest consumer of rice.

images.alt_text: India has no plans to curb food exports for now, Piyush Goyal, the Minister for Commerce and Industry, Consumer Affairs and Food and Public Distribution said on Friday, weeks after New Delhi banned private wheat exports.

site_title: Opec+ efforts to boost oil output 'not encouraging', UAE minister says
summary: UAE Energy Minister Suhail al-Mazrouei stated that Opec+ efforts to boost oil output are "not encouraging", with the group currently 2.6 million barrels per day short of its target. The Opec+ group's conformity rate is over 200%, indicating that member countries are producing less than their allocated output. This is a concern, particularly with China's potential to boost demand, which has been supporting crude prices. The UAE minister's comments suggest that Opec+ may need to reassess its production curbs.

site_title: Microsoft slashes Russia operations after war clouds outlook
summary: Microsoft is substantially reducing its business in Russia, joining other prominent technology firms in cutting back or exiting the country due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The company will continue to fulfill existing contractual obligations with Russian customers while suspending new sales. Over 400 employees will be affected, and Microsoft is working to support impacted employees. This move follows similar actions by IBM, Apple, Nike, and SAP, which are also winding down operations in Russia.

site_title: Singapore companies pay average S$1.5m after ransomware attack: report
summary: Singapore companies pay an average of S$1.5 million after a ransomware attack, according to a survey by cybersecurity technology company Cybereason. 80% of respondents from Singapore reported being hit by a ransomware attack in the last 24 months, with 55% saying their services were not released or were corrupted after paying the ransom. Furthermore, 56% of respondents reported being hit a second time within 4-7 days.

site_title: China retail car sales rise 30% in May vs April, preliminary data shows
summary: China's retail car sales surged 30% in May compared to April, driven by stimulus measures to revive the market hit by Covid-19 measures. Sales of passenger vehicles fell 17% from the same period last year to 1.35 million units. The China Passenger Car Association expects an additional 2 million car sales this year. Authorities have introduced incentives, including halved purchase tax for cars under 300,000 yuan, to boost the market.

site_title: JPMorgan backs software startup Codat at US$825m valuation
summary: JPMorgan Chase has invested US$100 million in software startup Codat, valuing the company at US$825 million. Codat connects small businesses with financial institutions, providing real-time data sharing and standardizing financial data. The funding round, led by JPMorgan's growth-equity arm, was joined by new investors Canapi Ventures and Shopify, and existing backers Index Ventures and PayPal Ventures. Codat aims to increase its integrations with small business financial applications and is targeting US$30 million in annualized revenue by the end of 2022.

site_title: Jokowi urges Indonesians to use idle land to plant rice, corn
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged citizens to use idle land to plant rice and corn to boost the nation's food supplies amid the global shortage caused by the war in Ukraine. He called on his ministers to investigate why abandoned plots remain despite land use permits issued decades ago. The government must also speed up land redistribution and improve infrastructure for farmers to make everything productive. Indonesia has resorted to price caps, export bans, and subsidies to stave off a food crisis, affecting household budgets and public discontent.

site_title: Japan’s blurred vision for the future of capitalism
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has unveiled the "Grand Design" for his "New Form of Capitalism", a policy aimed at revitalizing Japan's economy through greater government cooperation and oversight, as well as redistribution of cash to workers. The plan rejects neoliberalism and emphasizes stakeholder capitalism, but critics say it lacks concrete policies to lift wages and has watered-down elements. The initial reaction has been muted, with some praising the focus on lifting wages and others criticizing the lack of clarity. Kishida's popularity has helped him maintain a platform to enact changes, but he must distill his vision into clear messaging and policies that workers and businesses can embrace.

images.alt_text: Support for Kishida and his cabinet climbed to 66 per cent, a rise of five points from the previous April survey.

site_title: Mortgage market index falls to 22-year low: MBA
summary: The Mortgage Bankers Association (MBA) reported a 22-year low in mortgage loan application volume, with its Market Composite Index falling 6.5% to 288.4 in the week ending June 3. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate rose to 5.4% after three weeks of declines, as the Federal Reserve aims to cool the housing sector and curb inflation. The Purchase Composite Index and Refinance Index also declined, with falls of 7.1% and 5.6%, respectively.

site_title: Contrarian who called China tech rout says sector still a sell
summary: Contrarian analyst Manuel Muehl from DZ Bank is sticking to his bearish call on China's tech sector despite growing optimism that a crackdown may be easing. Muehl cites concerns over slowing revenue growth, deteriorating margins, and falling free cash flows, and believes the sector's woes may persist. To reverse his call, Muehl would need to see a deal preventing US delisting, a relaxation of anti-monopoly rules, and a significant increase in consumer confidence and spending.

images.alt_text: US-listed China stocks surged to the highest since early April on increased speculation that a year-long government crackdown on the technology industry is easing.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Wednesday, bucking regional trend; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to close at 3,225.80 on June 8, bucking regional trends. The decline was attributed to concerns of slower economic growth and higher inflation, with private-sector economists expecting a 3.8% GDP growth in 2022 and 5% inflation for the full year. Local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, were among the decliners, while SATS shares rose 2%.

images.alt_text: Private-sector economists now expect headline inflation to hit 5 per cent, and core inflation to reach 3.4 per cent for the full year.

site_title: Spotify looks to stoke Wall Street enthusiasm amid cooling economy
summary: Spotify is hosting its first investor day since going public in 2018, aiming to boost Wall Street enthusiasm despite a slowing global economy. The company's stock has dropped 53% in 2022, but it has fared better than Netflix, which lost 67% of its value due to subscriber losses. Spotify added users and paying subscribers in the first quarter, despite suspending its service in Russia and controversy over Joe Rogan's podcasts. The event aims to reassure investors and restore confidence in the company's growth prospects.

site_title: Taiwan's banks face mandatory climate stress tests next year
summary: Taiwan's banks will undergo mandatory climate-change stress tests in 2023 to measure the impact of environmental catastrophes on their assets. The Financial Supervisory Commission plans to finalize the tests by year's end and publish the results in June. Some banks, including CTBC Financial Holding and Cathay Financial Holding, have already started preparing for the tests, examining risks such as rising sea levels and industries vulnerable to climate change. The move follows global trends, with the Bank of England warning of climate-related losses for UK banks and insurers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Private-sector economists now expect Singapore's full-year inflation to reach 5% and core inflation to hit 3.4%. In contrast, they forecast 4.8% growth in the second quarter, up from 3.7% in Q1. Grab has launched GrabMaps as a new enterprise service to tap the US$1 billion mapping and location-based services market in South-east Asia. Meanwhile, ST Telemedia is planning to establish a second data centre in Seoul, South Korea, backed by Samsung.

site_title: OECD sees lower world growth due to Ukraine war's 'hefty price'
summary: The OECD predicts lower global GDP growth due to the Ukraine war, slashing its 2022 forecast to 3% from 4.5%. The organization also forecasts higher inflation among its member countries, reaching 8.5%, its highest level since 1988. The war's humanitarian crisis is expected to disproportionately affect the poorest households, with the OECD urging policymakers to implement temporary fiscal measures and invest in clean energy and defense spending to mitigate the economic impact.

images.alt_text: OECD secretary-general Mathias Cormann told a panel at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, that progress on ironing out technical details on the digital tax deal was going less quickly than planned.

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate at record low despite inflation
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, held its key interest rate at a record low of 0.50% despite rising inflation, and raised its 2022 growth forecast to 3.3% from 3.2%. The decision was in line with economists' predictions, and the bank expects inflation to remain elevated for longer than expected. The bank also raised its forecast for foreign tourist arrivals and export growth for 2022 and 2023.

images.alt_text: Thailand's retail inflation quickened in May to its highest in nearly 14 years, a level that may test the central bank's resolve to stand pat on borrowing costs.

site_title: 3 charged with graft in separate bunker fuel trading corruption cases
summary: Three individuals, Ng Kit Sze, Gary Lim Wei Xiong, and Ong Zhi Xian, have been charged with corruption under the Prevention of Corruption Act for separate bunker fuel trading cases. Ng, a fuel trader, is accused of receiving US$95,000 in bribes from two individuals, while Lim is accused of accepting bribes worth US$400. Ong, an assistant manager at a shipping company, is accused of accepting S$1,200 in bribes. They face charges that can result in fines up to S$100,000 and jail terms of up to 5 years.

images.alt_text: CHINA has issued 4.5 million tonnes of quotas for refined fuel exports, sources told Reuters on Tuesday (Jun 7), a top-up to the first issue for 2022 to ease high domestic inventories as demand was dented by Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex’s quarterly profit jumps 80% despite Ukraine war
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a 80% increase in quarterly profit to 760 million euros (S$1.1 billion) in the first quarter of its financial year to April 31, despite closing stores in Russia due to the Ukraine war. This marks a significant recovery from the 2021 financial year, which was heavily impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. Inditex had warned earlier that 2022 sales would be affected by the conflict, but the company's strong performance suggests it has adapted to the changing market.

images.alt_text: BRITAIN'S biggest sportswear retailer JD Sports and rival Elite Sports broke competition law by fixing the retail prices of certain branded clothing products of Rangers Football Club, UK's competition watchdog provisionally found on Tuesday (Jun 7).

Senior Walmart executives said on Friday (Jun 3) some suppliers have been responding to the largest US retailer’s efforts to lower prices despite their own struggles with high inflation, material and labour costs.

site_title: Singapore Pools further gives back to the community
summary: Singapore Pools' Giving Week, a 2-week initiative, took place from May 17 to 28, featuring 26 community events, including outreach programs for the elderly and engagements with underprivileged children. The company, established in 1968, has been involved in community initiatives since its inception, with over 150 staff volunteers participating in this year's events. The activities aimed to uplift lives and communities, with beneficiaries bonding with staff volunteers over meaningful activities, such as baking and Bingo sessions. The company's CEO emphasized the importance of giving back to the community and embracing the spirit of doing good.

images.alt_text: Staff volunteers from OCBC Bank on a ride out with seniors from Care Corner Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.24% on Wednesday, driven by a rise in tech firms amid speculation that China's crackdown on the sector may be ending. The Hang Seng Index rose to 22,014.59, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the region's markets, which have been impacted by China's regulatory changes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) is seen at the financial Central district in Hong Kong, China September 14, 2020. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: The one way to avoid greenwashing in ESG investing
summary: US President Joe Biden's executive orders to boost domestic solar manufacturing have boosted clean-energy funds, with solar stocks including Sunrun and Sunnova Energy International rising. The sector has been vulnerable to rising interest rates and commodity shortages, resulting in a 25% loss in value since the start of last year. A report by Util found that only 3 ETFs - Global X Hydrogen, Fidelity Clean Energy, and Invesco Solar - scored the highest in contributing to the UN's 17 Sustainable Development Goals, with the latter two holding companies with 50% of their revenue positively aligned with SDG 13.

site_title: A new way to choose your next book
summary: A new app, Tertulia, aims to replicate the serendipity of discovering new books in brick-and-mortar stores by harnessing online conversations about books. The app aggregates book discussions and recommendations from social media, reviews, and podcasts, generating personalized lists of five books daily. Users can browse lists of notable titles in different genres, ranked according to buzz rather than sales. Tertulia's founders hope to bring "word-of-mouth" recommendations online, addressing the industry's long-standing problem of online discovery. The app functions as a vast online bookstore, partnering with Ingram Content Group to fulfill and ship orders.

images.alt_text: A rare first edition and signed by the author copy of 'Harry Potter and the Philosophers Stone' by British author J K  Rowling, which is to be put up for auction at Christie's auction house in London.

site_title: Macron could lose absolute majority in Parliament vote: poll
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's party and its allies may lose their outright majority in the upcoming legislative elections, according to fresh polls. Support for a rival left-wing grouping, Nupes, is growing, with projections of winning 195-230 seats, up from 170-205 seats in a previous poll. Macron needs 289 seats to retain an absolute majority. If his party falls short, the government may struggle to pass laws and could be forced to form a coalition or pick up extra votes on a case-by-case basis, potentially leading to compromises and ministerial positions for rival parties.

images.alt_text: At long last, Réinventer Paris is beginning to bear fruit; several projects selected a few years ago are now underway.

site_title: In the oil market, the strong dollar is the world’s problem
summary: The US dollar's record high against other major currencies is creating a problem for countries importing oil, leading to balance-of-payments crises and economic strain. As the dollar strengthens, oil prices rise in local currencies, making it difficult for nations like Malawi and Sri Lanka to afford commodities. The broken dollar-oil price relationship is also benefiting the OPEC+ oil cartel, which can maintain higher prices. Experts warn that demand destruction is imminent due to the rising prices, which could have significant economic implications globally.

images.alt_text: The key to targetting Russia's oil resources is lower oil prices, not lower export volumes.

site_title: Beloved Japanese manga One Piece heads into final chapter
summary: Beloved Japanese manga One Piece is entering its final chapter after 25 years and 490 million copies sold worldwide. Creator Eiichiro Oda announced a month-long break to rearrange the series' structure and conclude the final chapter as soon as possible. One Piece first appeared in 1997 and has become a global cultural phenomenon, with a Guinness World Record for most copies published by a single author. The franchise's TV series is set to release its 1,000th episode, and a live-action adaptation is in the works.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund makes second US$1b bet on Swedish gaming
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has made its second $1 billion investment in the Swedish gaming industry, acquiring almost 100 million shares in Embracer Group, the second-largest owner in the company. This move follows a similar $1.05 billion acquisition in January and marks PIF's third investment in a Japanese games company. The deal, valued at 10.3 billion kronor ($1.49 billion), will give PIF an 8.1% stake in Embracer, with plans to set up a regional hub in Saudi Arabia and continue its acquisition strategy.

site_title: Shanghai working to revive confidence with foreign firms post Covid lockdown
summary: Shanghai officials are seeking to revive confidence among multinational firms by holding meetings and easing border requirements for overseas workers. The city plans to hold 20 meetings with foreign firms in key industries, including automobiles and biomedicine. The Shanghai government will no longer require official invitation letters for foreigners returning for work, addressing a major issue for expatriates. This move aims to encourage foreign investment and production resumption in the city, which was severely impacted by the Covid-19 lockdown.

images.alt_text: Residents line up for nucleic acid tests during lockdown in Shanghai, China, April 30, 2022. REUTERS

site_title: Grab launches GrabMaps as a new enterprise service
summary: Grab is launching GrabMaps, a new enterprise service offering mapping and location-based services to companies in South-east Asia, aiming to tap the $1 billion market. The service provides routing, estimated time of arrival, distance, and points of interest, and is expected to be self-sufficient by Q3 2022. GrabMaps will utilize real-time feedback and contributions from drivers and riders, and offers a software-as-a-service option for companies to build their own maps, including a proprietary map-making camera called Kartacam.

images.alt_text: As co-founder of multi-billion dollar ride-hailing and food delivery firm Grab, Tan Hooi Ling is already smashing stereotypes in tech but she's also trying to blaze a trail for the next generation of female entrepreneurs in the industry.

site_title: Fed hikes won’t sway US dollar unless pace much faster than forecast: BOJ’s Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that US dollar movements may not be significantly affected by US interest rate hikes unless the pace is faster than expected. The US Federal Reserve has made clear its intention to raise interest rates, which has already been priced into markets. Kuroda also expressed confidence that China's Covid-19 lockdowns will have a temporary impact on global economic growth, rather than a long-term effect.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recover at open
summary: European stock markets recovered slightly at the open on June 8, 2022, following overnight gains on Wall Street and Tokyo. The Frankfurt DAX index rose 0.2% to 14,579.08 points, while the Paris CAC 40 edged up 0.1% to 6,505.83. The London FTSE 100 index remained steady at 7,601.16 points.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades Valuetronics to ‘neutral’ but expects continued headwinds
summary: RHB Research upgraded Valuetronics to "neutral" from "sell", citing a recovering outlook despite ongoing headwinds from supply chain and component shortages. The research house maintains its target price of S$0.53, but remains cautious of pressure on gross profit margin. Analysts expect the industrial and commercial electronics segment to rebound in 2023, contributing positively to the group's profitability. Valuetronics' FY2022 results exceeded expectations, and the company is preparing for trial production with newly-acquired customers.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Research expects margins for electronics manufacturing services provider Valuetronics Holdings will remain weak amid headwinds from supply chain disruptions and macroeconomic uncertainties.
Valuetronics said the severe shortages of certain key electronic components had impacted the company’s ability to meet orders in the full-year period.

site_title: From the Big Short to the Big Scam
summary: Cryptocurrencies, introduced in 2009, have yet to find significant real-world uses despite their large market value and widespread adoption. The Federal Trade Commission reports that cryptocurrency is a popular target for scammers, with around $1 billion in losses since 2021. Stablecoins, designed to be a more stable alternative to traditional currencies, are also questioned for their legitimacy. Economists argue that stablecoins resemble 19th-century banks, which often failed due to bad investments. The author, Paul Krugman, suggests that the "incredulity factor" may be at play, making it difficult to see the value in cryptocurrencies, leading to a comparison between the housing bubble and the current crypto market, labeling it the "Big Scam".

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat as investors await China, US economic data
summary: South Korean shares ended flat at 2,626.15, reversing early gains as investors awaited China and US economic data. China's vice-commerce minister cited uncertainty and pressure due to logistics and raw material issues, while South Korea's economy grew 0.6% in the first quarter. Foreigners were net sellers of 103.3 billion won worth of shares, and the Korean won strengthened.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi ended 44.31 points, or 1.66 per cent, lower at 2,626.34.

site_title: Garuda administrators recognise 120.5t rupiah of claims
summary: Garuda Indonesia's administrators have acknowledged claims worth 120.5 trillion rupiah (S$11.4 billion) as the airline seeks to restructure its debts. The largest claim comes from Airbus at over 7.8 trillion rupiah. The figures are ahead of a scheduled court date on June 9 to present a restructuring plan, with a final vote on the proposal set for later this month. The airline's debts are largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with operations currently operating at 20% of pre-pandemic capacity.

images.alt_text: After Garuda and its creditors reached an agreement on the US$9.8 billion debt recast, the government will inject 7.5 trillion rupiah (S$714.6 million) through the first rights issue.

site_title: SIA to sell green fuel credits from July
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will start selling green fuel credits from July, allowing passengers and freight forwarders to reduce their carbon footprint. The credits are produced from used cooking oil and animal fat from food-industry waste by Neste, in partnership with SIA and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. Freight forwarders can sell the credits to their clients to reduce emissions from their business operations, promoting the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in the Republic. This initiative aims to encourage the adoption of greener fuel options in the aviation industry.

summary: Oceanus Group, a mainboard-listed seafood supplier, saw its trading volume surge with 182.5 million shares changing hands on Wednesday, June 8. This prompted a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for "unusual volume movements." The counter closed 4.6% lower at S$0.021, following a 2.5-month high of S$0.023 on Tuesday. Oceanus denied any unannounced information or reasons for the trading, stating it was not aware of any unusual activity. The Singapore Exchange Regulation asked the company to confirm its compliance with listing rules.

site_title: Stablecoin market shrank between end-March and end-May amid Terra collapse: Fitch Ratings
summary: The stablecoin market shrank between end-March and end-May due to the collapse of algorithmic stablecoin TerraUSD, according to a report by Fitch Ratings. TerraUSD's collapse, caused by a failure in its algorithmic mechanism pegging its value to the US dollar, had a significant impact on the stablecoin market. site_title: Citi to hire 3,000 staff for institutional business in Asia
summary: Citi plans to hire approximately 3,000 new staff for its institutional business in Asia, primarily in Hong Kong, Singapore, India, South Korea, China, and Australia. The new recruits will work in investment, corporate, and commercial banking roles. This move comes as the bank aims to grow client assets in Asia by $150 billion by 2025, with existing wealth assets valued at $200 billion. The hiring is part of Citi's expansion strategy in the region, which has been a key focus for the bank for 120 years.

images.alt_text: Citigroup plans to hire more than 4,000 tech staff to help move its institutional clients online in the wake of the pandemic.

site_title: Global food shock is getting tougher to stomach
summary: A worsening global food shock, driven by supply chain disruptions and escalating prices, is expected to linger through 2024 due to factors such as fertilizer shortages, export controls, and disrupted global trade. The crisis, exacerbated by the Russia-Ukraine war, is likely to disproportionately affect low- and low-to-middle income countries. Rising food prices, which are 22.8% higher than last year, are making staple foods unaffordable, despite concerns that the problems are not due to inadequate supply. The world's population is projected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, making sustainable food production imperative to address climate issues.

Rising food and energy prices, in part sparked by the war in Ukraine, could kill millions both directly and indirectly, Peter Sands, the executive director of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria, said.
UK consumers are being urged to brace for inflation getting worse before it gets better as soaring costs force retailers to keep raising prices.

World food prices fell slightly for the second consecutive month in May but wheat prices rose again as Russia’s war in Ukraine rages on and India banned exports of the commodity, a UN agency said Friday.

site_title: Reserve Bank of India raises key lending rate as expected, comments in focus
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) raised its key lending rate by 50 basis points to 4.90% on June 8, as expected, to curb persistently high inflation. This is the second hike in as many months, aiming to return monetary conditions to pre-pandemic levels. Analysts expect the RBI to reduce liquidity, reinforcing its fight against inflation. The Standing Deposit Facility rate and Marginal Standing Facility Rate were also adjusted higher by 50 basis points.

site_title: Anger, praise in China after Eileen Gu reveals US Olympic bid role
summary: Eileen Gu, a Chinese freestyle skier born in California to an American father and Chinese mother, has announced she will be an ambassador for Salt Lake City's Winter Olympics bid in 2030 or 2034. This move has sparked mixed reactions in China, with some questioning her motivation for competing for China and others praising her "international influence as a Chinese athlete". Gu's decision also comes amid tensions between Beijing and Washington, where the US led a diplomatic boycott of the Beijing Games.

site_title: Four in 10 limited partners report net annual returns of over 16% across PE portfolios: report
summary: A new survey by Coller Capital found that 4 in 10 limited partners in private equity (PE) portfolios report net annual returns of over 16% across their portfolios, a record high since 2004. More than half of LPs saw over 16% returns from Asia-Pacific venture investments, while nearly 40% achieved similar returns from buyout investments. Most LPs also reported outperforming their public equity holdings, with 70% saying their PE portfolios outperformed public equity since the global financial crisis.

summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB has reiterated its "overweight" rating on Singapore's property sector, citing the release of the H2 2022 Government Land Sale (GLS) programme, which saw 14 sites released, a 12.5% increase from H1. Analysts expect developers to replenish their landholdings and extend their development income visibility, with private home prices projected to rise by up to 5% in 2022. CGS-CIMB has also maintained its "add" calls and target prices on companies such as CapitaLand Investment, City Developments, and UOL Group.

site_title: US cuts to China tariffs may boost yuan 1.2% or more: Goldman
summary: US may cut tariffs on Chinese goods, potentially boosting the yuan by 1.2% or more, according to Goldman Sachs economists. Rolling back tariffs could reduce US inflation and push the yuan up if all consumer products are exempted. However, major tariff reductions are unlikely due to the US risk of appearing "soft" on China ahead of midterm elections. The economic impact of partial tariff reductions is expected to be "modest," with a potential boost to China's real GDP growth of less than 0.5 percentage point.

site_title: Solana Ventures raises fund to help battered Korean crypto scene
summary: Solana Ventures has launched a $100 million investment and grant fund to support crypto projects in South Korea, particularly those based on the Solana blockchain. The fund aims to help projects affected by the Terra blockchain collapse and also invest in non-fungible token and decentralized finance projects, focusing on the virtual gaming industry. The move seeks to revitalize the struggling Solana blockchain, which has faced outages and a market downturn.

site_title: Australian regulator sues Airbnb for allegedly misleading customers on pricing
summary: Australia's competition regulator sued Airbnb for allegedly misleading customers on pricing by displaying US dollar prices without local currency clarification. The ACCC claims Airbnb misled consumers from January 2018 to August 2021, stating prices were displayed in US dollars due to user selection, when often it was not the case. The regulator seeks pecuniary penalties and compensation for those misled, citing consumers paying higher prices and incurring additional currency conversion fees.

site_title: Credit Suisse extends losing streak with expected quarterly loss
summary: Credit Suisse Group expects a loss at the groupwide and investment bank levels in the second quarter due to challenging market conditions and weak customer flows. The bank attributed the expected loss to ongoing client deleveraging, low capital markets issuance, and widening credit spreads. CEO Thomas Gottstein faces pressure after a string of setbacks, including a US$5.5 billion hit from Archegos and the collapse of partner Greensill Capital. The bank aims to reduce risk at the investment bank while shifting resources to wealth management and accelerating cost initiatives.

site_title: Ex-Citadel analyst gets over 4 years in prison for hedge fund Covid scam
summary: A former Citadel analyst, Gregory Blotnick, was sentenced to over 4 years in federal prison for scamming US$4.6 million in Covid relief loans. Blotnick, 35, pleaded guilty to submitting 21 fraudulent loan applications and will pay US$4.6 million in restitution. He was ordered to spend 51 months behind bars and had previously accepted full responsibility for his actions. The scheme involved falsifying information about his hedge fund, Brattle Street Capital LLC, and losing more than US$3 million in unsuccessful stock trades.

site_title: UK annual house prices slow for third month in a row: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 10.5% annually in May, the smallest increase since January, for a third consecutive month. Despite a shortage of homes for sale, a tightening cost-of-living squeeze and inflation approaching 10%, Halifax attributes the slowdown to cooling demand and decreasing mortgage activity. Mortgage approvals dropped in April, and the Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates again next week. A slowdown in the housing market is likely, with Halifax suggesting the market may be past its peak sellers' market.

site_title: Japan crypto exchanges may scrap system for screening tokens: sources
summary: Japan's cryptocurrency exchange governing body, the Japan Virtual and Crypto assets Exchange Association (JVCEA), is in talks to abolish strict rules for listing digital tokens. The proposed change would allow local exchanges to list cryptocurrencies without the JVCEA's screening process, focusing on policing assets once listed. The move could liberalize Japan's market and benefit foreign newcomers, but an easing of rules wouldn't apply to initial coin offerings. A final decision is expected by the end of the year, with a government panel criticizing the current listing process for being too time-consuming.

site_title: South Korea’s Q1 GDP growth revised slightly down to 0.6%
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.6% in Q1, slightly lower than the initial estimate of 0.7%. This is a slight revision from the 3.0% growth over the previous year. The country's GDP growth for 2021 was revised to 4.1%, the fastest in 11 years, up from the previously announced 4.0%. The downward revision follows an upward adjustment in the final quarter of 2021 to 1.3% from 1.2%.

site_title: StarHub’s contract-free EPL plan priced from S$19.99 a month
summary: StarHub has launched a contract-free English Premier League (EPL) plan called Premier+, priced from S$19.99 a month for those with other StarHub plans, and S$34.99 a month for others. The service, available from June 9, offers 380 live matches per season, accessible from 5 registered devices and 2 simultaneous streams. There is no contract lock-in, and fans can cancel and rejoin whenever they want. This marks a first for Singapore, with the goal of making the EPL more accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: TSMC expects 30% sales rise despite global economic ructions
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) expects a 30% sales rise in 2022, despite global economic uncertainty, chairman Mark Liu announced at the company's annual shareholder meeting. The company's revenue growth is expected to accelerate from 24.9% in 2021, with gross margins potentially reaching 58%. TSMC cited strong demand for electric vehicles and other areas as a factor in its optimism, while playing down the impact of inflation on its business.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS initiates ‘buy’ on BRC Asia with S$2.40 target
summary: DBS Group Research initiated coverage on BRC Asia with a "buy" call and a target price of S$2.40, citing the company's strong sales volume growth, higher market share, and dominant position in the construction industry. The research house projects 16% higher rebar sales volumes and 40% growth in revenue for BRC in 2022, driven by a construction sector recovery. DBS forecasts BRC's gross margins to increase to 8.7% in 2022-2024, driven by cost synergies.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street rally, boosted by China hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on June 8, driven by a Wall Street rally and hopes for China's economic reopening. Stocks in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets rose as Beijing relaxed Covid-19 lockdown measures. Key firms like Alibaba, Netease, and Tencent surged, with the Hang Seng Index climbing over 1%. Analysts warn of near-term volatility due to inflation, interest rates, and the Ukraine war, but see a positive signal from China's policy support. The market's outlook remains cautiously optimistic, with a focus on China's economic recovery.

site_title: Rich nations may fork out billions to wean Indonesia off coal
summary: Indonesia, the world's second-biggest coal producer, is seeking billions of dollars in funding to transition away from coal and achieve carbon neutrality. Rich nations, including the US and Europe, are offering financial aid and assistance in exchange for Indonesia's commitment to phase out coal power. The Indonesian government has set a goal to shut all coal-power plants by 2055 and rely on renewable energy by 2060. However, the transition will require significant investment, estimated at $150-$200 billion annually until 2030, and may face challenges due to the country's monopoly power distributor, which benefits from cheap coal prices.

summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have revised their forecasts, predicting 4.8% growth in the second quarter, up from 3.7% in Q1, and 3.8% full-year GDP growth. They expect headline inflation to hit 5% and core inflation to reach 3.4% for the full year. This is in line with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's forecast range.
