site_title: Ravi Menon to chair board of Apac network helping financial institutions reach net zero
summary: Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, will chair the advisory board of the Asia-Pacific network of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ), supporting financial institutions' net-zero transition. The advisory board consists of leaders from institutions like the Asian Development Bank, Singapore Exchange, and South Korea's KB Financial Group. The network aims to provide guidance, advice, and knowledge-sharing on net-zero opportunities and challenges, with GFANZ director Yuki Yasui leading the Apac network.

site_title: These are the world’s 20 most expensive cities for expats
summary: Hong Kong is the world's most expensive city to live in as an expat for the second year in a row, according to a new study by ECA International. The city's strong currency and rising prices, particularly in housing and petrol, contributed to its top spot. New York and Geneva took second and third place, with London and Tokyo rounding out the top 5. Petrol prices increased by 37% globally, and Beirut recorded a 1,128% increase, while Turkish cities fell in ranking due to a weakening currency.

site_title: Chinese carmaker joins SpaceX in low-earth-orbit satellite race
summary: Chinese carmaker Geely's unit, Geespace, has launched its first satellites into low-earth orbit, with plans to deploy a network of 72 satellites by 2025 and 168 by the end of the decade. The satellites will help Geely and other companies access and transmit data for autonomous driving. Geespace's ambitions are smaller than those of SpaceX, which has over 2,000 satellites in orbit, and focus on providing a travel experience for users, rather than internet access. Geespace aims to collaborate with other industries and make its network open to other brands.

site_title: Thailand tourism sector likely to rebound from 2022 amid higher tourist arrivals
summary: Thailand's tourism sector is expected to rebound in 2022 and 2023 with 7 million and 15 million tourist arrivals, respectively, driven by falling Covid-19 infections and relaxed entry rules. Analysts, including CGS-CIMB and Maybank, upgraded their calls on the sector to "positive" and "neutral", citing higher hotel occupancy rates and a campaign by the Thai government to promote tourism. Foreign tourists are also expected to benefit from instant approval and exemption from mandatory quarantine.

site_title: Western Digital reviewing alternatives after Elliott's push to split
summary: Western Digital is reviewing strategic alternatives, including splitting its flash-memory and HDD businesses, following Elliott Management's push. Elliott, which owns 6% of Western Digital, offered over $1 billion of incremental equity capital for the flash business at an enterprise value of $17 billion to $20 billion. The company aims to optimize the value of its businesses through this process, with Elliott prepared to provide additional capital to help realize the full value of both businesses.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following Wall Street rallies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.61%, and the Topix index increased 0.45%, driven by a cheap yen supporting exporters.

site_title: Soaring fuel prices heighten the risk of stalling aviation recovery
summary: High fuel prices are heightening the risk of stalling the aviation industry's recovery. Jet fuel prices have more than doubled to US$158 a barrel, making it difficult for airlines to turn a profit. Emirates has levied fuel surcharges on air tickets, and many other airlines have followed suit. The International Air Transport Association estimates that fuel prices could impact the industry's total fuel bill by US$122.8 billion in 2022. The high fuel costs could dampen demand from discretionary travel and hurt airlines' profitability, especially as they are still repairing their debt-laden balance sheets.

site_title: BlockFi looks to raise new cash at reduced US$1b valuation: sources
summary: BlockFi, a cryptocurrency lending platform, is seeking new funding to value the company at approximately $1 billion, down from its previous $3 billion valuation. The firm may raise around $100 million, with investors including Bain Capital Ventures, DST Global, and Peter Thiel's Valar Ventures. The move comes as the company faces a broad-based selloff in digital assets, following other crypto businesses that have laid off staff or frozen hiring. BlockFi has also agreed to pay $100 million to the US Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations of selling a crypto lending product as an unregistered security.

site_title: PayPal allows transfer of crypto to external wallets
summary: PayPal has announced it will allow users to transfer cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin, to external wallets. The feature will be available to select US users starting Tuesday, with a rollout to all eligible US customers in the coming months. This comes nearly two years after PayPal initially opened its platform to digital currencies. Users had been requesting the new feature, and the company's shares rose 0.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Gold investors in wait-and-see mode before US CPI data
summary: Gold prices were little changed on Wednesday as investors awaited the US inflation report for further cues on the economy. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,850.41 per ounce, while US gold futures added 0.1% to $1,853.30. The World Bank slashed its global growth forecast to 2.9% for 2022 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expects inflation to remain high, and the Biden administration may increase its inflation forecast.

images.alt_text: Gold prices extended losses for a third straight session on Tuesday, as expectations of interest rate hikes in the United States and Europe dulled bullion's demand.

site_title: Ray Dalio says central banks to cut rates in 2024
summary: Billionaire hedge fund founder Ray Dalio predicts that central banks will cut interest rates in 2024 due to a structural inflation situation that could lead to stagflation. This comes as markets are already pricing in rate cuts in the US and other developed economies. The World Bank has warned that even if a global recession is averted, stagflation may endure for several years. Dalio's forecast is based on the idea that a tightening mode will cause corrections and downward moves in financial assets, forcing central banks to ease again around the next presidential elections in 2024.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Wednesday, with a slight dip of 0.02 points to 3,231.52. The index saw gains outnumber losses 84 to 45, with Procurri being the top traded counter. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS down 0.1% and OCBC falling 0.5%. This follows a mixed global market session, with the US stocks finishing higher despite a World Bank warning on global growth and inflation.

site_title: 5 questions with Indonesia’s cross-economy veteran Pandu Sjahrir
summary: Indonesia's cross-economy veteran Pandu Sjahrir shares insights on his journey and "no asshole" rule. He began his career as an investment banker, transitioning to private equity and then into technology investing. Currently, he's focusing on energy transition and digital localization, having shifted TBS Energi Utama from coal to renewable energy. Sjahrir advises younger investors to prioritize team dynamics over individual founders and to maintain humility and kindness in the investment business. He also shares his biggest setbacks, including being fired and struggling to establish his investment firm. Sjahrir believes unicorns should list on their domestic exchanges to tap into local investors and capitalize on regional trends.

site_title: ST Telemedia to establish second data centre in South Korea, backed by Samsung
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) plans to establish a second data centre site in Seoul, South Korea, backed by Samsung SRA Asset Management. The 31,205 sqm facility will deliver 30 megawatts of IT power and is strategically located near substations, telecommunications, and logistics hubs. The project is expected to be ready for service in H1 2025, with STT GDC completing the remaining DC fitouts. The expansion is seen as a "natural next step" to meet growing customer demand for complex digital infrastructure services.

site_title: Food shortages are next global health crisis: expert
summary: A global health expert warns that rising food and energy prices, linked to the war in Ukraine, could kill millions, posing a similar threat to the Covid-19 pandemic. Peter Sands, executive director of the Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria, says food shortages can lead to both direct and indirect deaths, primarily through malnutrition. He urges investment in strengthening health systems to prepare for the repercussions of food shortages, which is part of the Global Fund's remit, as it aims to raise $18 billion for 2024-2026.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.19% to 21,788.89, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The gains were attributed to tech firms, which saw significant buying interest amid hopes that a China-led crackdown on the sector may be coming to an end. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also showed slight gains, while US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as miners, energy stocks boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, snapping a two-session losing streak, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks. The Reserve Bank of Australia's 50-basis-point interest rate hike, the largest in 22 years, also contributed to the market's rebound. The metals and mining index jumped 2%, led by gains from BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group. Energy stocks also rose 2.2%, while gold stocks increased 1.9%. However, financials dropped 1.5%, with the "Big Four" banks losing between 0.9% and 2.1%.

site_title: Out of the frying pan: Indonesians pay price of cooking oil crisis
summary: Indonesia is experiencing a cooking oil crisis, with prices skyrocketing to 20,100 rupiah per liter, forcing millions of consumers and small business owners to close their shops. The crisis began after Russian troops invaded Ukraine, disrupting global grain and sunflower seed markets. The Indonesian government has issued export permits for 302,000 tonnes of palm oil, but prices remain high, particularly in rural areas. Small business owners, like Liesye Setiana, have been forced to lay off employees and raise prices, leaving many struggling to afford staple goods, including school fees for her children.

site_title: China export boom fades as spending shifts, cheaper rivals gain
summary: China's export boom has fizzled out as consumers in major markets cut spending due to Covid lockdowns and soaring inflation. Despite a temporary boost from Shanghai's reopening, exports are likely to grow just 1.6% this year, down from a 30% surge in 2021. The decline is attributed to a shift in supply chains to cheaper manufacturing in South-east Asia, elevated raw material prices, and freight rates. Policymakers are concerned about the impact on economic growth, with Beijing's target of 5.5% growth further out of reach.

site_title: Japan’s Q1 GDP revised up to 0.5% annualised contraction
summary: Japan's economy shrank 0.5% annually in the first quarter, revised from an initial estimate of 1.0% contraction. Consumption remained resilient despite resurgent Covid-19 infections. On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP fell 0.1%, slightly better than the initial minus 0.2% reading. The revised figure met economists' median forecast.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, PSC Corp, Raffles Education

summary: Affirm CEO Max Levchin expressed confidence in his company's growth despite Apple's upcoming buy now, pay later service. Levchin stated that Affirm's longer-term plans (6 weeks to 60 months) and more extensive options provide a competitive advantage. Levchin believes there is room for growth for all involved and that Apple's service creates a "nice tailwind" for Affirm.

summary: Billionaires behind food-delivery companies like DoorDash and Just Eat Takeaway.com have seen their fortunes dwindle as the pandemic recedes and investors shift focus to cost-cutting. site_title: Battle in Ukraine’s east rages as Zelenskiy vows to retake territory
summary: Ukrainian forces are struggling to hold their ground in the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk, with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy vowing to retake territory from Russia. The battle, part of a broader conflict in Ukraine's Donbas region, has left significant damage and killed thousands. Zelenskiy pledged to respond in kind to Russia's advances, while the US and other countries impose sanctions on Moscow and provide financial aid to Ukraine. The conflict has created a global food crisis, with Ukraine's Black Sea ports blocked by Russia, and the situation remains dire for civilians caught in the crossfire.

site_title: Canada issues monkeypox-related travel notice, warns of potential delays returning home
summary: Canada has issued a level 2 travel notice for over 30 countries where monkeypox has been reported, advising travellers to take precautions and potential delays returning home if infected. The Public Health Agency of Canada warns that travellers may experience limited access to healthcare and delays in returning home. Canada has confirmed 81 cases of monkeypox, mostly in Quebec, and the disease is mostly found in west and central Africa.

site_title: Is taxing shipping really the best way to net zero?
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is considering a global carbon tax on bunker fuel to incentivize lower-carbon emitting fuel options, but shipping industry representatives, the Global Shippers Forum, warn that this could lead to higher freight costs for shippers. The forum argues that the proposed carbon tax will be passed on to shippers, potentially suppressing demand for world trade and increasing inflationary pressures. However, the author suggests that achieving net zero will require increased costs across the supply chain, and regulatory approaches have been effective in the past, such as the low sulphur fuel regulations.

site_title: EU sets better gender balance in European corporate boards
summary: The European Union has agreed on a rule requiring listed companies to fill at least 40% of non-executive board seats with the underrepresented gender by 2026. Companies with quotas in both executive and non-executive boards must meet a 33% target. Those that fall short must use transparent and gender-neutral criteria to fix the issue. The EU aims to address the current imbalance, where only 31.3% of women sit on EU company boards, with 69% of board members being men.

site_title: UK travel-chaos row escalates as airlines chief slams minister
summary: UK Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has faced criticism from airline lobbyist Willie Walsh, who described him as "absolutely useless" in addressing the coronavirus crisis. Walsh, director-general of the International Air Transport Association, blamed the government for not knowing what it was talking about when it came to aviation. The UK government has provided £8 billion in support to the industry, but Walsh and other airline executives are concerned about staffing shortages, management missteps, and the impact on travel demand. A 3-day rail strike by 50,000 workers is also expected to disrupt travel.

images.alt_text: Passengers rest on benches at Heathrow airport in London;   Airports across Europe have struggled to cope with a post-pandemic rebound in demand, but British airports have been particularly hit by major disruption over the past week.

site_title: Raffles Education to issue convertible bonds, placement to repay loans
summary: RAFFLES Education is issuing S$26.2 million in convertible bonds to repay existing loans and for general working capital. The 5-year bonds will bear a 6% coupon and are priced at S$0.85, offering a 9.8% discount to the security's closing price. A S$17.9 million placement in convertible bonds will also be issued in a bought deal arrangement with UOB Kay Hian Holdings. The company's board of directors expects the proceeds to supplement its cash flow and meet ongoing financial obligations.

site_title: Amazon is closing its gig economy delivery service in Germany
summary: Amazon is closing its gig economy delivery service, Amazon Flex, in Germany, a move that affects around 1,000 drivers. The company cited a shift towards a more formal delivery network, relying on small startups, as the reason for the decision. Amazon is offering a one-time payment to Flex drivers and encouraging them to join one of hundreds of German Delivery Service Partners. Despite this, Amazon's sales in Germany totalled $37 billion in 2021, up 26% from the prior year.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com shares rose on Monday, in the first trading session following a 20-for-1 stock split, the e-commerce company's first such move in more than 2 decades.

site_title: Oil settles up 1% on tight supply, US crude at 13-week high
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, with US crude reaching a 13-week high, driven by supply concerns, including no nuclear deal with Iran and lockdown relaxations in China. Brent futures settled at $120.57 a barrel, its highest since May 31, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 91 cents to $119.41. Analysts expect a drop in US crude inventories, which could further support prices, and a potential nuclear deal with Iran could add 1 million barrels per day of global oil supply.

site_title: European gas extends losses amid easing demand, ample LNG supply
summary: European natural gas prices declined for a fifth day, easing to 79.608 euros (S$117) a megawatt-hour, amid ample liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports and reduced demand. European storage sites are now almost 50% full, within a 5-year average, with supplies from Russia and Norway remaining relatively robust despite disruptions. Disputes over payment terms with Russia appear to be resolved, and analysts expect storage facilities to be full by the end of summer, barring significant disruptions. Volatility remains, but current supply and demand dynamics are driving the softness in prices.

images.alt_text: As the EU stalls on a gas ban, Russia’s state giant Gazprom has already begun cutting off European countries that have refused to pay for their gas in roubles.

site_title: IMF urges countries to support vulnerable, avoid blanket subsidies as food, fuel prices soar
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urges countries to target aid to vulnerable citizens rather than issue blanket subsidies to soften the impact of soaring food and fuel prices, triggered by the war in Ukraine. Over half of 134 surveyed countries have introduced subsidies or tax cuts, but the IMF advises that this approach can add to public finances. Policymakers should allow high global prices to pass through to the domestic economy while protecting vulnerable households, making this approach less costly.

site_title: South Korea truckers go on strike at ports as fuel costs soar
summary: Thousands of truck drivers in South Korea have gone on strike at ports and container depots, threatening to slow exports of goods. The strike, held by the Korean Public Service and Transport Workers' Union, is in protest of a planned removal of a minimum wage calculation scheme based on operating costs. With soaring fuel prices, the strike's impact is already being felt, and if it continues, it could slow exports of steel, plastics, and consumer goods. The strike affects ports in Busan, Pyeongtaek, and Uiwang, and is part of a global supply chain struggling to recover from lockdowns and war.

site_title: How to regulate the crypto world: market players offer myriad solutions but little concurrence
summary: Singapore regulators are strengthening investor protection amid the ongoing cryptocurrency rout, triggered by the collapse of TerraUSD. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is considering regulations on exchanges, including conducting due diligence on listed coins and tokens, mandating customer asset isolation, and introducing insider dealing rules. Other proposed measures include suitability tests for retail customers, a "kill switch" mechanism for account freezing, and a platform for user complaints. Industry stakeholders suggest the need for consistent global regulations to prevent market manipulation and protect investors, with some warning that overly restrictive regulations could stifle innovation.

site_title: Merkel defends Russia legacy, says ‘nothing to apologise for’
summary: Former German Chancellor Angela Merkel defended her policy of detente towards Russia, saying she had "nothing to apologize for" despite the Ukraine war casting a pall on her legacy. Merkel recalled her support for economic sanctions and efforts to keep the Minsk peace process alive, but acknowledged the February 24 invasion of Ukraine marked a "turning point." She criticized Putin's actions as "brutal" and illegal, but argued that dealing with Russia was necessary due to its size and influence. Merkel insisted that finding a way to co-exist despite differences was key.

site_title: Alphabet's Waymo, Uber Freight in deal for future self-driving trucks
summary: Waymo, the self-driving trucking unit of Alphabet, and Uber Freight have signed a long-term strategic partnership to allow future Waymo customers to deploy autonomous trucks more efficiently. The partnership will enable the use of Uber Freight's software to connect truckers with shippers and reduce shipping costs. No timeline was provided for when the partnership could be used by paying customers, and financial details were not disclosed. This marks the latest in a series of company tie-ups in the autonomous trucking space as technology companies race to commercialize their products.

site_title: Thailand’s Minor International keen on Asean expansion, with KL on its radar
summary: Minor International, a Thai hospitality operator, is expanding its regional footprint in Southeast Asia. The company is eyeing Kuala Lumpur, Manila, and Jakarta for its near-term expansion plans, with a focus on partnering with local companies. Minor Hotels aims to build a 4-star or 5-star business hotel with around 200 rooms in Kuala Lumpur, while exploring opportunities in Manila and Jakarta. This expansion is driven by the resumption of international travel and the company's goal to increase its presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Holiday house hunting
Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan had a meeting with Malaysian prime minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob (left) in Putrajaya on May 18, 2022.

site_title: US: Stocks rise, shrugging off gloomy World Bank outlook
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, shrugging off a World Bank warning that cut its global growth estimate to 2.9%, citing the impact of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Despite inflation concerns and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's caution, investors viewed the US economic policies as stable, leading to gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average (0.8%), S&P 500 (1.0%), and Nasdaq Composite Index (0.9%).

site_title: Singapore equities may still gain as Fed steps up pace of rate hikes
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to step up the pace of interest rate hikes, potentially leading to higher rates in Singapore. This may result in a slowdown in economic activity, negatively impacting equity prices, particularly for riskier assets. However, Singapore's equity market may still outperform due to its value-oriented sectors, such as financials and real estate investment trusts, which tend to thrive in a higher interest rate environment. Investors may rotate into Singapore equities as a tactical allocation to shelter from rising rates in growth stocks.

images.alt_text: “Top Gun: Maverick” was a very much welcomed sequel. By contrast, the uncertainties of the early 1980s is clearly not a welcome resurrection.

site_title: US senators unveil bill to regulate cryptocurrency
summary: US Senators Cynthia Lummis and Kirsten Gillibrand introduced a bipartisan bill to regulate cryptocurrency, handing oversight to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC). The bill establishes rules for "stablecoins" and aims to provide certainty and consumer protections. It is seen as a starting point for future debates, despite its uncertain passage this session of Congress. The measure is intended to classify most crypto products as commodities, rather than securities, which would simplify regulation.

site_title: Are capital markets flying in the danger zone?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is navigating a narrow path to control inflation while maintaining economic growth above zero. Underestimating the economy could lead to above-target inflation, tighter monetary policy, and lower stock markets, while overestimating it may result in a recession and lower interest rates. The ongoing war in Ukraine and China's lockdown policies are also contributing to uncertainty in commodity markets and global supply chains.

images.alt_text: Movie still: Top Gun: Maverick

site_title: Market bottom: Are we there yet?
summary: The article discusses the market's potential bottom, with investors waiting for a falling market to stabilize. A head and shoulder reversal pattern on the S&P 500 chart suggests the market may not fall further, with a potential target near 3,650. However, a similar pattern in 2008 resulted in a false breakout rally, and the authors predict a repeat of this scenario. Meanwhile, China's economic management has taken steps to improve market liquidity, including decisions on ETFs and the bond market, which could signal a developing opportunity for investors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A maze of crude oil pipes and valves is pictured during a tour by the Department of Energy at the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Freeport, Texas, U.S. June 9, 2016.  REUTERS/Richard Carson//File Photo

site_title: Israel mainly to blame for conflict: UN report
summary: A UN report blames Israel for the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, citing the country's occupation and discrimination against Palestinians as the main causes of violence. The report, which was released after a 12-month investigation, found that Israel has "no intention" of ending its occupation and that past recommendations for accountability have been largely ignored. The report's lead investigator, Navi Pillay, stated that the lack of implementation and sense of impunity are key factors in the conflict's recurrence, and that Israel's actions are "an indicator of the asymmetrical nature of the conflict."

images.alt_text: Abbas slams West's 'double standards' on Ukraine, Palestinians

site_title: ADDX is first Singapore financial institution to recognise crypto assets of accredited investors
summary: PRIVATE market exchange ADDX has become the first Singapore financial institution to consider cryptocurrency assets in verifying accredited investors. ADDX will recognize Bitcoin, Ether, and USD Coin, applying a 50% discount rate for Bitcoin and Ether, and a 10% discount rate for USD Coin, to calculate investors' holdings. This move aims to enable crypto investors to diversify into regulated private markets, which are considered more stable. The recognition of cryptocurrencies as part of investors' portfolios may open up more investment opportunities for individuals.

images.alt_text: ADDX chief executive Choo Oi Yee estimates that at any given point, there could be trillions of dollars stuck in a system that is not being used productively.

site_title: Europe: Growth concerns weigh on shares; retail stocks fall
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% on Tuesday, with retail stocks down 0.9% after Target's quarterly margin forecast was slashed for the second time in less than a month. Investors worry about economic growth due to central banks' aggressive monetary policy tightening to combat rising inflation. The European Central Bank is set to meet this week, and investors await US inflation data, which may lead to further interest rate hikes. Slowing economic growth and weakening demand also affected German industrial orders, and individual stocks like Biffa and SAS declined.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows most on record on muted China imports
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed by the most on record in April, falling to $87.1 billion, due to a drop in Chinese imports amid COVID-19 lockdowns. Factory activity in China, which has been restricted, fell to its lowest level since February 2020. Exports climbed, but decades-high inflation is expected to weigh on trade this year, with the World Trade Organisation cutting its forecast for global merchandise volumes.

site_title: 4,477 new Covid-19 cases reported in Singapore, more than double that of Monday
summary: Singapore reported 4,477 new Covid-19 cases on June 7, more than double the 2,162 cases on Monday, with a week-on-week infection ratio of 0.87. The number of hospitalised cases rose to 267, with 8 in intensive care and 22 requiring oxygen support. One death was also reported, bringing the total to 1,394 deaths. The country has recorded 1,325,623 Covid-19 cases.

site_title: What’s next for IT built for Covid tracing?
summary: Organisations can repurpose Covid-19 contact tracing tools to support post-pandemic work environments, leveraging existing infrastructure to improve business functionality. With a bit of tweaking, these tools can be adapted to enhance remote connectivity, employee wellbeing, and data analytics. Agility is crucial in this process, allowing organisations to view technology as flexible and elastic, rather than rigid and purpose-built. By adopting cloud-based operating models and modernising infrastructure, organisations can ensure they remain agile and prepared to respond to the ever-changing operational landscape.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong recounted how the airline group's operating numbers plunged when the pandemic began.

site_title: IBM winding down Russian operation, laying off employees: memo
summary: IBM is winding down its business in Russia and laying off employees, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February. The company, led by CEO Arvind Krishna, made the decision due to escalating sanctions and uncertainty about the country's long-term ramifications. Several hundred IBM employees in Russia will be affected, and the company will provide support and make their transition as orderly as possible. This move follows many other companies, including hundreds of others, in suspending or exiting their business in Russia.

site_title: IHH Healthcare divests education arm for RM1.35b
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest hospital group, is selling its medical education arm International Medical University (IMU) for RM1.35 billion to a consortium of investors led by The Rise Fund and the Hong Leong Group. The sale includes a hospital under construction, and IMU's other units, such as a private medical university and a dialysis centre, will be retained by IHH. The transaction is expected to complete by the first quarter of 2023, allowing IHH to focus on strengthening healthcare operations and investing in new growth.

images.alt_text: Dr Kelvin Loh, Managing Director and CEO of IHH Healthcare, in his office on May 11, 2021.
TPG nears US$300m deal to buy IHH's education arm

site_title: Indian officials asked to exercise caution on religious issues after Islamic nations protest
summary: India's Hindu nationalist ruling party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), has instructed officials to be "extremely cautious" when discussing religion on public platforms after derogatory remarks about the Prophet Mohammad drew protests from Islamic nations. The move comes amid rising tensions between Hindus and Muslims in India, with clashes during recent religious processions and deadly riots in 2019-20. The BJP has denied any rise in communal tensions, but its hardline Hindu groups have emboldened anti-Muslim sentiment, prompting the US State Department to report attacks on minority communities in India.

images.alt_text: India accidentally fires missile into Pakistan: defence ministry

site_title: 7 new sites unveiled in H2 2022 GLS Programme
summary: The Singapore government has unveiled seven new sites for the 2022 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme, offering land for 7,310 private homes, including executive condos. Three sites are on the confirmed list, including a mega 5-ha commercial and residential plot near Ikea Tampines, and an executive condo site in Tengah Plantation Loop. The Marina Gardens Lane plot near Marina South MRT station is also on the list, expected to be highly contested. The reserve list includes four private housing plots, including a 825-unit plot in Tanjong Katong and a 500-unit plot near Nan Hua High School.

images.alt_text: Condominiums along Alexandra Road at night on Feb 26, 2022.

site_title: US faces 'unacceptable levels of inflation,' Yellen tells senators
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen told senators that the US faces "unacceptable levels of inflation" and an appropriate budgetary stance is needed to help dampen inflationary pressures without undermining the economy. Yellen emphasized the need for smart, fiscally responsible investments, such as cutting deficits and reforming prescription drug pricing, to complement monetary policy actions by the Federal Reserve. She also expressed hope that Congress will implement a global minimum tax of 15% among 137 countries.

site_title: US steps up sanctions, bars investors from buying Russian debt
summary: The US Treasury has stepped up financial sanctions on Russia, restricting investors from buying the country's debt in the secondary market. US firms can hold or sell Russian debt, but not buy it. The move brings trading activity to a halt, with Russian bonds falling 3 cents on the dollar. The sanctions are the latest blow to Russia, following the US Treasury's ban on accepting bond payments from the Russian government last month.

site_title: China issues 60 new video game permits, none for Tencent or NetEase
summary: China's gaming regulator granted publishing licenses to 60 new games, bringing relief to the sector after a regulatory crackdown and lengthy suspension. The licenses included titles from smaller developers, but not major players like Tencent or NetEase. The move comes after a pause in game approvals that lasted nearly eight months, and a ban on foreign titles for 12 months. Tencent's shares rose 1.54% and NetEase's shares rose 1.35% following the news, despite the lack of direct impact from the new licenses.

images.alt_text: Chinese gaming and social media giant Tencent Holdings reported virtually no growth in first-quarterly revenue, its worst ever such performance.

site_title: Johnson seeks to rally his party after surviving leadership test
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson narrowly survived a confidence vote by 211 votes to 148, avoiding immediate resignation. Despite this, he faces a significant threat to his leadership, with many of his senior allies questioning his integrity due to scandals surrounding lockdown-breaking parties and his response to inflation. Johnson plans to set out new policies to ministers and make key speeches to move forward, but his position remains uncertain, with some party members calling for him to step down.

site_title: Buy now, pay later stocks roiled by Apple's entry
summary: Apple's entry into the buy now, pay later (BNPL) market with Apple Pay Later has roiled shares of BNPL companies, including Affirm, PayPal, and Block. The move is seen as a direct challenge to Afterpay-owner Block, with Apple's existing 85% presence among US merchants giving it a competitive advantage. Shares of Affirm, PayPal, and Block fell between 1.1% and 4.8%, while Australia-listed peers Zip Co and Sezzle Inc closed down 5.2% and 14.4%, respectively. The sector is under pressure due to geopolitical tensions, regulatory scrutiny, and rising interest rates.

site_title: FDA experts weigh authorising Novavax Covid-19 vaccine in US
summary: A US panel of experts convened on June 7 to consider authorizing the Novavax Covid-19 vaccine, a late entrant in the fight against the virus. The vaccine, if approved, could help overcome vaccine hesitancy. Three vaccines are currently approved in the US: Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson, which was recently restricted due to a rare clotting condition. The FDA's decision will play a role in addressing vaccine hesitancy and could pave the way for the Novavax vaccine to be used in the US.

site_title: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust to acquire first logistics property for RM80m
summary: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire two plots of freehold land and industrial properties in Penang, Malaysia, for RM80 million. The 12.6-acre site comprises a single-storey warehouse, double-storey office building, and detached warehouses, with a net lettable area of approximately 335,000 square feet. The acquisition is expected to be completed by mid-2022 and is expected to contribute positively to CLMT's earnings and increase gearing to 37.2%.

images.alt_text: 120 Spencer Street, a 22-storey freehold office tower in Melbourne’s Central Business District, is CLI’s fifth investment in Australia within 6 months.

site_title: The new 4C’s pushing the renewable energy market: Covid, climate, commodities, conflict
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, commodities inflation, and conflict in Ukraine have accelerated the growth of the renewable energy market, dubbed the "4C's" by industry experts. Despite challenges, renewable energy solutions are becoming more viable, with demand for solar energy and energy storage increasing. However, grid infrastructure and regulatory hurdles remain significant barriers to widespread adoption. Experts emphasize the need for governments to redesign energy strategies and create an environment for innovation, while also addressing financing and policy challenges.

images.alt_text: The renewables sector represents a US$30 billion opportunity by 2030, US$20 billion of which will be for solar energy.
