site_title: Tesla faces big increase in complaints over ‘phantom braking’
summary: US regulators have received 758 complaints about Tesla vehicles suddenly braking at high speeds, more than double the number of reported incidents earlier this year. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) opened a probe into the "phantom braking" issue in February, affecting an estimated 416,000 Tesla Model 3 and Model Y vehicles. No crashes or injuries have been reported, but Tesla has yet to respond to a request for comment. The agency is seeking a response from Tesla by June 20.

site_title: Corporate US making consumers pay for inflation
summary: US corporations are passing on inflation costs to consumers, despite claiming to be responsible and committed to sustainability. Companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo increased prices within days of each other, recording a 28% profit margin. Data shows that over half of the corporate-led price increase came from bigger profit margins, not just offsetting costs. The consolidation of market power by large firms is a key factor, allowing them to gouge prices and increase profits. Policymakers should consider imposing price limits and taxing excess profits to protect consumers and prevent corporate-induced inflation.

images.alt_text: UK consumers are being urged to brace for inflation getting worse before it gets better as soaring costs force retailers to keep raising prices.

site_title: Euro zone May business growth robust but outlook darkens
summary: Eurozone business growth was robust in May, with the S&P Global PMI falling to 54.8, just shy of 55.0. However, the outlook darkens due to soaring living costs, supply chain disruptions, and uncertainty surrounding Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The manufacturing sector remains constrained by supply shortages, and the services sector's demand is starting to wane. Companies scaled back growth expectations, citing supply shortages, rising costs, and tightening monetary conditions, with the composite future output index falling to 59.9.

images.alt_text: The Frankfurt DAX was up 0.5 per cent at 14,557.50 points in early trading while the Paris CAC 40 was up by a similar rate at 6,530.24 points.

site_title: EU deal on single mobile charging port likely June 7 in setback for Apple: sources
summary: EU countries and lawmakers are set to agree on a common charging port for mobile devices on June 7, despite criticism from Apple. The proposal, first introduced over a decade ago, aims to address the issue of different chargers for iPhones and Android devices. Outstanding issues include expanding the scope to laptops and harmonizing wireless charging systems by 2025. EU lawmakers want a longer lead-in period for technical reasons, while Apple argues that forcing users to change chargers could create electronic waste.

images.alt_text: Apple has made several changes in recent months to placate workers and cope with a tight US labour market.

site_title: Europe: Shares end week lower as rate hike bets rise
summary: European shares fell 0.9% on Friday, June 3, wiping out earlier gains, as US jobs data supported the Federal Reserve's aggressive policy tightening and investors raised bets on European Central Bank (ECB) rate hikes following strong inflation numbers. The Stoxx 600 index declined 0.3% with the rate-sensitive IT sector leading losses.

images.alt_text: The Frankfurt DAX was up 0.5 per cent at 14,557.50 points in early trading while the Paris CAC 40 was up by a similar rate at 6,530.24 points.

site_title: The new normal? Lessons for businesses beyond the pandemic
summary: Businesses can learn from the lessons of the pandemic, where over 130 firms returned S$97 million in Jobs Support Scheme payouts to support those in need. Amid the crisis, consumer spending was cut, and businesses responded by implementing cost reduction measures. However, this negative feedback loop can be broken by businesses supporting their communities, generating collective resilience and growth. Companies can adopt a "4 'I' Framework" to integrate and institutionalize doing good, achieving double wins of gaining new customers and improving their confidence. The pandemic has also highlighted growing expectations for businesses to play a larger role on issues like climate change and social justice, driving the need for businesses to rethink their purpose and create shared value for all stakeholders.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Green Plan 2030 advances Singapore's national agenda on sustainable development.

site_title: US added 390,000 jobs in May amid efforts to cool the economy
summary: The US added 390,000 jobs in May, marking the 17th straight monthly gain, with the unemployment rate remaining near a half-century low at 3.6%. Average hourly earnings rose 0.3% and were 5.2% higher than a year earlier. The Federal Reserve aims to cool the economy and ease inflation, but rising labor costs may be passed on to consumers, constraining efforts to bring down inflation near a 40-year high.

images.alt_text: Demand for labour remains strong, though some signs of cooling are emerging.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after strong jobs data; Apple, Tesla weigh
summary: US stock indexes fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones down 0.79% to 32,986.32, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite down 0.94% and 1.78% respectively. The decline was driven by shares of Tesla and Apple, while a solid jobs report raised concerns over tighter monetary policy and soaring inflation.

images.alt_text: The logo for the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is displayed on a screen on the trading floor in New York City, U.S., June 1, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Collective action to save our one and only Earth
summary: The world is using the equivalent of 1.6 Earths to maintain its current way of life, straining ecosystems. This is a result of 50 years of rapid industrialization. The 1972 United Nations Conference on the Human Environment marked a historic milestone in environmental sustainability. However, despite global agreements, the planet's resources are being overused, threatening its ability to sustain life.

images.alt_text: Climate-related solutions and the technology exist and are increasingly affordable., but the collective, transformative action on a global scale to protect the planet is being set back.

site_title: To enjoy life more, embrace anticipation
summary: Embracing anticipation can boost mood and reduce stress, according to experts. Planning small, delightful experiences can be just as enjoyable as looking forward to a big event. Writing down daily things to look forward to, imagining a desired life, and clarifying life values can also increase motivation and optimism. Harnessing anticipation through experiences, such as dinner with a celebrity, or small activities like hosting a party for a pet can maximize happiness. Acknowledging both positive and negative emotions can also help make anticipation a powerful tool in manipulating emotions.

images.alt_text: Recessions are adverse events, but there is always a silver lining

site_title: Twitter says waiting period for Musk's deal has expired
summary: Twitter's waiting period under the HSR Act for Elon Musk's $44-billion acquisition has expired, allowing the deal to move forward subject to customary closing conditions, including Twitter stockholder approval and regulatory approvals. The HSR Act requires review of large transactions by the Federal Trade Commission and US Department of Justice Antitrust Division. Musk secured $33.5 billion in equity financing and $13 billion in loans against Twitter, and the deal's status was previously "temporarily on hold" while Musk sought more information about Twitter's fake accounts.

site_title: Shanghai warns of Covid resurgence as cases in community rise
summary: Shanghai, China's financial capital, has warned of a potential Covid-19 resurgence as community cases rise. The city reported 7 new infections on Thursday, the highest tally since loosening restrictions, and authorities are bolstering testing capacity. Shanghai will add more PCR testing booths and increase staff to meet residents' needs, while the city remains committed to its Covid-Zero policy, despite the risk of renewed cases. Nationwide infections have dropped significantly, but experts predict China will remain shuttered until the Party congress later this year.

images.alt_text: Shanghai residents are required to have proof they have taken a Covid test within the last 72 hours in order to enter areas like malls and offices, and — use subways and buses.

site_title: ABBA and the rise of the work-from-home rock star
summary: ABBA's virtual concert, "Voyage," has successfully combined in-person and digital performances, breaking new ground in the entertainment industry. The digital "Abbatars," created from 1979 footage, performed seven shows a week while the human band members stayed at home and collected royalties. This innovative approach has shown the potential for a new category of events that blur the lines between physical and virtual performances. With the potential to generate $4 billion-5 billion annually by 2028, live-streamed concerts are becoming increasingly popular, with artists like BTS and Little Mix embracing digital innovations.

site_title: Global food prices fall again but wheat soars
summary: Global food prices fell 0.6% in May, marking the second consecutive month of decline, according to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization. However, wheat prices rose 5.6% due to an export ban by India and concerns over crop conditions in Ukraine. The ban, citing inflation and food security needs, was announced after India's hottest March on record. Despite the decline in food prices, they remain 56.2% higher than last year, highlighting the ongoing impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on global food markets.

images.alt_text: UK consumers are being urged to brace for inflation getting worse before it gets better as soaring costs force retailers to keep raising prices.

site_title: Zelensky says 'victory will be ours', on day 100 of Russian invasion
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky vowed his country's military will fend off the Russian invasion, marking 100 days of Moscow's assault. Zelensky stated "victory will be ours." Fighting continues across the east, with Russia tightening its grip on Ukraine's Donbas region. The Ukrainian government calls for international help and economic isolation of Russia. Former boxer Volodymyr Klitschko urged continued pressure on Putin's regime, while Ukraine's foreign ministry demands a special court to investigate war crimes.

images.alt_text: Ukraines's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy accused Moscow of “madness” on Tuesday after Russian troops hit a chemical plant in their bid to complete the capture of a key eastern city.

site_title: New York lawmakers embrace new funding plan to rescue public housing
summary: New York lawmakers have passed a bill that could unlock billions of dollars for the New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) by leasing up to 25,000 apartments to a public benefit corporation. The corporation can borrow money to pay for repairs, and residents would retain their protections, including a cap on rent payments. The bill, expected to be signed by Governor Kathy Hochul, aims to address the agency's long-standing problems and provides a financial rescue for the nation's largest public housing system. The move is seen as a victory for Mayor Eric Adams, who has pledged to address NYCHA's issues.

images.alt_text: Buyers have gotten a slight reprieve in recent weeks from the massive run-up in mortgage rates that has dominated this year.

site_title: Singapore’s competition watchdog flags concerns over Tata group’s takeover of Air India
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has raised concerns over Tata group's takeover of Air India, citing potential anti-competition issues. The CCCS notes that Air India and Vistra, a joint venture between Singapore Airlines and Tata Sons, are major competitors along overlapping air passenger and cargo transport routes. The commission has completed its first phase of review and will assess whether the merger will result in a "substantial lessening of competition" within Singapore's market. The outcome of the review will determine the impact of the takeover on the airline industry.

images.alt_text: Struggling Air India sold after 69 years in government hands

site_title: 10 years after 'Gangnam Style', Psy is happier than ever
summary: Ten years after releasing the global phenomenon "Gangnam Style," South Korean rapper Psy is living his best life, free from pressure to repeat its success. The song, which became the first YouTube video to reach one billion views, catapulted Psy to global recognition, leading to collaborations with Madonna and US President Barack Obama. However, the song's success also brought pressure, with Psy describing it as one of the most difficult periods of his life. Today, Psy is proud of his "greatest trophy" and is enjoying a new era of success with his record label and artist agency, P NATION.

site_title: Alibaba replaces Lazada CEO in South-east Asia shakeup
summary: Alibaba has replaced Lazada CEO Chun Li with James Dong, the head of its Thailand business and former business assistant to Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang. Dong takes the reins of Lazada with immediate effect, amid intense competition in South-east Asia. The move comes as Lazada faces stiff rivalry with Shopee and Tokopedia, and follows frequent management shuffles at the Singapore-based company. Dong brings experience in logistics and operations, having overseen growth in Vietnam during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group plans to expand its South-east Asian arm, Lazada, to Europe, 2 sources familiar with the matter told Reuters, as the Chinese e-commerce company seeks further overseas growth amid slowing opportunities at home.

site_title: Malaysia says higher revenue collection not enough to offset subsidy spike
summary: Malaysia's Finance Ministry stated that increased government revenue from rising commodity prices is insufficient to offset an expected surge in subsidy spending this year. Subsidies on petroleum and cooking oil are expected to increase to 30 billion ringgit (S$9.4 billion), despite an initial estimate of 4 billion ringgit. The government plans to cushion the shortfall with additional tax measures and targeted approaches to minimize leakages, ensuring subsidies reach vulnerable groups.

site_title: Four weeks’ jail, 5-year ban for former company director who allowed laundering of nearly S$50 million
summary: A former company director, Eng Cheng Song, was sentenced to 4 weeks in jail and disqualified for 5 years after being found guilty of failing to exercise reasonable diligence in allowing the laundering of nearly $33.5 million of fraud proceeds through his company.

site_title: Malaysia Smelting Corp unit to acquire Asas Baiduri to boost tin mining output
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corp (MSC) has proposed acquiring Asas Baiduri Sdn Bhd (ABSB) via its subsidiary RHT, aiming to boost tin mining output. The acquisition will give RHT control of 568 ha of land, allowing it to expand mining and store waste rock. The deal, valued at RM664.5 million, is expected to contribute to MSC's operation and future performance. Following the acquisition, ABSB will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of RHT, with RHT becoming an 80% owned subsidiary of MSC.

site_title: Takeaways from the pandemic
summary: A recent article "The Winding Road" by Vivien Ang explores the habits and lifestyle choices formed during the pandemic that are worth keeping. The author reflects on how the pandemic's social isolation has led to a renewed appreciation for simple pleasures like Pasar Malam (night markets) and a desire for a zero-waste lifestyle. The article concludes that the pandemic has taught us the importance of slowing down, appreciating the little things, and adopting more sustainable habits.

site_title: F&N Malaysia proposes RM488m privatisation of Cocoaland
summary: FRASER & Neave Bhd (F&NHB) has proposed to acquire the entire equity interest of Cocoaland for RM488 million (S$153 million), or RM1.50 a share, representing 72.3% of Cocoaland's share capital. F&NHB currently owns 27.7% of Cocoaland's share capital. The proposed privatisation will involve acquiring 325 million shares held by scheme shareholders.

Coinbase extended its hiring freeze and rescinded some accepted offers, while Gemini plans to slash its workforce by 10%. Rain Financial, backed by Coinbase, laid off dozens of employees. The insurer had already stopped accepting new business in Russia and is likely to fully exit the country.

site_title: UK retail boss condemns imperial measurement plan
summary: UK retail boss Stuart Rose has condemned a government plan to revive imperial measurements, calling it "complete and utter nonsense" at a difficult time for industry. The plan, proposed by Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government, aims to give companies greater choice over product measurements post-Brexit. However, Rose and other businesses argue the move would increase costs and hinder living standards, as the UK faces soaring inflation and a projected fall in living standards. A consultation will consider the proposal, which would allow companies to sell products in pounds and ounces alongside metric units.

images.alt_text: British consumer sentiment tumbled in April to its second-lowest reading since records began nearly 50 years ago, as the worsening cost-of-living crisis hurt households’ confidence.

site_title: Toronto home prices drop for third straight month as rates jump
summary: Toronto home prices fell 3.1% in May to C$1.18 million, marking the third consecutive month of declines, amid rising interest rates. The decline brings prices nearly 9% from their February peak. The Bank of Canada's rate hikes have led to a reversal in the city's previously hot housing market, with commercial banks raising variable mortgage rates and buyers fleeing the market. The number of home sales fell 9.3% in May, and sellers are piling in, increasing the number of homes for sale 26% from May 2021.

images.alt_text: The global property market frenzy that gathered pace during the pandemic as people scrambled to buy more living space is likely over as interest rates rise, and house price inflation is expected to drop off.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on June 3, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.27% or 347.69 points to 27,761.57, while the Topix index advanced 0.35% or 6.75 points to 1,933.14. The gains followed rallies on Wall Street, with investors awaiting the release of US jobs data.

site_title: Carlyle, Blackstone CEOs see critical supply chains localising
summary: Carlyle Group and Blackstone CEOs Kewsong Lee and Steve Schwarzman emphasize the need for countries and companies to localize supply chains due to historical trading partner disruptions. This shift requires significant investment and repurposing of existing supply chains to store inventory and bring manufacturing closer to control. The Covid-19 pandemic, China's shutdowns, and Russia's war in Ukraine have intensified supply shortages, leading to potential price increases for consumers. Lee and Schwarzman predict a transition towards more localized supply chains, but acknowledge the challenges and costs involved.

site_title: Skilled workers can relocate again as borders reopen, but low risk of mass ‘brain drain’ from Singapore: analysts
summary: Singapore's borders reopening may lead to an increase in skilled workers relocating abroad, but the risk of a "brain drain" is considered low. Global job vacancies, particularly in the UK, remain high, with 1.3 million job openings in the 3 months to end-April 2022. Singaporean workers are in demand globally, and overseas stints still confer prestige on a résumé. Analysts suggest that rising global uncertainty may limit the relocation trend, but Singapore's value proposition remains globally competitive, and many Singaporeans are willing to pursue career opportunities abroad.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Friday, tracking gains in Asia and on Wall Street, ahead of a key US jobs data release. The Frankfurt DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.5% each, while London was closed for a holiday. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to maintain its tightening of monetary policy despite weaker-than-expected US private jobs data, citing high inflation concerns.

site_title: WTO seeks fish, vaccine deals as war ignites trade tensions
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is hosting a ministerial conference this month to strike deals on fish and vaccines amidst mounting trade tensions. The conference, dubbed MC12, aims to conclude 20 years of negotiations on reducing fishing subsidies, fairer vaccine sharing, and agricultural trade reform. However, the Ukraine war and China's zero-Covid policy have added uncertainty to global trade, which is expected to slow this year. The meeting faces challenges in finding consensus, with some members refusing to negotiate with Russia and disagreements over vaccine inequity. The WTO's ability to set trade rules is being tested, and some observers question its relevance in the face of global trade discord.

site_title: Delivery Hero seen leaving Germany’s DAX Index in reshuffle
summary: Delivery Hero is likely to be removed from Germany's DAX Index, a move that could further strain the company's struggling stock amid a post-Covid economic reopening. The exclusion is part of a quarterly review that aims to rebalance the index towards more old-economy stocks. Beiersdorf, the maker of Nivea skin cream, is expected to replace Delivery Hero. This move comes as the DAX index has declined 8.8% in 2022, underperforming the Stoxx Europe 600 Index.

site_title: Sri Lanka can’t use US$1.5b swap on China IMF concerns
summary: Sri Lanka is unable to access a $1.5 billion credit line from China due to concerns from Beijing that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) may delay repayment terms. The credit line, which is part of a three-year swap agreement, could be viewed as a loan and may be rescheduled, potentially harming China's interests. The IMF has requested that Sri Lanka demonstrate progress in reducing its existing debt burden before disbursing aid. Sri Lanka is seeking a staff-level agreement with the IMF, which could increase confidence in the country's financial assets, but negotiations are ongoing.

site_title: Chemicals company Borouge soars in debut after staging Abu Dhabi’s biggest IPO
summary: Borouge, a chemicals joint venture between the UAE's main oil company and Borealis, made its debut with a successful IPO in Abu Dhabi, raising US$2 billion. The shares rose 20% to 2.95 dirhams, valuing the company at over 88 billion dirhams (S$32.9 billion). The IPO drew interest from major investors, including BlackRock and Fidelity, and is part of a trend of strong demand for listings in the region, with Gulf stock exchanges on track for their best-ever first half.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on mining boost, post third weekly gain
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.9% to 7,238.80, marking a third consecutive weekly gain. site_title: Australia: Shares set for third weekly gain on tech, miners boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.1% on Friday, on track for a third consecutive weekly gain, driven by tech and miner stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 7,253.4 points. Weaker US private payroll data raised hopes that the US Federal Reserve might scale down interest rate hikes, boosting investor sentiment globally. Domestic tech stocks snapped a three-day losing streak, while miners and mining sub-index climbed over 2% and are poised for a third weekly gain.

site_title: London’s Camden Market up for sale: FT report
summary: Israeli billionaire Teddy Sagi has put Camden Market in London up for sale with an asking price of £1.3 billion. The market, which hosts over 1,000 stalls, shops, bars, and cafes, attracts 28 million visitors annually and covers 16 acres in north-west London. A discreet sales process has begun with a handful of prospective bidders, with Roschschild & Co serving as financial advisor.

images.alt_text: Post-Brexit, London continues to be a leading global financial and business hub.

site_title: Musk feels ‘super bad’ about economy, needs to cut 10% of Tesla jobs
summary: Elon Musk has warned Tesla executives that the company needs to cut about 10% of jobs due to his "super bad feeling" about the economy. The move comes amid growing concerns about a recession, with Musk stating that a "hurricane is right out there" and citing high inflation in the US. The decision follows a recent hiring freeze and staff cuts, with Musk demanding that employees return to the office or leave. Tesla's shares have fallen 3% in pre-market trade, and analysts predict slower deliveries and economic slowdowns.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 12.1% in April as tourists return
summary: Singapore's retail sales surged 12.1% in April, driven by tourists' return as international borders reopened. Sales across categories rose, with higher demand for bags and footwear, partly boosted by tourist spending. Online retail accounted for 12.5% of sales. Excluding motor vehicles, retail receipts increased 17.4% year-over-year, with food and beverage services growing 11.4%. Experts expect domestic retailers to benefit from the recovery in domestic activities, forecasting 6.0% full-year retail sales growth in 2022.

site_title: Greenland Group-linked Green Link Digital Bank becomes first digital bank to launch in Singapore
summary: Greenland Group-linked Green Link Digital Bank has become the first digital bank to launch in Singapore, receiving a digital wholesale bank license in December 2020. The digital bank aims to serve micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises with banking and financial services, and expand its service coverage to cater to high-growth industries. GLDB chairman Geng Jing said the bank aspires to contribute to digital economy advancements in Singapore and create a digital banking industry benchmark, incorporating advanced technologies and environmental, social, and governance factors.

Digital banks seen debuting strongly in 2022, but 'long and difficult' path to profitability

site_title: IMF says world needs US$3.3t a year in green investments
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that the world needs approximately $3.3 trillion in annual energy-related investments by 2030 to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. According to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva, the current financing effort falls short of what is needed, and countries must find urgent ways to attract more climate funding, particularly for emerging economies. The IMF warns that missing the net-zero path poses a significant risk for the world of finance.

site_title: Pump prices in Singapore hit new highs, with costliest grade above S$4 a litre
summary: Pump prices in Singapore have reached new highs, with the costliest grade of 98-octane petrol exceeding S$4 a litre. Diesel prices also surged, ranging from S$3 to S$3.08 per litre. The increase is attributed to an imminent ban on Russian oil and rising demand as economies recover from the pandemic. RBOB Gasoline, a proxy for refined petroleum products, has reached its highest level in over 2 decades, with Brent crude oil prices above US$117 a barrel.

images.alt_text: US crude oil stockpiles fell by 5.1 million barrels, compared with analysts’ expectations in a Reuters poll for a 1.3 million-barrel drop.

site_title: US sues cryptocurrency exchange run by Winklevoss twins
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has filed a lawsuit against Gemini, a cryptocurrency exchange run by the Winklevoss twins, for allegedly making false or misleading statements about a bitcoin futures project in 2017. The CFTC accuses Gemini of not being upfront about how easy it would be to manipulate the project. The agency is seeking financial penalties, the surrender of any ill-gotten gains, and an injunction to prevent similar behavior in the future. Gemini has defended its record and plans to prove its case in court.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Education, Fraser and Neave
summary: Raffles Education (REC) denied recent allegations of theft, forgery, and extortion, stating they are "without basis and without merit." The group plans to defend itself rigorously. Meanwhile, Fraser and Neave's subsidiary Fraser & Neave Holdings Bhd and Cocoaland requested trading suspensions on Bursa Malaysia pending announcements.

site_title: Traveloka nears US$200m funding after SPAC talks
summary: Traveloka, South-east Asia's largest online travel startup, is nearing a US$200 million funding round after ending talks to go public via a SPAC merger. The Jakarta-based firm is pulling in fresh funds after deciding not to pursue a listing via Bridgetown Holdings. Traveloka aims for a US IPO this year, with the valuation of the deal currently undisclosed. The company, backed by investors including GIC and Expedia Group, has seen a surge in foreign travelers in countries such as Thailand after pandemic-era restrictions were lifted.

images.alt_text: Traveloka fuels up 'buy now, pay later' engine for super app take-off

site_title: How Singapore Airlines beat the pandemic and came out ahead
summary: Singapore Airlines managed to survive the COVID-19 pandemic with minimal impact, unlike some of its international rivals. By April 2020, the airline was operating at just 3% of pre-pandemic capacity. CEO Goh Choon Phong took drastic action, calling a crisis meeting in January 2020, and the airline took measures to stay afloat. Singapore's unique situation, lacking a domestic market, helped the airline avoid the financial struggles experienced by some of its competitors. The airline's resilience has allowed it to emerge ahead of its peers.

BRITAIN'S Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has told airlines to stop selling tickets for flights they cannot staff after a spate of airline cancellations caused widespread disruption for holidaymakers.

Now that Singapore and most other countries around the world have opened again for quarantine-free travel, SIA was able to increase traffic to more than 1 million passengers in April, the most since the pandemic began.
Boeing in April delayed deliveries of 777X jets to 2025, 5 years later than expected, prompting some plane lessors to suggest the product’s future is in doubt.

site_title: Raffles Education’s board says allegations against it in India are ‘without legal merit’
summary: Raffles Education, a Singapore-based educational institution, has responded to allegations in India, stating that the claims are "without legal merit." The company has issued a statement saying it will "rigorously defend its position" and believes there's a "good chance" of the case being quashed. The allegations were made by a company associated with Shantanu Prakash, the founder of Educomp Solutions and a former business partner of Raffles Education. The case, initially closed, has been reopened following these allegations.

images.alt_text: REC clarifies reports regarding charges filed over India dispute

site_title: Gold prices hit 1-month high as dollar weakens, set for weekly gain
summary: Gold prices reached a 1-month high, rising 0.2% to $1,871.69 per ounce, as the US dollar weakened. This sets the stage for a third consecutive weekly gain. A lower dollar makes gold more attractive for overseas buyers, while signs of an economic crisis support gold demand as a safe-haven asset. The Federal Reserve is expected to continue tightening monetary policy, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold.

images.alt_text: US crude oil stockpiles fell by 5.1 million barrels, compared with analysts’ expectations in a Reuters poll for a 1.3 million-barrel drop.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street rally ahead of jobs data, oil holds gains
summary: Asian equities rose on Friday ahead of US jobs data, following a strong Wall Street performance. The US private jobs reading was below forecast, giving the Federal Reserve some room to ease rate hikes. Oil prices held gains despite a 50% production increase by OPEC and other major producers. Analysts remain cautious, citing uncertainty from the Ukraine war and China's economic struggles, and warn of a potential supply shortage.

site_title: Toshiba to flag that activist board nominees not approved unanimously: sources
summary: Toshiba plans to notify shareholders that two activist board director nominees, Nabeel Bhanji and Eijiro Imai, were not approved unanimously by its nomination committee. This move highlights the contentious issue between Toshiba's board and its activist shareholder base, who have called for the conglomerate to be taken private. Toshiba has received eight initial proposals for a take-private deal and two proposals for capital alliances, indicating its receptiveness to the idea. The company's board currently has eight members, set to increase to 13.

site_title: Indonesia raises 81b yen from Samurai bond sale
summary: Indonesia raised 81 billion yen from a Samurai bond sale of 3- to 10-year maturities, with proceeds to be used to help plug a fiscal deficit. The largest portion was the 68.2 billion yen sale of 3-year bonds with a 0.96% coupon. The bond sale, the largest by a sovereign issuer in the Japanese debt market this year, came amid choppy global market conditions. The funds will be used to address a budget deficit, despite a US$7 billion budget surplus recorded in the January-April period.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's inflation rate accelerated slightly in May due to rising food prices and airfares, official data showed on Thursday, roughly in line with market expectations and within the central bank's target range.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending gains on Wall Street ahead of US jobs data. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.92%, while the broader Topix index advanced 0.60%. The gains follow rallies on Wall Street.

site_title: Slump in new car sales in May raises specter of US recession
summary: US new car sales dropped 11% in May to 12.8 million vehicles at a seasonally adjusted annualized rate, the lowest level since December. The decline is attributed to high prices and low inventories amid a semiconductor shortage. Analysts, including RBC Capital Markets, warn that the data may signal a broader economic downturn, with some predicting a recession could keep sales in the low 12 million range. Automakers expect a recovery as supply-chain woes ease, but concerns over macroeconomic headwinds persist.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 11.74 points to 3,238.46 at 9:01 am, driven by overnight Wall Street rallies. The top traded counters included 3Cnergy, Keppel Reit, and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which rallied in early trade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained 1.3% and 1.8%, respectively, as markets await key jobs data and its implications for inflation and monetary policy.

site_title: US adds Russian airplane factories to economic blacklist
summary: The US added 71 Russian and Belarusian entities to its trade blacklist, including aircraft factories and shipbuilding institutes, in response to Russia's war in Ukraine. The entities include 70 Russian companies and 1 Belarusian entity, and were added to the Commerce Department's economic blacklist since February, bringing the total to 322. The restrictions aim to deprive the Russian military of US technology and other items. The US has also imposed prohibitions on additional Russian oligarchs and members of the country's elite.

site_title: South Korea’s May consumer inflation near 14-year high, surpasses expectations
summary: South Korea's consumer price index (CPI) rose 5.4% in May, exceeding expectations and marking the fastest annual growth since August 2008. This was the 14th consecutive month the CPI surpassed the central bank's 2% target. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy prices, rose 3.4%, its fastest rise since February 2009. The increase was attributed to higher prices for goods and services, contributing to a near 14-year high in consumer inflation.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on LHN Logistics with ‘add’, S$0.22 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB initiated coverage on LHN Logistics with an "add" call and target price of S$0.22, citing the group's projected earnings growth due to recovering trade activity and the commencement of its ISO tank depot in end-H1 FY2023. The depot is expected to drive revenue compound annual growth rate up by 28% from FY2022 to FY2024, with enhanced cross-border trucking services and storage services also contributing to growth. The analyst believes LHN Logistics will benefit from heightened trade activity in South-east Asia, particularly in Thailand.

site_title: Jump Crypto says Terra was a losing game for retail investors
summary: Jump Crypto, a firm involved in the defunct Terra blockchain, has published a report stating that large investors were able to exit their positions in Terra's UST stablecoin earlier than smaller investors, exacerbating the collapse. The report found that large depositors withdrew almost 15% of their UST position in May, while small depositors increased their exposure, leading to a "death spiral" that sent UST and Luna's prices to virtual zero. This highlights how cryptocurrency remains a game for large professional players, with smaller investors often left vulnerable to market fluctuations.

site_title: Biden says ‘Enough!’ on gun violence, demands action from Congress
summary: US President Joe Biden called on Congress to pass gun control measures, including banning assault weapons and expanding background checks, following recent mass shootings in the US. Biden visited the site of a school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, and urged lawmakers to take action, warning that Americans would make the issue central in the mid-term elections if nothing is done. The National Rifle Association opposed Biden's proposals, citing infringement on law-abiding gun owners' rights. The US has a higher rate of gun deaths than any other wealthy nation, and lawmakers are exploring measures to address the issue.

site_title: Coinbase to extend hiring freeze and rescind some accepted offers
summary: Coinbase is extending its hiring freeze indefinitely and rescinding some accepted job offers due to current macroeconomic conditions. The decision follows a 35% slump in total revenue and a 75% decline in its stock price since its market debut last year. The company cited volatility in the cryptocurrency market and larger economic factors as reasons for the pause. CEO L.J. Brock stated that the company is prepared to test its limits, but will reassess when the macro environment improves.

site_title: F&N Malaysia, Cocoaland suspend trading on Bursa pending announcements
summary: Bursa Malaysia suspended trading of Fraser & Neave Bhd (F&NHB) and Cocoaland on June 2, pending announcements. F&NHB owns a 27.65% stake in Cocoaland, which manufactures sugar confectionery products. The suspension comes amid reports that Cocoaland is a takeover target of a European private equity firm and an Asian buyout firm, with the co-founding brothers considering selling the company.

site_title: India’s May services growth at 11-year high, input inflation at record
summary: India's services sector expanded at an 11-year high in May, with overall demand rising at the fastest pace since July 2011. The S&P Global India Services Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 58.9, beating expectations and marking the longest streak of expansion since 2018-2019. However, inflationary pressures increased, with input prices rising at the sharpest pace in survey history, and business expectations remaining low. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to hike interest rates further to curb price pressures, posing a risk to the country's growth prospects.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on Thursday ahead of jobs data
summary: US stocks rallied on Thursday ahead of key jobs data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.3% to 33,248.28, the S&P 500 gaining 1.8% to 4,176.82, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 2.7% to 12,316.90. Private employment rose by 128,000 positions in May, less than expected, and may signal a weakening labor market and less wage pressure, potentially easing inflation worries. Federal Reserve Vice Chair Lael Brainard reaffirmed interest rate hikes through September.

site_title: Australia’s new PM endorses wage increase to ease pain of inflation
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has proposed raising the minimum wage to ease the financial burden on families affected by inflation. He had previously promised a 5.1% wage increase during the election campaign. The Fair Work Commission will decide on the minimum wage in the next few weeks, with the government recommending a wage rise matching inflation. This move aims to help low-paid workers, with the current minimum wage at A$20.33 an hour. The decision comes as Australia faces a spike in energy prices and a 0.8% increase in gross domestic product.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on Thursday after two-day decline
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% on Thursday after a two-day decline, driven by gains in industrial and luxury stocks. The index was limited by concerns over slowing economic growth and rising prices. French spirits group Remy Cointreau climbed 4.9% after beating profit estimates, while luxury stocks like LVMH and L'Oreal also rose. However, oil stocks declined as crude prices erased earlier losses. The European Central Bank may accelerate its interest rate tightening path amid inflation data, with some analysts predicting a 50 basis point hike in July.

site_title: Oil rises 1% as US crude drawdown overshadows Opec+ boost
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday as US crude inventories fell 5.1 million barrels, exceeding expectations. The increase in US crude stockpiles overshadowed Opec+'s agreement to boost crude output by 650,000 barrels per day to offset Russian production losses. The European Union's sanctions against Russia also supported oil prices, with Brent futures settling at $117.61 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising to $116.87.

site_title: Hong Kong: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Hong Kong's financial markets are closed on Friday for a public holiday. This follows a similar closure in China, Taiwan, and Thailand for public holidays. The closures do not impact the overall market sentiment, which remains influenced by US-EU trade tensions and global economic factors.

site_title: Apple to improve working hours for retail staff after union push
summary: Apple has agreed to improve working hours for retail staff, including a minimum of 12 hours between shifts, a maximum of three days a week working past 8 pm, and a dedicated weekend day off for full-time employees every six months. The changes aim to address unionization efforts and worker frustrations with scheduling. The plan is part of a series of recent changes, including doubling paid sick days, increasing vacation days, and raising hourly wages to $22 an hour.

images.alt_text: The news represents a setback for the nascent efforts by several US unions to organise Apple’s retail stores.
People visit the newly opened Apple Museum in Warsaw, Poland. The museum sets out to tell the story of the development of consumer electronics through the "successes and failures" of Apple.

site_title: China’s Dajia weighs US$1b sale of 3 US luxury hotels: sources
summary: Dajia Insurance Group, which took over most of Anbang Insurance Group's operations, is exploring a potential sale of three US luxury hotels, including the Montage Laguna Beach, Four Seasons resorts in Jackson Hole and Scottsdale, for over US$1 billion. This comes as the lodging industry experiences surging travel demand, but rising interest rates and market volatility may make financing more expensive. Dajia is tapping advisers for the transaction, which would be a significant sale for the company and potentially lucrative for a buyer.

site_title: Startup ecosystem not as bullish now, but fresh capital is available, says panel
summary: A panel of investors at InnovFest x Elevating Founders discussed the current state of the startup ecosystem in South-east Asia, noting that the region's startup scene is not as bullish this year due to global crises. However, fresh capital is available from venture capitalists, with $600 million recently raised by Jungle Ventures. Despite the challenges, investors believe that startups can still tap into the available funds and ride the wave of opportunities, particularly in Vietnam, which has seen significant growth in funding between 2017 and 2021.

site_title: Citi’s fat-finger trade could cost bank more than US$50m
summary: Citigroup is facing potential losses of at least $50 million due to a single employee's "fat-finger trade" that caused a flash crash in European stocks on May 2. The mistake, which occurred when a trader incorrectly added an extra zero to a trade while working from home, led to a five-minute selloff and wiped out $300 billion in market value. The employee has been placed on leave as the bank reviews the incident and investigates why its algorithms allowed the mistaken trades to go through.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6 per cent on Thursday after losing nearly 2 per cent over the last two sessions.

site_title: All options on table in China tariff review: USTR official
summary: The Biden administration is reviewing potential changes to US duties on Chinese imports, considering "all options" including tariff relief and new trade investigations. Deputy US Trade Representative Sarah Bianchi said the agency aims to address long-term challenges from China and realign the relationship, focusing on non-market practices and economic coercion. The shift in focus aims to create a "long-term tariff structure that makes sense."

site_title: US backs Philippines in China fishing ban
summary: The US has backed the Philippines in criticizing China's unilateral seasonal ban on fishing in the South China Sea, citing a 2016 court ruling rejecting Beijing's claims and international law. The State Department stated that China's actions are "inconsistent with the 2016 Arbitral Tribunal ruling and international law." The Philippines, a US treaty ally, had summoned a Chinese diplomat over the ban and alleged harassment of a marine research vessel. China has declared a fishing ban each year, citing overfishing concerns, but its actions have been disputed by the Philippines and other Southeast Asian nations.

site_title: Microsoft warns of forex hit, cuts forecast
summary: Microsoft has lowered its fourth-quarter forecast for profit and revenue due to a stronger US dollar and heightened geopolitical tensions. The tech giant, which gets half its revenue from outside the US, now expects revenue of $51.94-$52.74 billion, down from a prior range of $52.40-$53.20 billion. This is the latest US company to warn of a currency hit, following companies like Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble. Microsoft's shares fell 3% after the announcement.

site_title: Biden to visit former ‘pariah’ Saudi Arabia: reports
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to visit Saudi Arabia this month, reversing his previous stance of treating the kingdom as a pariah. The visit comes after Saudi Arabia agreed to a production hike in oil and helped extend a truce in Yemen, addressing two of Biden's priorities. Biden will meet with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who was accused of ordering the 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The visit aims to engage with leaders from the Middle East region and address concerns over human rights, which may be complicated given the prince's response to previous criticism.

site_title: Fed's Brainard says 'very hard' to see case for September pause
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Lael Brainard stated that it's "very hard" to see a case for pausing interest rate hikes in September, citing the need to bring inflation down to the 2% target. Brainard supports at least two more half-point interest rate hikes and indicated that policymakers will reassess the economy in September. This contradicts Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic's suggestion to pause policy tightening by September.

site_title: Elvis wedding crackdown leaves Las Vegas all shook up
summary: Authentic Brands Group, the company controlling Elvis Presley's likeness, sent cease-and-desist letters to dozens of Las Vegas wedding chapels offering Elvis-themed nuptials, sparking outrage. The move aims to safeguard the King's legacy in Las Vegas, but has been met with concern from Elvis impersonators, chapel owners, and the mayor. ABG has since offered financial "partnerships" to chapels, including annual licensing deals, but this has been met with skepticism. The move comes ahead of the release of Baz Luhrmann's Elvis biopic.

site_title: US factory orders rise modestly in April
summary: US factory orders rose 0.3% in April, slightly less than expected, but demand for goods remains strong. Manufacturing, accounting for 12% of the US economy, is driven by strong demand despite spending shifting back to services. China's zero Covid-19 policy and Russia's war against Ukraine could slow supply chain improvements. Shipments of manufactured goods gained 0.2% and inventories increased 0.6%, while unfilled orders rose 0.5%. These data suggest domestic demand will continue to support the economy, despite a 1.5% annualized GDP contraction in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Demand for labour remains strong, though some signs of cooling are emerging.

site_title: US jobless claims drop; layoffs fall in May
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 200,000 in the week ending May 28, with demand for labor remaining strong despite signs of cooling. The Federal Reserve's Beige Book reported slowed job growth in some districts, while the US central bank aims to dampen labor demand without pushing unemployment too high. Layoff announcements dropped 14.7% in May, with 20,712 job cuts announced, a 48% decrease from the same period in 2021. The government's employment report on Friday is expected to show strong job growth persisted in May.

images.alt_text: The weaker-than-expected figures indicate that US companies are still struggling to hire from a limited pool of workers.

site_title: 'Nein danke': Musk's office ultimatum faces pushback in Germany
summary: Elon Musk has faced pushback from Germany's IG Metall union after issuing an ultimatum to Tesla employees in Germany, requiring them to return to the office for at least 40 hours a week or leave the company. The union, which represents around 4,000 Tesla employees, has pledged to support any employee who opposes the demand. Many German employers, including Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz, have already adopted hybrid working models, and the labor ministry is working on policies to increase flexibility for workers.

site_title: Elizabeth II makes appearance as UK honors her 70 years as queen
summary: Queen Elizabeth II celebrated her 70 years on the throne with a joyous ceremony at Buckingham Palace, marking a milestone in British history. Despite family members Prince Harry and Prince Andrew being absent, the monarch was joined by her remaining heirs, including Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George. World leaders, including President Emmanuel Macron and former US President Barack Obama, praised Elizabeth II's lifetime of service, calling her the "golden thread" that binds the UK to its nations. The Platinum Jubilee celebrations, which will last four days, feature a military parade and other festivities.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II said on Wednesday that her British subjects and Commonwealth nations should look ahead with “confidence and enthusiasm” as they prepared to celebrate her record-breaking 70 years on the throne.

site_title: Only 17% of sustainability leaders in Asia-Pacific’s finance sector are in C-suite: report
summary: Only 17% of sustainability leaders in Asia-Pacific's finance sector are in C-suite positions, compared to 50% globally. The majority of sustainability leaders in the region have finance and reporting experience, with 37% holding this background, while 54% have experience in sustainability and CSR. The report suggests that the focus on finance experience may be due to mandatory disclosures in recent years, and that future sustainability leaders will likely move up the ranks to management positions, with 67% of leaders appointed in the last 5 years having sustainability experience.

site_title: Muted response to PLH projects launched in May
summary: Singapore's Prime Location Public Housing (PLH) projects, launched in May, saw muted responses, with overall application rates for 3-room flats slightly above 1 and for 4-room flats around 4. This is lower than previous projects, with the exception of King George's Heights, which had a 5.8 times application rate. Experts attribute the lower response to the availability of resale flats in the area, with buyers waiting for upcoming BTO launches closer to MRT stations. Despite this, 4-room flats in Bukit Merah Ridge drew the highest number of applicants, and demand for bigger PLH flats remains strong.

site_title: Ford to invest US$3.7b for production of EVs, petrol-powered vehicles
summary: Ford is investing US$3.7 billion in US assembly plants for the production of both electric and petrol-powered vehicles. The investment includes US$2.3 billion for electric vehicles, with plans to produce over 2 million EVs annually by 2026. The company will add over 6,200 hourly jobs and convert 3,000 temporary workers into full-time employees with health-care benefits and higher pay. The investments are part of Ford's US$50 billion EV spending till 2026, with a goal of catching up to industry leader Tesla.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor needs to overhaul its century-old business model - from slashing advertising spending to reworking its dealer network - if it is to earn enough profit on electric vehicles to compete with Tesla and others, the automaker's chief executive said on Wednesday.

site_title: Untrained pilots landed passenger jet in India, risking lives
summary: Vistara, an Indian joint venture of Tata Group and Singapore Airlines, has been fined 1 million rupees after a first officer landed a passenger flight without completing required training. The incident, which occurred in August, was a serious violation that endangered passenger lives. The plane landed safely without incident, and no one was hurt. The airline's captain was also not simulator-trained on guiding a first officer during landings. The fine is a result of a probe into the incident, which was voluntarily reported by Vistara.

images.alt_text: India’s Jet Airways said on Friday the country’s aviation regulator has cleared it to resume operation of commercial flights.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Microsoft offsets oil relief
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on June 2, 2022, as Microsoft shares fell 4.5% after lowering its profit forecast. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.01%, 0.14%, and 0.41% respectively. The decline was partially offset by a pullback in oil prices, easing inflation concerns.

site_title: China to double wind, solar energy capacity by 2025
summary: China aims to double its wind and solar capacity by 2025, according to a new road map, potentially reaching its 2030 Paris climate accord goal earlier. The plan, released by China's central economic planner, targets 33% of power supply from renewable sources by 2025, up from 29% in 2020. However, China's reliance on coal-fired power plants has increased in recent months to support its ailing economy, contradicting its climate pledge.

site_title: US companies add fewest jobs of pandemic recovery, ADP data show
summary: US companies added 128,000 jobs in May, the fewest since the pandemic recovery began, according to ADP Research Institute data. The decline was attributed to a decrease in small business employment. Despite near-record job openings, employers continue to struggle to recruit and retain workers due to high inflation and a falling savings rate, potentially leading to increased labor market participation in the coming months.

site_title: Opec+ brings forward oil output rises as Biden's Saudi visit looms

The move is seen as a sign of Saudi Arabia's willingness to pump more oil after months of pressure from the West. Oil prices rose to US$117 a barrel, but analysts say the real production boost will be insignificant due to most Opec members already pumping at capacity. The decision comes ahead of US President Joe Biden's visit to Saudi Arabia to discuss oil output, Gulf security, and human rights.

site_title: Strategy's important, but operations even more so
summary: A new management thought prioritizes operational excellence over strategy, driven by the pandemic's challenges to traditional corporate strategies. Key areas of focus include supply chain redesign, inventory policies, delivery tactics, and order management, as companies seek to optimize operations to meet changing consumer demands and ensure timely delivery. This shift emphasizes the importance of operational smartness, technology, and agility, rather than relying solely on strategic planning.

site_title: Singapore electronics PMI falls in May despite overall uptick in factory confidence
summary: Singapore's electronics industry PMI fell to 50.5 points in May, down 0.2 from the previous month, raising concerns about a slowdown. Despite this, regional manufacturing confidence inched up to 50.4 points, driven by faster expansion in new orders. The Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management attributed the uptick to growth in new orders making up for slower growth in output, employment, and exports.

site_title: Malaysia's Health Minister Khairy says export ban on chickens unlikely to last too long
summary: Malaysia's Health Minister Khairy Jamaluddin has expressed optimism that the country's export ban on chickens to Singapore will not last long. The ban, implemented on June 1, has led to shortages and price hikes in Singapore, which relies on Malaysia for one-third of its chicken supply. Khairy attributed the shortage to supply chain issues and climate-related challenges, but assured that efforts to increase production and secure cheaper substitutes for chicken feed are underway. He hopes to resume exports to Singapore soon, citing the importance of the bilateral relationship between the two countries.

site_title: US mortgage rates slip as market shows signs of ‘normalising’
summary: US mortgage rates have declined for the third consecutive week, dropping to 5.09% for a 30-year loan, down from 5.1% last week, according to Freddie Mac. This slight reprieve from the massive rate increases this year is expected to have a cooling effect on the housing market, with nearly 1 in 5 sellers cutting listing prices in the past four weeks, the highest level since 2019. Borrowing costs remain up nearly 2 percentage points from the end of 2021.

site_title: Pfizer seeks US authorization of Covid vaccine for young children
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech have completed the filing with the US FDA seeking authorization for their Covid-19 vaccine in children under 5 years of age. Data shows a 3 lower-dose shot generated a strong immune response in children as young as 6 months of age. The FDA's independent advisers will discuss the applications on June 15. This move comes as no Covid-19 shot is yet approved for children under 5 in most parts of the world, despite low demand for vaccines in this age group among parents.

site_title: Look out for Malaysia’s recovery-themed stocks in 2H2022: analysts
summary: Malaysia's recovery-themed stocks are gaining attention from analysts as the country's economy recovers from the pandemic. Despite plantation companies performing well in the first quarter due to rising crude palm oil prices, analysts expect softer price growth in the second half. Analysts recommend focusing on value and cyclical stocks that can leverage on the recovery, while maintaining core holdings in defensive sectors. The FBMKLCI index is expected to reach 1,635 by the end of the year, valuing at 16.2 times its price-earnings ratio in 2022.

site_title: US for-sale homes rise for first time since 2019 on Realtor
summary: US home listings rose 8% year-over-year in May, marking the first increase since June 2019, according to Realtor.com data. The increase was driven by new sellers and a slowdown in would-be buyers deterred by high prices. Despite this, the median listing price reached a record $447,000 in May, and buyers made purchasing decisions more quickly than ever. However, rising mortgage rates and a softening economic outlook may have thinned out buyers, leading to accelerated price cuts. The housing market remains undersupplied, with listings still 48.5% below their 2020 level.

site_title: Euro and yen rebound vs US dollar, Swiss franc gains on inflation jump
summary: The euro and yen rebounded against the US dollar on Thursday, reversing recent losses, while the Swiss franc reached a 1-month high against the euro due to soaring Swiss inflation. The US dollar was down 0.4% against a basket of major currencies, while the euro climbed 0.4% to $1.0696. The yen also erased its early weakness, rising to 129.74 yen per US dollar. The Swiss franc's gains were driven by the highest inflation in 14 years, surpassing the euro's 1-month high.

site_title: Self-driving cars from GM’s Cruise could soon carry paying riders in San Francisco
summary: General Motors' Cruise may become the first company to secure a permit to charge for self-driving car rides in San Francisco, pending approval by the California Public Utilities Commission. Despite objections from city officials citing safety concerns, disability and business groups have expressed support for Cruise's proposal. The company has faced challenges, including a brief blockage of a fire engine and incidents involving human error, but claims its vehicles understand complex social dynamics and take safe actions to mitigate risks. However, his tendency to announce sweeping decisions in public without consulting his team has led to disastrous effects, including the collapse of projects like fully self-driving cars and a rocket-powered flying car. site_title: Engine No 1 rushes to back ESG disclosures at top companies

The China Securities Regulatory Commission released draft rules requiring investment banks and asset managers to share data with regulators, conduct penetration testing, and set up a centralized data backup center. The rules could disrupt operations and create significant risks for the sector, with the lobby group expressing concerns over the potential for hacking and data breaches.

These measures will take full effect by October 31, 2022, and will be progressively implemented by banks in consultation with MAS and the Singapore Police Force.

Loans to developers have plummeted 30% in recent months, undermining efforts to arrest a property slump and slow the world's second-largest economy. The banks are counting on a lifeline to the industry, which is facing a slowdown in bond funding and home sales.

images.alt_text: China’s property market problems are likely to worsen this year, with no growth in home prices seen for the full year.

site_title: Glencore to reject offer for Yancoal Australia stake as too low: sources
summary: Glencore is likely to reject a US$3.60 per share offer by Yancoal Australia Ltd's Chinese parent Yankuang Energy Group to buy its 6.4% stake in Yancoal, as the offer undervalues the company's stock. The US$1.8 billion offer, which is a discount to the current market price, was made last week. Glencore's decision is seen as a significant move in the energy commodities market, with the company holding a substantial stake in Yancoal. The rejection may impact the global coal market and lead to further negotiations between the parties.

images.alt_text: Glencore will pay US$1.5 billion to settle US and UK investigations into alleged wrongdoing by the giant commodities trader, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Indonesia's inflation inches up in May, stays within central bank target
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate rose 3.55% in May, the highest since December 2017, but remained within the central bank's 2-4% target range. Rising food prices, airfares, and global commodity prices contributed to the increase. The annual core inflation rate remained steady at 2.58%. The government has increased energy subsidies to keep energy prices stable, but some economists predict inflation will continue to rise in the country.

images.alt_text: INDONESIA cancelled a plan to send its citizens to work in palm oil plantations in neighbouring Malaysia, which has faced a labour shortage, its envoy to Kuala Lumpur said on Tuesday (May 31).

site_title: Swiss drugmaker Novartis resumes Ukraine business
summary: Novartis, a Swiss drugmaker, has resumed business operations in Ukraine after reviewing safety protocols following Russia's invasion in February. The company condemned the war and has been providing humanitarian support, financial donations, and medicine to those in need. Novartis prioritizes the safety and security of its people, regularly reviewing the situation and its business operations in Ukraine.

site_title: Indonesia has issued palm oil export permits for nearly 180,000 tonnes: official
summary: Indonesia has issued export permits for 179,464 tonnes of palm oil, lifting a 3-week export ban that controlled soaring cooking oil prices. The government had allocated 1 million tonnes of exports based on domestic sales during the ban. So far, permits have been issued for refined palm oil (87,109 tonnes) and cooking oil (90,255 tonnes), with the rest allocated for RBD olein. The move aims to balance domestic demand with exports.

site_title: Cotton rally squeezes Asian garment makers, threatens recovery from Covid
summary: Asian garment makers are struggling due to a near doubling of benchmark cotton futures to 11-year highs, exacerbated by freight and fuel price spikes. The surge has rendered thousands jobless, undermining a pandemic recovery and posing a fresh challenge for policymakers battling high inflation. Some manufacturers are replacing cotton with cheaper synthetic fabric to cut costs, while others have suspended operations. An uncertain outlook for European demand amid the Russia-Ukraine war has added to the woes of apparel makers, with Bangladesh exports accounting for over 60% of its garments to Europe.

site_title: China's Geely launches first 9 low-orbit satellites for autonomous cars
summary: China's Geely Holding Group successfully launched its first 9 low-orbit satellites, GeeSAT-1, on June 1, becoming the second major automaker to have a space business. The satellites will provide accurate navigation for autonomous vehicles and are expected to reach 240 by 2025. Geely partnered with a Chinese state-owned entity to launch the satellites using a Long March 2C rocket. The satellites have a 5-year lifespan and will disintegrate in the atmosphere, reducing space debris. This move follows China's government call for an integrated network of satellites for communications and navigation.

images.alt_text: Mazda Motor Corp will aim to achieve carbon neutrality at its factories worldwide by 2035, it said on Thursday.

site_title: Japan price pressures mounting as firms ditch ‘deflation’ model, says Bank of Japan official
summary: Japan may experience inflationary pressure as companies shift away from the "deflation" model, according to Bank of Japan board member Seiji Adachi. With global commodity prices rising, firms are raising rates, indicating a shift towards a higher-profit business model. However, Adachi warned that it's premature to tighten monetary policy, as inflation remains short of the 2% target and the economy hasn't fully recovered from the Covid-19 pandemic. He cautioned that tightening policy now could harm business and household activity.

site_title: Julius Baer sells Fransad business to management
summary: Julius Baer is selling its Geneva-based wealth manager Fransad Gestion to its management team for an undisclosed amount. The decision aims to simplify the bank's portfolio and strengthen Fransad's position as a major Swiss independent wealth manager. Fransad manages around 1.5 billion Swiss francs (S$2.15 billion) of assets and will continue to work with Julius Baer.

site_title: Kim Kardashian to start new skin-care line with Coty
summary: Kim Kardashian is launching a new skin-care line, SKKN by Kim, with Coty, set to debut on June 21. The initial products include a cleanser, toner, and various serums and creams, priced between $43 and $95. This venture follows Kardashian's previous beauty business ventures, including KKW Beauty and KKW Fragrance, which she rebranded and shut down in 2021. The move is part of Coty's strategy to leverage Kardashian's star power to boost sales, as the company has previously acquired stakes in her beauty businesses.

site_title: The ECB’s interest-rate balancing act
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a balancing act in addressing record-high eurozone inflation, which is largely driven by high energy prices and supply chain disruptions. Policymakers must consider financial stability and a faster green transition when raising interest rates, as cutting green investments to push down prices in the short run could make the economy more vulnerable to climate-related shocks. The ECB should differentiate refinancing rates and collateral policies to ensure that monetary policy supports long-term green investments and bolsters the economy against inflationary shocks.

images.alt_text: Euro zone inflation rose to another record high in May, boosting government bond yields as markets saw the data as a challenge to the European Central Bank’s view that gradual interest rate increases from July will be enough to tame fast price growth.

site_title: Rate hikes spur bets that Asian central banks will keep going
summary: Asian central banks are expected to hike interest rates more aggressively amid rising inflationary pressures, with traders pricing in higher terminal rates in countries such as India, South Korea, and Malaysia. The Bank of Korea raised its inflation forecast to 4.5% and the Japanese firm Nomura Holdings projects a terminal rate of 6.25% by April 2023. These rate hikes are driven by concerns over global inflation, oil prices near a 3-month high, and European inflation data exceeding expectations, with risks of higher terminal rates in Asia considered "certain" but already priced into markets.

site_title: Singapore warehouses likely to fill up more quickly if oil prices keep rising
summary: Singapore's warehouse occupancy is expected to rise as oil prices continue to increase, according to IREUS. The research institute notes that higher oil prices lead to higher costs for manufacturers, narrower margins, and a tighter market for storage space. This may drive up rents for warehousing, particularly if new supply is quickly absorbed. The trend is seen in previous periods, such as 2006-2008 and 2010-2012, where oil price hikes coincided with sharp rises in warehouse occupancies and rents.

site_title: KKR veteran hunts for startup stars with new fund
summary: Sanjay Nayar, a veteran KKR adviser, has raised US$125 million for his new venture fund, Sorin Investment Management, targeting early-stage startups in India. The fund, which plans to back 10 startups, aims to capitalize on the current funding drought in the country's tech sector. Nayar's fund will focus on sectors including consumer tech, fintech, and software-as-a-service, and will provide capital, advice, and global perspectives to its portfolio companies. This move comes as some prominent venture investors are nursing quarterly losses due to the tech rout.

site_title: Australia offers Samoa new coastguard vessel as part of charm offensive
summary: Australia will provide a new coastguard patrol boat to Samoa, replacing one that recently ran aground, as part of a charm offensive to reset ties and counter growing Chinese influence. Foreign Minister Penny Wong announced the offer during a visit to Samoa, following a meeting with Prime Minister Fiame Naomi Mata'afa. The Guardian-class vessel is expected to be supplied next year, addressing Samoa's maritime security concerns. The move comes as Australia seeks to counter China's growing presence in the Pacific region.

site_title: Ancient Mayan maize god sculpture found in Mexico
summary: Archaeologists in southeastern Mexico have discovered a 1,300-year-old sculpture representing the head of a Mayan maize god in the ruins of Palenque. The sculpture, found in humid conditions, is slowly drying out before restoration. According to researcher Arnoldo Gonzalez Cruz, the discovery allows for a better understanding of the ancient Maya's mythical passage of the birth, death, and resurrection of the maize deity. The sculpture, facing east to west, symbolizes the birth of the maize plant with the first rays of the sun.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday with losses, influenced by global economic concerns and interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.12% to 21,057.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.37%. The losses were attributed to worries about the global economy, with central banks raising interest rates to counter inflation.

site_title: No 'red line' against central bank digital currency, BoE's Hauser says
summary: Bank of England executive director Andrew Hauser stated that a central bank digital currency (CBDC) would not pose a significant challenge to the Bank of England's operations, contrary to concerns about its impact on traditional banking systems. He noted that a CBDC would be a new type of central bank liability, but one that aligns with the BoE's goals and would not replace cash. The BoE views a CBDC as a broader form of public access to its sterling reserves, potentially reducing banks' role in day-to-day payments.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Australia wins bid to operate bus services in Darwin
summary: ComfortDelGro Australia's wholly-owned subsidiary CDC Darwin has won a 6-year contract to operate bus services in Darwin, Palmerston, rural areas, and special needs services. The contract, starting July 1, will cover 170 vehicles and 180 bus routes, with CDC Australia planning to hire over 340 people and operate more than 210 buses. The company will also introduce reduced emissions buses, including 9 new Volvo hybrid buses. This win expands CDC Australia's bus services, which also include Alice Springs, Batchelor, and Jabiru school services.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 2.64 points or 0.17% to 1,550.77. The index saw 208.3 million lots traded worth RM69.9 million, with 135 gainers outnumbering 129 losers.

site_title: South Korean ruling party wins landslide in local elections
summary: South Korea's ruling People Power Party (PPP) won a landslide victory in local elections, securing 12 of 17 major posts, including the capital Seoul and Busan. President Yoon Suk Yeol's party gained a significant boost ahead of his presidency, which faces scrutiny from the opposition-controlled National Assembly. The opposition Democratic Party (DP) suffered a setback, winning only five key races, amid internal rifts and scandals. The PPP's victory is seen as a significant boost to Yoon's presidency and a potential challenge to the DP's dominance.

site_title: India’s new VPN rules spark fresh fears over online privacy
summary: India's new VPN rules require VPN providers to retain user data and IP addresses for at least five years, sparking fears over online privacy and freedom of speech. Many VPN providers, including ExpressVPN, are leaving India or considering removal due to the potential for data breaches and abuse. The rules have raised concerns among tech firms and digital rights organizations, who argue they could undermine cybersecurity and put users' data at risk. India ranks among the top 20 countries in VPN adoption, with many users using them to access blocked websites and protect their identity.

site_title: Australia: Tech, financials drag shares lower on Thursday
summary: Australian shares fell 1% to 7,164.50, dragged by losses in technology and banking stocks due to potential US Federal Reserve rate hikes. Technology stocks dropped 2% and financials fell 1% with major banks trading in negative territory. Energy stocks, however, rose 2% on sharper oil prices following the EU's phased ban on Russian oil. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand allowed registered trading banks to resume paying dividends.

site_title: Who is Javier Olivan, Meta's next COO?
summary: Meta Platforms veteran Javier Olivan is taking over as the company's chief operating officer, replacing Sheryl Sandberg. Olivan, 44, has been with Meta for 15 years, overseeing its international growth and expansion into countries like India and Japan. He will continue to lead infrastructure and corporate development, but also take on advertising and business products. The move comes as Meta struggles with slowing growth and rising costs, transforming from a social media company to a metaverse-focused business. Olivan's more traditional COO role may contrast with Sandberg's more visible presence.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Thursday after Wall Street loss
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, following a decline on Wall Street due to inflation concerns. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% to 27,317.32, and the Topix index dropped 0.81% to 1,923.02. The decline was attributed to investor worries about inflation, with the US stock market experiencing a similar downturn.

site_title: Ford may slash ad spending, revamp dealers to boost EV profit, CEO says
summary: Ford Motor CEO Jim Farley says the automaker needs to overhaul its century-old business model to compete with Tesla and others in the electric vehicle market. To boost EV profit, Ford may slash ad spending and rework its dealer network. Farley describes the shift to EVs as a "huge price war" as competition shifts from established players to newcomers from China and Silicon Valley.
