site_title: Thailand's budget bill increase expected to pass, bodes well for contractors: CGS-CIMB
summary: Thailand's proposed 3.19 trillion baht (S$127.3 billion) 2023 budget is expected to pass, potentially benefiting contractors, according to a CGS-CIMB research report. The budget includes a 22% increase in rail transport and logistics spending and a 14% increase in investment budget. The bill's passage is crucial for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's premiership, and while opposition concerns about using funds to boost popularity are valid, CGS-CIMB believes the bill will pass in the first reading. summary: Philippine billionaire Enrique Razon's Prime Infra will acquire a controlling stake in the Malampaya deep-water gas-to-power project from businessman Dennis Uy's Udenna. Malampaya's service contract expires in 2024, and the field's reserves are expected to be depleted by the end of the decade. Prime Infra plans to apply for an extension and expand production to support it.

site_title: Russia fails to meet bond obligations, triggering swaps payout
summary: Russia has failed to meet its bond obligations, triggering a credit-default swaps payout potentially worth billions of dollars. The Credit Derivatives Determinations Committee (CDDC) ruled that a "failure-to-pay" event occurred after Russia missed a $1.9 million interest payment. This triggers an insurance payout for holders of the bond, who will also receive the original bond payment. The missed interest is a small amount, but it sets off a chain reaction of payouts for all of Russia's outstanding credit default swaps, valued at $1.5 billion.

site_title: Gold prices steady as easing Treasury yields lift appeal
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Thursday, supported by lower US Treasury yields, as investors sought safe-haven bullion amid concerns over stubborn inflation worldwide. Spot gold was steady at $1,847.49 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2% to $1,851.40. The appeal of zero-yield gold increased with benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields dipping, and the US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation.

summary: Amazon workers seeking to recoup remote work-related expenses incurred during the pandemic moved closer to trial after a California judge rejected the company's request to dismiss the class-action lawsuit. The celebrations are forecast to bring in £1.2 billion to the economy, with 5.3 million Britons taking time off work. site_title: Why building cyber resilience needs more than just technology
summary: The threat of cybercrime in Asia has reached an all-time high, with fifth-generation cyber attacks growing in complexity and magnitude. A 2022 IBM study found Asia was the most targeted geography of 2021, with 26% of global attacks on organizations. A perception gap exists between business executives and security leaders on cyber resilience, with 92% of executives believing their organizations are secure but only 55% agreeing they have taken adequate measures. Stronger safeguards are needed to navigate the growing cyber risk, and organizations, especially SMEs, must adopt a holistic cybersecurity strategy that includes enhancing cloud resiliency, monitoring insider threats, and having regular cyber exercises.

summary: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase CEO, warned investors of an impending economic "hurricane" due to tightening monetary policy and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. summary: The US economy appears to be downshifting due to rising interest rates and inflation, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report. summary: GameStop reported a 50% increase in total quarterly revenue, exceeding market expectations, driven by higher demand for video games and software collectibles. The company's online sales capabilities have been bolstered amid increasing competition from large retailers. Net loss for the first quarter widened to $157.9 million, but shares soared 687% last year following a "short-squeeze" battle with hedge funds. GameStop has also launched a digital asset wallet for cryptocurrencies and NFTs, although an analyst has expressed skepticism about its viability.

site_title: Sheryl Sandberg, key executive at Facebook’s Meta, to step down
summary: Sheryl Sandberg, Meta's COO and second most powerful executive, is stepping down after a 14-year tenure, citing the company's uncertain future and fierce competition. Sandberg's departure comes as Meta rebrands itself to pivot toward the metaverse and faces accusations of prioritizing profit over user privacy. Mark Zuckerberg stated that Sandberg's role won't be replaced, and Javier Olivan will become the next COO, but with a more traditional role. Meta shares fell 2% on the news, adding to the company's declining stock value.

site_title: Oracle wins regulatory approvals for US$28b Cerner takeover
summary: Oracle has received all regulatory clearances to complete its $28.3 billion purchase of digital medical-records provider Cerner. The acquisition, announced in December, is expected to be "substantially accretive" to Oracle's earnings in fiscal year 2023 and a "growth engine for years to come." Oracle chairman and CTO Larry Ellison stated that the deal will transform healthcare delivery by providing medical professionals with new healthcare information systems. The acquisition will expand Oracle's presence in the healthcare industry, allowing it to gain ground in cloud computing.

site_title: China’s May new home prices up slightly, private survey shows
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.03% in May from the previous month, according to a private survey, as the country's property market remains fragile due to tight Covid-19 curbs. The growth is a slight increase from April's 0.02% gain. Despite policy easing measures, home prices are unlikely to grow this year, with many cities reporting no monthly growth. Local governments are expected to further ease restrictions in June, with tier-two cities relaxing home purchase restrictions for households with multiple children.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as weak economic data heightens growth worries
summary: European shares fell on Wednesday, dropping -1.0% due to weak German retail sales and slowing factory activity in the euro zone. Weak economic data fueled concerns about economic growth amid record-high inflation. The Stoxx 600 index has marked losses for all months except March, with investors worried about central bank policy tightening and the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Investors making their voices heard, votes count in AGMs
summary: Investors in Singapore are becoming more active at listed companies' annual general meetings (AGMs), making their voices heard through their votes. A recent trend shows that investors are challenging resolutions proposed by companies, with some being rejected due to concerns over board composition, independence, and long tenure. This increased activism is attributed to the growing influence of institutional investors, who are pushing for greater accountability and transparency. Experts say that companies' boards should respond to these developments by being more proactive in their engagements and addressing concerns raised by investors.

site_title: Levi sees sales reaching US$10b in new set of targets
summary: Levi Strauss & Co. sets new sales targets of $9 billion to $10 billion by 2027, aiming for 6-8% annual sales growth. The company plans to boost investment in its stores, website, and women's apparel, with a focus on premium and digital customers. It also expects 55% of annual sales to come from its own channels, up from 39% in the first quarter. The shares rose 2.4% following the announcement.

site_title: Trump still calling the shots in the GOP?
summary: Donald Trump's hold on the Republican Party may be weakening after the recent primaries in Georgia and Nebraska, where his candidates lost to other Republican contenders. Despite his popularity among the MAGA base, Trump's unsubstantiated claims about the 2020 election have not resonated with voters, and many Republicans have distanced themselves from his claims. Trump remains the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, but recent losses suggest his momentum may be ebbing, and his influence over the party may be waning.

site_title: Some real estate markets seen falling as global frenzy fades
summary: Global property market frenzy is fading as interest rates rise and house price inflation is expected to drop off. Analysts predict modest falls in housing prices in 2023, but affordability remains a concern for first-time buyers, particularly with rising basic costs of living and mortgage rates. The decline in prices won't make housing more affordable, and experts warn that huge price rises of up to 50% may be coming to an end.

site_title: Oil rises as EU to phase in Russian  oil ban, Shanghai ends lockdown
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as the European Union agreed to a phased ban on Russian oil imports, with Brent crude settling at $116.29 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $115.26. The ban, which aims to cut 90% of oil imports from Russia by the end of the year, is expected to significantly impact Russia's oil exports. Meanwhile, China ended its two-month Covid-19 lockdown in Shanghai, potentially bolstering fuel demand.

site_title: Ukraine war, pandemic set to speed Europe’s green energy transition: report
summary: Most EU countries have increased their renewable energy plans since 2020, aiming to cut fossil fuel use this decade. 17 of the 27 EU countries have boosted their plans, which would see 63% of EU electricity produced from renewables by 2030. This would lead to a 114% drop in EU fossil fuel-based power generation. Despite concerns over energy costs and supply shocks triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, countries like Germany, the Netherlands, and Austria are accelerating their renewable energy goals, with some setting coal exit dates.

site_title: Saudis may exit Opec+ pact early amid Russia turmoil: RBC Capital Markets
summary: Saudi Arabia may exit the Opec+ oil supply pact early due to Russia's turmoil, according to RBC Capital Markets. The pact, which aims to restore production halted during the pandemic by the end of September, could be brought forward as European Union sanctions threaten to curtail Russia's exports. Saudi Arabia would likely attach conditions to any changes, seeking to rehabilitate its partnership with the US and secure regional security assurances. The Biden administration may pressure Saudi Arabia to make the change.

site_title: Listed companies should use technology to strengthen bonds with retail investors
summary: Singapore-listed companies can use technology to strengthen bonds with retail investors, despite the latter group's relatively smaller influence compared to institutional investors. Companies can leverage technology to engage with retail investors through corporate videos, podcasts, and webinars, providing them with insights and updates on the company's operations, industry developments, and sustainability initiatives. This can help build relationships and deepen engagement with a large number of retail investors, potentially making them more important for listed groups in the future.

site_title: Queen ‘inspired by goodwill’ for historic jubilee celebrations
summary: Queen Elizabeth II urged British subjects and Commonwealth nations to look ahead with "confidence and enthusiasm" as they prepare to celebrate her 70-year reign. The Platinum Jubilee festivities, which began Thursday, coincide with a surge in inflation and doubts over the monarchy's future. The queen expressed gratitude to those involved in organizing activities and hopes the coming days will provide an opportunity to reflect on the past 70 years. The celebrations include Trooping the Colour, a military parade, and a fly-past of Spitfires, with the goal of boosting sales and marking a turning point in the monarchy's history.

site_title: Depp wins in bitter Heard defamation trial
summary: A US jury found Johnny Depp and his ex-wife Amber Heard liable for defamation, but sided more strongly with Depp, awarding him $15 million in damages. The jury also found Heard defamatory, awarding her $2 million in damages. Heard called the verdict a "setback" for women, stating it undermines the seriousness of violence against women. The six-week trial featured testimony from dozens of witnesses, including Depp and Heard, and included video recordings of heated arguments and photographs of alleged injuries.

site_title: YTL Power acquires Hyflux's Tuaspring power station for S$270m in cash
summary: YTL Power International has completed the acquisition of Hyflux's Tuaspring power station in Singapore for S$270 million in cash. The power station, which was originally part of a desalination project, will add 396 megawatts to YTL PowerSeraya's existing capacity, making it one of the largest power generation companies in Singapore. The acquisition complements YTL Power's existing power generation assets in Singapore and creates significant synergies across its portfolio of utility businesses.

site_title: US manufacturing sector regains speed in May
summary: US manufacturing activity rebounded to a reading of 56.1 in May, indicating expansion, as demand for goods remains strong despite fears of an imminent recession. The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey also showed a rise in new orders and a decrease in supplier deliveries. However, factory employment contracted for the first time in nearly a year, with a measure of 49.6, potentially due to worker shortages. The strong manufacturing data could further alleviate recession concerns, but the nation's central bank continues to raise interest rates to tame inflation.

images.alt_text: Orders placed with US factories for durable goods rose in April, highlighting firm and sustained demand for equipment and merchandise.

site_title: Biden takes aim at inflation but short on weapons
summary: US President Joe Biden has launched a battle against soaring prices as inflation reaches its fastest pace in over 40 years. Despite a strong economy, Biden's administration is struggling to find effective solutions to ease the pain faced by American families ahead of key congressional elections. The Federal Reserve has taken the lead in tackling inflation, raising interest rates to cool the economy, and Biden has pledged to give the central bank space to do its work. With public dissatisfaction growing, Biden's approval ratings are barely in the 40% range, and his options for immediate action are limited.

site_title: Ukraine braces for Severodonetsk fall, awaits new US weapons
summary: Ukraine is bracing for the potential fall of Severodonetsk to Russian forces, but a US decision to send advanced rocket systems, including the Himars multiple launch rocket system, may boost Ukrainian defenses. The US package also includes air-surveillance radar, anti-tank rockets, and helicopters. The Kremlin has accused the US of "adding fuel to the fire" and discouraging peace talks. Ukraine's prosecutor general has identified thousands of war crimes cases, and Kyiv is set to prosecute 80 suspects. The conflict has also threatened a global food crisis, with Ukraine's grain harvest effectively taken off the world market.

site_title: Return to office or leave, Musk tells Tesla staff
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has asked employees to return to office or leave the company, with a minimum of 40 hours in the office per week, according to an email. If employees don't comply, they will be assumed to have resigned. This comes as some tech workers resist returning to work in California due to a resurgence of coronavirus cases. Musk's decision joins a wave of companies mandating a return to office, with Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal also reopening Twitter offices while allowing employees to work from home if preferred.

site_title: Singapore launches trade data sharing platform to cut supply chain inefficiencies, rebuild trust
summary: Singapore has launched the Singapore Trade Data Exchange (SGTraDex), a digital platform that enables over 70 participants to share trade data and reduce supply chain inefficiencies. The platform aims to rebuild trust in the local and global supply chains, with initial use cases focusing on financing integrity, container logistics, and bunkering industry digitalization. By 2026, the platform is expected to unlock over S$100 million in value for existing participants through cost savings and improved efficiency. The platform is backed by a S$50 million investment from the Infocomm Media Development Authority and the National Research Foundation.

summary: The Biden administration has initiated trade dialogue with Taiwan, aiming to strengthen economic ties and counter China's influence in the Asia-Pacific region. The talks, set to begin in Washington, will focus on digital trade, reducing red tape, and addressing mutual complaints over Chinese trade practices. The US seeks to eliminate forced labor and non-market practices, while Taiwan hopes to deepen its trade ties with the US. The discussions will be held under the auspices of the American Institute in Taiwan and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office.

site_title: China's Tencent revises pay rise policy in memo, amid cost savings pressures
summary: China's Tencent Holdings has revised its pay rise policy, no longer guaranteeing employees a pay raise upon promotion, amid a wider cost-cutting drive. The decision, made as part of a yearly review, reflects the changing circumstances of the company amid a regulatory crackdown and a slowing economy. Tencent reported its worst quarterly earnings since going public in 2004, with profit halved and revenues stagnating. The company has implemented cost control measures and scaled back non-core businesses, including shutting its Penguin Esports unit.

summary: US stocks slid for a second consecutive session on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.5% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declining 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. Despite a stronger-than-expected American factory growth report, inflation worries continued to weigh on sentiment, with the Federal Reserve's "beige book" survey indicating a slowdown in business growth and concerns about a recession.

site_title: DWS sends ‘shock waves’ through ESG fund management industry
summary: Deutsche Bank's DWS Group CEO Asoka Woehrmann resigned amid allegations of greenwashing, sending shockwaves through the ESG fund management industry. The departure coincides with growing cynicism around ESG claims and regulatory scrutiny of the industry's quality control. European regulators, including the French Financial Supervisory Authority, have questioned the effectiveness of the EU's Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, citing loopholes that allow for greenwashing. This marks a turning point for the industry, with fund managers expected to be more cautious about their ESG statements and regulations aiming to improve the industry's standards.

This move comes as China's economic activity contracted in April and unemployment rose sharply, with Premier Li Keqiang warning of risks from a possible year-on-year contraction in the second quarter. The credit line could help finance a significant chunk of infrastructure costs this year, supporting China's growth-boosting policies.

summary: France's financial watchdog criticizes European ESG regulations, warning that the current framework opens the door to greenwashing. The head of the Autorite des Marches Financiers, Robert Ophele, expresses concerns over the design of the EU's Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation, citing a lack of harmonization and coordination among national regulators. He also criticizes the EU's failure to effectively police ESG claims, leading to a "tendency to push, to race to the bottom" and a "fragmentation of the union."

site_title: Awareness of ESG gaining momentum in Malaysia, says Surbana-owned consultancy SMEC
summary: Malaysia aims to increase its renewable energy capacity from 18% to 40% by 2035 to meet its Paris Agreement targets and reduce carbon intensity. Hydropower currently dominates the renewable energy mix, accounting for around 86% of the country's renewable energy sources. The government's efforts towards achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 are gaining momentum, with energy transition playing a bigger role in every company's sustainability and growth strategy.

site_title: Dollar edges up against euro, hits two-week high vs yen
summary: The US dollar edged up against the euro, hitting a two-week high versus the yen, as global inflation worries increased. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 101.96, while the euro fell 0.2% to $1.068, following a record high in euro zone consumer inflation. Treasury yields also rose, lifting the dollar against the yen to a 129.54 high. Markets are pricing in half-point interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve, but the outlook beyond that is uncertain.

site_title: The Rolling Stones open 60th anniversary tour in Madrid
summary: The Rolling Stones kicked off their 60th anniversary tour in Madrid, marking six decades since the band's formation. The tour will include 14 European concerts, including two shows in London, and follows the band's "No Filter" tour, which resumed late last year after a pandemic delay. The tour features the band's classic hits and celebrates their 50th anniversary of iconic album "Exile on Main St." with frontman Mick Jagger, 78, and fellow band members Keith Richards, 78, and Ronnie Wood, 75, performing in cities across Europe.

site_title: The Hour Glass to acquire Brisbane property for A$82m
summary: Luxury watch retailer The Hour Glass has acquired a freehold property in Brisbane for A$82.2 million. The 2-storey retail and office building is located at the junction of Edward Street and Elizabeth Street in Brisbane's central business district. The acquisition is in line with The Hour Glass's strategy of owning properties in prime locations in selected cities. The group will fund the acquisition through internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: South Korea’s new president gets boost in big election win
summary: South Korea's conservative President Yoon Suk Yeol's party is expected to win at least 10 of 17 major city and provincial posts in elections held on June 1, a joint exit poll showed. This would boost Yoon's political power to push his policy agenda, including economic growth driven by the private sector. The Democratic Party, which took 14 posts in the last election, is projected to suffer a sharp fall, taking at least 4 posts. Yoon's policies, including addressing housing prices, may help him push through changes at the local level despite a roadblock in the National Assembly.

site_title: Sri Lanka lifts import curbs to help tackle worsening shortages
summary: Sri Lanka lifted import restrictions on 369 essential items to alleviate shortages of food and medicine. The move allows imports to be shipped without an Import Control Licence, and importers are advised to prioritize essential purchases. The Finance Ministry also postponed open-account payment changes, allowing cargoes to be released immediately. The goal is to conserve foreign exchange for essential commodities and ensure uninterrupted supply.

site_title: UK house prices defy slowdown fears with 10th consecutive gain
summary: The UK housing market defied slowdown fears with a 10th consecutive monthly gain, with house prices rising 0.9% in May, according to Nationwide Building Society. The average price of a home reached a record £269,914, an 11.2% increase from last year. Strong labour market conditions and low home inventory continue to support demand, despite inflation and rising interest rates. However, economist Robert Gardner expects the market to slow as the year progresses due to further budget squeezes and less affordable mortgages.

site_title: Denso bullish on business prospects as it tackles chip shortages
summary: Japan's largest auto supplier, Denso, expressed bullishness on its business prospects despite semiconductor shortages affecting Toyota Motor, its largest shareholder and customer. Denso expects demand for automotive chips to increase by a third by 2025, driven by growing use in fossil-fuel cars, electric vehicles, and autonomous drive technology. site_title: Biden to devote US$2.1b to strengthen US food supply chain
summary: The US government will announce $2.1 billion in funding to strengthen the US food supply chain, including expanding small- and mid-sized processing plants, cold storage facilities, and assisting farmers shifting to organic production. The initiatives aim to address weaknesses in the country's food supply chains, such as the baby formula shortage and soaring food prices. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack will focus on creating a more resilient food system, moving away from dominance by a few highly concentrated businesses, and addressing climate change challenges.

site_title: Vietnam develops 'world's first' African swine fever vaccine for commercial use
summary: Vietnam has successfully developed the world's first commercial vaccine for African swine fever, a devastating livestock disease that has killed hundreds of millions of pigs globally. The vaccine, developed in partnership with US experts, has been tested and confirmed safe and effective. Vietnam aims to become the first country to commercially produce and export the vaccine, which has a 6-month immunity period. The vaccine's development is seen as a significant milestone for the veterinary industry, providing a shield for the global hog-raising industry and pig production.

site_title: Saudi Arabia is planning the largest buildings ever built
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to build the world's largest buildings as part of its $500 billion Neom development, a brainchild of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The project, known as The Line, will feature twin skyscrapers stretching 500 meters tall horizontally for dozens of miles, with residential, retail, and office space. The Line is part of Prince Mohammed's plan to diversify the Saudi economy and attract foreign investment, with a possible cost of up to $200 billion. The project will be built in stages based on demand, and its feasibility has been questioned in the past, but officials say it will be a sustainable, modern city.

The government's efforts to lift restrictions and reopen businesses contributed to the improvement, with dining hours extended and gyms and beauty salons allowed to reopen.

site_title: As recession looms, UK markets clash with BOE stance on interest rates
summary: The UK's central bank, the Bank of England, is facing a challenge in balancing the economy amid a looming recession and high inflation. Despite policy makers' cautious approach, money market traders are betting on a rapid tightening of interest rates, with some speculating for a 2 percentage point increase in the benchmark rate. The gap between the BOE's guidance and market pricing has widened, with investors questioning the bank's credibility. The UK's unique economic situation, including energy price volatility and labor shortages, is making it harder for the BOE to control inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The London Stock Exchange Group. London has been gradually losing ground to continental exchanges in the wake of the Brexit vote, with the Netherlands and Sweden narrowing the listings gap over the past couple of years.

site_title: Europe can stop Russia’s aggression now
summary: The European Union can effectively stop Russia's aggression in Ukraine by imposing a high tariff on Russian oil exports, rather than just an oil embargo. This approach has been shown to be more effective in reducing Russian revenue and has the added benefit of not slowing the global economy. By forming a buyers' cartel, the EU can increase the price of Russian oil, making it less attractive to buy and potentially forcing Russia to redirect its exports to Asia. This strategy can help to reduce Russian brutality in Ukraine and prevent the use of nuclear weapons, but it requires a coordinated effort from EU member states.

images.alt_text: European Union leaders agreed to pursue a partial ban on Russian oil, paving the way for a sixth package of sanctions to punish Russia and its president, Vladimir Putin, for the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Abu Dhabi moves to restrict single-use plastics
summary: Abu Dhabi has implemented a single-use plastic bags ban, effective immediately, to encourage sustainable living and support the emirate's goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050. Retailers are encouraged to offer reusable bags with a nominal fee. Exemptions include medicine bags, supermarket produce bags, rubbish sacks, and large brand name shopping bags. The move follows Dubai's announcement to end free single-use plastic bag provision and comes ahead of the COP28 global environmental conference in 2023.

images.alt_text: Maria Nissan, an environmental activist and artist, with an installation made from plastic waste collected from the streets, in Amman; Nissan's art is often collages themed on women’s faces, flowers and Oriental motifs.

site_title: Thailand to meet revenue collection target this year and next: Finance minister
summary: Thailand is expected to meet its revenue collection targets for 2022 and 2023, driven by strong exports and a recovery in tourism. Despite a global surge in food and energy prices, the country's economic indicators, such as exports, have performed well. The government proposes a budget of 3.185 trillion baht and targets revenue of 2.49 trillion baht for the next fiscal year. Tourism revenue is expected to increase following the reopening to foreign visitors, while higher imports will also contribute to tax revenue, with the state planning agency forecasting 7 million foreign tourist arrivals this year.

site_title: Which way is the NFT art market headed?
summary: NFT collectors are shifting towards a "flight to quality" due to the collapse of stablecoin Terra and financial instability, favoring digital art with long-term value. Creators are also holding off new releases to hone their skills, indicating a more selective and cautious approach in the NFT market.

site_title: RedBird buys Italian champions AC Milan
summary: US investment firm RedBird Capital Partners has agreed to buy Italian soccer champions AC Milan for 1.2 billion euros, with current owners Elliott retaining a minority investment. The transition to new ownership is expected to take place over the summer, with a closing no later than September. RedBird, which also owns Liverpool FC and Toulouse, aims to return Milan to its rightful place at the top of football. The club has just won the Italian Serie A league title for the first time in 11 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on June 1, 2022, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.65% or 178.09 points to 27,457.89, driven by a weaker yen and investor buying of exporter shares. The broader Topix index rose 1.36% or 25.97 points to 1,938.64.

site_title: At least 66 international events secured for rest of 2022: STB
summary: Singapore has secured at least 66 international events for the rest of 2022, including marquee events like Food Hotels Asia Food and Beverage and the Bloomberg New Economy Forum. Events previously held in Hong Kong, such as Jewellery and Gem World Singapore, SuperReturn Asia, and Cosmoprof Asia, have been relocated to Singapore. The return of MICE activities is expected to boost visitor traffic, with the busiest venues including the Sands Expo and Exhibition Centre, Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre, and Singapore Expo.

images.alt_text: STB to focus on business tourism as part of strategy to recapture demand
WINE and spirits exhibition Vinexpo Asia will be moving to Singapore in 2023, from its original event location in Hong Kong where it was held for more than 20 years, said organiser Vinexposium.
Constellar group chief executive officer Jean-Francois Quentin

site_title: Euro-Asia Apartments up for en bloc sale at S$218m guide price
summary: A 56,476 sq ft site in District 12's Boon Keng and Bendemeer estates is up for collective sale at a guide price of S$218 million. The 84-unit Euro-Asia Apartments, completed in 1990, has an allowable plot ratio of 2.8 and could yield 173 new dwelling units. The site is located near Farrer Park, a growing catchment, and is close to amenities and transportation links. The tender exercise will close on July 25, with a strong interest from developers expected due to the site's palatable price quantum and potential for new units.

images.alt_text: Kovan’s Jansen Mansions will be put up for its third collective sale with an increased reserve price of S$18.9 million via public tender on June 2, marketing agency PropNex Realty announced on Wednesday (Jun 1).

site_title: Review of compulsory acquisition requirements underway
summary: Acra proposes amendments to the compulsory acquisition framework to address concerns raised by minority shareholders of TTJ Holdings, following reviews of the Companies Act. The changes aim to strike a balance between ensuring requirements are fair and not overly burdensome for companies to restructure. The proposed amendments will be introduced to address the "takeover loophole" and its impact on minority shareholders, as highlighted in recent letters to the editor.

site_title: Philippines to fix weak spots in path to US$500b economy
summary: The Philippines aims to boost its economy to a $500 billion target by 2028, with a growth rate of 6-8% annually. Incoming economic planning secretary Arsenio Balisacan plans to address weak spots by increasing investment in agriculture and manufacturing, and building infrastructure. He targets at least 6% annual growth and aims to reduce poverty to 9% by 2028, with a focus on targeted support measures to ease inflation's burden on the poor.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Philippine president-elect Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr., son of late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, speaks during a news conference at his headquarters in Mandaluyong City, Metro Manila, Philippines, May 23, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Marie David/File Photo

site_title: Britain tells airlines to stop selling flights they can't deliver
summary: Britain's Transport Secretary Grant Shapps has instructed airlines to stop selling tickets for flights they cannot staff due to staffing shortages. The decision comes after a series of airline cancellations caused widespread disruption for holidaymakers. Shapps said the government has taken steps to help the industry, but airlines must now take responsibility for ensuring flights can be staffed. The move aims to prevent a repeat of recent disruptions during the school half-term holiday and Jubilee public holiday weekend.

images.alt_text: Cancelled flights, long queues and staff shortages have disrupted the travel plans of British holidaymakers during the half-term break, a grim sign of possible summer strife for a global sector battling to rebound from a two-year Covid slump.

site_title: China iron ore futures extend gains on demand hopes, steel output controls may weigh
summary: Chinese iron ore futures rose for the fourth straight session, driven by investor sentiment after the state council's package to rescue the economy. Benchmark futures surged 1.1% to 906 yuan (S$185.78) a tonne, while seaborne iron ore prices increased US$2 to US$138.5 a tonne. However, steel output controls may restrain further price jumps, according to analysts. Other commodity futures, including coking coal, coke, and steel rebar, also rose, but some, such as stainless steel futures, declined.

images.alt_text: A slump in Chinese iron ore imports extended into April, as suppliers struggled with disruptions while a Covid outbreak suppressed demand.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades SATS to ‘hold’ amid rising cost pressure
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded its call on SATS to "hold" from "buy" due to lower-than-expected Q4 results and rising cost pressures on operating margins. Analyst Jason Sum lowered his target price to S$4.50 from S$4.90, citing potential upside of 4.7%. SATS reported a net profit of S$7.2 million for its second half of FY2021-22, swinging into the black from a net loss in the year-ago period, but recorded an operating loss of S$46.6 million. The analyst expects SATS to be back in the black in FY2024 with dividends reinstated.

images.alt_text: H2 revenue was up 14.7 per cent to S$607.3 million, as travel continued to recover with the easing of border restrictions.

site_title: Singapore’s Mice industry expected to see full recovery in 2-3 years: STB
summary: Singapore's meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) industry is expected to recover fully from the COVID-19 pandemic in 2-3 years, according to the Singapore Tourism Board. The industry has already seen a significant recovery, with over 150 events hosted in the first 3 months of 2022, and 66 international events secured for the rest of the year. The board has also launched an enhanced incentive program, Inspire Global 2.0, to attract more business tourism.

images.alt_text: More than 60 events are slated to take place in Singapore in the second half of this year.
STB to focus on business tourism as part of strategy to recapture demand

site_title: Japan's Panasonic sees global car output improving this business year
summary: Panasonic Holdings expects global car production to recover this fiscal year, despite a two-year-long chip shortage. The company predicts a 19% increase in sales and nearly 17% rise in operating profit for its automotive business. CEO Masashi Nagayasu stated that the business will continue to operate with risk management in mind, but Panasonic is not considering entering the car manufacturing industry. The automotive unit generates 14% of Panasonic's total revenue.

site_title: Japan Q1 corporate capital spending rises 3%, led by manufacturers
summary: Japan's corporate capital spending rose 3.0% in the first quarter of 2022, led by manufacturers, despite uncertainty from the Covid-19 pandemic and war in Ukraine. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of increased capital spending, with gains in transport equipment and metals production. The figure is expected to influence revised GDP numbers, with economists divided on forecasts ranging from a 0.5% annualized contraction to a 1.7% slump. Despite a fragile recovery, economists expect the economy to return to growth in the coming quarters as the service sector recovers from the pandemic.

site_title: Pfizer to exit GSK's consumer health arm after spin-off
summary: Pfizer plans to exit its 32% stake in Haleon, its consumer health joint venture with GSK, after the business is spun off as an independent listed company in July. This decision follows Pfizer's previous signal to sell its shareholding, with GSK retaining its 68% controlling interest in the company. The spinoff will result in GSK receiving over £7 billion (S$12.1 billion) in dividends, while Pfizer will exit its investment in a "disciplined manner".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Pfizer logo is seen at the entrance to Pfizer UK headquarters in Tadworth, Britain, December 2, 2020.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Rimac raises 500m euros in new funding round, CEO talks potential IPO
summary: Croatian carmaker Rimac has raised 500 million euros in new funding, bringing its total valuation to over 2 billion euros. CEO Mate Rimac stated that the company would consider an initial public offering (IPO) only if revenue reaches over a billion euros, currently around halfway there. The funding will be used to expand production facilities and increase volumes in the technology business, with the goal of producing 100,000 batteries per year by 2026.

images.alt_text: Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer WM Motor Holdings is considering raising about US$1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter.
Electric supercars in race to lose weight, power up and cool down
For Bugatti, business is booming

site_title: Deutsche Bank's DWS CEO steps down in wake of greenwashing claims
summary: Deutsche Bank's asset manager DWS CEO Asoka Woehrmann steps down, effective June 9, amid allegations of misleading investors about "green" investments. The move comes after German prosecutors raided DWS and Deutsche Bank's headquarters on Tuesday. Stefan Hoops, a Deutsche Bank executive, will replace Woehrmann. DWS has denied the allegations, stating it has cooperated with regulators and will continue to do so. The company's annual general meeting will take place on June 9, the day of Woehrmann's resignation.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank and its asset management unit had their Frankfurt offices raided by police, adding to the legal headaches facing Germany's largest lender.

site_title: Mapmaker TomTom to cut 10% of jobs due to improved automation
summary: TomTom, a navigation and mapping company, plans to cut 10% of its global workforce, approximately 500 employees, due to improved automation. The move aims to enhance its mapmaking capabilities, enabling it to address a wider market across its carmaker and tech customers. Despite supply chain shortages and Russia's war in Ukraine, TomTom reaffirmed its cash and sales forecasts in April. The company will provide an update on its quarterly financial results on July 15.

site_title: Asian factories remained under pressure in May as China slowed
summary: Asian factories faced pressure in May due to China's economic slowdown, with export gauges declining. The Taiwan Manufacturing PMI fell to 50, while Malaysia, the Philippines, and Australia also saw declines. However, Vietnam bucked the trend with its PMI rising to 54.7, its eighth consecutive month of expansion. China's factories continued to contract, though at a slower pace, with the official manufacturing PMI rising to 49.6. Economists warn of a more subdued global goods trade trajectory ahead due to inflation and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at the slowest pace in three months in May.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on June 1, 2022, as investors mulled the outlook for soaring inflation. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.2% to 7,622.14 points, while the DAX index added 0.6% to 14,469.73 points. The news comes after eurozone inflation hit a record high in May due to rising energy costs, putting pressure on the European Central Bank to act quicker to rein in prices.

site_title: Certis launches recruitment drive to boost tech workforce amid growing digitalisation
summary: Certis launches a recruitment drive to boost its tech workforce, targeting tech professionals, managers, executives, and technicians. The company aims to develop innovative smart security solutions incorporating AI, IoT, and robotics. With 77% of its global tech workforce upgrading their skills in the last year, Certis will also upskill existing employees. The company has supported the development of smart integrated solutions in various sectors, and interested job candidates can apply at join.certisgroup.com.

images.alt_text: Certis launches platform for businesses to hold immersive meetings, project tours
Certis donates S$30,000 to help persons with disabilities realise their sporting ambitions

site_title: Geopolitical risks fuel stagflation fears; Europe vulnerable
summary: Global economic growth is threatened by the Russia-Ukraine conflict, with Europe being more exposed to geopolitical and economic risks. The conflict is fueling stagflation fears, with 8 in 10 fund managers expecting "below-trend growth and above-trend inflation". The US, however, is less affected, with a strong job market and consumers having a cash cushion to offset rising prices. Europe, on the other hand, faces a higher risk of negative shock on growth, with rising oil, gas, and grain prices expected to add over 100 basis points to inflation.

site_title: Singtel partners Lendlease to jointly redevelop Comcentre HQ into S$3b office project
summary: Singtel has partnered with Lendlease to jointly redevelop its Comcentre headquarters into an S$3 billion office project. The redevelopment will be a net-zero energy development built with carbon neutral construction principles, featuring a 110,000 sq m gross floor area with Grade A office buildings and retail space. Singtel will occupy 30% of the redeveloped space and remain its anchor tenant, while Lendlease will provide development, construction, and property management services.

images.alt_text: A man walking pass the Singtel Shop Comcentre at 31 Exeter Road on 11 Nov 2021.
Singtel's redevelopment of Comcentre to unlock value is a well-trodden path

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with losses on June 1, 2022, as profit-takers stepped in following a healthy run-up in recent sessions. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.56% to 21,294.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.13% to 3,182.16. The losses were fueled by a weak lead from Wall Street, where inflation angst is driving market volatility.

site_title: Trump's 'Big Lie' comes to big screen and makes box office splash
summary: A documentary film, "2000 Mules," has become a surprise box office hit despite debunked conspiracy theories about widespread voter fraud in the 2020 US presidential election. The film, directed by Dinesh D'Souza, claims that a group of "mules" was used to rig the election, but experts say the theories are unfounded and easily disproven. The film's success has been seen as a boost to former President Donald Trump's "Big Lie" about election fraud.

images.alt_text: Former US Vice-President Mike Pence (left) and Governor Brian Kemp, at a campaign stop in Kennesaw, Georgia on May 23, 2022.

In the latest legal blow to Trump, a federal judge on Friday, May 27, dismissed a lawsuit the former president filed that sought to halt the New York attorney general’s civil investigation into his business practices. (Veasey Conway/The New York Times)

site_title: Taiwan says to hold more trade talks with United States
summary: Taiwan's chief trade negotiator John Deng will hold additional talks with US Trade Representative Sarah Bianchi on bilateral trade issues, following Taiwan's exclusion from the US-organized Indo-Pacific Economic Framework. This comes after Taiwan expressed "regret" at the decision, with Deng pushing for Taiwan's inclusion in the framework to counter China's economic and military coercion. The talks aim to strengthen the trade relationship between Taiwan and the US, particularly on semiconductor supply.

site_title: Heralding a unified approach for Asean data-driven economy
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has been awarded the top World Summit of Information Society (WSIS) prize for its initiative on the Asean Data Management Framework (DMF) and Asean Model Contractual Clauses (MCCs) for cross-border data flows. This recognition highlights Asean's contribution to the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals and underscores the importance of a unified approach to digital data governance in the region. The Asean digital economy is projected to grow significantly, with a projected GDP of $1 trillion by 2030, and Asean needs to focus on building organizational capabilities, harnessing new technologies, and harmonizing regulations to unlock data opportunities.

images.alt_text: Loyalty is still the least evolved dimension in a brand’s marketing and sales plan. The fact that loyalty has a strong impact on a brand’s topline growth is still an ‘unexplored country’ by many brands.

site_title: Top Thai banks weighs stake sale in data centre operator: sources
summary: Thailand's top banks, including Siam Commercial Bank and Kasikornbank, are considering a stake sale in data centre operator Supernap Thailand, valued at around $800 million. The sale is driven by increasing investor interest in the industry. Shareholders are working with a financial adviser to find a minority investor, with preliminary interest from other industry players and investment funds. Switch, a US data centre giant, is not planning to exit the joint venture. The sale is part of a trend of data centre companies attracting takeover interest due to their stable returns and growth expectations.

site_title: Bank of Singapore opens wealth management entity in Malaysia
summary: Bank of Singapore (BOS), the private banking arm of OCBC, has opened a wealth management entity in Malaysia to capture growth opportunities in the South-east Asian region. The new entity, BOS Wealth Management Malaysia, will provide customized wealth management solutions and investment advisory services to ultra-high and high net worth clients. Malaysia is the first market after Singapore where OCBC has a comprehensive onshore presence in banking, wealth management, and insurance.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore is appointing industry veteran Robert Reid as its new global head of alternative investments and managed solutions, with effect from May 30.
OCBC unit sells private market feeder funds for US$5m
Bank of Singapore hires former UBS exec as global head of investment advisory solutions

site_title: Australia in talks with US to supply infant formula
summary: Australia is in talks with the US to supply infant formula, following a nationwide shortage in the US. The Australian government will work with the Biden Administration to confirm regulatory arrangements and facilitate exports. Several Australian dairy companies have already submitted applications to the US Food and Drug Administration. This move aims to address the shortage caused by the US relaxing its import policy.

site_title: China's EV maker WM Motor said to weigh US$1b Hong Kong IPO: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer WM Motor Holdings is considering raising about $1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), according to people familiar with the matter. The company, which doubled sales to 44,152 vehicles in 2021, has established 2 manufacturing bases and a total annual production capacity of 250,000 units. Deliberations are ongoing, and details including size and timeline could change. WM Motor has already filed pre-listing documents with the Hong Kong exchange, following similar moves by competitors Xpeng, Li Auto, and Nio.

images.alt_text: An electric car is charged at a roadside EV charge point, London, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Toby Melville
Electric Last Mile Solutions warned Friday it may run out of cash in June, at least one month sooner than previously projected, unless it can raise additional capital.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed on inflation worry, oil edges up after drop
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday following losses on Wall Street and data showing no easing of inflation. Oil edged up after a sharp drop, with Opec considering suspending Russia from an output deal, potentially allowing producers to pump more. Regional equities were mixed, with Tokyo and Singapore rising, while Hong Kong and Shanghai slipped. Investors remain concerned about inflation and the European Central Bank's response, with some warning of harder interest rate hikes if action is delayed.

site_title: No Signboard announces changes to board effective Jun 14
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed restaurant operator, announced changes to its board of directors effective June 14, 2022. Executive Director Lim Lay Hoon will step down to focus on her COO role, and non-executive Director Su Haijin will also resign with effect from June 14. The changes are in light of the company's current financial situation.

images.alt_text: The Singapore High Court has granted itNo Signboard Holdings and 2 of its subsidiaries a moratorium lasting till October.
The Singapore High Court was scheduled to hear moratorium requests by No Signboard and 2 of its subsidiaries at 2.30pm on May 26.
In No Signboard’s application, it requested that OCBC, which is the creditor of S$3 million under a temporary bridging loan facility, be excluded from the terms of the moratorium order.

site_title: HSBC to invest 3b yuan in Chinese business: Xinhua
summary: HSBC plans to invest over 3 billion yuan (S$615.4 million) in its China operations over a five-year period until 2025, according to CEO Noel Quinn. Despite challenges in the Chinese economy, Quinn sees opportunities for investment and growth potential. China's commercial hub lifted a lockdown for its 25 million population, allowing some businesses to resume operations. Quinn expects short-term market volatility but believes China's economy remains resilient and attractive for foreign firms and investors.

site_title: In an ancient shark showdown, 'Jaws' may have doomed 'The Meg'
summary: Scientists have found evidence suggesting that the massive prehistoric shark megalodon may have been outcompeted by the great white shark, leading to its extinction. Researchers analyzed zinc content in shark teeth, finding that the great white shark's arrival about 5.3 million years ago disrupted the food chain, allowing the great white to occupy the apex predator position. This competition, featured in movies such as "Jaws" and "The Meg," may have contributed to megalodon's demise, with climate change and food source decline also being considered possible factors.

images.alt_text: The molar attributed to a young female individual of the extinct human species called the Denisovans, found in cave Tam Ngu Hao 2 in northeastern Laos, is seen in 2018 in the hand of paleoanthropologist Fabrice Demeter in this handout picture. site_title: Bank of Japan must maintain easy policy until wages rise more: deputy governor Wakatabe
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masazumi Wakatabe stated that the central bank must maintain massive monetary stimulus until wages rise more sustainably, as inflation has yet to achieve the 2% target. Wakatabe emphasized that monetary policy is not the best tool to deal with cost-push inflation driven by fuel costs, and suggested alternative measures such as fiscal and energy policies to reduce dependence on petroleum and natural gas.

site_title: Cadi Scientific aims to bring tech to more hospitals in South-East Asia, Greater China, Middle East
summary: Cadi Scientific, a Singapore-based medical technology company, aims to expand its digital monitoring technology to more hospitals in South-East Asia, Greater China, and the Middle East. The company's flagship Cadi SmartSense solutions use IoT devices to monitor various aspects of hospital operations, including patient tracking, hand hygiene, and vital signs monitoring. After establishing a strong presence in Singapore, Cadi is now seeking partners to bring its technology to other markets, with a focus on the Middle East and Greater China. The company has seen significant demand for its products, with 70% of Singapore's hospitals adopting or adopting at least one module of Cadi SmartSense.

images.alt_text: RHB believes that the stronger demand for treatments and digital developments may lift earnings of Asean healthcare players.
Topline: Walter Tarca, Deputy Group CEO of Mainboard-listed VicPlas International.

site_title: Australia: Banking, energy stocks drive markets higher ahead of GDP data
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 7,217 on Wednesday, driven by gains in the financial and energy sectors ahead of GDP data. Banks climbed 1% and energy stocks 0.4% following a spike in oil prices and EU's 90% cut in Russian oil imports. However, energy retailer Origin Energy fell 13.6% after withdrawing earnings guidance due to coal market volatility. Australia's GDP is expected to grow 2.9% year-on-year in the first quarter, slower than the 4.2% growth in the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: 'Pure gambling' prompts wild swings in new Luna cryptocurrency
summary: Terra's new Luna cryptocurrency token experienced extreme price swings after being distributed to investors in an airdrop, with prices ranging from $1 to $30. The token, known as Luna 2.0, was initially valued at around $17 but surged to $9. Analysts describe the move as "pure gambling" and speculate that it may be driven by speculative investors seeking quick gains. Despite some investors receiving less than expected, Terra's community is working on a solution, and the new token's liquidity remains relatively low.

images.alt_text: If you need a reminder that memories are short in the world of crypto, look no further than the relaunch of the Luna token that played a key role in the collapse of the Terra blockchain ecosystem that cost investors billions little more than 2 weeks ago.

site_title: Jansen Mansions at Kovan in third collective sale attempt at S$18.9m reserve price
summary: Kovan's Jansen Mansions will be put up for collective sale for the third time with a reserve price of S$18.9 million, up from its previous attempts of S$19.8 million and S$22 million. The 12-unit development sits on 16,592.7 sq ft of land and has a 999-year leasehold tenure. More than 80% of owners have given their consent for the sale, and the public tender will close on Jun 28. The site can be redeveloped to offer 21 dwelling units with an average size of 100 sq m.

images.alt_text: Analysts say that higher land costs, along with the increased cost of construction and materials, are contributing to cost pressures.
The site is located in the downtown District 7 and is a 5 minutes walk to Nicoll Highway and Lavender MRT stations.
The guide price works out to a land rate of about S$1,414 per square foot psf ppr, after including the development charge payable of around S$178.1 million, CBRE said.
Golden Mile Complex in Beach Road.

site_title: Shanghai’s modest post-lockdown ‘revenge spending’: beauty products, bubble tea
summary: Shanghai's economy is experiencing modest "revenge spending" post-lockdown, with a focus on necessities like food, beauty products, and bubble tea. Despite the city's grand re-opening, consumers remain cautious due to China's zero-Covid elimination strategy and fear of future uncertainty. Retail spending in April plummeted 48.3% year-on-year, and stimulus payments are not expected to boost shopping. Luxury brands are seeing a return to form, but initial spending recovery is expected to be slow, with consumers prioritizing necessities over discretionary purchases.

site_title: Australia's GDP exceeds estimates, signalling more rate rises
summary: Australia's GDP expanded 0.8% in the first quarter, beating forecasts and bolstering the case for the central bank to raise interest rates further. Household consumption drove the growth, with the household saving to income ratio falling to 11.4%, the lowest level since the pandemic. The Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to see this data as validation of its hawkish stance, with money markets pricing in a benchmark of 2.7% by year's end.

images.alt_text: Australian home prices posted their first fall in 20 months, led by declines in Sydney and Melbourne, as a combination of higher interest rates and a rising supply of properties damped demand.

site_title: Gold hits near 2-week low as US bond yields, dollar firm
summary: Gold prices hit a near 2-week low, falling 0.2% to $1,834.09 per ounce, as rising US Treasury yields and a strengthening dollar reduced demand for bullion. The dollar index steadied after gaining on Tuesday, making gold more expensive for buyers holding other currencies. This marks the second consecutive month of declines in gold prices, with benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields rising. The decline in gold prices is attributed to the opportunity cost of holding it, as gold itself yields no interest.

images.alt_text: Gold prices dropped on Tuesday, as a higher dollar and rising US Treasury yields weighed on demand for greenback-priced bullion, which is set for a second straight monthly loss for the first time since March 2021.

site_title: Japan’s May factory activity growth slows as China lockdowns weigh: PMI
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity grew at its weakest pace in three months in May, with the final au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 53.3 from 53.5 in the previous month. Supply disruptions and raw material price hikes exacerbated by China's lockdowns and the Ukraine conflict pressured the economy. New overseas orders shrank at the fastest pace since July 2020, while manufacturers' input prices jumped at the fastest pace since August 2008. Despite this, manufacturers became slightly more optimistic about output conditions for the next 12 months.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,243.81 on Wednesday, driven by gains from banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The STI outperformed Wall Street, which fell overnight due to concerns over inflation, interest rate hikes, and weakening consumer confidence. In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7%, the S&P 500 fell 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite shed 0.4%.

The region needs to invest in digitalization, improve logistics infrastructure, and develop cybersecurity measures. Tying digital supply chain initiatives to environmentally sustainable business practices can also enhance the region's competitiveness.

site_title: Ikea plans to sell factories, reduce jobs in latest Russia cuts
summary: IKEA to sell factories, close offices and reduce workforce in Russia, citing continued devastating war and no possibility to resume operations. The company, which owns nearly 15,000-strong workforce, will sell its 4 factories and keep its 14 malls open. This move is the latest by the world's biggest furniture brand to cut its operations in Russia following Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open after Fed hike, before BOE
summary: Europe's stock markets opened lower on June 16, 2022, as investors digested a 0.75% interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve to tackle soaring inflation. The London FTSE 100, Frankfurt DAX, and Paris CAC 40 indices dropped 0.5%, 0.5%, and 0.3% respectively. Asian equities rose despite the Fed hike, while the Bank of England is forecast to raise interest rates for a fifth straight time to cool inflation. Economists expect a quarter-point hike to 1.25% and hope that economies can withstand rising borrowing costs.

site_title: WWE CEO McMahon steps down as board investigates alleged misconduct
summary: WWE CEO Vince McMahon has stepped down as board investigates alleged misconduct, including a $3 million settlement for an alleged affair with a departing employee. An external legal counsel has been engaged to assist with an independent review, which also includes a probe into misconduct claims by former female WWE employees and head of talent relations John Laurinaitis. McMahon will retain his creative content responsibilities while interim head Stephanie McMahon takes over as the board's investigation continues.

site_title: Britain to defy EU by scrapping Northern Ireland trade rules
summary: Britain plans to override post-Brexit trade rules with Northern Ireland, potentially sparking a trade war with the EU. The move, expected to be presented to parliament on Monday, aims to scrap customs checks and allow goods to move freely between Britain and Northern Ireland. Critics say it will harm businesses and introduce uncertainty, while the EU believes it may breach international law, risking tariffs and legal action. The plan has sparked alarm in Washington, where US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has warned there will be no US-UK trade deal if the protocol is scrapped.

images.alt_text: Anti Brexit group protest at entrance to Hillsborough Castle before the arrival of British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, in Hillsborough, Northern Ireland, May 16, 2022. REUTERS/Peter Nicholls

Britain on Wednesday rejected European Union proposals to resolve a standoff over post-Brexit trade rules for Northern Ireland, saying it would not shy away from taking direct action in the latest escalation between the two sides.

site_title: Gold edges higher as investors await big Fed rate hike move
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,810.59 per ounce on Wednesday, as investors awaited a potential 75-basis-point interest rate hike from the US Federal Reserve to combat inflation. This move has fueled a violent selloff across world markets, with benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields edging off a multi-year peak. A stronger dollar makes gold more expensive for foreign buyers, while a drop in short-term US interest rates provides some support to gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices hovered near a 4-week low on Tuesday, as a strong dollar countered safe-haven demand fuelled by economic slowdown fears amid prospects of aggressive monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Despite major gas deal, energy giant warns consumers to turn down heating
summary: TotalEnergies CEO Patrick Pouyanne announced a $2 billion deal with Qatar Energy to expand production in the world's largest natural gas field, but warned consumers to "turn down the heating" to ease the growing energy price crisis. The deal is part of a "success story" with Qatar, and Pouyanne said more investment is needed to bring prices down. Consumers in Europe are advised to reduce their energy consumption, with Pouyanne suggesting they turn down their heating and air conditioning to ease the pressure on energy supplies.

site_title: The darker shade of green: When carbon markets meet poor governance
summary: A growing carbon market in Asia, particularly in South-east Asia, is marred by a lack of transparency and oversight, creating opportunities for shady deals and abuse. The region's weak governance, conflicts of interest, and high verification costs contribute to this issue. Observers warn that the market's opaque nature allows countries to disguise dubious deals, and indigenous communities may be forced off their land without proper safeguards. To address these concerns, experts recommend increasing transparency, improving benefit-sharing arrangements, and establishing independent complaint mechanisms.

summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has highlighted the largest growth in carbon emissions from fossil fuels and industry, with voluntary carbon markets facing scrutiny over their impact. The Voluntary Carbon Markets Initiative launched a provisional Claims Code of Practice to guide companies in using carbon credits, requiring them to reduce emissions before purchasing credits and detail their use in annual reports. Experts warn that carbon credits can overshadow real emissions reductions and recommend prioritizing reduction over offsetting, with environmental activist Chris Lang stating that planting trees is not a panacea for carbon removal.

site_title: Healthcare S-Reits see stable growth and resilience
summary: Healthcare-related real estate investment trusts (REITs) in Singapore, such as ParkwayLife Reit and First Reit, have reported stable growth and resilience despite the impact of the Omicron variant. ParkwayLife Reit's gross revenue grew 2.3% year-over-year, while First Reit's net property and other income increased 34.9% and distribution per unit (DPU) grew 1.5%. These REITs invest in healthcare-related properties, such as hospitals and nursing homes, and have diversified tenant bases, providing downside protection. Their growth is attributed to the growing and resilient healthcare sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish flat, Shanghai rises
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on June 14, 2022, after an early loss following a previous day's hefty drop. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.41 points to 21,067.99, while mainland Chinese markets, including the Shanghai Composite Index, rose 1.02% and 0.19% respectively. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 33.36 points to 3,288.96, driven by bargain-buying in the afternoon.

site_title: Goodbye Golden Arches: rebranded McDonald's to reopen in Russia
summary: McDonald's has rebranded and reopened its restaurants in Russia under new ownership, marking a significant shift in the country's fast-food landscape. The iconic "Golden Arches" have been replaced with a new logo featuring 2 fries and a hamburger patty against a green background. The relaunch, which began on Russia Day, initially covers 15 locations in Moscow and surrounding areas, with plans to expand to 1,000 locations within two months. The move is seen as a symbol of Russia's growing distance from the West, following the sale of McDonald's restaurants to local owner Alexander Govor.

site_title: Canada suspends random Covid tests at airports over travel delays
summary: Canada has suspended random Covid-19 tests at airports until June 30 to reduce chronic travel delays. The tests, which were in place since 2021, were criticized for worsening wait times at airports. The move comes as the country faces a nationwide labor shortage affecting all sectors, including aviation. The government has promised to hire more screening officers, with 865 new hires since April. The suspension will resume "off-site" on July 1.

summary: General Motors (GM) is considering selling the electric Hummer vehicle in Europe as part of its planned return to the market. The company may start importing the electric Cadillac Lyriq model, which is already on sale in the US. This move aims to expand GM's presence in the European market, where it currently only sells luxury vehicles. The Hummer brand was revived in 2022, and GM has recently produced an electric pickup. The company is also considering setting up a mobility startup in Europe and traditional sales, with a goal of converting its entire Cadillac lineup to electric vehicles by 2030.

site_title: Why companies must be agile enough to adapt their talent game
summary: In a tight labor market, senior management is leaving their jobs, and companies must adapt to retain talent. A report by KellyOCG found 81% of senior management in Singapore plan to leave their jobs in 2 years, highlighting the need for improved workplace culture and employee experience. Companies identified as "Vanguards" have reported an increase in employee wellbeing, productivity, and revenue by embracing workforce agility, diversity, equity and inclusion, employee experience, and adopting tools and technologies. These companies redefine the employee experience, prioritize work-life balance, and implement innovative initiatives to improve diversity and inclusion, ultimately attracting and retaining top talent.

site_title: Real estate sector in Asia-Pacific to remain ‘resilient’: ULI
summary: The Asia-Pacific real estate sector is expected to remain "resilient" over the next few years, with stable capitalisation rates, according to the Urban Land Institute (ULI). Singapore's logistics sector is expected to lead, with a capitalisation rate of 6.4% this year, while Hong Kong's retail sector is expected to see a decrease in rates. Shanghai's office sector is expected to see a rise, from 5.0% in 2022 to 5.1% in 2024. ULI forecasts stable capitalisation rates for Tokyo, Seoul, and Sydney, with Sydney's office sector expected to witness a 4.40% rate this year.

site_title: China regulator says not conducting work on Ant IPO revival
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), says it is not conducting review and research work on an Ant Group initial public offering (IPO). The CSRC supports platform companies meeting qualifications to list in mainland China and overseas. Earlier, Bloomberg reported that Chinese regulators were holding early-stage discussions on a potential revival of Ant's listing. The CSRC also denies a report that established a team to assess Alibaba Group Holding's share sale plans, which led to a 2% decline in Alibaba's US-listed shares.

site_title: When a colleague is grieving: Navigating bereavement in the workplace
summary: A recent article discusses the importance of navigating bereavement in the workplace, highlighting the need for empathy and compassion towards grieving employees. Experts emphasize that businesses should not expect employees to "business as usual" after a loss, as grief can significantly impact cognitive performance and work performance. Companies can support bereaved colleagues by providing paid leave, grief counseling, and financial assistance. Effective support includes allowing remote work arrangements, adjusting workload, and reassuring employees that they will not be penalized for reduced productivity. Additionally, managers should prioritize emotional support and provide a listening ear to help employees heal and return to work.

site_title: Volkswagen is looking at making its own batteries in North America
summary: Volkswagen is considering setting up its own battery cell manufacturing operation in North America to supplement suppliers and ease a coming battery shortage. The company's chief operating officer, Johan De Nysschen, stated that vertical integration is a strategic option being weighed. VW plans to scout US battery plant sites and make a decision by the end of 2022. The move is part of the company's efforts to electrify its lineup and catch up with Tesla, with investments totaling $800 million in the Chattanooga assembly plant and a new testing lab.

summary: GlobalFoundries and STMicroelectronics are in talks to build a semiconductor factory in France, taking advantage of the European Commission's push to produce 20% of the world's chips by 2030. The project could focus on producing energy-efficient chips with advanced technology and would be the second foundry to result from the EU's Chips Act, following Intel's plans to build a massive foundry in Germany. The companies have not made a final decision and no details on the project's size are available.

summary: Russian state airline Aeroflot plans to raise up to 185.2 billion roubles (S$4.1 billion) in an emergency share issue amid heavy pressure from Western sanctions and airspace bans. The company, controlled by the Russian state, aims to raise funds after passenger numbers declined by a third due to the sanctions. The airline has been severely hit by Western sanctions, including airspace bans and supply chain disruptions. The government's National Wealth Fund will invest 107 billion roubles in Aeroflot, and the airline will not pay dividends on its 2021 earnings.

site_title: Elevated Asian cuisine at Pangium
summary: Renowned Peranakan chef Malcolm Lee has elevated his familiar cuisine to fine-dining status at his new restaurant, Pangium. The restaurant, set amidst breathtaking scenery in Singapore's Botanic Gardens, offers precise, nuanced flavors in each course. Lee's dishes, such as pang susi, kueh pie tee, and prawn crackers, showcase his mastery of traditional Peranakan recipes. With a focus on authenticity and soul, Pangium offers an exceptional dining experience at a price of S$258 per person, earning it an 8-star rating.

summary: The Nederlander Organization has announced that it will rename the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Broadway after singer and activist Lena Horne, making her the first Black woman to receive such recognition. The change brings the organization into compliance with an agreement to name a theatre after a Black artist. Horne, who died in 2010, was a renowned performer and civil rights activist, and her granddaughter Jenny Lumet expressed pride and gratitude for the decision. The name change is expected to take place this fall.

summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are gaining appeal as a near-term defensive play amid rising inflation and interest rates. Analysts predict the sector will benefit from supply chain disruptions, inflation, and interest rate hikes, offering a foil against rising inflation. S-Reits are trading at a 5.5% forecast distribution yield, above the benchmark Straits Times Index, and are expected to deliver sector growth of 6% in FY2022 and 3% in FY2023.

site_title: Targeted subsidies for fuel, cooking oil in the works: Malaysia’s Economy Minister
summary: Malaysia's Economy Minister, Mustapa Mohamed, announced plans to replace blanket fuel and cooking oil subsidies with targeted subsidies to help those in need. The move aims to alleviate pressure on the government's budget, which is expected to rise by about RM30 billion due to unanticipated subsidies. Despite inflation rising 2.3% in April, the country's inflation rate is forecast to remain within 2.2-3.2% in 2022. The government also plans to support economic growth, with a forecast of 5.3-6.3% GDP growth in 2022.

site_title: South-east Asian car marketplace Carro takes 50% stake in Indonesian rental firm
summary: Carro, a South-east Asian online used-car marketplace, has acquired a 50% stake in Indonesian rental firm PT Mitra Pinasthika Mustika Rent (MPMRent) for nearly US$54 million. MPMRent, one of Indonesia's leading car rental firms, has a fleet of over 13,000 cars and provides financing services. This investment marks Carro's expansion into the Indonesian market, following its significant funding and partnerships with investors such as SoftBank Group's Vision Fund and Temasek.

site_title: Malaysia to set up chicken stockpiles to overcome shortages
summary: Malaysia has halted exports of live chickens until production and prices stabilize, amid growing global food shortages. The country aims to stock up on chicken to secure domestic supplies and control rising food prices. Following a global feed shortage exacerbated by the Russia-Ukraine war, prices of chicken in Malaysia have soared in recent months. The move is part of measures to address the shortage and mitigate the impact on the country's food supply.

site_title: India says no plans for now to curb food exports
summary: India's Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal stated that the government has no plans to curb food exports for now, citing no need to restrict other commodities like rice. The country had previously banned private wheat exports and restricted sugar exports to prevent price surges. India is the world's biggest rice exporter, selling a record 21.2 million tonnes in the fiscal year to March 2022. The government is currently examining requests from foreign governments for wheat supplies, and will consider "genuine requirements" for exports.

site_title: Japan considers resuming tourism discount as Covid eases: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government is considering resuming a national travel discount campaign, "Go To Travel", as soon as late this month to stimulate consumer demand and boost the tourism industry after a Covid-19 slump. The campaign, which subsidized up to 20,000 yen per night, was rolled out in 2020 but was shelved 5 months later. Japan plans to ease border controls for foreign tourists from July 10, and the "Go To Travel" campaign will likely be a core measure to help the industry recover. A decision on the campaign's revival is expected soon.

The move comes after Wong was selected as the leader of the ruling People's Action Party's fourth-generation team, paving the way for him to eventually succeed PM Lee as Singapore's next Prime Minister.

summary: Australia's ASX appointed Helen Lofthouse as its first female CEO, replacing Dominic Stevens. Lofthouse, who starts on August 1, will earn A$2 million annually, the same as Stevens'. summary: China has unveiled a new voluntary ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) reporting program, which includes over 100 metrics, to help the country catch up with global peers on reporting standards. summary: The European Union (EU) plans to end its reliance on Russian oil and gas by 2027, investing 210 billion euros in renewable energy and energy efficiency measures.
